Description: The chef came over from the world of French cuisine to fry tonkatsu. Ingredients and cooking techniques are a complex mix of various elements, creating flavours found nowhere else. Wielding a blend of multiple oils, the chef lends his skills as a baker to the coating. Red wine accentuates the sauce. Experience inspires the ideas of this chef, who was indelibly impressed by the tonkatsu craftsmen of Tokyo. A chance meeting that changed a life, resulting in beautiful flavours.

Name: Tonkatsu KATSU Hana
Description: Having long devoted himself to Western cuisine, Chef Koga was struck by the subtlety of tonkatsu. The restaurant stocks an impressive array of famous pork brands, so diners can choose based on their preference for the sweetness and flavours of the fat, the fineness of the meat, or other qualities. The sauce, made from tomato and cumin, is based on his experience with Italian cuisine. The minced cutlet kneaded with several types of pork is especially recommended.

Name: DEUX FILLES
Description: Owner-chef Daisuke Iwata bills his fare as ‘modern French? His purpose in using generous portions of vegetables is to showcase the bounty of Kyoto. The salad with 30 kinds of vegetables is a perennial favourite. Selecting a white plate as a canvas, he colours it in with vegetables he buys himself in places such as Kameoka and Kamigamo. His skill in déclinaison ?taking a single ingredient and turning it into sauté, sauce and powder, then serving it as a single dish ?is unique.

Name: Kikunoi Mugesambo
Description: This bento and coffee shop was opened to introduce people to the taste of Kikunoi. The menu was created mindful of the refreshments served at a tea ceremony. In addition to appetisers, tsukuri and nimono soup, there is a rich variety of side dishes in the bento box. At the end come seasonal vegetables and tai takikomi-gohan. Relax while gazing at the mossy garden. After lunch, it operates as a shop for modern-style Japanese sweets.

Name: Vegan Ramen UZU
Description: Art and veganism fuse in the novel dining experience that is Vegan Ramen UZU. In the dark interior, jet-black tables and displays like ink drawings conjure an otherworldly milieu. Ramen ingredients are plant- and algae-based: vegetables, kombu kelp and so forth. Soups of soy sauce and miso are enlivened with fragrant oils. Kombu and shiitake grounds are put to use in à la carte dishes of tofu-skin rolls. The philosophy here is that every part of every ingredient is used.

Name: Sobadokoro Toki
Description: The lights are on late at this restaurant in Kitashinchi, attracting soba lovers well after dark. The owner-chef prepares nihachi and juwari soba from buckwheat grown in Otoineppu, Hokkaido. Staple offerings are chilled curry in summer and yuba with mushrooms in winter. A full selection of appetisers to precede the soba is also available. It might be a nice to tip back a cup or two of sake, accompanied by snacks of sweetened and boiled herring and braised duck breast.

Name: Chukasoba Uemachi
Description: The first thing you notice at Uemachi are the constant queues outside the door. The shop took the name of the neighbourhood as it aims to be a place beloved by locals. Its signature ramen dishes are ‘Shoyu?(soy sauce) and ‘Shio?(salt). The broth derives its richness from its meat base; the flavour of dried fermented fish and crunchy sardines add depth. Insisting on noodles with a satisfying finish, the shop kneads its own. The fare is somehow nostalgic, in both taste and presentation.

Name: Ayamuya
Description: Yakitori born from self-taught techniques and sensibilities. Different seasonings are applied to each cut; each skewer is served on a separate dish. Salt use differs by item and soy-sauce dip is enhanced with wines and spirits to build complex flavours. Interesting combinations include chicken breast dressed with grated daikon radish in ponzu sauce or horseradish and cartilage with spices. Omakase menus switch texture and flavour with each course. For à la carte items, guests can specify their seasoning preferences.

Name: Mendokoro Janomeya
Description: This ramen shop focuses on making soup using locally raised chickens. Its three signature flavours are soy sauce, dried sardines and white broth. Be sure to try the chicken ramen. To make the signature soup, dashi is drawn from chicken bones and whole chickens. A blend of several soy sauces is then used to deepen the flavour. The fragrance of the wheat is drawn out by using thin noodles. The ambience is reminiscent of the aristocratic culture of old Kyoto.

Name: Sushizen
Description: The chirashi-zushi is as bright as a garden full of blossoms. The thin yellow strips of omelette cover it so extensively you can’t even see the seafood underneath. With doubt battling anticipation, you search the dish with your chopsticks, then your spirit leaps as you find it chock-full of hidden tai, squid, octopus, tuna and shrimp. The thick-cut ingredients are carefully selected for freshness and texture. No sugar is used; instead, salt is added to draw out the natural sweetness.

Name: Nihonshuzammai Utsutsuyo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Notable sake list,Shoes must be removed
Description: The name of the restaurant is inspired by the expression ‘is this a dream or reality??and embodies the desire for you to enjoy sake and good food to your heart’s content with a touch of enchantment. The sheer range of local sakes on offer can make choosing hard. Start with an appetiser and decoratively arranged sashimi with your first cup. The drinking snacks are varied too, from tofu preserved in miso and stew of beef tendon to Western items such as sweetfish confit and milt meunière. With such an array of appetisers, the sake slips down easily.

Name: Donostia
Description: This restaurant is currently closed. Enjoy Basque and regional cuisine from all over Spain at this Spanish-style restaurant-cum-café/bar. As well as the familiar pinchos, tortillas, etc., the blackboard menu has a variety of small-plate dishes of the day. Popular items are the dry-cured ham , sliced only once an order is placed, and the asado of aigamo bred in Katsuragi, Nara prefecture, sautéed on a hot plate. To finish, we recommend the arroz meloso: a rice and seafood dish.

Name: Oribe
Description: Owner-chef Hirotaka Uzaki bills his establishment as a ‘teppan bistro?that defies genres. Using fresh ingredients, he combines French techniques with teppanyaki. Here the signature dish is the ‘Cabbage Steak?drizzled with gorgonzola cheese and white dashi sauce on the aromatic grill marks. In true Osaka style, Uzaki also serves okonomiyaki and yakisoba (stir-fried noodles). His distinctive blend of Japanese and French gastronomy is a must-try.

Name: Bistro Cerisier
Description: A bill of fare deeply rooted in regional food culture is the attraction here. The sauté of frog Provençal is fragrant with herbs and garlic. The cassoulet à la Castelnaudary is a stew of goose confit and pork. The baeckeoffe, a go-to dish in winter, is a traditional one of meat and vegetables simmered in Alsatian crockery. The service of the cheerful proprietress lends warmth to the cooking.

Name: Fuyacho 103
Description: The name is simply the address of this restaurant hidden in a mixed-use complex. Cross the threshold and the interior is filled with the warmth of wood panelling, the coffered ceiling reminiscent of the partitions in an oden pot. The menu ranges from standard fare such as daikon radish and deep-fried tofu to more exotic choices only a former Italian cuisine chef could conjure, such as caciocavallo cheese. Taking a hint from bistecca, the steak is paired with oden dashi soup stock.

Name: Kamigata Rainbow
Description: ‘Ramen is a musical ensemble in a bowl?is something only someone like former rock-band member, and current owner-chef, Genki Okumura would say. In place of drumsticks, chopsticks beat out the rhythm in his steaming bowls of soup with homemade noodles. Flavour, taste and trailing notes each play to their own rhythm. In the soy sauce-flavoured ramen, the sweetness of wheat that exudes from the noodles and the changing temperature of the soup continuously modulate the experience.

Name: Juu-go
Description: Akiya Ishibashi tills the field, harvests the grain, kneads the buckwheat. The chef’s passion for soba permeates a menu consisting purely of soba and soba mash. ‘Think of it as cereal? he says of his dishes rich in rustic goodness. Soba is deliciously fragrant, thick-cut and al dente. Soba mash, served with roasted buckwheat grains, is delightfully pungent. To enjoy the pure flavour of Ishibashi’s soba, try it first on its own, without seasoning.

Name: Tan
Description: ‘Tan?comes from the city of Kyotango in Kyoto Prefecture. Naturally, the food hails from the Tango region too: rice grown by employees where the restaurant was founded; vegetables from the region’s farmers. Service begins with breakfast loaded with vegetables; lunch consists of bowls of rice with toppings and noodle dishes; evening fare is à la carte. Each dish is simple yet prepared and plated creatively. The view of the willows along the Shirakawa River seen from the modern interior is wonderfully elegant.

Name: Canton Shunsai Ikki
Description: The restaurant holds its own niche in Chinese cuisine. The talents of the Guangdong-trained chef are on full display. Guangdong is blessed with the bounty of sea, mountain and river, as is Kyoto, and the light flavour of its cuisine, which draws out the flavour of the ingredients, work well with the food culture of the ancient capital. Shrimp wontons are dressed with Hong Kong soy sauce, Cantonese fried rice is accented with lettuce and roast pork.

Name: Izakaya Tokitame
Description: Before anything else, be sure to order the Obanzai Moriawase. The simple flavouring of this assortment of Kyoto cuisine side-dishes, such as shira-ae and vinegared burdock, makes a great companion for drinks. The line-up ranges from familiar offerings such as decorative sashimi and fried foods to Japanese, Western and Chinese dishes accented with a touch of creativity. The restaurant name derives from a movie about a couple who grew old together. The couple who manage Izakaya Tokitame also gather beautiful moments with their guests as time marches on.

Name: EL ALMA
Description: El Alma feels like a culinary journey, as the dishes hail from every region of Spain. The shrimp-and-mushroom ajillo represents the traditional flavours of southern Spain. Salted cod and almond sauce lend the tapas salad a Catalan flair. The meat dishes are charcoal-grilled for a smoky flavour that evokes the Basque Country. The chef, who’s made numerous trips to Spain, aims for an authentic feel that conveys the richness of regional Spanish cuisine.

Name: Sumibiyakitori Ikoka
Description: Sumibiyakitori Ikoka would like you to experience as many different cuts of chicken as possible, so a recommended start to your order is a five- or seven-piece omakase. Rather than insist on a particular brand, the owner-chef chooses poultry on quality and freshness alone. Chicken tail drizzled in yuzu and chicken skin covered in oroshi ponzu are a finishing touch. Chicken pieces prepared with slight twists are mixed together to offer a variety of flavours.

Name: Muginoyoake
Description: The owner-chef’s journey toward opening a ramen shop traces all the way back to primary school, when the ramen his grandmother cooked for him kindled his love for the dish. After getting a job at a flour-milling company, he made himself an expert on wheat. Eventually he devised his own unique take: ‘Ramen with Scallops and Japanese Pepper? made with flavoursome homemade noodles. The restaurant name means ‘a new dawn for wheat? announcing that a new day has dawned for the ramen industry.

Name: Izugen
Address: 391 Takeyacho, Takakuradori Ayanokojisagaru, Shimogyo-ku, Kyoto, 600-8093, Japan
Description: Mackerel sugatazushi (a whole mackerel sliced up into sushi) is a staple of Kyoto sushi. The traditional flavours here, inherited from the founder, are now in the hands of the third-generation owner-chef. To ensure agreement with the toppings, the sushi rice is cooked in dashi for added flavour. The sushi pressed in a box comes with salted white fish or hamo teriyaki. In the summer, hamo sugatazushi is a sought-after dish here, as is steamed sushi in winter.

Name: Ogimachi Udonya Asuro
Description: The menu is a compendium of ways to enjoy udon from every perspective. The secret to distinctive body and texture is mixing. Koki Nishigori uses his experience to adjust water temperature and volume as he mixes two types of wheat flour. Recommended dishes include Hiyakake, whose accent is on harmony with the dashi, and Kijoyu, which highlights the inherent flavour of the noodles. In Bukkake, the noodles and topping complement each other perfectly for a distinctive character.

Name: via del emme
Description: When the chef returned from Italy, he brought with him recipes rooted in the land and techniques for making pasta by hand. He now applies his experiences in Marche, a region rich in the bounty of sea and mountains, to the foodstuffs of Japan. Guests can choose from an impressive list of pasta dishes, some made with seafood and even game. The meat in the Bolognese sauce is hand-chopped, in a nod to Marchese practice. Always attentive to guests?wishes, Maeda is happy to adjust flavours while hewing true to his cuisine’s Italian roots.

Name: Oryori Menami
Description: This restaurant began as a place serving obanzai and yakitori, and the sauce that the chicken and green onion skewer is grilled in goes all the way back to then. Kyoto culinary delights line the counter, such as a stew of deep-fried tofu and leafy vegetables, Kujo leek dressed in vinegar miso and boiled nama-yuba. Here you can linger and relax to the gracious hospitality of the tunic-clad proprietress, who keeps her grandmother’s name alive in the name of the restaurant.

Name: Uo China Yo
Description: The concept at this restaurant is Chinese cuisine with an emphasis on fish. First, try the set menu, with your choice of main dishes. Pick four fish dishes you like, which come with an assortment of appetisers including seafood carpaccio. This fully rounded meal even comes with fried rice at the end. Various dishes on the menu make good use of seasonal ingredients such as lobster stew with chili sauce and seafood mapo tofu.

Name: JIBUNDOKI
Description: The owner-chef pours his creativity into teppanyaki dishes of incredible variety. In true Osaka style, both pork and mixed okonomiyaki are available. Though the batter is thick, the finished texture is light. Imaginative grilled skewers hint at the cuisines of many countries, with offerings such as nama-fu, salmon tartare and tteokbokki. All items are served in bite-sized pieces, so patrons can enjoy sampling a variety of flavours.

Name: Mugito Mensuke
Description: Pursuing an original approach to ramen, the chef works with carefully selected ingredients.  Soup is prepared from free-range chicken and guinea fowl to bring out maximum flavour. Noodles, produced on the premises, are crafted for a delicious finish. Wontons stuffed with wagyu filling are the very flavour of luxury. Counter seating features an earthen wall made by a plasterer and wooden trays typical of Japanese restaurants. A ceaseless drive for improvement is evident in every bowl of ramen.

Name: Ichihana
Description: A typical lunch offering is sashimi and items served in small bowls, while the evening lineup boasts a full complement of sashimi and items served in rice and cooked individually for each guest. Ten ingredients are always available, with gomoku (‘five ingredients? and wild plants being perennial favourites. To express the seasons through kamameshi, Ichihana offers flavours like bamboo shoots, sweetfish, mushrooms and oysters. While the rice is cooking, enjoy Kyoto flavours such as steamed wheat gluten with sweet miso sauce and steamed tilefish.

Name: Oryori Amenimomakezu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining,Notable sake list
Description: On a narrow alley off Oimatsu-dori, the backlit sign saying ‘Ame ni mo makezu?(Be not Defeated by the Rain) arrests the eye. The script has a character all its own, as the owner-chef wrote it himself using chopsticks dipped in charcoal. Fare is prepared with plenty of fermented seasonings to complement the sake. Grilled fish is marinated in malted rice; chicken liver garnished with rice-bran bread. The way of living shown in Miyazawa Kenji’s masterpiece is manifested in the food on offer.

Name: Kannomiho
Description: Open the menu and the first line reads, ‘Kannomiho is the shop run by Miho, who loves warmed sake? Miho offers home-style seasonal fare accompanied by sake and all its appeal. Seared duck is a year-round favourite. As cup follows cup, unwind as the sake warms you right through. Songs of the Showa (postwar) era pipe through the dining room. With sake cup in hand, guests leisurely soak in the pub-like atmosphere.

Name: kushiage 010
Description: These creative kushiage incorporate culinary influences from many countries. The sheer variety is endlessly fun. For your first skewer, you might start with angel shrimp from New Caledonia. The samgyeopsal (grilled pork-belly slices) wrapped in perilla and Korean lettuce is spiced with gochujang for a real Korean treat. With the tandoori chicken in curry and yogurt sauce, the fragrance of India floats in the air. An excursion through the flavours of the world through kushiage awaits.

Name: La pleine lune
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Interesting wine list
Description: Chef Naoaki Nishii brings ingredients to life using traditional cuisine. One example is the thick-cut smoked salmon, paired with chestnuts in autumn and turnips in winter to emphasise the seasonal feeling. Meat dishes are garnished with kuro shichimi (‘seven black spices? to add a Kyoto touch. In homage to classic French cooking, he does not spare the sauce, taking care to impart a modern flavouring. Butter and cream are used sparingly for a lighter taste.

Name: sonoba
Description: Two friends from an arts university started sonoba as ‘a soba shop that makes pottery? The interior sports an industrial décor, with pendant lights hanging from a ceiling made of recycled wood; adjacent is a pottery studio. Having majored in interior design, the chef was involved in the restaurant’s design and construction. Both artists mould shapes from powder and water—earth for the potter, buckwheat grains for the chefs. An unexpected point in common between vessels and food.

Name: Sambongi Shoten
Description: Char-grilled meats are the signature fare here. Sambongi Shoten bills itself as an izakaya, but the atmosphere is more like a char-grill bar. The focus is on wine being organic, sake being warm. The menu is remarkably varied, with many creations borrowing ideas from Japanese, Western and Chinese influences. Meats include beef, pork, mutton and duck, as well as game; the Miyama venison is a crowd-pleaser. The trained eye of a butcher and the flame control of a master of French cooking are on display here.

Name: Shichiku Kiko
Description: The tiled-roof row house on Gen’i-dori makes an immediate impression. The owner-chef, wearing a bow tie, rushes about, unable to rest unless he does everything himself. With his wealth of experience, he takes familiar ingredients and raises them to new levels, creating graceful Kyoto cuisine ?and it’s good value for money. Appetiser platters are served with rice at lunchtime and in the evening with drinks. The gentle demeanour of the proprietress makes you feel at home.

Name: Shitennoji Hayauchi
Description: Oribe stoneware and distinctive Japanese-style paintings give presence to the interior. Crockery is produced by a potter with whom the owner-chef has cultivated a relationship. Recycled materials and earthen walls give the space a rough-hewn feel and a folk-art charm. Two kinds of soba are prepared: fine-ground seiro soba and coarse-ground inaka soba. Both are rolled to the same thickness. At lunchtime, customers start queuing in front of this popular shop before it opens. ‘Soba trays?of soba with snacks are available with reservations.

Name: Oudon Yomogi
Description: This à la carte udon shop is a project of the proprietress of the Japanese restaurant Miyamoto. The use of bamboo gives the restaurant a kappo feel. In the evening the style is a fixed menu to which drinking snacks can be added. Great care is taken with the use of crockery ?this is an udon restaurant with the flair of a soba place. The star of the udon items is the dashi soup stock, which is created with the basic soup stock, particularly drawing inspiration from soup dishes in traditional multi-course meals. A flavoursome lesson in Osaka dashi culture.

Name: NOODLE SHOP RENNOSUKE
Description: The residential neighbourhood is a maze and there’s no sign for the restaurant. A spotlight on a bowl of ramen in a showcase indicates you’ve arrived. The industrial space has the feel of a laboratory. ‘Raamen?is a blend of Kyoto wheat noodles in a clear soup of seafood dashi stock. Thinly sliced roasted pork fillet is from Kyoto-raised swine. Blue bowls of specially ordered Kiyomizu ware set off each meal to its advantage. Custard pudding, sweetened with refined sugar, is a popular item.

Name: Sakamoto Sushi
Description: Good-humoured Kei Sakamoto views his enterprise as ‘sushi for the masses? The staple item is the temari sushi of boiled shrimp. The vinegared rice, with delicately sweetened rice vinegar, brings out the Kansai character of the sushi. The toro and takuan rolled sushi is made by beating the tuna before rolling it ?an entertaining spectacle. Sardine is cut into accordion pleats; grilled kichiji rockfish is garnished with its liver. It is these subtle touches that proclaim the artisan’s skill.

Name: Kushikatsu Gojoya
Description: Specialising in kushiage skewers with a creative twist, this restaurant incorporates influences from around the world. The owner-chef strives to create skewers that are found nowhere else. The squid-ink risotto offers an Italian touch, and the escargot with its aroma of truffles has a French inspiration. Dishes such as these are interwoven with perennial favourites of shrimp and beef. Enrobed in fine breadcrumbs and lightly deep-fried, one skewer quickly follows another.

Name: Nikomi Kimura
Description: ‘Nikomi?means ‘stew? and owner-chef Kimura’s stews are justly famed. She prizes the deep umami she extracts from her ingredients through hours of patient stewing. Year-round favourites are the tofu with beef and konnyaku with beef sinew. For added flavour, she adds chicken broth and ichiban-dashi. The oden, with its numerous ingredients, is a winter’s delight. The shuko, a fried fish paste called Jakoten brought in from Ehime Prefecture, conveys the flavours of her hometown.

Name: Tempura Kozaki
Description: The owner-chef runs this tempura house with his parents, creating a homely atmosphere. The fish and vegetables, chosen through careful quality judgement at the market, create an almanac of seasonal flavours written in tempura. The batter is thin so that the ingredients can speak for themselves. He frequently prepares new batter, taking great care to keep it airy. The menu consists solely of an omakase of ten tempura items. Tempura Kozaki is packed with customers night after night.

Name: Teuchisoba Kanei
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Shoes must be removed
Description: The owner-chef fell in love with soba, so taught himself how to make it. Using a stone mill, he grinds his “Rough-ground Soba?by hand to create wonderfully rustic juwari, or 100% buckwheat noodles. A shark skin grater and stick of wasabi are provided, so you can start grating your wasabi while you wait for your soba. Pre-soba snacks created with drinks in mind are on offer, including broiled miso, itawasa and dashimaki tamago. The ambience of the traditional wooden townhouse looking out on the verandah of an inner garden sets the mood.

Name: Lapintaika
Description: The menu is broad, reflecting the wide range of local Italian cooking styles the chef has studied. Each plate feeds two, so sharing is the order of the day. The assorted appetiser, generous in both portion and variety, is a perennial favourite. A full complement of pasta dishes is on offer—the list of spaghettis alone is extensive. The restaurant’s name means ‘coming back? and indeed the satisfying weekend lunch draws plenty of repeat visitors.

Name: Itsutsu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: Under its motto of ‘buckwheat and cooking? Itsutsu’s focus on seasonal cuisine is the Wakuden way. Soba is made into thin noodles, using only the smallest amount of filler and well water from Daitoku-ji Temple. The chef doesn’t brace the noodles with cold water, so the flavour jumps to the fore. Similarly, soba dipping sauce is mild, based on its salt flavour. ‘Itsutsu-setto? an assortment of appetisers, is recommended. Reservations are required for the prix fixe Buddhist vegetarian cuisine, which includes soba.

Name: YI PAN CAI TANAKA
Description: ‘Yi Pan Cai?is Mandarin Chinese for ?la carte? The name reflects the restaurant’s desire for patrons to enjoy dishes they love with a light-hearted spirit. The ‘Dragon’s-Hair Rolls?are minced shrimp and hamo rolled up in kadaif noodles and deep-fried. Dishes such as pig’s feet marinated in Tsingtao beer and deep-fried; and shumai steamed dumplings made variously of pork, beef, fish or shellfish, are creatively prepared and served as an assortment. Each dish is delightfully inventive.

Name: Rubino
Address: 53 Old Bakery Street, Valletta, VLT 1454, Malta
Description: This sweet little bistro started life in 1906 as a confectionery shop, serving, among other things, cassata Siciliana ?which it still offers today. Sit in one of three cosy, traditional rooms and receive hands-on service from the owner. The blackboard menu lists classic Maltese and Italian dishes.

Name: Grain Street
Description: Situated on the main pedestrianised street in the centre of town, this restaurant with an attractive outdoor dining space serves simple, informal Mediterranean cuisine. Dishes include lasagne with squid, cuttlefish ink and nduja sausage as well as delicious desserts such as lemon meringue tart with olive oil and thyme ice cream.

Name: Commando
Address: Misraħ Iz-Żjara tal-Papa, Mellieħa, MLH 1080, Malta
Description: This restaurant has a long and very interesting history, starting with the building itself (around 300 years old) and continuing with the history of the family at the helm, who have been here since 1930 and once provided support for the Royal Marines. The dining room boasts a rustic yet personalised decor with exposed brickwork and contemporary furnishings, while the cuisine focuses on fresh ingredients that are full of flavour. Our inspector particularly recommends the pappardelle pasta with a duck ragù and a few chopped hazelnuts for added flavour.

Name: Terrone
Address: Fort St. Angelo, Birgu Waterfront, Birgu, BRG 1734, Malta
Description: Tucked away on the tip of the small town of Vittoriosa, just around the corner from the Birgu seafront with its stunning yachts at anchor, this restaurant run by Italian-Australian chef Adrian Hili serves Italian and Maltese cuisine. The superb Mediterranean-style local fish specialities include turbot with Sicilian clams and cannellini beans. As a result of ongoing restoration work, the entrance is currently to the rear of the building (not particularly attractive), but once inside the elegant decor and outdoor dining space more than compensate.

Name: Löwen
Description: This is a charming traditional restaurant with a gorgeous terrace. Representing the fourth generation, Roman Pfaff has breathed new life into this family business. The high-quality ingredients used here come almost exclusively from the (Lake Constance) region ?their origin is indicated on the menu. However, international flavours also come into play and, in addition to one or two classics, the chefs conjure up imaginative modern dishes such as pan-fried Lippertsreute salmon trout fillet with a paprika and tarragon topping, baba ganoush and oriental potato wedges. This often means a full house, so it is best to make a reservation!

Name: Zum Vaas
Description: It is always a delight to visit a friendly and welcoming restaurant with a lively atmosphere. This one can look back on over 150 years of tradition and boasts a spruce, upscale interior. The service is cordial and attentive, and the food is delicious and made using high-quality ingredients from carefully selected producers. In addition to the menu of the day, which also features Mediterranean touches, there are the Vaas classics, such as roast Swabian-Hall pork. The impressive wine list comprises a remarkable range of vintage wines from various producers ?predominantly from Germany and France, but also from Austria and other Old World countries. Comfortable guestrooms are available in the hotel of the same name.

Name: Lindenhof
Description: Like their hotel, with its cosy individually designed guestrooms, the Hankhs' restaurant is also very popular. This is down to the excellent seasonal cuisine, which has regional and Mediterranean influences. You can order à la carte or opt for a set menu (vegetarian version available). Friendly and competent waitstaff. The small terraces in front of and to the rear of the building are delightful.

Name: Zum Lamm
Description: This inn is everything you could wish for! Your cordial hosts, Ulrike and Manfred Kreger, put their heart and soul into running this popular restaurant. He is the chef and specialises in regional cuisine ?one of his specialities is pike-perch from the Rhine, which is practically on the doorstep! Another equally delicious option is the herb-crusted rack of lamb with mint sauce, grilled watermelon and gnocchi. In summer, the tables in the garden to the rear of the building are in high demand. Smart guestrooms available for overnight stays.

Name: Dutters Stube
Description: The Dutter family have been running this charming 16C inn for four generations, and the seasonal and regional cuisine served here is a hit. Their Stubenrestaurant is more sophisticated (the set menu is popular); the Dorfwirtschaft serves simpler fare, such as flammkuchen and rump steak. As an alternative to the terrace, there is the pretty summerhouse. Chef Arthur Dutter is a member of the charity Deutsche Fußballköche (German football chefs).

Name: Rössle
Description: This family-run restaurant serves fresh, flavoursome cuisine made with choice ingredients. Alongside the intriguing "Chef's Menu", there are specials written up on the board, plus a menu of classic dishes ?they all go down a treat. To round off your experience, attentive waitstaff, a friendly atmosphere and a delightful terrace. The attractive guestrooms combine warm wood and sleek design.

Name: DELI
Description: Here, in an appealingly down-to-earth and relaxed atmosphere, you can enjoy interesting international cuisine that is based on the seasons and drawn from select ingredients. The terrace on Niagaraplatz, a square with a waterfall feature, is also charming?The traditional hooded beach chairs are great for really chilling out. Good to know: They serve hot food all day.

Name: Weinstube Brand
Description: Here, diners can look forward to really good food which is both fresh and seasonal, as well as cordial service. Everything is pleasantly down-to-earth ?just as you would expect in a wine tavern. The wine and game, like most of the produce, come from the region. Whether you opt for the classic rump steak, one of the daily specials or a vegetarian dish, be sure to leave room for the molten chocolate cake ?just heavenly! Delightful courtyard terrace. In short: a fun dining experience!

Name: Krone
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Krone has been properly invested in: from the façade to the hotel rooms, everything is chic and high quality, the restaurant is modern and sleek. The food is very good, with select produce turned into aromatic dishes with plenty of flavour. At lunchtime, a smaller range of interesting options. If you are staying longer, Basel and Alsace are very close by.

Name: Heinzler am See
Description: Whether in the Jagdstube, in the Panorama Restaurant or on the great terrace (almost at the water's edge), here at the Heinzler brothers' you can look forward to good seasonal fare. For example: smoked fillet of Bodensee whitefish on a beetroot salad with horseradish mousse and potato pancake, or duo of veal in a peppercorn sauce with Brussels sprouts and fried potatoes.

Name: Gehrlein's Hardtwald
Description: Somewhat tucked away, the Gehrlein family's restaurant boasts a warm and welcoming interior, as well as a lovely garden terrace. Meticulously crafted using the finest ingredients, the dishes served here are remarkably flavoursome. One shining example: Label Rouge guinea fowl, celeriac, carrot, miso, fritter. The friendly waitstaff pull out all the stops to ensure a perfect dining experience. The guesthouse opposite provides comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Fährhaus
Description: Practically right behind the dike and just a few minutes' walk from the ferry port, this restaurant serves distinctly local cuisine made with produce sourced from local fishers and farmers. Completely unpretentious and free from unnecessary frills, owner Gerold Janssen's dishes are brimming with freshness and flavour, as in the Helgoland crab cocktail or the crispy baked plaice fillets. Good to know: Well-kept guestrooms are available for overnight stays or holidays.

Name: Vier Jahreszeiten Restaurant Imhof
Description: You will certainly eat well at Andreas Imhof's restaurant. The cuisine is regional and uses ingredients selected with seasonality in mind. Dishes made with Allgäu heifer, for example, are popular. The interior of this friendly place is bright, refined and modern; outside, the beer garden is presided over by an impressive lime tree.

Name: Anetseder
Description: Traditional German public house culture is alive and well here, and at the same time they tap into the zeitgeist. The lovely dining space has a high ceiling and a trendy, modern feel and the waitstaff are friendly. They serve fresh and tasty food, with seasonal ingredients, preferably from the region, taking pride of place.

Name: Gambero Rosso da Domenico
Description: Domenico Cannizzaro has been on a mission to showcase Italian cuisine in Franconia for well over 20 years, and has run this restaurant at the small marina with his wife, Teresa, since 2012. Here, they live and breathe hospitality, serving two set menus, "Domenico" and "Teresuzza", which each comprise three or four courses ?it's also possible to mix and match. Astute wine recommendations come courtesy of the chef-patron himself. Gorgeous terrace overlooking the Main River.

Name: Weinrestaurant Turmschänke
Description: In this restaurant in the Nicolaiturm, the lovely historical details, such as paintings and original furniture dating from 1912, foster a rustic yet elegant feel. The waitstaff are pleasingly laid-back and down-to-earth. Meticulously prepared seasonal dishes are served as a set menu or à la carte; mouthwatering options from the barbecue are also available. Complete with helpful descriptions, the wine list comprises some 140 items ?most are from the region, but international labels also feature. Special wine evenings are also hosted here.

Name: Anne-Sophie
Description: We recommend getting a table in the light and airy winter garden: here you have beautiful views over the garden! The food is tasty and seasonal, with classics such as braised veal cheeks also proving popular. At lunchtime there is a reduced menu as well as inexpensive daily specials. The restaurant is located on the Schlossplatz, some 150m from the main hotel building.

Name: Gasthaus Widmann's Löwen
Description: This cosy establishment serves up classic regional fare and seasonal dishes made from high-quality, fresh ingredients. The Widmann family places great emphasis on their restaurant's connection to the region. Why not try "Widmann's spare ribs"? Alternatively, you could opt for a surprise menu comprising three or four courses? Don't miss the chance to enjoy the lovely beer garden in the summer ?it really is a delightful spot! Cookery classes and various other events are also held here.

Name: Münstermanns Kontor
Description: What started as a shop selling eggs and butter later became a delicatessen and today this spot is a popular bistro with a pleasingly lively urban atmosphere and an open kitchen. The tasty dishes include German classics such as currywurst and Wiener schnitzel, but also international dishes. The food is accompanied by decent wines by the glass, and the service is friendly. Open from noon to 8pm, last orders 6.30pm. NB: They don't take reservations at lunchtime ?so come early, as the place gets very busy.

Name: Westerndorfer Stube
Description: The cosy Stube of the Landgasthof Karner is a good alternative to the fine dining restaurant. The combination of rustic charm and discreet modern features makes for a harmonious whole. Here, the connection to the region is strong; from the schnitzel with roast potatoes, to the braised leg of lamb or trio of dumplings, great store is set by local and seasonal ingredients.

Name: Nußbaumerin
Description: Here in her cosy restaurant Johanna Nußbaumer recreates a little bit of Austria in the heart of Berlin. Specialities include breaded fried chicken, Wiener Schnitzel, sirloin steak, and a range of Austrian stews and sweet dishes. The excellent wines also hail from her home country.

Name: Im Kittchen
Description: This little restaurant is located in the middle of the old town, in a narrow side street near the Eiermarkt. The dining area has a rustic feel and tightly packed table, which contributes to the charming atmosphere, as does the cordial proprietress, who is in charge of the service. The delicious options are written on the blackboard and also come in smaller portions as a surprise menu. The impressive wine list features around 230 labels.

Name: Scheidels Restaurant zum Kranz
Description: Conscious of their long family history (the restaurant is now run by the seventh generation), the owners here are committed to maintaining their traditions yet the food remains resolutely down-to-earth. Charming historic ambience, plus warm and welcoming staff. Simple, tasty dishes take pride of place, inspired by regional and seasonal produce. A vegetarian menu is also available.

Name: Gutshof Andres
Description: Surrounded by venerable old trees, this listed manor house has been owned by the same family since 1839. It boasts a delightful beer garden overlooking a small lake. Your hosts put everything they have into providing friendly service and fresh, seasonal regional cuisine. Their focus on sustainability is apparent in their selection of ingredients, some of which they make themselves. House-made spreads, sauces, brandies etc are also available for purchase. Should you wish to stay the night in this lovely, quiet spot, there are two flats in the former brewery, chic, modern double rooms in the coach house, and a comfortable holiday home ?Gutsverwalter Haus. A practical tip: there are two charging stations for electric cars.

Name: Weißes Roß
Description: All the meat served by Hans-Jürgen Nägerl comes from the restaurant’s own butchery. This is a fact much appreciated by his guests, as are his ‘chalet snacks?and ‘kitchen parties? His delicious cuisine includes Tafelspitz (Viennese-style boiled beef) with herb sauce and roast potatoes.

Name: Treibgut
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: As a sophisticated alternative to Seestern, Treibgut adds to the gourmet credentials of the Lago hotel. Modern cuisine is served in a trendy and exceedingly stylish interior. There are also dishes for sharing, e.g. steak cuts, whole fish or snack platters. They offer a nice selection of goods from their own bakery, butcher's shop and ice cream factory.

Name: Mühlenhelle - Bistro
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This beautiful bistro with its pleasant bright, airy atmosphere is an attractive alternative to the gourmet restaurant ?and the food is just as good, with tasty seasonal cuisine prepared from fresh ingredients in the open kitchen. Game dishes often feature on the menu.

Name: Little John's
Description: Housed in a spruce building dating from 1905, Tim Lellau's restaurant is appealingly laid-back with a Scandinavian feel. Here, attentive and well-drilled waitstaff serve high-quality, fresh cuisine. There is a choice of two set menus: "Weide & Wasser" (Pasture & Water) and the vegetarian "Wald & Wiese" (Forest & Meadow) ?this can be made vegan by prior arrangement. Alternatively, you can also order à la carte. There is also a reasonably priced three-course set menu at lunchtime. From the entrance area, you can see into the kitchen, which is sure to whet your appetite! N.B. cash payments only.

Name: Sommerau
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The trip to the Hegar family's restaurant just outside Bonndorf is definitely worth it! Nestled in a quiet valley, surrounded by woods and meadows ?the setting could not be more idyllic. There's an inviting terrace, but you can also enjoy the view from inside. The cuisine is regional and seasonal, made using top-notch ingredients. In the hotel of the same name, there are cosy, modern rooms and a beautiful sauna house, plus a natural swimming pond.

Name: Seehaus
Description: This is a gorgeous spot at any time of the day. In the summer, the terrace overlooking the lake is perfect for a relaxed lunch or afternoon cake, and in the evening, you'll be just as happy to sit inside ?there's something romantic about this charming restaurant done out in warm rustic wood. They also serve fantastic modern and international cuisine. Tip: try the homemade pannacotta for dessert!

Name: Lucky Leek
Description: "Fine Natural Dining" is the concept here at this pleasant restaurant. Charming staff serve up fully vegan cuisine in the form of a three- to five-course tasting menu ?it's also possible to order à la carte. Made with seasonal vegetables, the creative, plant-based dishes are packed with flavour, and they are just as popular with international visitors as they are with locals. In summer, the best place to dine is on the terrace out front.

Name: Landhaus Lebert
Description: In a small town about 10km from Rothenburg ob der Tauber, this cosy restaurant serves really flavoursome cuisine made from good-quality regional produce ?importance is attached to sustainability. In summer, there is a lovely beer garden. Well-kept guestrooms for overnight stays, and a barn for private events. Tip: In the old shepherd's caravan, you can buy products made on site, such as lemon liqueur, spice mixtures, jellies and jams.

Name: Almer Schlossmühle
Description: This carefully converted old mill next to the little Schloss Alme is a highly appealing restaurant that abounds with rustic charm. The delicious food features seasonal dishes from the regional repertoire as well as classic fare from the chef's native Austria. Head for the lovely terrace in fine weather. There are also guestrooms for an overnight stay.

Name: Mussumer Krug
Description: Whether you are seated in the rustic-style old brick building or the laid-back modern annexe, the atmosphere at this restaurant is very pleasant. The menu features modern international dishes such as yellowtail ceviche and traditional specialities, for example braised beef shoulder. A three-course surprise menu is also proposed. The kitchen takes its cue from the changing seasons with a penchant for regional produce. There is a great selection of German wines, and the service is friendly and attentive. Covered terrace.

Name: Restaurant Villa Esche
Description: Built in 1903, the former coach house of Villa Esche (now the Henry van de Velde Museum) houses this bright, tastefully designed restaurant where diners can enjoy attentive service and top-notch seasonal cuisine. Opt for the four-course menu or order à la carte. At lunchtime, the options are slightly more limited but include moderately priced daily specials. Delightful terrace overlooking the grounds.

Name: EssBar
Description: The outwardly unimposing restaurant run by Daniel Baur and Olga Jorich is situated only a few steps away from the Hofgarten public park. Pleasant atmosphere, plus flavoursome dishes prepared from good-quality ingredients and offering good value for money. Neither will you be disappointed by the wine list! Attractive protected terrace to the rear.

Name: Staudenwirt
Description: This well-established restaurant with its small, well-kept hotel has been run by the same family for three generations. Each dining area has quite a different style, from rural to contemporary charm, plus there is a delightful terrace. The menu comprises a good array of regional-traditional, modern-seasonal and internationally influenced dishes. Vegetarians are well catered for, too. Plus it is all reasonably priced!

Name: Rührberger Hof
Description: This historical Rührberger Hof estate has been around since 1902. The fact that it was once used for farming is no longer apparent today. The pleasingly modern interior is an attractive setting in which to enjoy the excellent cuisine, which is based on classical foundations and takes its cue from the region and the seasons. At lunchtime, the reasonably priced set menu of the day is very popular. There are also well-kept contemporary-style guestrooms.

Name: Fürstenfelder
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This former monastery makes for a wonderful setting. In what was once the cattle shed, the impressive Bohemian vaulted ceiling has been incorporated into the modern interior design, with a centrally positioned open kitchen. Out in the courtyard of the Cistercian monastery, there is a lovely terrace, slightly separated from the beer garden. The menu is varied, featuring dishes with a modern twist and made with sustainably produced (organic) regional produce. Options include dishes from the Josper grill, as well as vegetarian and vegan alternatives. Lunchtime buffet.

Name: Zöllner's Weinstube
Description: Surrounded by splendid gardens, this 18C half-timbered sandstone building is as charming on the outside as it is on the inside. Sitting beneath a striking vaulted ceiling, diners can enjoy regional as well as Mediterranean-inspired cuisine made from first-rate produce. There is also an excellent selection of Franconian wines. In summer, the terrace is a must!

Name: Aschbacher Hof
Description: This pretty country hotel run by the Lechner family offers not only fabulous views of the region and tasteful, cosy rooms but also exceptionally good, fresh cooking. The regional and seasonal dishes include game as well as classics like Zwiebelrostbraten (fried beef and onions in gravy). Wonderful terrace.

Name: Zur Krone
Description: Run with dedication and a real sense of tradition by nine successive generations of the same family for over 200 years, this cosy country-style restaurant offers good food and comfortable rooms. The tasty menu options include veal roulade in a creamy cheese sauce with vegetables and spätzle.

Name: Café Rapp
Description: Originally a bakery and café, the family business is now also a restaurant, where quality, flavour and price are spot on. The emphasis is on regional and seasonal products ?vegetables and meat are sourced from the village, herbs are grown in the kitchen garden. A must in the afternoon: the delicious fresh cakes! Pretty guestrooms.

Name: Sennhütte
Description: Family hospitality is the name of the game here! Since 1918, the Grether family have put their heart and soul into this place and not least into the good food, made mostly with regional produce. Dishes ranging from traditional to slightly more sophisticated are served in a space divided into smaller rooms or out on the lovely verdant terrace. Snacks and cakes are available throughout the day. They have their own distillery, smokehouse and Alpine dairy. Pretty, comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Weedenhof
Address: Mainzer Straße 6, Jugenheim in Rheinhessen, 55270, Germany
Description: This pretty restaurant with its wood and dry-stone interior offers a warm and welcoming setting in which to enjoy flavoursome regional dishes including veal chop in a leek crust. Don’t forget to leave a little space for the excellent desserts ?the apricot dumplings with zabaglione are excellent! There are also a number of pleasant guestrooms.

Name: Gutsausschank im Baiken
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Great view,Terrace
Description: Set amid the vines and with a lovely view of the vineyards and Eltville, this restaurant is worth a visit for its location alone. It goes without saying that the terrace is in great demand. The menu features delicious down-to-earth dishes made with regional produce and respect for the seasons. Attentive service comes courtesy of a friendly and laid-back front-of-house team. Tip: Be sure to reserve well in advance ?they are almost always fully booked!

Name: Allgäuer Stuben
Address: Lindauer Straße 75, Isny im Allgäu, 88316, Germany
Description: The good food and welcoming atmosphere are the main draws of this restaurant run by the Rimmele family, whose dedication to their work is palpable ?that is certainly the case for chef Susanne Rimmele. She cooks regional as well as Mediterranean dishes. The front-of-house team are charming and obliging. Tip: the delightful terrace. They also offer cookery classes, tackling eg pasta, asparagus, game. Pleasant overnight accommodation is available at Hotel Hohe Linde.

Name: Capricorn [ i ] Aries Brasserie
Description: Located in a neighbourhood with a unique character, this appealing, laid-back restaurant has plenty of regulars. Welcoming and lively, it's everything a brasserie should be. The menu, too, is down-to-earth, including mouthwatering options ?house-made venison ham, brasserie classics such as steak-frites and vegetarian dishes. Tip: Take a punt on the moderately priced surprise menu. Friendly and professional service. Pavement terrace.

Name: Restaurant Corona im Hotel zur Post
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: It's a real treat to eat here! In this classic restaurant, Sergio and Kerstin Corona work as a well-coordinated team, providing charming service and Mediterranean-inspired cuisine. In addition to the "Méditerranée" and "Corona" set menus, from which you can also choose à la carte, there is also a bargain to be had in the three-course lunch menu.

Name: Die Windmühle
Description: In this former corn mill, the Lemke family now run a restaurant that serves excellent food. There are two comfortable dining spaces ?the Mühlenstube and the Kaminzimmer ?plus a delightful terrace where you can tuck into delicious seasonal and regional dishes. The friendly and attentive front-of-house team take delight in talking diners through their selection of German wines.

Name: Landgasthof Löwen
Address: Kirchdorfer Straße 8, Kirchdorf an der Iller, 88457, Germany
Description: Alexander Ruhland represents the fourth generation of his family to run this traditional country inn, and his kitchen turns out top-notch dishes. He combines classic and modern influences, with the region and the seasons playing a major role. Modern and comfortable guestrooms are also available.

Name: Poppenborg's Stübchen
Description: This is the more relaxed alternative to Poppenborg's more traditional eatery. Try the Atlantic sea wolf with mustard sauce or the Westphalian-style boiled top-side of veal. Pretty garden terrace.

Name: HYGGE Brasserie & Bar
Description: This place is certainly hip! In Danish, hygge describes a feeling of cosiness and comfortable conviviality ?just like the atmosphere conjured up in this pleasantly lively and stylish timber-framed restaurant with an open hearth at its centre. Delicious seasonal and regional dishes are served here, and many of the ingredients come from their own farm. Opt for the "HYGGE" set menu, the surprise menu, or order à la carte. There are appealing vegetarian options, too. The trendy bar-lounge is also popular.

Name: Zur Krone
Description: In the centre of the village you will find this charming restaurant with its comfortable dining rooms. Ralf Restel serves simple, flavoursome regional fare with international influences. Try the boiled rump of beef with herb sauce and pan-fried potatoes or the breast of corn-fed chicken with stir-fried vegetables and curry sauce. In summer the best tables are those outside on the quiet leafy terrace.

Name: Nil
Description: Diners are bound to enjoy their time here! This restaurant in the trendy Schanze district has a delightful ambience, the service is informal and friendly, and you can certainly expect to eat well. The delicious food follows the seasons and draws on international influences. Opt for the five-course set menu. Excellent and reasonably priced short wine list.

Name: Gasthaus Egertal
Description: The Rupprecht family have brought together two concepts in their attractive traditional guesthouse: the elegant restaurant and the bistro serve the same menu. It features freshly prepared dishes with regional and classical influences. Most of the fruit and vegetables are home grown. The terrace out front is lovely in summer.

Name: Wirtsstube im Hotel Burkhard
Description: In the second restaurant of the hotel Landgasthof Burkhard, the cuisine is somewhat simpler, which does not detract from the quality. Dishes range from cordon bleu to sea bream with lemon. The dining areas are cosy and prettily done out ?you can choose to enjoy your meal in the Wirtsstube or the Esszimmer. The inner courtyard terrace, which is shared with the Kaminstube, is also very appealing.

Name: Kleines Meer
Description: Laid out over two levels, this convivial restaurant has exposed roof timbering that lends a pleasant airy atmosphere. Lake Müritz is just in front of the building, making the terrace with its small lounge area a popular spot with guests. Made from good-quality ingredients, the cuisine here is regional and seasonal; there are also vegetarian options. The hotel of the same name has well-kept guestrooms.

Name: Long March Canteen
Description: Currently one of "the" places to eat, Long March offers a dimly lit interior, informal service and a kitchen open to the diners?gaze. The menu features Cantonese fare in the form of a variety of dim sum and dumpling dishes. Wide selection of wines, spirits, cocktails and tall drinks.

Name: Landgasthaus Hirsch
Description: The Waldenmaier family (now in their fourth generation) cook excellent, seasonal, regional fare at their traditional country inn. The game is locally hunted, the bread comes from the little bakery next door, and even the schnapps is home distilled. There is also a pretty terrace on the first floor and a lovely rustic beer garden.

Name: Freihaus Brenner
Description: This lakeside inn overlooking Tegernsee is picture perfect; in summer, the terrace is the stuff of dreams. The interior is especially inviting, with cosy dining spaces done out in warm wood. The menu features delicious regional classics such as roast pork with dumplings or locally caught char with parsley potatoes, as well as more upscale fare such as turbot fillet with pumpkin risotto. The service is friendly and efficient, and the staff are all dressed in traditional Bavarian attire. Gorgeous suite on the top floor.

Name: Erbgericht Tautewalde
Description: Inside, the modern dining rooms are done out in a pretty, rural style; outside, there is a lovely courtyard with a view of the kitchen. The seasonal cuisine is regional and international, and they are keen to use local produce. You can choose between the "Landidyll" set menu and "A la carte menu". And those who want to do without meat can look forward to a vegan set menu. Overnight accommodation in the traditional Erbgericht.

Name: Landgenuss
Description: Run by the Hämmerle family, this restaurant enjoys great popularity, so it is advisable to book well in advance! With a friendly country house feel, charming service and great food, this place is a nice alternative to the gourmet restaurant. Made with plenty of local produce, the dishes served here are seasonal with occasional Mediterranean touches. The wide-ranging menu includes their "Original Wiener schnitzel" and sea bass with rosemary and thyme. In summer, make a beeline for the terrace.

Name: Bergfriedel
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: This establishment has been run by the same family with great dedication for years! The welcoming team serves delicious, fresh food that diners can enjoy as they take in the views over the Bühlertal. The wide-ranging menu includes traditional cuisine from Baden, vegetarian/vegan dishes and gourmet specialities. Add to that an extensive wine list. The chic restaurant extension is done out in a modern take on regional style. Pleasant overnight accommodation is available ?the rooms and suites ("Natur-Zimmer" and "Natur-Suiten") are done out in locally sourced materials and are contemporary in their design.

Name: Gasthof Brink
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: A place with charm! The traditional style that is cultivated here will evoke childhood memories for many diners. Family-run since 1880, the restaurant serves classic French cuisine that is down to earth and delicious. The pleasant setting has an elegant feel. The house-made pâtés and terrines are just as popular as the saddle of veal with Béarnaise sauce or the sole meunière.

Name: Hirsch
Description: "Modern tavern cuisine" is the name of the game in this family-run establishment, which has been in business for 12 generations in a quiet suburb of Ellwangen. At the helm is the son, Dennis Wiche, who has worked in several MICHELIN-starred restaurants. The menu comprises an abundance of appealing dishes, from regional classics such as Zwiebelrostbraten (roast beef with onions) and spaetzle to the chef's more modern creations, such as vitello forello. Be sure to try the house-made maultaschen! The chefs work only with the finest seasonal and regional produce ?in fact, the restaurant had its own farm until a few years ago. In summer, you can dine on the terrace, which is sheltered from the wind. Overnight accommodation is available on site, in the hotel of the same name.

Name: Zur Glocke
Address: Friedrich-von-Teck-Straße 12, Höchstädt an der Donau, 89420, Germany
Description: The Stoiber family have put their heart and soul into running this trendy, modern restaurant. Their commitment is particularly evident in the excellent cuisine, which sticks close to the seasons and draws on quality ingredients. There are two set menus, one of them vegetarian, but you can also dine à la carte from the small menu of the day. The terrace in the front garden is ideal for warm summer days, and there are modern guestrooms ranging from "classic" to "design".

Name: Zum Fischer am See
Address: Harrasser Straße 145, Prien am Chiemsee, 83209, Germany
Description: The name says it all. As soon as you set foot in the small entrance hall you are greeted by a picture of various freshwater fish, and the kitchen specialises in fish dishes. However, the well-curated menu also includes steaks, regional classics such as braised ox cheek, and vegetarian options. The grappa and brandy selection is really impressive and might tempt you to stay for a nightcap. In fine weather, the best spot is the terrace with a view of the lake ?small boats can also moor there. Good overnight accommodation available. Motorists will be pleased to know there is a large private car park.

Name: Ostiner Stub'n
Address: Schlierseer Straße 60, Gmund am Tegernsee, 83703, Germany
Description: This typical regional inn proposes two separate culinary concepts: The fine dining restaurant is open Thu to Sun from 6pm, and the more rustic Hirsch & Jägerstüberl is open Mon from 6pm and Thu to Sun 12-2.30pm and 6-9.30pm. The emphasis is on produce from the region, and the dishes take their cue from the changing seasons. Attentive service. In summer, the lovely terrace overlooking the garden is very popular.

Name: Schwarzkopf
FacilitiesAndServices: Credit cards not accepted,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Run by Stefan Pumm and his charming wife Anja, this restaurant serves fresh, tasty cuisine including chateaubriand steak with Béarnaise sauce (for two), a popular house speciality. Elegant wood-panelled dining room, inviting terrace, plus good accommodation also available (ask for one of the refurbished rooms).

Name: Schäck's Adler
Description: Christoph and Sandra Schäck have brought to life this picture-perfect hotel. The atmosphere in the wood-panelled dining rooms is really cosy, the service is very friendly, the cuisine is ambitious and tasty ?the emphasis is on regional ingredients and seasonal produce. There is also the appealing Strumbel Bar and a number of extremely well-kept rooms.

Name: Gasthaus Scherz
Description: A native of Vorarlberg, Michael Scherz ?no stranger to Cologne's gastronomy scene ?focuses on Austrian cuisine, with classics such as Tafelspitz (boiled beef), Wiener schnitzel and Kaiserschmarrn (shredded pancake with raisins). Great Austrian wines. The service is speedy; the staff friendly and well-trained. Very nice terrace to the rear of the house. Good to know: the restaurant is easily accessible from the city centre by tram.

Name: Gasthaus Weißenbeck
Description: You will find plenty of satisfied customers here, and no wonder! The mother and daughter Weissenbeck team cook up a storm using regional and seasonal produce ?and the prices are fair. The lovely inn also makes for a cosy setting, and in summer the delightful garden terrace is most inviting.

Name: Zum Rebstock
Description: A fun place to eat! In this historic half-timbered house (in the family since 1750) you can sit back in the delightful wood-panelled interior and enjoy charming service and really good Baden cuisine. Tip: sample the array of starters and desserts as little "temptations" (Versucherle). Great wine list. Buy some home-made cherry or plum brandy to take home with you. You can also stay overnight comfortably.

Name: ROSE
Description: The Tress family is all about organic produce, with a vegetarian and vegan take on regional cuisine taking centre stage. The complex, aromatic and carefully considered dishes win diners over with their depth of flavour ?the pea and broad bean tartare, for instance, make a lasting impression. Meat can be ordered as a side dish ?here, they follow the principle of nose-to-tail eating. All the wines are Demeter-certified. Should you wish to stay over, there is the guesthouse opposite.

Name: LAMM
Description: A really cosy place, where you will also eat very well: seasonal Swabian-Baden cuisine, with an emphasis on regional produce; some of the meat comes from the restaurant's own highland cattle. There are good wines to accompany your meal, as well as a special whisky offer. In summer, try and bag a spot on the terrace. Pleasant guestrooms also available.

Name: Zu den drei Linden - Lindenblüte
Description: Tanja and Thomas Siemes run their family business with great dedication, and the food here is exceptional. He cooks up international cuisine that takes its cue from the seasons and incorporates Mediterranean and regional influences; she provides charming service. You can opt for the set menu or order dishes à la carte, such as the mouthwatering pan-fried turbot fillet with spinach and truffle ravioli. The atmosphere is friendly and the decor has an elegant Mediterranean feel.

Name: Flux - Biorestaurant Werratal
Description: Unpretentious, natural, simple and honest ?that's the motto here. The dishes, which are created using organic seasonal produce sourced from the region wherever possible, are packed with flavour. The menu is vegan/vegetarian, but meat and fish can be ordered as add-ons. Gluten- and lactose-free options are also available. In summer, the garden is idyllic. Cosy guestrooms at Biohotel Werratal.

Name: Seehof
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Great view,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Boasting a lovely lakeside location on the marina, this restaurant offers a popular terrace as well as its “Badische Weinstube?and panoramic “Alois?dining rooms. Flavourful and classic artisan dishes feature on the menu. Tip: the local classics ("Alemannische Klassiker"). Accommodation is also available ?the “boathouse?and rooms with views are particularly recommended.

Name: Zur Flottbeker Schmiede
Description: Hamburg offers a taste of Portugal in this old listed forge building, where a traditional German ambience (with authentic decor and an old open fireplace) combines with a more informal southern European feel. The menu focuses on Portuguese-Mediterranean cuisine, with a selection of delicious tapas.

Name: Jouliard
Description: This French bistro has been set up in a well-maintained townhouse located a little outside the city centre. The kitchen proposes classic fare such as confit chicken with herbs and scalloped potatoes, as well as more modern dishes like fjord trout with potato foam, braised carrot and passion fruit. Lovely terrace out front.

Name: Feilmeiers Landleben
Description: This cosy and modern restaurant knows how to makes diners feel welcome. For Johann (who goes by Hans) Feilmeier, his "country life" cooking reflects both a love of his native region and a sense of duty. He cooks regionally and seasonally inspired food. Choose from one of the different set menus or order à la carte. Extremely charming and cordial service - matching wine advice included. Tip: the home-made jams!

Name: Weinhaus Stern
Description: A popular address and deservedly so: an inviting, rustic-style interior, a pretty courtyard, friendly service and, last but not least, good seasonal cuisine. Chef Klaus Markert relies on honest craftsmanship and flavours, along with fine wines from the region. Be sure to try the house brandy production. Charming guestrooms are also available, and there are home-made fruit jams for breakfast.

Name: Felsenbirne
Description: This restaurant with a friendly atmosphere and a sleek modern interior is located on a cobbled street in the pretty old town, not far from the Elbe. Chef-patron Felix Mikulla uses seasonal ingredients ?his dishes are fresh and delicious, as well as good value. The menu also includes vegetarian and vegan options. In summer, diners can make the most of the terrace in the inner courtyard.

Name: Gasthaus Wolters - Zur Börse
Address: In der Langen Straße 22, Wurster Nordseeküste, 27639, Germany
Description: Formerly a livestock exchange, this appealing inn is steeped in tradition. Behind the typical brick and half-timbered façade, tables are laid out in a pleasingly rural interior where diners enjoy a quality take on regional home-style cooking made using excellent produce. Friendly service completes the picture. Be sure to reserve your table ?the Gasthaus Wolters tends to get booked up.

Name: Gasthaus Stromberg
Description: This old-established restaurant in the pedestrian zone offers minimalist-style and a friendly atmosphere as traditional meets modern. The food is seasonal and regional ?try the pumpkin variations with Dorstener goat’s cheese or the beef roulade with speck and curly kale. Werkstatt, just 1. 5km away, is ideal for groups.

Name: Talblick
Description: Brothers Claus and Rainer Weitbrecht are carrying on the tradition of their parents' business ?the dedication of the whole family is palpable. As head chef, Claus Weitbrecht delights diners with both Swabian and international cuisine, including vegetarian dishes. The craftsmanship and harmonious flavours are excellent in equal measure. There is also a well-curated wine list. For a more upscale alternative, head to the hotel's Gourmetrestaurant. Comfortable guestrooms available.

Name: Landhaus Gräfenthal
Description: Peter Lauterbach represents the fourth generation to run this family restaurant in an idyllic location. The food is a contemporary take on regional, seasonal cuisine influenced by Mediterranean culinary tradition. Inside, pale wood, a tiled stove and pleasing decorative touches make for an inviting setting; outside there is a beautiful garden terrace. Friendly waitstaff.

Name: Altdeutsches Restaurant
Description: Florian Kellerbauer divides his menu into two sections "Unsere Heimat" and "Unsere Leidenschaft" (Our Homeland and Our Passion), in each the emphasis is on the quality of the ingredients. The service is friendly and charming. Thanks to its location in the historical centre, you can sit on the terrace in the heart of the action. The Deutsches Haus hotel, a patrician house from 1440, has comfortable guestrooms.

Name: ElbUferei
Description: This friendly restaurant with a gorgeous terrace, bar and open kitchen is just outside the centre, on the Elbe Cycle Route. The atmosphere here, on the ground floor of ARCOTEL HafenCity, is pleasantly laid back, and the modern decor has a maritime feel. The food is predominantly Mediterranean (served à la carte or as a set menu) along with light bites and steaks. Mouthwatering options include dishes such as Arctic char, potato, fennel, mustard and sauerkraut.

Name: Schatzhauser
Description: Another iteration of the Finkbeiner family's Traube Tonbach suite of restaurants. The interior is minimalist and modern, airy and light, with a terrace boasting a great view of the valley. They serve a pleasant mix of international cuisine and regional classics, plus steaks cooked on the Lavastein grill. The service courtesy of well-trained staff is very friendly. Incidentally, the place is named after the good forest spirit from a Black Forest fairy tale.

Name: Kaufmann's
Description: In this lovingly renovated former castle brewery, nowadays the name of the game is good, fresh cuisine. In an attractive setting of exposed old brickwork, vaulted ceilings and sleek, modern style, the restaurant serves flavoursome dishes with a regional dimension as well as international influences. For example, Rhön trout is served all year round, along with seasonal dishes such as braised haunch of venison.

Name: Die Bürgermeisterei 1728
Description: A location steeped in history in which to enjoy a meal! The lovingly restored building, which gives directly onto the market square, was once the mayor's residence and dates back to 1728. The elegant fusion of modern style and historical details lends the place atmosphere. The evening menu is ambitious, fresh and full of flavour, with appetising options such as beef bourgignon, dried fig crumble and potato-parsnip mash. The small selection of seasonal dishes is also proposed in the form of set menus, one of which is vegetarian. In summer, make the most of the secluded terrace.

Name: Lotters Wirtschaft - Tausendgüldenstube
Description: Hotel Blauer Engel not only offers lovely guestrooms, it is also home to this restaurant. With 360 years of tradition to its name, it oozes historical charm. Warm wood panelling lends the space a cosy atmosphere, and the old tiled stove is a quaint detail. Added to that is service with a personal touch and very good food ?to be sampled à la carte or in set menu form. Lotters Wirtschaft brewery is also pleasant with its rustic-style vaulted ceiling.

Name: Bistro
Description: It's no wonder the charming restaurant in this spruce historical building is so popular: the food here is unpretentious and packed with flavour! The combination of a modern yet cosy interior and genuine, personable service overseen by the owner fosters a truly pleasant and welcoming atmosphere. The small terrace overlooking the church and market square is also lovely. At lunchtime there is a three-course meal deal and in the evening a choice of tasting menus.

Name: Barra
Description: Be careful not to overlook the house with the inconspicuous front! A thoroughly and unabashedly trendy concept, from the minimalist urban look and relaxed, pleasantly neighbourly atmosphere to the nicely pared-down modern cuisine served in the form of small sharing dishes. High-quality ingredients with a preference for those sourced in the region. Tip: From the seats at the counter you have a very good view of what's happening at the cooker.

Name: November Brasserie
Description: Located in a busy neighbourhood, this Japanese brasserie entices diners with an appealing range of Japanese specialities in the evenings ?including sushi and sashimi, of course. Other draws of this place include competent service provided by a friendly and down-to-earth front-of-house team, as well as the pleasingly bright and modern minimalist-style interior, complete with small sushi counter.

Name: Holzgarten
Description: This pleasant, bustling restaurant in Holzgartenstraße (from which it takes its name) serves modern, seasonal cuisine that also incorporates international influences. The appealingly straightforward dishes (eg brasato, parsley root purée, rapini) are often reduced to a few components and carefully prepared for maximum flavour. The menu, which is purposely kept short and changes frequently, is accompanied by a well-curated wine list. Diners are seated in a trendy interior with an open-plan kitchen; there are some high tables too. Lovely terrace. Be aware that bookings are possible for two time slots.

Name: Poststuben
Description: It is hardly surprising that this restaurant is so popular. As well as charming and attentive service, diners are drawn by the regionally influenced cuisine conjured up by chef-patron Sven Molitor. Made using carefully selected ingredients, his dishes reveal talent and good craftsmanship. They are down-to-earth, but also show a certain finesse here and there. The traditional family-run hotel Die Post offers well-kept guestrooms for overnight stays ?an ideal base for exploring the beautiful surroundings of the village, which is located in the Meerfelder Maar volcanic crater.

Name: Rotes Ross
Description: If you are a fan of fresh and seasonal regional cuisine, the Bogner family's restaurant will be right up your street. This place is cosy and the service comes courtesy of friendly and well-drilled waitstaff managed by the lady of the house. As for the wine, the focus is also on the region. In summer, the leafy courtyard terrace is in great demand. You can also spend the night in one of the well-kept, comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Zum Falken
Description: Lars Zwick has been running this cosy, rustic-style inn in the charming Tauber Valley for many years. The cuisine is regional and seasonal, and the excellent produce is sourced locally as far as possible. Freshly prepared sausages (made in-house) are served on Thursdays and Fridays. Some of the wines ?to pair with delicious dishes such as rack of lamb in a herb crust ?come from the restaurant's own vineyard. They also produce their own fruit brandies and keep bees. The old barn serves as a function room and wine tastings are held in the vaulted cellar. The pretty guestrooms exude rural charm.

Name: AS am See
Description: "AS" refers to the lakeside location (am See) as well as to owner and head chef Andreas Staack. In this inviting cross between a wine bar and a bistro, the affable chef-patron proposes a modern five-course menu featuring dishes such as venison fillet, wild broccoli, cranberry jus. This restaurant is nestled in a side street in a quiet, leafy residential area, a stone's throw from Kurpark Bad Saarow. Lovely terrace.

Name: Gasthaus Goldener Stern
Description: Run with great dedication by the same family for three generations, this place operates as a traditional gasthaus at lunchtime and as a casual fine dining restaurant in the evening. The attractive interior is modern and cosy. The menu features flavoursome regional and seasonal cuisine that also draws on contemporary influences, with a focus on sustainability. Friendly and adept front-of-house team. The Eichen Loft can be booked for events, and from October to April, the stylish wine shop can be reserved for celebrations (max. 12 people). The pleasant beer garden has a slightly smaller menu.

Name: Stocks Restaurant
Description: This restaurant is housed in a charming half-timbered building with a thatched roof. The comfortable interior is done out in dark tones that exude an air of chic elegance. Friendly waitstaff serve delicious fish dishes or sushi, and those who prefer meat will also find plenty of tempting options on the menu. There is an additional lunchtime special. Tip: Parking is available to the rear of the building.

Name: Moarwirt
Description: Here at the Bio-Landhotel Moarwirt, the excellent food is made out of primarily organic ingredients ?indeed, the place has Naturland and Slow Food certification. The modern Alpine-style dining rooms are very pretty; in summer the terrace is a real hit. You can also stay overnight comfortably. N.B. weekly closures vary out of season.

Name: Jägerwirt
Description: With its cosy rustic-style interior, charming service and down-to-earth, flavoursome cuisine, this is the archetypal Bavarian inn at its best. The menu features regional dishes and Mediterranean-influenced options. The chefs make a point of sourcing their ingredients locally and work with trusted producers. Alongside the standard menu, there is a varying menu of the day plus a weekly special. Popular grilled veal and pork hock dishes, as well as goose and duck, are also available if ordered in advance. The rural location is also delightful.

Name: derWaldfrieden
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Rural inn.

Name: Gasthof zur Sonne
Description: Set directly across from the Swiss border, Gasthof zur Sonne serves fresh, flavoursome cuisine with regional and Mediterranean influences in a country-style setting. Try the emmer risotto with Trollinger and grilled Calabrese salami or the duet of skrei and wild salmon in lemon sauce. The restaurant also offers three simple but beautifully kept guestrooms.

Name: Knippschild
Description: With its homely farmhouse furniture this restaurant makes a great first impression. The great regional menu makes an already perfect dining experience even better!

Name: Klösterle Hof
Description: Chef Markus Klein and his wife put their heart and soul into running this restaurant. In a charming rustic setting, friendly waitstaff serve delicious regional and seasonal cuisine made using good-quality ingredients. Good to know: Hot meals are available from noon to 8pm. Guestrooms available in three different levels of comfort.

Name: Am Kring - Büschker's Stuben
