Description: In the mood for traditional regional dishes like Münsterländer Zwiebelfleisch (beef and onions)? Enjoy your meal in the rustic-style dining room or cosy fireside lounge. In addition, the hotel Am Kring offers modern guestrooms. Attractive location in this village built around the church.

Name: Gasthaus Hofmann
Description: It is no wonder that this inn run by Bettina Hofmann attracts so many regulars ?diners are won over by the cosy, elegantly furnished interior, as well as the exceptional food. Her appetising cuisine is regional, seasonal and dotted with modern influences, and the wines are excellent. In addition, they serve a vegetarian set menu. The service is friendly and well organised. There are also comfortable guestrooms. The eggs served at breakfast are laid by the establishment's own hens!

Name: Gasthof Berghof - Ursprung
Description: Rustic wood matched with clean lines and fresh splashes of colour provide an ‘old meets new?look at this restaurant. The decor is mirrored in Alexander Schütz’s excellent cooking, which comes both as an upmarket set menu or simply a hearty Bratwurst. The delicious food and reasonable prices make dining here a real pleasure.

Name: Tölzer Schießstätte - Hager
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: This gem of a restaurant brimming with traditional Bavarian charm serves exceptional food in an inviting rustic setting. It is understandably popular, so be sure to book well in advance! Andreas and Michaela Hager form a harmonious team and this is clearly reflected in the delicious dishes they craft. Their short menu showcases superb local ingredients in classic dishes such as liver dumpling soup, Tafelspitz (prime boiled beef) with horseradish or salmon trout fillet with a mustard sauce. Service comes courtesy of a friendly front-of-house team.

Name: Weinhaus Zum Ritter
Description: This converted 500-year-old farmhouse certainly has character. The many regulars come for the cosy atmosphere in the charming dining area (the old Swiss church window draws the eye), the cordial service and, of course, the fresh regional cuisine courtesy of chef-patron Thomas Hausin ?his flavoursome dishes are clearly the work of a chef with experience at top-flight establishments! NB: different opening hours in summer.

Name: Landgasthof Rebstock
Description: In the heart of the wine village, the Keller family runs this cosy, rustic, centuries-old house, where the welcoming hosts offer fresh, seasonally inspired cuisine. They like to use ingredients from the region, but international influences can also be detected on the menu. The service is professional and very attentive. They also have guestrooms.

Name: Reck's
Description: Cuisine, art and accommodation are combined in this long-running family business. Three sisters run both the hotel ?with some classic, some stylishly modern guestrooms ?and the restaurant, which offers really good seasonally influenced cuisine. There are three cosy dining areas inside; outside, there are tables on the terrace in the shade of the plane trees, which affords views of the orchards! There is art displayed everywhere in the house.

Name: Forst's Landhaus
Description: Run with great dedication, this restaurant is located by a small stream ?tables on the terrace overlooking the water are in great demand! The seasonal menu uses plenty of regional produce, such as lamb from the Bavarian Jura. The vegetarian dishes are also appealing, imaginative and delicious! The friendly maître d' provides good service with a personal touch. There are simple but well-kept guestrooms for overnight stays.

Name: Landhaus Hohenlohe
Description: The interior at Hohenlohe comes in two styles: cosy and rustic or casually elegant. Matthias Mack’s cuisine is also a mix, offering Mediterranean dishes such as saddle of lamb in a Provençal garlic crust with pimento cream and baked saffron risotto alongside classics such as pan-fried beef steak and onions. The service is friendly and the restaurant also offers a few well-kept guestrooms.

Name: Zur Sonne
Description: You should also try a meal at the Glück family’s friendly restaurant. Zur Sonne serves up tasty regional fare alongside a few more sophisticated dishes. Why not try the braised belly and loin of Swabian-Hall pork with creamed carrots and mustard?

Name: Gaststube
Description: Housed inside Krone is this pleasant and down-to-earth restaurant that is also run by the Wölfelschneider family. The Gaststube menu will appeal to those who appreciate traditional regional fare. As well as delicious food, guests can enjoy the friendly service, which contributes to the congenial atmosphere. In summer, the terrace is a dream!

Name: Bärenkrug
Description: Whether you are seated in the Friesenstube or the secluded courtyard garden with its old chestnut trees and abundant greenery, at the Sierks family's restaurant you can look forward to quality cuisine with a regional and seasonal focus in the form of daily specials, classics or set menus. Tip: Be sure to try the home-made chocolates. The hotel of the same name, also part of this long-standing family business, has attractive, comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Freihardt
Description: Eating here really is a pleasure! The cuisine is international and seasonal, the highlight being the Bavarian beef. A friendly atmosphere reigns in the restaurant and its conservatory, and the terrace on the busy street is a place "to see and be seen". Right next door is the restaurant's own butcher's shop, which has for many years employed so-called humane slaughtering methods.

Name: Gasthaus Waltz
Description: A fashionable and lively restaurant in Munich's Glockenbachviertel, run by an enthusiastic young team. The secret of its success is the chefs' modern take on Alpine cuisine ?sometimes creative, sometimes more traditional, but the presentation is always sharp, and the ingredients are the region's finest. Dishes such as the Tafelspitz-Sülze (jellied prime boiled beef) with horseradish, root vegetables and seed oil vinaigrette or the char with lentils, apple, trout caviar and beurre blanc can be ordered à la carte or together as a set menu comprising four or five courses. Wine is taken very seriously here and, consequently, the list is not only well curated in terms of quality, but also surprisingly extensive. Motorists should note that parking options are limited.

Name: Landhotel Krone
Description: Here, tradition rubs shoulders with current trends in cosy little spaces that feature an attractive blend of old brickwork, wood, steel and glass. The regional and seasonal cuisine is scattered with international influences. Medieval vaulted cellar for events. This family-run business also offers attractive, individually designed guestrooms and wellness facilities.

Name: Kulturhof Stanggass - Gasthaus
Description: The Gasthaus, which annexes the Kulturhof Stanggass located on the road between Bischofswiesen and Berchtesgaden, offers a culinary alternative to the restaurant Solo Du. Done out in light wood, the minimalist-style interior has a modern yet cosy feel. The glass façade affords views of the garden, which includes a children's playground. Book a spot at the "Stammtisch", a long handmade wooden table for 25 diners. The menu draws on the region and nature's bounty ?the ingredients are locally sourced. The good food is complemented by friendly service.

Name: WEINreich
Description: A modern wine bar in a tranquil little village. The historical setting has been given a makeover including attractive decorative touches; to complement the numerous wine bottles on display, the ceiling is adorned with a depiction of the wine route marked with its famous wine villages. Outside, there is a charming courtyard terrace. Led by Jeanette and Henning Weinheimer, the very friendly and proficient team go about their work with great dedication, serving high-quality regional and seasonal cuisine ?as a set menu or à la carte. Meat-eaters should ask about their "Steak Weeks"; Sunday roast is available if pre-ordered. You can also purchase their bread, which they bake on site. For overnight stays there are really pleasant guestrooms.

Name: CARUSO Pastabar
Description: Neapolitan-born Anna and Marcello Caruso, working with Emanuele Barbaro, have come up with a cool concept: a tasty, relaxed and lively dining experience, played out in a chic atmosphere. Service comes courtesy of a relaxed, attentive team under the tutelage of the charming proprietress. They serve a reasonably priced three-course set menu, which you can put together yourself ?there's delicious homemade pasta for the main course!

Name: Weinstube zum Engel
Description: With his Weinstube (or "wine tavern"), Christian Beck, son of the owner of the hotel and restaurant Heiligenstein, also located in Neuweier, has brought a new layer of culinary enrichment to the village. The cuisine here comprises regional, seasonal and Mediterranean dishes. Vegetarian dishes and small bites are also available. Friendly service in a cosy interior that blends tradition and modernity. The terrace is also lovely.

Name: Rebblick
Description: Housed in Korb's Remstalhalle, this restaurant has retained a certain 1970s feel, while incorporating chic modern design features and an attractive glass façade. Jochen Gromann serves up flavoursome seasonal cuisine drawing on regional and international influences (including Swabian Zwiebelrostbraten). Managed by Nadine (his wife), the front-of-house team are friendly and well drilled and provide astute wine recommendations. Delightful terrace ?with a view of the vineyards, depending on where you sit.

Name: Regional Friesoythe
Description: "Regional" is more than a name here, it is a philosophy! Since September 2022, Timo Plenter and Ina Stuke have been running this traditional restaurant in the centre of town and are completely committed to sustainability. The chef cooks honest flavoursome food, sourcing seasonal ingredients from the region and favours local suppliers. You can choose between a three to five-course menu (also vegetarian) and the 7-course "Signature Dish" menu. The interior decor marries modern and rustic elements. Cordial service from the attentive staff. In summer a few tables are set up in front of the building.

Name: falke23
Description: This delightful spot is a well-kept, typically rustic-style Bavarian inn. In a lively, atmospheric and pleasantly informal setting, diners sit at large wooden tables and are waited on by a laid-back front-of-house team. The menu is divided into a modern and creative set menu and specialities including well-known classics such as veal cream goulash or cheese spaetzle ?with lots of variety, there is something for everyone. The regular events and themed evenings are also worth noting.

Name: Wirtshaus Mättle
Description: Dating from 1848, this inn has been given a tastefully modern makeover. High-quality, market-fresh produce is used to conjure up cuisine that looks to the Mediterranean as well as the local region for inspiration. In addition to à la carte dishes (the whole roasted trout, for instance, is a house speciality), a surprise menu is also on offer. Gorgeous terrace. Located in the basement, bar-cum-restaurant THEODOR is ideal for events.

Name: Salt & Silver Levante
Description: With this friendly urban restaurant, Salt & Silver in the St Pauli neighbourhood also has a Levantine version in addition to its Latin American eatery. Here you dine mezze-style, following the example of the cuisine of the southeastern corner of the Mediterranean: Levant-inspired dishes, both big and small, come together to the table and are made for sharing.

Name: Geberts Weinstuben
Description: Freshness, flavour, aroma ?this is how you might sum up Frank Gebert's cuisine. He also likes to use produce from the region to create his classic dishes. The restaurant, located in a side street not far from the Rhine, is furnished with a touch of elegance; outside, meanwhile, it is pleasant to sit in the courtyard on the vine-clad terrace.

Name: Landgasthof Schwanen
Description: A Landgasthof ?country inn ?in the best sense! The Fräulin family is committed to its patrons; the whole establishment is very well looked after, from the restaurant to the comfortable guest rooms. The tasty food is fuss-free and influenced by regional culinary tradition ?in the evening, the menu is somewhat more extensive. As for the interior, the dining rooms are done out in a traditional-rural style with the occasional modern touch.

Name: Landgasthof zum Müller
Description: At their established country inn, Ingrid and Markus Buchner serve fresh regional and seasonal cuisine with international and Mediterranean influences ?responsible for this is chef Marcel von Winckelmann. The service is friendly and cordial, the rustic-style restaurant rooms are inviting, and the leafy terrace with its small open barn ("Salettl") is delightful. They have modern rural-style guestrooms, too.

Name: Hirsch
Description: Hirsch is an extremely well-kept and well-run family business, where you can stay overnight and, first and foremost, eat very well. The kitchen's repertoire ranges from breaded pork schnitzel to sole fillet with shrimp and Riesling sauce. Really friendly and charming service completes the picture of the ideal country inn.

Name: das asam
Description: You dine in the Modlersäle, once the refectory, on the first floor of this former monastery building. It has beautiful high ceilings decorated with lovely mouldings and paintings ?the historical setting is tastefully combined with an interior design of clean lines. The food is modern and seasonal, and the tasty Zwiebelrostbraten (fried beef and onions in gravy) is a classic. On warm summer days, the terrace in the cloister garden of the monastery courtyard is idyllic! You can stay overnight in well-kept, simply charming guestrooms.

Name: Die Krone
Description: Chef Volker Lahn continues the family tradition in the kitchen at Die Krone. The cosy Baden setting of the dining rooms is matched by good local Baden cooking. The seasonal fare is available in the form of a set menu or à la carte.

Name: Gasthaus Schwanen
Description: Now in its third generation, this charming family-run inn opposite the church serves very good food. A cosy atmosphere awaits you inside, while the idyllic garden terrace beckons outside. Here, they keep chickens, hunt game and make schnapps, and their own produce often features on the menu. Accommodation options: Gasthaus Schwanen, Villa Pfarrhus with its beautiful garden, and the Malermeisterhaus guesthouse.

Name: Gutsküche
Description: It is a real pleasure to see the terrific produce gracing the plates at Gutsküche, just outside Hamburg ?this is sustainable gastronomy par excellence! The organic ingredients from their own estate, Hofgut Wulksfelde, are the absolute focal point of the cooking, and the menu features vegetarian dishes that can be supplemented with fish, poultry and meat "garnishes". GUT's caprese with hand-scooped buffalo mozzarella, rocket and tomato pesto, for example, is a marvellous seasonal dish ?the wonderful aroma of fully ripe tomatoes remains in the memory! Tip: Snacks can be purchased at GutsDeli and delicatessen shop, as well as organic produce in the on-site farm shop. In summer: organic ice cream in the lovely GutsGarten.

Name: Lohmayr Stub'n
Description: Chef Sebastian Oberholzner puts his heart and soul into his cooking, meaning his delicious dishes are much in demand. He uses seasonal and regional ingredients, making sure to know his suppliers and the origin of the produce. There is also a good selection of wines. Diners enjoy charming service in the setting of a fine historical building.

Name: Sticky Fingers
Description: Located in the beautiful Old Town, this is a fashionable restaurant and bar. The decor and background music are very much on trend and lend this laid-back establishment something of a club atmosphere. The appealing international menu features flavoursome dishes including fish and chips, panzanella and paella ?all served by very friendly waitstaff. As well as wines, there is an extensive selection of cocktails, another big draw of this place.

Name: Auers Schlosswirtschaft
Description: It's no surprise that this restaurant, run with dedication for over 30 years, is so popular! Diners are won over by both the cosy space that is beautifully done out to exude rustic charm and chef Astrid Hilse's fresh cuisine, which takes the form of a menu that changes on a daily basis. Top-notch produce goes into seasonal dishes with a definite wow factor, such as braised lemon chicken with roasted vegetables and garlic potatoes, or local lamb prepared two ways and served with olive confit and green beans. The service is friendly ?and the chef, too, gets in on the act. Attractive tree-shaded terrace. N.B. Credit cards are not accepted.

Name: MundArt2015
Description: Located in a beautiful spot not far from Salzburg, the attractive Gut Edermann hotel awaits you with tastefully designed guestrooms and a 2 700m2 spa area, as well as appealing dining options including Bauernstube1910 and MundArt2015. Friendly waitstaff serve up the flavoursome seasonal cuisine in a cosy setting. The preference for locally sourced ingredients reflects the restaurant's commitment to sustainability.

Name: Graf Everstein
Description: The Multhoff family's restaurant draws in diners with the promise of skilfully prepared food and wonderful views over the Weser. The friendly and attentive staff serve up beautifully fresh cuisine that sets great store by both seasonal produce and selected ingredients.

Name: Zur Linde
Description: The Trautwein brothers run this 300 year-old former posting house with its charming mix of historical and modern decor with great dedication. The menu includes Swabian classics such as Gaisburger Marsch beef stew, maultaschen ravioli and veal tripe with braised oxtail, alongside seasonal offerings. The rustic vaulted cellar is available for events.

Name: Landhaus Zum Rössle
Description: Family tradition since 1780! Here the hospitality extended to diners is just as important as the tasty cuisine made from regional produce. Besides classic dishes, a surprise menu is also served. In summer the garden is a delight! There is a fantastic barn venue for parties. You can also stay overnight.

Name: Landhotel zum Hirsch
Description: This traditional inn dating back over 300 years serves regional cuisine made with seasonal and predominantly locally sourced ingredients. The menu ranges from classics such as Hirschwirts Gaisburger Marsch (a traditional Swabian beef stew) and Swabian tripe ragout to Mediterranean-influenced dishes such as fried Atlantic sea bream fillet with a white wine sauce on bell peppers and courgettes with risotto. This elegant family-run establishment has comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Das August
Description: It's no wonder this place is so popular! The Gehrke family have made it a point of honour to uphold their long-standing tradition of offering outstanding cuisine, plus friendly service and an inviting atmosphere. The food is fresh, seasonal and made with select ingredients. The menu includes, for example, vegetable curry, roast corn-fed chicken breast with mushrooms or local game. There is also an impressive selection of schnitzels. Well-stocked wine cabinet. Attractive guestrooms at Schmiedegasthaus Gehrke.

Name: Die Krone
Description: Owner and head chef Markus Elison previously worked at Herrengass in Gschwend, where he proved his worth in the kitchen. Here, he cooks up delicious dishes made with high-quality ingredients. His cuisine is regional, with some Mediterranean influences. One of his signature dishes is Zwiebelrostbraten in a Spätburgunder wine sauce with spaetzle. Dine à la carte or opt for the seasonal set menu or "Das Krone Menü". Friendly service. Sleek modern decor. For overnight stays, there are functional yet chic guestrooms available ?the prices are lower in the guesthouse.

Name: Am Osterfeuer
Description: Hans-Jörg Dunker and his team have long been synonymous with quality and Westphalian cuisine with an international twist. The restaurant interior is attractive and cheerful, having been given a skilful modern makeover, but care has been taken to leave the traditional character of the building intact. One of the chef's specialities is the wonderful fish and shellfish soup with aioli, bread and parmesan. A gorgeous terrace for summer.

Name: Schorse im Leineschloss
Description: This pleasantly down-to-earth restaurant is the second in the cube-like extension of the Leineschloss, along with Votum. The flavoursome food is made with select ingredients and draws on French influences, for example pan-fried meagre with Champagne cabbage, grapes and herby mashed potatoes. They also serve a simpler quick lunch set menu. Delightful terraces at the Leinewehr and on Platz der Göttinger Sieben.

Name: Froschgrundsee
Description: This appealing country house lies above a small lake, in the town's Schönstädt neighbourhood. Hannes Scammell shows his culinary mettle, cooking up fresh and tasty seasonal dishes. You can also dine outside. At lunchtime, the menu is somewhat reduced. The good cuisine is complemented by the friendly service provided by the hostess. Barbecue fans, take note: they also organise regular evening events dedicated to grilled meats.

Name: Cube by Mika
Description: Somewhat tucked away, this is a trendy and lively maisonette-style restaurant occupying two levels. The atmosphere is laid-back and casual and, on the lower floor, you can also sit at bar tables. This place specialises in delicious izakaya cuisine ?predominantly Asian dishes and finger food for sharing. On certain days, they also propose an ambitious tasting menu.

Name: Jäger & Lustig
Description: With its cosy atmosphere and great food, this is a truly charming place. "Heimatküche" is how they themselves term their fresh and flavoursome cuisine. The emphasis is on classic German dishes and game ?goose is the seasonal speciality of the house. Tip: Order the "whole goose for four people". Don't miss out on the beer garden in summer.

Name: Melkhus
Description: The former cowshed of this beautifully renovated historical Immenhof estate houses this charming alternative to the Rodesand restaurant. The cuisine is traditional, regional and seasonal, made with top-quality, fresh produce. The classics on the menu include Holstein-style sour meat and roasted suckling pig ham. Vegetarian options are also available. The food is complemented by friendly service and a cosy, rustic atmosphere ?the open fireplace is a nice touch. In summer, make a beeline for the terrace, which overlooks the lake. Coffee and cake are served in the afternoon. Pick up some home-made jam, souvenirs etc at the farm shop.

Name: Winzerstube - Vinum
Description: A friendly and modern restaurant in the tastefully done out hotel of the same name. In summer, it is a treat to sit on the Mediterranean-style terrace. The kitchen serves tasty Baden dishes prepared with precise craftsmanship and based on choice ingredients. When it comes to the wine, too, the restaurant has a clear penchant for the region. There is also the Weinstube ?a traditional rustic-style wine bar.

Name: Bistro Margarete
Description: In addition to Sein, Thorsten Bender now runs this second restaurant. The place has a stylish and lively atmosphere and, outside, the terrace in the courtyard verges on the romantic in summer. The food is tasty and regional, with a menu that includes classic and modern dishes. There is also a fairly priced wine list. The service is pleasantly friendly and casual. Tip: try the appealing lunch menu.

Name: WurzelWerk
Description: Two houses, built in 1875 as an agricultural estate, now house a guesthouse (with café service at weekends) and a restaurant, where owner Benjamin Bendzko promises and delivers fresh market-based cuisine. Excellent ?and almost exclusively regional ?ingredients go into the tasty and pleasingly straightforward dishes. Rural charm and pretty decor make for a beautifully cosy backdrop. In summer, the garden terrace is a real hit.

Name: MaMi's
Description: Having gained many years of experience in the fine dining sector, brother-and-sister team Marcel and Miriam Hertrampf have opened this laid-back little restaurant. The location alone is great: the street lined with tall trees and buzzing with a lively atmosphere has a charm all of its own ?the terrace on the wide pavement is especially inviting. In the kitchen, patron Marcel serves up flavoursome modern fusion cuisine, drawing on a wealth of culinary influences from Spanish to Asian, with or without meat. There is also a sharing menu comprising eight or ten small dishes. The service team led by hostess Miriam is charming and professional. She is a professionally trained sommelier and will be happy to guide you through the wine list, which features around 200 different labels.

Name: Berggasthof Schlüssel
Description: This mountain inn dating back over a hundred years is located at an altitude of 700m in the district of Pfaffenberg. Your dedicated hosts propose regional dishes that are in tune with the seasons and peppered with modern touches, to be savoured in cosy dining rooms with plenty of rustic charm. If you fancy a bottle of wine with your meal, why not stay over in the well-kept guestrooms?

Name: Dorfstuben
Description: The Clock Room and the Förster Jakob Room are lovingly decorated, 19C country rooms, which could hardly be more charming and cosy. Tasty regional food is served, the prices are fair, and the service is friendly.

Name: Alter Esel
Description: The couple who run this restaurant put everything they have into creating a warm atmosphere and serving seasonal cuisine that draws on regional and Mediterranean influences. The set menu also comes in a vegetarian version. In addition to the cosy, lovingly decorated dining area inside, there are a handful of outdoor tables affording views of the historical buildings of this charming little town. This business is a Slow Food member and is committed to sustainability.

Name: Michels Stern
Description: The Michel family have always run their restaurant with great dedication, and now the fourth generation is at the helm. Two brothers make this an experience to remember: Wolfgang draws on good produce to cook tasty dishes ranging from traditional home-style fare to refined cuisine. Stefan will be delighted to recommend the right Franconian wine to go with your food. Plus well-kept guestrooms.

Name: Funky Fisch
Description: Are you in the mood for fish of the uncomplicated and Asian-inspired variety? Then head to the trendy and lively Funky Fisch by The Duc Ngo. The centrepiece is the large fish counter, where you choose the fish you want to eat, which is then prepared in the open kitchen. A wide range of Asian food, from Chinese to Vietnamese, is served, with influences from all over the world.

Name: Speisemeisterei Burgthalschenke
Description: The Großhammer family has been renowned for its good cooking for years! Diners can choose between the set menu or classic dishes. The cuisine follows the seasons, with ingredients being sourced in the local area. Laid out over three levels, the restaurant also has a lovely terrace. On a practical note: large car park.

Name: Sternenschanz
Description: A fun dining experience! The Linck family put their heart and soul into running this delightful restaurant. Diners can look forward to friendly service and the chance to eat really well without breaking the bank. The menu focuses on Swabian fare and home-style cooking, with dishes such as Flädlesuppe (pancake soup) and creamy veal goulash. No wonder there are so many regulars! In summer, the gorgeous garden terrace beckons.

Name: Das Jagdhaus
Description: Built in 1856, this charming timber house has three dining areas and is a really pleasant alternative to the other restaurants run by the Bolkart-Fetz family in Oberstdorf. Only ingredients sourced from within Germany ?preferably from the region ?go into the dishes on the traditional menu, including some excellent game options. Decent wine list. There is also a lovely beer garden shaded by chestnut trees.

Name: Lamm
Description: A modern ambience, a pleasantly informal atmosphere and the warmth of a traditional inn go hand in hand here. The menu whets your appetite with an interesting array of regional and international dishes. The set menus, which include a vegan one, are also excellent. A much sought-after place ?for weekends you should book early!

Name: Stumpenhof
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Great view,Terrace
Description: Diners are in such good hands here that they can't help but enjoy themselves! The waitstaff are exceptionally friendly, while the owner herself, who radiates good humour, is always ready to cater to her guests' needs. On the menu: plenty of the classics of Swabian cuisine, such as tripe soup or creamy veal goulash (which is best enjoyed with the home-made spätzle).

Name: MEIER
Description: This restaurant in a fabulous countryside location boasts a delightful garden and terrace. Inside, the decor is a winning blend of tradition and modernity. The Meier family also run the gorgeous HILZHOF, a hotel with chic guestrooms, and the small fine dining restaurant HIO. More down-to-earth, MEIER serves delicious food with from organic produce sourced from the region or even from their own vegetable field or herb garden. Delightful front-of-house team.

Name: Kamin- und Bauernstube
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Among the dining options at the exclusive Hotel Dollenberg, you can choose to eat in the cosy, rustic-style Bauernstube, the elegant fireside Kaminstube or out on the wonderful spacious terrace ?both the terrace and the Kaminstube offer beautiful views of the Black Forest. Whichever space you opt for, you can look forward to high-quality regional and international cuisine. The excellent wine list served in the fine dining restaurant is also available here! Tip: try the set menu ("Menü der Woche").

Name: Die Halde
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Situated at an altitude of 1 147m, this stylish restaurant successfully bridges the gap between history and modernity! The food is served in cosy traditional dining rooms, where guests are looked after by friendly, well-trained staff. Local produce is favoured, and the water comes from the house's mountain spring. There are also lovely guestrooms done out in a modern, regional style.

Name: Gasthaus Sternen Post
Description: This beautifully restored 1875 restaurant is a fine example of the dedication of its owner. Diners sit in comfortable rooms complete with tiled ovens to sample delicious dishes such as venison stew with spaetzle (a Swabian pasta speciality) and red cabbage or apple fritters with vanilla sauce. Overnight accommodation comes in the form of lovely country house-style rooms.

Name: Zum Dückerstieg
Description: An attractive, cosy restaurant with rural flair which serves seasonal and regional cuisine. Here, you can look forward to flavoursome dishes that pack a punch. The delicious options on offer include salmon, North Sea prawns, sea bass, suckling pig and game. Steeped in tradition, this family-run business ?now in its fourth generation ?also has attractive, comfortable guestrooms for overnight stays.

Name: Wirtschaft von Johann Gerner
Description: The journey out here to the countryside is well worth it, because Detlef Gerner and his wife Tanja live and breathe hospitality par excellence in their cosy restaurant. The hand-written menu features flavoursome dishes based on seasonal and predominantly regional produce ?incidentally, they bake their own bread. In summer, you can sit on the terrace out front. Overnight accommodation in the pretty "Häusla" (for two to seven people).

Name: Granit
Description: Between Carnac and Quiberon, this modern edifice, deep in the Brittany countryside, is a foodie’s paradise! Chef Charles Moreau has knocked around a bit from China to the Belgian kitchens of Sang Hoon Degeimbre (including the 2-star Air du Temps). Brittany whiskey, buckwheat, artichokes, oysters, gwell and Guéméné andouille, the food ticks all the boxes of traditional Brittany fare. The result is spot on, well-crafted and above all balanced, without forgetting the odd, inspired creative note (such as the dessert of black olives, strawberries and burrata). Concise (mainly organic and biodynamic) wine list and a black and white minimalist interior.

Name: Topaze
Description: The town centre is home to this couple of professionals who met in Paris at William Ledeuil’s Ze Kitchen. He is in the kitchen, she at the front of house and together they have crafted this irresistible gourmet gem. The chef works with the meticulousness of a jeweller: fresh local produce that varies with the season, high-precision, slow cooking techniques, aromas and colours. We feasted on a beef tartare with an iced oyster cream dotted with samphire, followed by pearlescent cod in a sesame seed and roast buckwheat crust, coated with a punchy jus of saffron-flavoured cockles.

Name: La Plage
Description:
This small hotel-restaurant in a coastal village between Cap Gris-Nez and Cap Blanc-Nez is just the ticket on the Opal Coast. Young chef Solène Elliott, helped in the dining room by her partner, who provides friendly service, has concocted a tempting menu with a focus on fish (sea bream, mackerel, pollack). There are also other delicious and beautifully presented dishes: free-range egg mayonnaise with chives, ravigote, salsify, gherkin chutney; shredded chicken leg, creamy parsnip, mint remoulade?
L'IØDE"

Name: Cabane
Description: Chef Jean-François Bury, who boasts stints at the George V and the Shangri-La, is masterfully regaling Nanterre with modern, bistronomic nosh. Well-crafted recipes, generous helpings and wholesome flavours, such as confit of finely sliced veal belly in oregano, smoked apple puree, sucrine lettuce, or the exquisitely crafted and fiendishly tempting lemon and raspberry showpiece.

Name: Sillage
Description: Piedmontese chef Gabriele Ferri and his wife Marie-Nolwenn run this bistro, which has been given a nautical makeover against a backdrop of pale stone walls and contemporary furnishings. The former chef of Le Verdurier ?Château de Drudas serves up seafood cuisine?with Italian influences, of course! Meat, meanwhile, only features during the hunting season. An example dish: pollack poached in seawater, chard with green curry, creamy Piedmont polenta with miso, fragrant consommé.

Name: La Croix Blanche
Address: 2 avenue de la Loire (à Veuves), Veuves, 41150, France
Description: At this former coaching inn, you can enjoy the modern cuisine of chef Jean-François Beauduin, who learned his trade in Michelin-starred restaurants. His tempting menu abounds with wonderfully indulgent treats, which does not preclude finesse ?the warm duck and foie gras pâté, shredded Brussels sprouts and langoustine sauce is a case in point. Seasonal and local ingredients are de rigueur. Note the selection of more traditional dishes, such as beuchelle tourangelle (creamed kidneys and sweetbreads). Charming service courtesy of the chef's wife, in a delightfully rustic setting. The pleasant terrace in the shade of mulberry trees is a real highlight.

Name: La Petite Grange
Description: In this picturesque Cantal village, home to a castle, the traveller is always delighted to take a seat in this tastefully renovated traditional barn (wood, stone and shale). Beneath a stunning raftered ceiling, gaze out at the Doire Valley through the large windows. In the kitchen, chef Olivier Cloteau expertly crafts seasonal dishes that pay homage to the Cantal region and its producers, without forgetting a few nods to his Charentes roots (mouclade (mussels in saffron) as an appetizer). 100% wholesome, hearty nosh.

Name: Brasserie d'Asten
Description: On Binic port, this contemporary brasserie has large bay windows overlooking the sea. The chef with a glittering track record (Le Coquillage ?Maison de Bricourt in Cancale, La Pyramide Patrick Henriroux in Vienne and K2 in Courchevel) likes to cook up his enticing brand of "bistronomy" cuisine, incorporated into set menus that represent good value for money.

Name: Bergamote
Description: The unusual façade of this bistronomic bijou can be found in the heart of a district in the throes of renovation. A youthful chef carefully crafts seasonal fare, depicted by crisp flavours in a simple, natural setting. The lunchtime prices are deliciously eater friendly ?more ambitious in the evening.

Name: L'Estacade
Address: 4 quai du Lénigo, Le Croisic, 44490, France
Description: This pleasant eatery on the quayside, opposite the fish market, is managed by two young people with experience in some elite establishments. They propose hearty and meticulously made food that makes good use of regional produce (fish, shellfish and seaweed, of course, but also meat). The lady of the house is a radiant hostess. Smiling staff and attentive service.

Name: L'Arbre Vert
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Wheelchair access
Description: The tree mentioned in the name of this restaurant could well be a genealogical one, so closely is its history bound up with that of the Koenig family. Now run by the fifth generation of this family, the restaurant serves specialities from Alsace, which are accompanied by good regional wines.

Name: La Récré
Description: This restaurant is housed in a former village school for boys. You will notice evidence of its previous incarnation in the decor with blackboards and geographical maps hanging on the walls. On the menu, the dishes are creative and make good use of locally sourced ingredients. It is enough to make us sign up for evening classes!

Name: Rolland
Description: Nestling in a valley through which a river flows, this former mill and farmhouse have been renovated from top to bottom and turned into this restaurant with an industrial-style interior. Two brothers, one in the kitchen and the other in the market garden, concoct healthy, natural cuisine based on seafood ingredients (fish, shellfish, crustaceans) and vegetables, some grown on site; meat is shelved. A 100% plant-based starter, such as the Jerusalem artichoke with lemon and black garlic purée, or a seafood main, such as skate wing with celeriac and a wild garlic sauce. Rolland is a roaring success!

Name: Rosemarie
Description: Cream, butter, zinc-topped counter, imitation leather and egg mayonnaise ?a recipe for happiness! This bistro was opened by two seasoned professionals, Nina and Philippe Cadeau (formerly at Le Beurre Noisette and Christian Constant's Cocottes, respectively), and named after their mothers. Their expertise is still going strong: Nina's enthusiasm continues to shine on the restaurant floor and Philippe turns out delicious traditional and seasonal dishes: leek vinaigrette, country terrine, salmon tartar, pollack, scallops, entrecote and shoulder of lamb for two, custard pie and chocolate mousse. There is a menu on the blackboard ?changes daily (around ?0 at lunchtime and ?0 in the evening) ?and an à la carte menu.

Name: La Fourchette à Droite
Address: 2 rue de la Pie-qui-Boit, Saint-Malo, 35400, France
Description: Welcome to Caroline and Étienne Corson's eminently hospitable eatery. She is in charge of the front-of-house and, left-handed, hence the fork in the restaurant's name is on the right! The dishes celebrate the best of Brittany, showcasing first-class seasonal ingredients: monkfish gravlax with creamy fennel and seaweed jam; plaice, partly mashed potatoes and mikan sauce; melt-in-the-mouth baked apple with a crunchy almond topping and cider caramel, for example. Booking is recommended, as seating is limited in the small cosy dining room.

Name: La Table du Square
Description: After a top-to-toe makeover, this bistro on the main boulevard sports a lovely contemporary decor complete with wooden floors, black and white striped walls and photos of the stars of French cinema enjoying good food. Cooking has no secrets for chef Romain Escoffier (well, he does share the name of a legend of French cuisine!): he chooses local produce (such as succulent lamb reared at the Ferme de Clavisy) with which to craft his market-fresh cuisine. The à la carte menu and set menu (derived from the à la carte menu) are updated every fortnight. Given the location in Beaune, you won't be surprised to learn that the wine list boasts some 800 labels ?so drink up!

Name: Baca'v par Gilles Choukroun
Description: Good wholesome food and a casual, down-to-earth vibe depict Émile Cotte’s approach. After a traditional textbook approach to cooking, he now favours a more instinctive, spontaneous style, adding a personal twist to updated bistro classics, such as oeuf parfait, country bacon and cream of parmesan. The regularly changing slate menu is deliciously affordable and there is also a 5-course surprise menu.

Name: Gribiche
Description: We fell head over heels with this endearing bistro! Traditional dishes, jazzed up for modern tastebuds and served generously, are enticingly chalked up on slate menus: porkpie, calf’s head gribiche sauce, lamb shank and desserts to die for with lashings of salted butter and cream. Fine choice of reasonably priced tipples.

Name: Auberge de La Mère Duval
Address: Impasse de la Linerie, Auzouville-sur-Saâne, 76730, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Wheelchair access
Description: Alexandre and Mélanie Baranzelli are thriving in a new venue oozing with country charm: picture a stream spanned by two bridges and a watermill! The chef, after honing his skills in top establishments, demonstrates his fondness for traditional recipes from his native Normandy, to which he is increasingly adding his own distinctive culinary hallmark.

Name: Le Clos Saint Martin - La Métairie
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Mélanie Zervos and her partner Mickaël Cappella welcome you to their restaurant in this small village between Mirepoix and Pamiers. The chef shines a spotlight on the local terroir: salad of pork trotters and herring "like a stuffed onion" on a potato emulsion, for a surf/turf dish that packs a punch; medallion of veal cooked until still pink in the centre, basil and vegetables from nearby market gardens; a deconstructed millefeuille that delivers on all its promises in terms of textures?Culinary bliss!

Name: Le 21ème Commis
Description: Located in the centre of Morlaix and surrounded by gorgeous half-timbered buildings, this recently opened restaurant is run by a chef with experience in MICHELIN-starred establishments. His original cuisine combines Breton ingredients and more exotic influences (particularly Asian). Flavour combinations that delight the taste buds and generous portions, as in his indulgent pear and wine dessert.

Name: Café de la Fontaine
Address: 4 avenue du Général-de-Gaulle, La Turbie, 06320, France
Description: A convivial atmosphere, good choice of unpretentious, enjoyable wines, as well as tasty and generous market sourced cuisine of Provencal inspiration. All chalked up on the slate. A memorable culinary experience guaranteed!

Name: Le Bouche à Oreille
Description: An opportunity to discover the work of a likeable, self-effacing chef, who is as modest as his food is good. Seasonal ingredients and premium produce feature prominently in his dishes: duck breast cooked rare with prunes and orange, einkorn risotto. It's tasty, flawlessly crafted and delicious! In fine weather, you can sit out on the pretty terrace in the garden to the rear.

Name: L'Auberge du Pas de Vent
Description: Authenticity is the name of the game in this Landes inn that specialises in hearty, wholesome nosh, light years from fads and fashions. The menu pays tribute to the terroir: Chalosse beef, free-range fattened duck, veal from calves fed on their mother’s milk, pure sheep milk cheese from a village shepherd and home-made sourdough bread (without additives). Examples of the nostalgic score include celery and fennel rémoulade, cream of split peas and crispy slivers of coppa or Jurançon calf’s sweetbread served in a skillet. Warm welcome and attentive, slick service. What’s not to like?

Name: Maison Cachée
Description: After stints in leading star establishments (Alain Ducasse, Maison Pic, Crillon), Alban Chartron (savoury) and his partner Sarah Alba (sweet dishes) have set up shop in Rochefort-sur-Terre, a drop-dead historic village, rife in quaint cobbled lanes and half-timbered granite houses. The duo of chefs knows the business inside out as their spot-on cooking (such as the cod of the day), spicy flavours (illustrated by oxtail with kimchi or a curry/peanut stock on fish) and play on textures (think carrot cake with a light, frothy yoghurt mousse) illustrate. Bistronomic cooking at prices that make sense flanked by a buzzy, homespun vibe and a quirky mismatched interior.

Name: Clément Artisan Culinaire
Description: This pretty little village in the upper Lot-et-Garonne, bordering the Dordogne, boasts a rich heritage. It is also home to this restaurant, in a large old building, with a young chef at the helm. Having worked in some fine establishments, he has a sure touch when it comes to preparing something like beef picanha, sourcing the tender, flavoursome meat from the village butcher and serving it with kale and chard from a market gardener in Monclar-de-Quercy. The chef seems to have a particular penchant for roasted notes such as coffee, in both the main course and the dessert. The bucolic space with an open kitchen, stone walls and exposed ceiling beams is delightful.

Name: La Closerie des Roses
Address: 455 rue de la Haute-Meilleraie, Varades, 44370, France
Description: Surrounded by rose bushes, this restaurant, which has stood on the banks of the Loire since 1938, affords a lovely view of the river and the abbey church ?St-Florent-le-Vieil. In a lovely contemporary space, the chef serves up appealing traditional cuisine drawing on regional fare (pike-perch, pike, eel, young free-range pigeon, calf sweetbreads) accompanied by classic sauces (beurre blanc, shellfish jus, wine sauce).

Name: Auberge Saint Fiacre
Address: 5 rue de la Fontaine, Veuil, 36600, France
Description: The couple at the head of this pleasant inn in a small village near Valençay can be relied upon to whip up amazing food; everything is homemade and the chef favours regional ingredients to concoct his delicate, toothsome recipes. Served in a charming rustic interior or alfresco on the flower-decked terrace in fine weather. The establishment’s success and excellent value for money mean that bookings are essential.

Name: Le Manoir de Kerbot
Description: This 16C manor house (once an orphanage) has been converted into a haven for food lovers. Guests are treated to fairly traditional cuisine ?warm oysters, semi-cooked foie gras, catch of the day, pulled pork in a spice crust served with an aromatic reduction: tasty, well-crafted recipes all the way! The service is very attentive, and the terrace overlooking a lake is delightful, as are the lovely guestrooms.

Name: O2C
Description: A former helicopter pilot who now devotes himself body and soul to cooking, Christophe Bellegaud is at the controls of this restaurant, which sports a tasteful cream and chocolate colour scheme. He uses local ingredients to create 100% homemade up-to-the-minute market cuisine that is always spot on. Chantal, the second “c?of this o2c, gracefully caters to diner’s needs.

Name: L'Envers du Décor
Address: 23 rue de la Bienfaisance, Les Herbiers, 85500, France
Description: This old bakery has been transformed into a smart, contemporary restaurant that sports a minimalist vibe. Chef Aurélien Jousseaume earned his stripes in Michelin-starred kitchens with the likes of Etchebest, Guy Savoy and Guy Martin. To-ing and fro-ing between his open kitchen and the restaurant floor, the chef, who is clearly having a ball, takes the orders and presents the dishes himself. His delicious seasonal cuisine showcases his flair for creating remarkable sauces and jus: creamy jus of trout roe, sabayon enhanced with smoked salt, watercress and horseradish sauce, veal jus with lovage.

Name: Le Bistrot 270
Description: The Domaine du Colombier’s sibling restaurant offers well-structured, bistro fare, inspired by tip-top quality ingredients. French staples take pride of place in the wholesome, savoury recipes: semi-cooked duck foie gras; haunch of tender veal; shepherd’s pie. In fine weather, the terrace near the pool and the pool-house bar overlooking the meadows and the fortified town are heavenly.

Name: Les Loges du Jardin d'Aymeric
Description: The quintessential country establishment, where they are still passionate about what they do. Mad about great ingredients, the chef uses vegetables from his kitchen garden and citrus fruits from the surrounding area, and makes his own bread made with ancient flours. Unpretentious family service, reasonable prices: an enjoyable experience.

Name: L'Ermitage
Description: This beautifully restored old barn has retained its rustic character and remains at one with its surroundings. The terrace is a lovely spot to sit and enjoy the traditional food, and in winter there is the fireplace.

Name: La Chênaie
Address: Rue du Lejat - lieu-dit La Berlanderie, Croutelle, 86240, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: The focus here is on good old-fashioned fare, in all its generosity and simplicity. Traditional French favourites, enlivened by the occasional more contemporary note, are served in a stylish space or, even better, in the extension overlooking the grounds, which are planted with century-old oak trees. A warm welcome and friendly service.

Name: Le Pré Saint Jean
Description: The frontage decked in Corten (steel with a rusty appearance) is part of a beautiful stone façade, on the town’s ring road. In the kitchen, the chef produce inspired and tasty gourmet cuisine. A success!

Name: Le 62
Description: Top marks for this restaurant that masterfully titillates our tastebuds thanks to the perfectly judged seasonings and harmonious flavours of the gifted young Vietnamese-born chef, who trained at Chamalières and the Belle Meunière in Royat. Polished bistronomic cuisine rich in French overtones, illustrated by farm-reared pork chop, sauce Grand Veneur, risotto and spring vegetables. The desserts are equally high-flying, depicted by yellow peach and an unctuous vanilla custard and whipped cream. Excellent value for money and a small courtyard patio add the final flourish to this irresistible establishment.

Name: Auberge de l'Abbaye
Description: Just a stone's throw from the romantic ruins of Hambye Abbey, this hotel and restaurant run by a welcoming and dynamic couple is well known among locals. The chef learned the trade here before moving on to other reputable establishments; now he is back, producing tasty, no-frills cuisine with solid traditional foundations. The risotto with Pont l'Évêque cheese, andouille sausage, a hint of cider vinegar and a crunchy tuile, for example, is a generous and tasty starter. Excellent value for money.

Name: Ô Moulin
Description: A young couple has transformed this charming Périgord mill into a peaceful country-style restaurant, open year-round. The chef produces fresh, tasty cuisine that is in tune with the times. Lovely shady terrace and attentive service. The first set menu is very reasonably priced. A pleasant place.

Name: Auberge Metzger
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Precise cooking, quality ingredients, well - presented accompaniments: Yves Metzger prepares regional cuisine that is quite simply delicious ?and a bargain. Another reason to stay the night at this welcoming place in the Bruche valley. Spacious and comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Le Brélévenez
Description: This pretty stone house in Brélévenez (a neighbourhood in Lannion) is run by Monsieur and Madame Le Marrec. Business is going strong, and this is not by chance: the well thought-out and tasty food is in tune with the land and the seasons. One last thing, the space is modern, refined and a pleasant place to be.

Name: Sodade
Description: Sodade is a song by Cesária Évora and a nod to the Portuguese origins of the late owner, Serge Vieira. In a large designer dining room or on the terrace overlooking the stream, you will sample dishes that are the epitome of tasty and simple. Pleasant guestrooms to stay longer.

Name: Le Cygne
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: This picturesque half-timbered Alsace edifice has successfully kept pace with the times and its veteran chef conjures up modern, bistro dishes. Examples include a mouth-wateringly juicy pink duck breast with golden rendered crispy skin served with a delicately orange-perfumed and slightly spicy gravy jus. Choice between two menus in a pared-down refreshingly minimalist interior.

Name: L'Épine
Address: 19 place de la République, Azay-le-Rideau, 37190, France
Description: The name of the restaurant means "blackthorn" ?a thorny shrub or tree commonly found in the hedgerows of France. Its fruit (sloes) can be turned into sloe gin. Formerly a school dating back to 1866, the premises are tastefully decorated throughout: exposed ceiling beams, large windows giving onto a tree-lined terrace, designer lighting and works of art. The chef cooks up a seasonal bistronomy menu that celebrates local produce and artisans, at affordable prices.

Name: L'Assiette au Jardin
Description: The setting comprises a small bistro-style dining area with shelves filled with delicatessen products, and a pretty extension. Sit back and tuck into tasty food, where tradition is nicely combined with influences from far and wide. The menu, which changes every two weeks, highlights local or regional produce. A charming place.

Name: Le Confidentiel
Description: Among all the restaurants (which include some real juggernauts! ) surrounding the lake, this place proves that good things come in small packages. In a tiny, light - filled dining room you can enjoy dish after formidable dish, the bold flavours going hand in hand with the friendly and relaxed atmosphere. Now that you're in on the secret, you know what to do.

Name: SaQuaNa
Description: Is Alexandre Bourdas in the process of redefining the codes of gastronomy? He has made his SaQuaNa a social hub, open from morning to night, the idea being to make good food accessible to as many people as possible. The menu is varied, with influences from near and far, and always features signature dishes such as monkfish in coconut broth and combawa oil, or his emblematic pascade. A confident and inspiring culinary offering.

Name: Auberge de l'Île
Description: Chef Pierre Koniecko has set up shop in this plush venue on Vienne Island, where he regales his guests with hearty, flavoursome creations, such as hake in bacon and croutons and braised, buttered cabbage. Delicately presented, premium ingredients served in a contemporary interior or, in summertime, on the exquisite riverside deck patio ?heavenly on hot sunny days!

Name: Double Dragon
Description: In this friendly "Asian canteen", sisters Katia and Tatiana Levha offer simple dishes of mixed inspiration (China, Philippines, Thailand etc) in an upgraded "street food" vein. This is cooking that is full of character, with pronounced flavours, and often deliciously spicy. A fun experience and tasty fare.

Name: Le Café des Arts
Address: 2 rue de la Poste, Beaulieu-sous-la-Roche, 85190, France
Description: A tastefully restored former village cafe-cum-restaurant set in a picturesque country town of Vendée has become the HQ of Virginie and Antoine Préteux, a young yet experienced couple with a few starred establishments on their CV. Antoine conjures up appetising recipes, strewn with modern twists, based on classical techniques honed during his career and inspired by market availability in a bid to celebrate regional produce. Cosy, welcoming interior (with seating for 12 maximum, so book in advance!).

Name: Manat
Description: In this old building with thick stone walls just a stone's throw from Cathédrale Saint-Jean-Baptiste, this restaurant has a refined interior decor with an open kitchen, a large corner counter, pale wood tables and a dining room that is packed to the rafters (be sure to book). There's a good reason it is so popular: at the helm are French-Japanese couple Yuka and Marc Meya, a highly inventive pair whose seasonal cuisine designed for sharing brings together Catalan and Japanese ingredients and draws on the culinary techniques of both countries. Mainstays on the menu include the iconic Kara Age, a boneless chicken leg fried in Shio Koji, served with fresh shiso leaves and spring onions; or the tasty tataki of locally fished bonito, leeks and wild garlic. Every day, there are 10 or so generous sharing plates to choose from (three for a meal for one, fix or six for two).

Name: Perle des Vosges
Description: In this family-run hotel-restaurant, the first thing you notice is the wonderfully traditional interior (chandeliers and silverware). The dishes range from the classic (marengo chicken supreme) to the regional (veal kidneys with mustard seeds, marrow quenelles and spaetzle), to the occasional more contemporary offering (lobster tempura). The cheese platter from the valley is a real highlight.

Name: Le Bon Temps
Description: By the side of the legendary Nationale 7 road, this small eatery may not look like much but is a reminder not to judge a book by its cover! In the kitchens, it is a couple who cook up delicious and hearty market-fresh cuisine, in alignment with local producers. Potato blini with oyster mushrooms; grilled pluma pork with Madeira sauce, potato gratin?Fresh produce (especially the vegetables), the joy of a good job well done and unbeatable prices.

Name: La Maison de Kerdiès
Address: 5 route de Perherel, à Saint-Samson, Plougasnou, 29630, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Great view,Wheelchair access
Description: This restaurant at the tip of Trégor province was originally a signal station then a holiday camp before being converted into a restaurant. From inside, you can enjoy a panoramic view over the Bay of Morlaix. But your attention will soon be drawn back to the food, which encompasses both regional dishes (catch of the day with a Roscoff onion sauce) and more traditional fare (chicken supreme with morel mushrooms and garlic-fried potatoes).

Name: La Chatellenie
Description: Emilie and Thomas Fournier have thrown all their enthusiasm and talent into this charming inn, hidden deep in the Vienne region. Regional produce takes the limelight in dishes as if art-directed and at deliciously eater-friendly prices. An example: grilled calf’s head that melts in the mouth with top-to-tail carrots. Well worth the detour.

Name: Atelier Salone
Description: Atelier Salone, the bistronomy sibling of Villa Salone, is pampered by Alexandre Lechêne, a chef with a stellar CV (Aux Lyonnais, Louis XV in Monaco) and a former Michelin-starred chef in Saint Véran (Hautes Alpes département). On the day of our visit, the menu included wild boar stew, squash gnocchi, quince confit and pear in a red wine, fillet of sea bream, raw and sautéed courgettes, and roast supreme of guinea fowl with green beans and figs. The original style of this early-20C building is underscored by contemporary details.

Name: Chez les Anges
Address: 54 boulevard de la Tour-Maubourg, Paris, 75007, France
Description: This chic brasserie, which was refurbished and revamped a few years ago, proposes an extensive set menu and an à la carte menu packed with premium ingredients (sole meunière, Galicia rib of beef). For solo meals, there is nothing like the central counter, where seafood is displayed on crushed ice. Tasty and masterful cooking, and a fine wine and whisky list?What a treat!

Name: Bird
Description: In the heart of this charming borough, on a pedestrian square near the town hall, a pocket-sized restaurant run by a young chef with an impressive cv. Market-inspired menu with the likes of fresh pasta with mussels, calamari and langoustines, or poultry quenelles with freekeh... Scandinavian style dining room, terrace overlooking a fountain. Delicious prices.

Name: Les 7
Description: This tiny place (no more than 25 covers) is the haunt of an enterprising young couple. The dishes are carefully presented, the flavours and textures are perfectly paired. Let's not forget to mention the absolutely delightful service.

Name: La Table du Pouyaud
Description: In the upper reaches of Périgueux, chef Gilles Gourvat (a local lad) has set up shop in a tastefully restored farmhouse. His modern recipes pay tribute to Périgord traditions, in which local produce (truffles in season) is cast in the star role. Examples: whole duck breast roasted with cèpes; scrambled eggs and truffles; semi-cooked duck foie gras smoked in hay. Heavenly.

Name: Les Petits Parisiens
Description: Chef Clément Gélard, after honing his skills in top establishments, is crafting modern bistro fare, adding an inspired touch to time-honoured family favourites such as stuffed cabbage. Food lovers won’t be able to resist the chocolate mousse with olive oil and fleur de sel or his absolute must: vanilla flavoured rice pudding with dried fruit and butterscotch ?to die for!

Name: 20 Eiffel
Description: In a quiet street a stone’s throw from the Eiffel Tower, this restaurant offers a understated interior full of light. On the menu, you can choose from a range of updated dishes, prepared by two chefs, all of which place the focus on flavour and taste. For example, a delicious fillet of wild Pollock with squash.

Name: Chez Davia
Description: This likeable establishment, run by the same family since 1953, was founded by grandma Davia and taken over in 1985 by mum, Alda, now retired. Since 2016, Pierre Altobelli, whose impressive CV features star establishments in France and Asia, concocts tempting recipes rich in the aromas of Nice. Every detail is perfect, and the ingredients are meticulously sourced. Served in a welcoming vintage bistro décor steeped in authenticity. Heavenly!

Name: Le Bouche à Oreille
Description: This top-notch establishment is laid out behind a tasteful glazed façade. The chef adheres to tradition when crafting his bold, generous and flavourful cuisine but puts his own stamp on dishes with the odd touch of originality ?think prawn tartare, prawn gyoza with coriander and lemongrass, bisque and cashew nuts. His friendly and efficient wife takes care of things front of house, dispensing insightful wine tips along the way.

Name: C'la Vie
Description: From a long line of bakers, chef Richard Durand has made C'la Vie a real mecca for food lovers. The food is good and life is good! The daily menu features terrific ingredients (most of them local), the flavours are distinctive, and the focus is firmly on dining pleasure. Enjoy your meal in the pared-back dining area inside, or on the terrace in the shade of a hundred-year-old plane tree. A fine selection of wines that celebrates the Rhône Valley and Languedoc, and rightfully so.

Name: Erasmo
Description: Venetian chef Matteo Vianello chalked up experience in the kitchens of Alain Ducasse and Jean-François Piège before becoming chef at Mensae and at Sellae. Now closer to the sea, in Finistère, he has dedicated his small contemporary bistro to the island of Sant'Erasmo (home of the famous purple artichoke). He has certainly not lost his touch, revisiting the classics in mouth-watering dishes that draw convincingly on the Breton and Italian repertoires ?for instance, onion soup and tiramisu.

Name: Téjérina - Hôtel de la Place
Address: 51 place de la Mairie, Polliat, 01310, France
Description: The epitome of a family-run inn, where hearty portions of tasty cuisine du terroir are served with a smile in a freshly refurbished dining area. Calf's head, chicken in creamy sauce, chicken liver soufflé and frogs' legs are all on the menu. Well-kept guestrooms for overnight stays.

Name: La Gare
Address: 4 rue des Ormelets, à Beaussais-sur-Mer, Ploubalay, 22650, France
Description: The chef reinterprets regional traditions by adding a fresh new twist to flavoursome surf - turf cuisine. As you explore the seaside resorts of the Emerald Coast, treat yourself to this countrified, gourmet Station!

Name: Le Garriane
Description: "Garriane" is the contraction of Garry and Ariane, and originality is the name of the game here! In the kitchens, Garry, an Australian, concocts seasonal, ingredient-focused cuisine that taps into influences from around the world. The restaurant is now open for lunch, with a menu of vegetarian and vegan options, and operates as a café in the mornings and afternoons (closed evenings and weekends).

Name: Bistrot Louise
Description: The small terrace facing the church resembles a traditional walnut drier?Welcome to this walnut-growing village where Yann Tanneau (formerly of MadaM in Grenoble and who trained at Ducasse) has set up shop. A fan of fine produce, he whisks up gutsy cuisine in menus that change weekly. Guaranteed to please, excellent value for money at lunchtime and refreshingly informal ambience.

Name: Kisin
Description: When a Bib Gourmand chef from Tokyo arrives in Paris, the first thing he does is open a restaurant, tantalising and bewitching our senses. Diners will sample Japanese produce and genuine udon, made in front of the diner. Natural, additive - free ingredients, most of which are imported direct from the Land of the Rising Sun. Healthy, wholesome and succulent.

Name: Agastache
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: This unfussy, up-to-date bistro sets the scene for instinctive, well-crafted food in the zeitgeist. Fine seasonal produce and a distinct fondness for vegetables result in dishes that combine formal elegance with flavoursome coherence. Now add lashings of generosity and a friendly vibe and you will find yourself in one of the best establishments on the Left Bank of Lyon.

Name: Les Trois Bourgeons
Description: This contemporary bistro, with its understated decoration, has blossomed in an old cellar of famous Chablis producer Domaine Laroche. An Asian team, who trained in some of the top French houses, invites its customers to partake in a fine dining experience inspired by regional recipes, revisited with taste and imagination. Unbeatable value for money.

Name: Simple et Meilleur
Address: Place Notre-Dame, quartier de Caseblanche, Saint-Martin-de-Belleville, 73440, France
Description: The brainchild of René and Maxime Meilleur, authentic Savoie produce takes the limelight in this pure-bred alpine establishment, decked in raw wood and cow bells with floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the mountains. On the menu are baked trout, Reblochon fondue, cold cuts and cheeses from the region, blueberry tart, or rabbit cooked in mustard, tarragon with creamy polenta. Even better, you can ski right up to the doorstep!

Name: Le Laurier Fleuri
Description: This former coaching inn may not enjoy the most appealing of settings, but once seated at your table you will have no trouble understanding the success of this restaurant run by a pair of industry professionals. With plenty of experience in prestigious establishments, the chef concocts a pleasingly refined and fragrant cuisine composed of bistronomy-style dishes delivered at reasonable prices.

Name: La Ferme de Victorine
Description: An authentic farmhouse with a pretty rustic - style restaurant, from which you can even see the cows in the cowshed in winter. The chef is passionate about Savoyard produce, and always on the lookout for the best cheeses and cold cooked meats. An eminently pleasant restaurant and very tasty dishes!

Name: L'Auberge des Gourmets
Address: 9 place de l'Église, Le Villars, 71700, France
Description: In a charming village above the River Saône, this restaurant has a traditional decor (exposed stones and beams, large colourful frescoes). Guillaume Laublanc, a native of these parts, sets about cooking his bistronomy-style cuisine with locally sourced ingredients and infectious enthusiasm. Cooked at low temperature, the Bresse chicken (from Johan Morand's farm) stuffed with morels and vin jaune cream is sure to win you over!

Name: Villa Mirasol - Bistrot 1912
Description: Villa Mirasol has entrusted the fate of its restaurant to Philippe Lagraula, a chef from Landes, who earned his stripes under Troisgros and Bras. His strong points are well known: presentation, originality, harmonious flavours, qualities that are illustrated by uncomplicated modern cuisine, such as black pudding with yellow pepper, runny egg and "cosa crocante".

Name: L'Artichaut
Description: Headed by a chef whose enthusiasm is contagious, this place is an ode to the seasons. Dishes are crafted from market-fresh ingredients and the menu changes regularly: wafer-thin tart of rock crab meat, avocado and green apple; roast duckling with stuffed thighs and mushroom and shallot duxelles. Fresh ingredients, recipes made from scratch, regional wines: a restaurant that cannot fail but win you over.

Name: Inspyration
Description: Travelling along the main road to Brive-la-Gaillarde, you are bound to notice this Corrèze-style building with its characteristic local stone walls and slate roof tiles. Inside, you'll immediately feel at home, thanks to the tranquil decor (wooden floors, oak tables, leather and fabric-upholstered seating) and the welcoming smile of the laid-back chef. He cooks by instinct, devising blind menus out of locally sourced ingredients. His delicious dishes, such as ox cheek confit in stock, smoked turnips and red cabbage, are never lacking in colour or precision.

Name: La Rochette
Description: This contemporary restaurant is a real find. A father and son team prepares tasty and refined dishes, such as chicken breast from Alsace with a pumpkin-seed crust and airy dumplings?Attentive service, a good selection of wines and guestrooms to prolong the stay complete the picture.

Name: Les Mets d'Adélaïde
Description: Are you sure you don't want to go back to school? Les Mets d'Adelaïde may well make you change your mind! The restaurant has taken up abode in the old village school, whose playground doubles as a summer patio. Rather than a nostalgic interior, however, expect a minimalist décor and a masterclass in contemporary cuisine. The service deserves a gold star!

Name: La Table d'Élise
Description: Conveniently opposite the fishing harbour, this seafood restaurant, an offshoot of the gastronomic La Marine, shines the spotlight on exquisitely fresh fish and seafood. The high-flying technique and hallmark of chef Alexandre Couillon can be tasted here in a bistro version at prices that won’t break the bank. Love at first bite!

Name: Les Grands Arbres - Verte Vallée
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This smart, contemporary interior is the stronghold of chef Thony Billon, who stylishly adds a new spin to regional ingredients. His flawless modern score is paired with a fine list of Alsace wines. It makes the heart sing!

Name: La Beaugravière
Description: It feels as if time has come to a standstill at this family-run inn ?and that is meant in the best possible way! Now in his 70s, chef Guy Jullien cooks up a delightful culinary offering that is sure to win over confirmed traditionalists: foie gras flan and cream of truffle soup, fattened Bresse chicken with truffles, roast rack of lamb with thyme, vanilla-raspberry ice cream vacherin?not to mention the simply irresistible truffle set menus. This is food in a classical vein that is as tasty as it is hearty, to be savoured peacefully in the shade of the trees in fine weather. The wines also hit the spot: the impressive cellar contains many treasures from the region. A real gem!

Name: L'Éden
Description: There are two styles at L'Éden: classic or a winter garden atmosphere with views onto the kitchens. The chef lovingly simmers his traditional dishes, which are spot on and hearty.

Name: Le Moulin Fouret
Address: 2 route du Moulin-Fouret, à Saint-Aubin-le-Vertueux, Bernay, 27300, France
Description: In an Instagram-perfect picture of the French countryside outside Bernay, we fell head over heels with this imposing country house smothered in Virginia Creeper and its waterside terrace shaded by birch trees, without forgetting the historic mill, whose cogwheels are still intact. This idyllic venue is even more so by the fireside in wintertime, providing the perfect foil to chef Cédric Auger’s culinary ethos: first-rate fresh ingredients, consummate craftsmanship and cooking and polished table arts. The regularly changing seasonal menus pay tribute to the chef’s homeland, Normandy. Cosy guestrooms to make the most of this rural paradise.

Name: A Mandria di Pigna
Description: This former sheepfold, a family business for 15 years, is perfectly in tune with its authentic, welcoming village. Corsican produce takes pride of place from the veg and herbs fresh from the garden to the grilled or spit roast suckling pork and tender lamb (wood fired cooking is the house specialty). Savour textbook perfect, generous fare on the refreshing shaded terrace.

Name: Bellavista
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: It is always a pleasure to return to this eatery at the foot of the ramparts of a fortified citadel, no less! The menu positively smacks of the terroir, which is not surprising as the chef uses local produce delivered by the farmers in person. Slow-roasted Catalan lamb in fresh herbs with seasonal veggies, without forgetting cheese from the Pyrenees... Cosy rooms for overnight stays.

Name: Le Chardonnay
Description: Hugues Maisonneuve is at the helm of this swish bistro. In the kitchen, a young chef rustles up a concise, seasonal à la carte menu and a particularly enticing market-fresh menu. Everything here looks as good as it tastes. Trendy vintage décor, soft lighting and a pleasant patio.

Name: Bistrot DuPont
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: By the River Seine, this affably French bistro conjures up vintage recipes served by a cheerful team: slab of foie gras, coq au vin, fillet of beef in cognac, and the house specialty, andouillette. A bustling, friendly vibe depicts this gregarious eatery with atmosphere by the bucket load.

Name: Le Cochon qui Boit
Description: Two former colleagues from MICHELIN-starred restaurant Têtedoie have joined forces here at "The Drinking Pig"! Savour tasty meat dishes (organic Aubrac beef cooked as best suits the day's cut, parsnips and leeks) and try out audacious combinations (braised Jerusalem artichokes, onion purée and coffee sabayon). The well-sourced local produce is cooked just right ?and the small batch wines are the perfect accompaniment.

Name: Brigade du Tigre
Description: The duo at the helm of Eels, both of whom trained with William Ledeuil and both of whom are passionate about Asia whose continent they’ve roamed, have now opened a second establishment to celebrate the joyful diversity of Asian cuisine in a two-storey bistro-style bolthole. The result: small fragrant nuggets, concocted from quality produce, such as a pressé of three meats, red wine and citronelle jelly or a pithiviers of black pudding and chistorra (sausage), flanked by tamarind and apricot pickles.

Name: Restaurant Dimofski
Address: 2 quartier de la Gare, Wœlfling-lès-Sarreguemines, 57200, France
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Interesting wine list,Terrace
Description: Committed and determined, Julien Dimofski’s enthusiasm can be tasted in his delicious, carefully crafted dishes (just-cooked langoustines with yuzu butter, or roasted pigeon with a parsley jus), in keeping with modern tastes. Airy, rustic interior some 12km/7mi from Sarreguemines.

Name: Saveurs de l'Abbaye
Description: A stone’s throw from the Abbaye aux Dames, now a concert venue, this stripped - back restaurant serves fresh, light, spontaneous food with a distinct preference for fine regional produce from the market, to which chef Vincent Coiquaud, basket in hand, goes daily. Plain, pleasant rooms for overnight stays.

Name: Ti-Coz
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This picture postcard stone inn offers both country appeal and a modern elegant interior, reminiscent of an English club. The chef is a fan of flavoursome, traditional cuisine that shines the spotlight on the best of Brittany’s ingredients. A former sommelier, he pairs his recipes with a fantastic 500-strong wine bin.

Name: Kalamansi
Description: Chef Frédéric Michel opened this delightful restaurant in his home town with his wife Manuella. He cooks up fresh and bold dishes, precisely cooked and with well-defined flavours, relying as much as possible on short supply chains (local fish and market gardening, Normandy beef).

Name: La Table
Address: 1 traverse de Jas, Les Ribas, Tourtour, 83690, France
Description: This charming small restaurant has a contemporary decor of paintings and designer chairs on the first floor of a stone - built house. Tasty cuisine showcasing seasonal market produce with an emphasis on vegetables.

Name: Racines by Daniel Gallacher
Description: This self-taught chef with Scottish roots can be relied on to turn out inventive and brilliant dishes that spurn conventionality; he changes his menu every week according to produce to be had at the market. Fresh and meticulous dishes, as in his sea bream marinated in a green herb infusion. The food is dependably delicious, and the restaurant, which calls to mind a modern bistro, is always full.

Name: Fidelis
Description: At their spot facing the ramparts, this professional couple are making a big splash with delicious traditional cuisine that remains true to the ingredients: salmon tartare tacos with guacamole, pico de gallo and crème fraîche; minced chicken, rice noodles, coriander, ginger, garlic and soy sauce; peanut and chocolate parfait, salted butter caramel and vanilla ice cream. A pleasant location and smiling bistro service!

Name: Spica
Address: 48 rue de la Préfecture, Dijon, 21000, France
Description: The former Café de la Préfecture is run by a young Japanese chef who worked (most notably) at La Maison des Cariatides. Think upcycled furniture, jazz music, unique menu with meticulously prepared market-fresh cuisine, and Burgundy wines at bargain prices. The pâté en croûte made in the traditional way made an impression, as did the rib eye steak with a red wine sauce and cardamom espuma: it's bold and it works!

Name: Le Malu
