Address: Rua do Doutor Sousa Rosa 23, Porto, 4150-719, Portugal
Description: Despite not being in the centre of town or on any of the main tourist routes, it is well worth heading to this peaceful, welcoming and contemporary-style restaurant. Here, Angélica Salvador, the young chef of Brazilian origin, interprets her personal vision of traditional Portuguese and international cooking through dishes that are elaborate and very well presented. Her aim is to create dishes that are different, personal and showcase innovative detail, extracting maximum benefit from the superb fish delivered to the nearby auctions in Matosinhos and Aveiro, as well as from the region’s outstanding meats.

Name: Semea by Euskalduna
Description: This restaurant has improved in every respect following its move to the banks of the Douro ?it has gained space, consolidated its culinary philosophy, and now boasts the added benefit of views of the river. The cuisine here, which includes rice dishes cooked in a wood-fired oven, is based around the grill and open fire, using local seasonal ingredients to create dishes that, although uncomplicated, are full of flavour and feature a strong focus on presentation. The restaurant’s other attractions include the delightful panoramic terrace on the first floor.

Name: Olaias
Address: Rua Abade Pedro 2, Figueira da Foz, 3080 081, Portugal
Description: This is a restaurant that provides you with an excuse to return at any time of year?and why not! The house speciality, the savoury Carolino rice (with rice grown in the Mondego valley), changes constantly with the seasons, and is cooked in a clay oven, which brings added flavour. We recommend starting with the mouthwatering and smooth Rissol da Tia Fernanda, which is absolutely delicious. Next, it has to be rice, of course (with any accompaniment ?duck, fish or oxtail ?all are excellent choices) and, to finish, the moist “pão de ló?cake with sea salt, which is truly heavenly. The restaurant is located in the Centro de Artes e Espectáculos and has a meticulous yet unpretentious decor, featuring floor to ceiling windows and fantastic views!

Name: O Pastus
Address: Avenida Marquês De Pombal 5, Paço de Arcos, 2770-066, Portugal
Description: This modest yet charming restaurant opposite the Paço de Arcos gardens is characterised by great enthusiasm, painstaking service and the hard work of young Annakaren Fuentes, who is on top of everything. The cooking here can be defined as modern Portuguese, based around respect for traditional ingredients and flavours and showcased on two tasting menus: Manifesto (4 courses) and Cabal (7 courses). Individual dishes can also be ordered à la carte style from both menus.

Name: Vila do Peixe
Address: Rua Doutor João Abel de Freitas 30-A, Câmara de Lobos, 9300-048, Portugal
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Great view,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: An ideal lunch or dinner option for visitors given its location in the upper section of the old town (opposite the municipal market) and its huge windows boasting superb views of both the bay and the ocean. If you’re looking for authentic maritime-inspired cooking and fresh fish caught the same day you won’t find a better option, as guests can choose the piece of fish they want to eat as if they were in the market; the fish is then weighed in front of you and cooked immediately on the grill. Typical dishes well worth sampling, if available, are the popular limpets and sea snails.

Name: Carnal
Description: This lively, centrally located restaurant has quickly become fashionable given that it is owned by famous chef Ljubomir Stanisic (head of the 100 Maneiras group). Carnal describes itself as a Mexican gastro-bar, and is one of those places that immediately appeals to the senses. In its informal, modern design setting featuring subtle details relating to Mexican culture, enjoy harmonious, well-thought-out cooking with a perfect balance between flavour and spiciness in every one of its superb dishes. Don’t miss the delicious pork tacos or the tacos with fried cauliflower.

Name: Flora
Description: Dishes such as spicy polenta with fennel pickle, confit cod, white trevally fish from the Azores and, to finish, the banana treacle ice cream with liquorice-flavoured rice pudding, are accompanied by a choice of "low intervention, biodynamic and organic wines" that are high on quality. This oasis of creativity can be found in a tiny contemporary bistro in Viseu’s historic centre, where it is run by João Guedes in the kitchen and Anna front of house.

Name: Rio by Paulo André
Address: Praça da República 8, Vila do Conde, 4480-715, Portugal
Description: A young and informal eatery with an open-view kitchen located at one end of Praça da República, one of Vila do Conde’s most beautiful squares thanks to its setting on the banks of the Ave river. In a nod to the name of his restaurant, chef Paulo André’s professional career is as surprising and unexpected as the meanders in a river! His cisHisontemporary-style cooking will definitely leave its mark given his passion, technical skill and a strong desire to please, plus a continual focus on using locally sourced vegetables (vegetarian dishes feature on the menu), fish and meat. If the weather’s fine, make sure you eat on the terrace.

Name: Kok Sur Mer
Description: Established in a handsome villa-cum-cottage, Jean-Philippe Furnémont’s traditional know-how is in the masterclass category, illustrated by flawlessly cooked beef fillet, exquisite noisette butter served with North Sea sole or explosively fresh tartar of seabass. Each dish bears the signature of this audacious chef. The formula menu is rich in enticing discoveries.

Name: Père et Mère
Description: Mum and dad, Ria and Frans, are food and cooking mad! Which is why they opened this welcoming, stylish bistro next - door to their son’s bakery, delicatessen and community hall. The menu features classical dishes that are fast becoming a rarity: rabbit in prunes or pig’s cheeks in Trappiste beer. Generous portions, oozing with flavour ?hearty, wholesome, country cooking at its best!

Name: Le Cabochon
Address: Boulevard Emile de Laveleye 191, Liège, 4020, Belgium
Cuisine: Modern French, Cuisine from the Marches
Description: Le Cabochon is always a safe bet for a slap-up lunch in downtown Liège. The concise selection of dishes on the set menu is flanked by daily suggestions that vary according to the seasons and market availability. Traditional textbook technique (such as mouth-wateringly tender beef cheeks and subtle homemade sauces) is married with side dishes oozing with an abundance of diverse influences. Food that hits the spot every time, to the delight of its many regulars.

Name: Le Variétés
Description: Le Variétés is steeped in the Art deco elegance of the Flagey “ocean liner?edifice, an iconic work by architect Joseph Diongre. Exotic wood dominates the sleek brasserie interior, while the terrace plunges you into the buzzy vibe of this lively district. Roast chicken is the house specialty, but the menu boasts a host of other dishes, including a patriotic line-up of Belgian family favourites: tomatoes stuffed with shrimp and vol-au-vent. All the food is down-to-earth, generous and steeped in flavour.

Name: Jeux de Goûts
Description: A warm, cosy restaurant flanked by comfortable guestrooms deep in the Luxembourg Ardennes. The scene is set for you to be pampered by Fanny and Jérôme. He adds a modern twist to recipes, rich in bona fide Gallic overtones. Organic, local and traditional ingredients take pride of place on the menu. Refreshing food that pays tribute to the region’s heritage and generosity.

Name: Monsieur V
Description: Jan Verhaert cooks what he himself likes to eat: traditional Gallic dishes with the occasional nod to Italy. His cosy neighbourhood restaurant specialises in bistro classics such as pâté en croûte and risotto with seasonal vegetables, and crispy millefeuille with vanilla-rich crème pâtissière for dessert. The flawless precision of the cooking and the chef's penchant for gutsy flavours are truly noteworthy. A champion of French culinary tradition, Monsieur Verhaert delivers exceptional food at a price that won't break the bank.

Name: Station 3
Description: In this characterful establishment, you can sample the many popular facets of Chinese food, which delicately combines gutsy sauces, exotic spices and the odd sweet-sour associations. The stars of the menu include smoked seabass paired with a subtle rice vinegar and soy sauce, together with numerous lobster dishes and a handsome vegetarian offering. A golden opportunity to taste lashings of Chinese cuisine under the best auspices.

Name: La Charcuterie
Description: The vintage charm of this former butcher's with its olde worlde tiles and wood panelling is eminently friendly. Walk past the delicatessen-cum-grocery store counter into the teeny bistro. Premium produce, wholesome, unpretentious cooking and mind-blowing flavours. Dishes to share, washed down with a glass of fine wine.

Name: Garde Manger
Description:
Picture a traditional Ardennes edifice in the Samson Valley whose interior is cosily pleasant and homely?Garde Manger (“larder?in English) inevitably brings a smile to our lips, which is largely thanks to the inspired recipes of Christophe Durand. He subtly reinterprets the authentic flavours of foie gras and juicy cuts of beef, pairing them with deftly crafted side dishes such as seaweed or an espuma of Belgian Herve cheese that add a fascinating kick to the main ingredient. All that remains is to try and solve the dilemma of choosing between the enticing à la carte and set menus?
La Marelle Café"

Name: Au gré des Saisons
Description: Welcome to the achingly scenic village of Achet in Condroz, the location of an excellent eatery, clad in characteristic Ardennes stone. Gregorio Clavello adds a subtle twist to his Italian roots, rustling up flavoursome modern dishes. Mediterranean tangs and a few judicious oriental notes perfume the food that respects seasonal availability. Balanced, authentic, delicious!

Name: Chez Chen Wépion
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Chinese restaurant on the banks of the Meuse. Exterior made from local stone, bright dining room with just a hint of an Asian feel to it, view of the river thanks to the large bay windows.

Name: Le Coin des Saveurs
Description: In this lively “corner?restaurant, Michel Norga deploys his wide-ranging talents; proof of which you can admire in the interior he helped renovate. In the kitchen, his attention to detail is unwavering, transforming each dish into a triumph of creativity and culinary skill. Head for the terrace in fine weather.

Name: Kline
Description: The brutalist concrete interior of the hip Kline restaurant is perfectly matched to the casual dining vibe. Unusual, unpretentious recipes and a few vegetarian options. Plancha-seared gherkin is paired with cream of smoked yoghurt, mustard seeds, dill, chunks of goat’s cheese and curry oil. “Locally sourced and globally inspired?(their own words) is the ethos of this zero-waste, sustainable establishment firmly in the zeitgeist.

Name: Plat préféré
Description: Are you a fan of fine Flemish fare and time-honoured bistro classics? If so, you can probably bet that your favourite dish will be on the menu here. Chef Gouwy bends over backwards to satisfy his guests and his disarmingly simple, wholesome menu is a treat for foodies: fresh fish served with risotto and beurre blanc ?what could be better? The elegant, gilded bicycle that stands next to the kitchen, the chef’s own handiwork, will convince you of his deft craftsmanship.

Name: Olijfboom
Description: Highly polished silverware, a fantastic collection of bottles and knickknacks set the quirky, antique dealer interior of Olijfboom, so you won’t be surprised to learn that the chef is a keen collector of vintage chinaware. However, his main talent is regaling us with old-school cooking. In keeping with tradition, he unfussily enhances the ingredient which he serves generously, focusing on the flavour. An impressive wine list completes this fine dining experience.

Name: Mona Lisa
Address: Rue du Colonel Tachet des Combes 19, Yvoir, 5530, Belgium
Description: A Grimaldi pizza oven immediately catches the eye as you enter this modern eatery, but, make no mistake, you are light years from your run-of-the-mill pizzeria. The Mona Lisa is helmed by two couples of Sicilian parentage, who are proud of their first-rate produce and of lovingly crafting old-fashioned Italian recipes. The pizzas are made entirely from premium ingredients, such as culaccia ham and Caseificio D’Elia mozzarella di bufala. The gutsy flavours of the ravioli explode in the mouth, underscored by a creamy burrata, while the signature chocolate dessert is deliciously balanced. We highly recommend the set menu with options.

Name: Bar Bask
Description: Gent now has a trendy tapas bar in the shape of Bar Bask. After perusing the long refrigerated counter piled high with seafood treats, you will make your way to the heat of the open fire to choose one of the many dishes to share of Basque inspiration: pinchos, spit roast turbot or a juicy slice of chistorra?A festival from the Basque country! Exciting flavours and subtle sauces, all of which at eater-friendly prices.

Name: Parc Le'h
Address: 1 rue de la Forêt, Dudelange, 3471, Luxembourg
Description: This trendy brasserie, clad in wood and other natural materials, is in perfect osmosis with the surrounding parkland. An ideal spot to enjoy mouthwatering modern cuisine prepared by the chef, who is a master in the art of seasoning and combining fine produce.

Name: l'Epicurien
Description: Sébastien Brela is a true food lover. His passion for fine ingredients is obvious as soon as you peruse the menu. Distinctive flavours play a central role, while generous sauces add a punchy twist. Unexpected associations and textures create a genuine surprise. The fixed-price menus demonstrate that it is possible to be a gourmet food lover without breaking the bank!

Name: Masu
Description: Masu is a bubbly eatery, just like Maxime and Sullivan, the colourful fresco and the cool vibes of the DJ’s soundtrack: youthful, funky and laidback! Every month, the duo of creative craftsmen concocts a new menu that keeps pace with the seasons, often drawing on their binchotan barbecue to add whoomph to inspired recipes. Examples include grilled corn on the cob with a spicy sauce and sweet-sour rings of shallots (the epitome of finger food, of course). It’s party time every day at Masu.

Name: Maïnoï
Description: Whilst refreshingly modern, Maïnoï nonetheless remains true to its traditional roots and the characteristic Thai interior creates a warm, welcoming vibe. The seasoned chef deftly crafts exuberant familiar flavours and cannot be rivalled for his way with sauces, jazzing up beef and vegetable side dishes, for example, with flair and talent. The creative menu is bold and daring and pleasant surprises await the diner. We recommend sampling the house signature dishes, marked up on the board.

Name: Bazaar
Description: A hint of Beirut, a whiff of Athens, together with a gust of Tel Aviv and Marrakech: this bustling restaurant brings together the best of the Mediterranean. Kick off your meal with a fresh cocktail and houmous or a mezze, before sharing a roast chicken. Spices and fruity flavours subtly underscore each dish. We must admit to having fallen head over heels with the grilled aubergine in tahini, candied garlic and peaches ?to die for!

Name: Nr.12 by Helsen
Description: In addition to being the most fashionable restaurant on Herentals?main square, N°12 is also the most delicious. Veteran chef Frédéric Helsen is a dab hand at rustling up dishes to share (of which we wager you will order too many, so vast is the choice!). He chooses to reinterpret culinary classics in an amusing, no-frills, highly individual manner to the delight of our tastebuds.

Name: L'Incontournable
Description: Fresh, preferably local produce is the backbone of a Bib Gourmand establishment. Now add consummate technique, be it for a classic terrine or more playful side dishes. Let’s not forget eater friendly prices. Voilà ?you have the quintessence of an exemplary Bib!

Name: Nénu
Description:
It is neither its sober contemporary décor nor its casual vibe that set Nénu apart from the many restaurants in the Avenue Louise neighbourhood, but its anh nhau concept. This Vietnamese tradition consists in sharing small and large dishes and a fine bottle of wine with friends and family. The kitchen team adds a modern twist to traditional flavours, creating a mouth-watering menu (choose at least three dishes). Spicy wontons, vegetarian red curry, grilled salmon head with sweet-sour flavours and traditional spices…Superlative Vietnamese fusion cooking?
Le Faitout"

Name: Trattoria Bazalia
Description: The Italian sibling of Hofke van Bazel is upstairs from the Michelin star establishment. Its romantic interior is perfect for a dinner for two, possibly alfresco on the patio overlooking a pretty church. Ingredients from Puglia take the limelight, but the chef also celebrates other regions of Italy. Just the ticket for an authentic vitello tonnato, ossobuco or tiramisu, prepared with Italian passion. Extensive menu (also veggie dishes).

Name: Den Duyventooren
Description: The spruce, traditional façade of this ancestral farmstead hides a vibrant modern interior. The peaceful terrace is bliss on hot summer days. The establishment has acquired a faithful cohort of regulars, attracted by the set menus and Inge Herteleer’s enticing carte. Her seasonal cooking throbs with traditional generosity and is dotted with contemporary touches. The shrimp fritters are stuffed to the brim, while a subtle champagne sauce enhances pheasant. Searingly good food!

Name: Au Tour du Vin
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: While wine may not be the only ingredient on the menu, it is clearly a prominent feature of this cheerful bustling bistro. The expert sommelier’s wine selection (excellent tips) is perfectly paired with the creative bistro fare. The chef is a dab hand at reinventing Gallic classics, without forgetting his surprising ‘light?version of pizza. Bold, spot-on cooking every time. We also recommend the next-door ice cream parlour.

Name: Le Charme de la Semois
Description: The picturesque Semois river and valley set the scene for this delightful riverside Ardennes country inn. The interior is amusingly adorned with a collection of hens, bringing the promise of bygone flavours on the menu. Fiercely traditional, the food is simple and generous and will delight lovers of authentic fare.

Name: Robertissimo
Description: Be forewarned ?once you have experienced the joyful vibe and flair of this lively establishment, you will be yearning to return again and again! The big-hearted chef skilfully and generously rustles up genuine Italian fare: immaculately cooked calf’s liver in a gutsy jus served with al dente pasta in butter. Bravissimo for this autentico banquet of Italian delicacies designed to appeal to discerning foodies!

Name: La Branche d'Olivier
Description: With its old tiled floor and leather seats, patinated woodwork, plus the peaceful terrace overlooking Kinsendaal Nature Reserve, this charming bistro is full of character. The many regulars come here to feast on classics such as foie gras maison, cod fillet in a chorizo crust with a saffron white wine sauce, and chocolate mousse for dessert. It is not without good reason that chef Demurger is hailed as a great sauce maker and rôtisseur. This Bib Gourmand restaurant is all about craftsmanship and generosity.

Name: Des Ardennes
Address: rue de la Hate 1, Corbion, 6838, Belgium
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: The Maqua family’s charming hotel has been welcoming guests in the Ardennes since 1900 and several generations continue to work in the family establishment. The peaceful rooms overlook the rolling countryside, while in the restaurant, the accent is on satisfying French favourites, albeit in keeping with today’s tastebuds. The cooking is spot on and flavoursome. Splendid wine cellar.

Name: Le Bistrot d'en Face
Address: rue de la Goffe 8, Liège, 4000, Belgium
Description: A nostalgic friendly vibe and good food are the backbone of this inviting local version of a “bouchon lyonnais? The traditional, extensive menu takes you back in time with dishes such as confit of duck and salardaise potatoes or boulets à la liégoise (meatballs) ?among the best in town! Heartwarming, no-nonsense food, served generously and prepared with respect for time-honoured recipes. Spot on every time.

Name: Au Cœur de Lacuisine
Address: rue du Fond des Naux 7, Lacuisine, 6821, Belgium
Description: The heart of Lacuisine is clearly devoted to good food. Ronny and Christel source only the best regional ingredients, assembling them with care in an effort to enhance and reveal their deepest flavours. Formulas that can be adapted according to your appetite.

Name: Enoteca
Address: rue de la Casquette 5, Liège, 4000, Belgium
Description: You will immediately feel at home at the Enoteca, which is depicted by tightly packed tables, a friendly vibe and cheerful service. Food lovers have been flocking here for over thirty years, lured by the unbeatable value for money and the text-book perfect Italian nosh. Farfalle al dente with fresh shrimp, preserved lemons and a knockout tomato sauce ?authenticity is the goal! Order the chef’s daily special with your eyes closed and don’t forget the enticing wine list.

Name: Le Moulin
Address: rue de la Lesse 61, Daverdisse, 6929, Belgium
Description: While on your getaway in the Ardennes be sure to knock on the door of this old mill. The welcome is warm, the setting cosy and the prices reasonable. The menu boasts up - to - the - minute flavours and an excellent lunch special. On the garden terrace you can hear the soothing sound of the river.

Name: Durbuy Ô
Description: This friendly restaurant (which also offers accommodation) is idyllically located to explore the picturesque small town of Durbuy. You will feel right at home here thanks to the family-run vibe and attentive care lavished by chef Timmerman on his guests. The pedigree French repertory is enhanced by local produce, such as scallops and venison. The chef treats all his ingredients with the utmost respect, further enhancing the experience with fascinating sauces and side dishes.

Name: Le Confessionnal
Description: Opposite Leffe Abbey, this nostalgic neighbourhood bolthole provides a showcase for the owner’s passion for flea markets. Red and white checked tablecloths, decorative soup tureens and silverware set the friendly scene. The traditional fare oozes with the charm of yesteryear and the regularly changing menu offers an array of hearty, traditional dishes, such as duck leg à la bourguignonne or roast shoulder of lamb with garlic confit. Hunger obliterating food free of fussy frills and a treasure trove of French wines at prices that make sense.

Name: Osteria Bolognese
Address: rue de la Paix 49, Ixelles, 1050, Belgium
Description: Giacomo’s mission is to correct the hackneyed image of ‘spag bol?and his mouth - watering tagliatelle al ragù does just that! All his ingredients are sourced direct from Emilia Romagna, ensuring an explosion of flavour in the mouth. A delightful Osteria that will introduce you to the real taste of Bologna.

Name: Cadre Culinaire
Description: In addition to hailing from Alsace, Grégory Baruthio avows a passion for pastries, as you will soon realise, and his Gugelhupf is truly second to none! Ever enthusiastic, the chef dons his apron to enhance ingredients that suit the modern palate without losing sight of high-precision cooking and traditional generosity. A welcoming establishment with eater friendly prices.

Name: Le Tournant
Description: The lively, vibrant Matongé district is home to an equally buzzy neighbourhood eatery: Le Tournant. People drop in to sample a glass of “natural?wine (trust the sommelier ?he knows his job!) and dig into unfussy, nostalgic dishes reminiscent of grandma’s cooking, together with a few more modern bistro recipes. Examples include gutsy beef cheeks braised in Orval beer or lamb in dried figs. Every dish is an authentic festival of flavour!

Name: Le Saint Boniface
Cuisine: Cuisine from South West France, Country cooking
Description: Picture tightly packed tables, red and white chequered tablecloths, a collection of biscuit tins and French songs and jazz playing in the background: the scene is set in this friendly welcoming bistro. The locals flock here to sample its specialities from the Basque Country, Lyon and Southwest France. Calf’s brain and tartare sauce, confit of duck leg, veal sweetbread and kidneys rich in regional flavours. Heart-warming authentic nosh steeped in traditional Gallic generosity!

Name: Les Potes en Toque
Description: This renovated farm cottage in the heart of a residential neighbourhood is depicted by a characteristic Belgian blend of rural chic. The menu majors in flawlessly prepared brasserie favourites, served generously.

Name: Cul de Poule
Description: A colourful, cartoon-inspired chicken adorns this small bistro, but the real draw is Arnaud Molle. This seasoned chef lets his creativity run riot in regularly changing menus with a Gallic slant. His food is flavoursome, original and ideally suited to make the most of fresh produce. His flawlessly cooked pheasant served with a creamy Fine Champagne cognac sauce is to die for! The meat, from his parent’s butchery, is first class and the prices are truly eater friendly ?what more can we say?

Name: De Vous à Nous
Address: rue de Grand Bry 42, Montigny-le-Tilleul, 6110, Belgium
Description: De Vous à Nous (From You to Us) sports a stylish interior, a peaceful, lush green landscape and eater-friendly prices. The know-how and generosity of chef François Duvivier are outstanding and he doesn’t hesitate to add a personal flourish to traditional recipes, such as croquettes of pheasant, pigeon with a gutsy sauce or Belle Hélène pear jus that will knock your socks off! A safe bet every time!

Name: Au Petit Château
Description: This endearing villa has, quite rightly, been a firm culinary fixture of Mouscron for eons and its infectiously friendly vibe is nurtured by the cheerful lady of the house. The traditional menu, which features the occasional modern tribute, always hits the spot. Carpaccio of sea bream, frog’s legs, Rossini tournedos?100% French recipes that pay tribute to the finest traditions of culinary know-how and generosity.

Name: Maza'j
Description: If you feel like exploring a new culinary horizon, why not book a table at Maza'j? Don't be misled by the bright contemporary interior, this establishment is a champion of traditional Lebanese culture and cuisine. All the dishes are laid centrally on the table for everyone to sample and the atmosphere is friendly and relaxed.

Name: Le Grand Maur
Description: An air of romantic nostalgia reigns throughout this charming small Ardennes castle. Ideally located for a spot of sight-seeing in Spa, the castle also serves a bang-up meal. The attractive range of dishes demonstrates the chef’s passion for first-class produce, which he prepares generously, flanked by polished side dishes and subtle sauces.

Name: Vilain
Description: Vilain offers a choice of 10 to 15 dishes to share, which often change weekly in line with the seasons and the suppliers and sports an irresistible vintage vibe, overflowing in good cheer and boasting a lovely garden for alfresco dining. The occasional international twist jazzes up the traditional pageant: butternut ravioles with ricotta, jus of bacon and walnuts. Sharing such delicacies can pose quite a dilemma!

Name: Onslow
Description: Onslow, a buzzy landmark in the peaceful Sint Anna district, offers casual dining and a terrace bathed in Mediterranean charm. Its international menu with a host of tasty dishes to share is extremely popular with the locals. Lieven Vynck whisks us off to Nice with a pissaladière that is a perfect balance between caramelised onions, anchovies, olives, thyme and lemon peel, unless you would rather sample the fresh, spicy, acidic tang of a mouthwatering ceviche. A feast of flavour awaits you at Onslow: “Food with Drinks, Drinks with Food?is their baseline!

Name: Au Phil des Saveurs
Description: A quick look at the pool and garden overlooking the countryside confirms the holiday vibe as soon as you set foot inside Phil Garcia’s HQ. The food features an intelligent blend of classical cooking techniques with Mediterranean influences. He offers a new spin on vitello tonnato with cod cooked on the skin, flanked by a velvety mousseline of mashed potato and leek oil. Enticing set menus and the cheerful relaxed service of the lady of the house add the final flourish to this fine dining portrait.

Name: Les 4 Saisons
Description: The charm of this Ardennes house is encapsulated by the landscaped garden, providing the perfect foil to the warm, inviting interior. Ingredients take the star role in gutsy nostalgic recipes, albeit with a scattering of refreshing creative twists. For example, the chef’s perfectly cooked veal in truffles with Asian flavours. The menu with options is a model of full-bodied generosity. Deliciously eater friendly prices!

Name: il était une fois toi et moi
Description: Looking for the perfect romantic spot? Look no further: this restaurant ticks all the boxes, starting with the name! A smart lounge interior serves as the backdrop to an exciting culinary story. The extensive menu, which offers made-to-measure options, combines traditional Gallic recipes and more contemporary offerings. The food is both inspired and suave, whilst remaining reassuringly familiar.

Name: L'épicerie Nomad
Description: Cosmopolitan par excellence, Brussels?international character is emblematic of this bustling eatery which features tightly packed tables and a slate menu that makes no distinction between starters and main courses. How about a fresh, bitter ceviche of seabass with mango and passion fruit, a Spanish zarzuela of seafood, or shakshuka - a vegetarian one-pan savoury dish? The chef’s creativity, which knows no bounds, is further enhanced by his superlative knack for marrying flavours. Pair this culinary journey with one of the carefully curated tipples to make the most of this fascinating experience.

Name: Le Sixième
Description: There is something for everyone in this modern bistro. Chef Clément draws his inspiration from top-notch ingredients, to which he adds a subtle personal spin. Asian influences, the authentic flavour of marinated beetroot, a velvety beurre blanc and the subtle smoky hints of the wood-fired Josper oven?Splendid harmonies and great value for money. A word of advice: if you would prefer a more romantic vibe, ask for a table in the second room.

Name: Magnific
Description: Lounge music in the background, trendy urban wall graffiti and the warm hospitality of Limburg: a meal at Magnific is always a treat. All the more so, as the chef cleverly juggles with French and Italian recipes, throwing in the odd Asian theme. Whether you start with cannelloni or continue with a venison steak and a cranberry sauce, you can rely on the stellar craftsmanship and full-bodied flavours to come up trumps every time! The set menu with choices is highly recommended.

Name: Bienvenue
Description: John van Leerzem is a fan of tradition and of the ingredient before all else. This institution on the main square of Maaseik does far more than showcase time-honoured classics. The chef happily subverts traditional recipes, particularly thanks to carefully devised side dishes, such as a terrine of veal cheek and tongue that he subtly contrasts with sweet-sour chutney. His stamp can also be tasted in the tournedos and stroganoff sauce that strikes a perfect balance of flavours. A feast for foodies!

Name: La Table du Boucher
Description: Luc Broutard avows a passion for top quality produce, red meat in particular, as you will immediately realise when you cross the threshold of this buzzy brasserie. Seared foie gras, tartare of Salers beef, marinated pork cheeks or grilled tenderloin: carnivores will be in seventh heaven as they drool over the extensive menu. Rich, spot-on cooking, happily free of gimmicks and there are even a few fish dishes. Everyone feels at home at the Table du Boucher, to such an extent that many return in their droves.

Name: Comptoir de l'Eau Vive
Address: place des Jardins de Baseilles 14, Erpent, 5101, Belgium
Description: Trendy and buzzy, this small eatery is the epitome of a Bib Gourmand. Whether you go for one of the classics on the à la carte menu (like meatballs in tomato sauce or rib of beef with fries) or for the more modern set menu (featuring Mediterranean ingredients such as mullet), all the food is depicted by wholesome, instantly recognisable flavours. The wine list and the sommelier’s suggestions are greatly appreciated, as is the possibility of purchasing cheese and wine, in particular, from the shop. One final word of advice: take a seat at the counter if available, you’re in for a treat!

Name: Arti'Choc
Description: The welcoming interior and Katja’s warm personality provide the perfect foil to this friendly modern stube. Chef Daniel is a fan of fine produce, such as trout and sweetbreads, that he pampers and enhances in traditional recipes. Expect rich flavours and authentic sauces rather than prissy details. You can even take a few preserves and liqueurs home.

Name: l'Amitié
Description: When you arrive in this fully renovated bistro, it won’t be friendship, but something more akin to love that you will feel. Fish takes pride of place and the first class ingredients are prepared according to modern techniques and served in small dishes. Scrumptious!

Name: Strofilia
Address: rue du Marché aux Porcs 11, Brussels, 1000, Belgium
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: Strofilia, an ever-buzzy establishment near the fish market, oozes with Greek hospitality and generosity. The appetising menu showcases cold mezze such as tzatziki and aubergine salad, hot mezze made with chicken and squid?Authentic food rich in vibrant, honest flavours that hit the spot every time. The impressive list of Greek wines is deliciously reasonably priced.

Name: Le Saint Michel
Address: rue de l'Église 17, La Roche-en-Ardenne, 6980, Belgium
Description: Quenelles of pike that melt in the mouth coated in a rich velvety lobster sauce that exalts the fish’s delicate flavour?The house speciality is often indicative of a restaurant’s mindset and philosophy and such is the case of this endearing, homespun, vintage bistro in the heart of La Roche-en-Ardenne. The menu keeps pace with the seasons at bargain prices. The chef, who knows all the ins and outs of traditional French cuisine, rustles up his own generous, gutsy version of Gallic fare here. A feast for connoisseurs of fine French nosh!

Name: L'Echappée Belle
Description: The quintessence of a Bib Gourmand, this eatery is embodied by Grégory and Camille’s warm friendly welcome. The couple has created strong ties with local producers, such as Ferme d’Artagnan and Ferme Fourchette, who have become part of the family. The chef crafts their excellent ingredients generously and creatively, underscoring the distinctive flavour of Belgian endive with braised beef cheeks, crunchy celeriac and marinated onion. Authentic Liège recipes and a fine view of the cottage garden from the terrace.

Name: Cœur de Bœuf
Address: avenue du Général Gracia 23, Profondeville, 5170, Belgium
Description: The grill gets ample use in this family-run brasserie, a genuine Bib Gourmand. Traditional meat dishes and ancient recipes such as sautéed calf’s brains are generously prepared with great delicacy and the respect for authentic whole-hearted flavours. Don’t hesitate to take the menu home ?you’re in a for a host of amusing surprises!

Name: French Kiss
Description: A pleasant restaurant renowned for its excellent grilled dishes and impressive wine list. Dining area with a low ceiling and bright paintings adding colour to the brick walls.

Name: dis-moi où ?
Description: Tell me where? Well, here! If you are looking for food that combines tradition and generosity, this upbeat eatery is the place for you (don’t forget to book). Chef Nicolas Michiels not only knows how to concoct good sauces and grill meat to perfection, he is also a dab hand at whipping up more elaborate recipes of great delicacy. He might mix a subtle quenelle of scallops and langoustine with a seafood jus, creating an exquisitely delicate balance. Choosing from the extensive menu may pose something of a conundrum. Why not try one of the excellent whiskeys suggested by the chef at the end of your meal?

Name: l'Apropos
Description: After a facelift, L’Apropos now sports a warm, bright interior with colourful artwork. Chef Fournier shares his love of world, Mediterranean, Asian and North - African food, which he skilfully mixes and prepares, demonstrating a flawless sense of balance.

Name: Tou.Gou
Description: A single glance at the wholesome country menu, featuring rustic staples such as grilled tripe and snails, pork pie and partridge with endives, will set your tastebuds tingling. The veteran chef, a true disciple of text-book Gallic fare, enjoys adding the odd international twist. Gutsy flavours, hearty helpings, culinary proficiency. A take-out delicatessen service is also available.

Name: Sel et Poivre
Address: rue de la Fontaine 3, Hollain, 7620, Belgium
Description: Welcome to Nathalie and Alexis?lovely little restaurant. Their enthusiasm is as communicative as their traditional cuisine. This is made from excellent produce and is enticing without forgetting the occasional dash of humour. A salt - and - pepper combination to which we will happily return.

Name: Borse van Amsterdam
Description: Borse is a landmark of Amsterdam, as much for its colossal architecture and historic Flemish décor as for its restaurant. With its huge terrace overlooking the Grand-Place, it has been a blue-chip value for donkey’s years. The menu focuses on generous helpings of time-honoured family favourites and you will instantly be able to taste the deft hand of a seasoned chef who knows how to enhance authentic flavours.

Name: Michel
Description: Time seems to have stood still at Michel’s. From the classical interior to the traditional, no - frills food, everything is authentic. Walloon produce and young cockerel take pride of place on the table. A treat for your taste buds.

Name: L'Ôthentique
Description: All that remains of the former farmstead are the old stone vaults, yet the land and its produce are at the centre of this establishment. Chef Collignon hunts out top-notch ingredients that he deftly crafts into appetising, primarily French classics. Don’t miss the house foie gras and its pageant of fresh, unctuous garnishes. The trout, straight from the aquarium on the terrace, is another house speciality. Authentic generosity.

Name: L'Entre D'Eux
Description: Caroline Druine combines delicacy and generosity in dishes that demonstrate her commitment to local, organic ingredients. For example, she pairs wild boar from the next-door forest with “grandma’s?red cabbage and a gutsy dark brown cocoa sauce that is so good you will be licking your fingers after mopping it up with bread! The casual vibe is further amplified by Alexandre’s natural, friendly service. A small patio in the garden planted with pear trees is ideal for alfresco summer dining.

Name: De Farmasie
Description: A good meal is just what the doctor ordered! So, book a table quickly in this fashionable establishment, quirkily adorned with a 17C pharmacy cabinet. The chef, a keen “farm to table?adept who is equally at home with rib steak and Thai curry, demonstrates an innate flair for flavours and tastes. The owner adores sharing his love of fine (Italian) wine with diners.

Name: L'Embellie
Address: rue de la Station 115, Soignies, 7060, Belgium
Description: Make your day that little bit better with a visit to this restaurant run by charming maître d' Géraldine and seasoned chef Pol. Grab a table at the front of the cosy dining space, or head to the back, where light pours in from the lovely garden ?either way, you're in for a treat! When it comes to the quality of his ingredients, the chef refuses to compromise, a pursuit of excellence that is matched by his culinary expertise. This cuisine is incredibly generous, and it shows in every dish, from the rich foie gras terrine served with succulent pheasant to the rich miso jus that lends a subtle spiciness to the sea bream. Pure passion is at play here!

Name: De Gebrande Winning
Description: This characterful farmstead with a cafe at the entrance has lost none of its authentic charm. The focus is on beer and premium produce before all else. Indeed, an annual beer festival, an awe-inspiring beer menu and knockout beer associations demonstrate the star role of brewed beverages here. Chef Sainte pairs this ethos with no-nonsense food that shines the spotlight on nostalgic Flemish recipes, albeit with subtle modern touches. Rare beef is served with fresh green peas, asparagus and a gutsy gravy: rugged, generous cooking that hits the spot every time and which never fails to bring a smile to the face of satisfied diners.

Name: Boris & Maurice
Description: It is crystal clear that Boris and Maurice have worked together before (at Bodo). Their friendly neighbourhood eatery with a long counter offers tasty bistro fare with a twist. For example, you may start with deep-fried bites of sole and tartare sauce, followed by a juicy breast of chicken and a masterful Archiduc sauce (mushrooms and cream), finishing with a chocolate mousse. The French wine list adds the final flourish to this appetising banquet.

Name: Ni Shifu
Description: The full scope of Sichuan cuisine is unveiled in this relatively unassuming restaurant, whose 10-page something menu seems endless! The talented chef plays with Chinese herbs, hot spices and a myriad of textures. The epitome of generous, Ni Shufu revolves around discovery and pleasure, without killer prices!

Name: Magma
Address: Rue Porte aux Oies 43, Liège, 4020, Belgium
Description: It is heaven to spend time in this hip, upbeat eatery. Tom Foguenne has creatively sourced a lineup of local organic produce out of which he crafts mind-blowing flavours. He might mix smoked trout and tomato with subtly spicy oils, or serve fried chickpeas with cream of yoghurt. Each dish is steeped in unusual tastes and savours, further enhanced by the knockout organic, natural wine list. Instinctive cuisine and a frequently changing menu.

Name: Furbetto
Description: Gust and Jasper have established their friendly eatery a stone’s throw from Heverlee railway station in a smart if somewhat low-key town house. Their love of cooking and devotion to simplicity shine through as you watch them wield their magic in the open-plan kitchen. Homemade is the name of the game here, underscored by a constant quest for superlative local produce. After nibbling on a delicious focaccia appetiser, dig into homemade pasta and subtle dishes, such as blue cheese pie paired with fermented raspberries. Furbetto hits the spot every time, all the more so due to its bargain prices!

Name: Bizie Lizie
Description: At Bizie Lizie you can choose from a modern brasserie dotted with vintage details or a swish, bordering on Baroque interior. However, those who find it difficult to make up their mind, may well find the amazing choice on the menu somewhat daunting! The menu that will find favour with lovers of nostalgic nosh features heart-warming brasserie fare, such as shrimp fritters, calf’s tongue in Madeira sauce or eels in sorrel.

Name: Glou Glou
Description: The distinctive sound of fine natural wine “glug glugging?into a glass is the hallmark of this friendly eatery. Let yourself be guided by the expert insights of the sommelier. The chef, for his part, showcases his personal take on contemporary tapas, mingling French, Asian and Italian influences with enthusiasm and generosity. Full-bodied soy flanks aubergine, while fresh, spicy kimchi jazzes up beef hanger steak without forgetting the irresistible lost bread. Everything is impossibly tempting –don’t forget to book!

Name: K restaurant
Description: The imposing K gives you a choice of a modern setting, a more elegant, classical room and a terrace. The fantastic range of dishes is further proof that everyone will find something to suit their palate. From classical dishes and brasserie fare to more elaborate recipes, all prepared generously and, wherever possible, at the last minute. Go on! Treat your taste buds!

Name: Bonifas
Description: Bonifas is steeped in the charm of a country inn. Welcoming staff and a warm contemporary interior. Chef Grégory enriches his French culinary score with international influences and modern techniques. The lunchtime and suggestion menus are very popular.

Name: St Kilda
Description: St Kilda is emblematic of Belgium’s capital, whose restaurants strive to please. Established on a lively street corner and depicted by a casual vintage vibe, don’t expect fussy frills. The menu is stuffed with unusual recipes such as terrine of leeks and nori with egg mimosa or a mandarin, honey and speculoos dessert, all packed with depth. Intelligent combinations, loving care and attention lavished on the veggies and bold punchy flavours set the culinary scene, explaining its success. Now add eater-friendly prices and you will quickly understand just why this eatery is so popular!

Name: Yoka Tomo
Description: A friendly restaurant in a residential neighbourhood with limited seating and a chef who crafts dishes from Southern Japan in his open-plan kitchen. Rather than decadent ingredients, you can expect authentic craftsmanship and seasonings that stimulate the tastebuds. Crispy chicken with a sweet-sour sauce is paired with crunchy vegetables and a rémoulade sauce in a tasty, almost addictive dish. Tomoyuki Ohara has no qualms about surprising us, whilst religiously respecting Japanese culinary traditions. Truly irresistible!

Name: Gaston Vouzote
Description: If you feel like a slap-up meal with all the trimmings, make a beeline for this authentic brasserie whose vintage interior is paired with a Parisian vibe. Family favourites that warm the soul, such as traditional terrine (depending on the season), steak tartare and soufflé, set the scene on the menu. Homemade, hearty cooking and a festival of flavours. Gaston Vouzoute knows how to satisfy our appetites and our senses!

Name: Mamy Louise
Description: This multipurpose new building is made entirely out of wood, glass and steel. It is home to a restaurant, cocktail bar with terrace, lounges and meeting rooms. The equally varied menu features a fine choice of brasserie fare, including tempting salads and confit of duck, all of which are at reasonable prices.

Name: Origines
Address: Rue de la Coupe 25, Mons, 7000, Belgium
Description: A narrow lane near the main square leads to this endearing restaurant whose rear patio features an olive tree in its centre. Chef Céline finds her inspiration in seasonal market ingredients, which form the backbone of her mouth-watering menu. Modern, complex-free dishes of Gallic origins, underscored by feminine delicacy and exquisite, distinctive flavours.

Name: abCd
Description: The abCd of French cuisine has no secrets for Borg Da Silva. Pairing goose liver or suckling lamb with just the right sauce and just the right crunchy vegetables is second nature to this artisan chef, whose technical prowess can also be sampled in drop dead desserts. Generosity is the watchword in this tastefully appointed restaurant.

Name: CCnomie
Description: David Coisman seeks to add his signature originality and generosity to regional produce. Rather than gimmicky combinations, he woos us with consummate skill and familiar flavours, adding a fresh twist to pheasant or steak with shallots thanks to inventive side dishes. One thing is certain: a visit to this restaurant, established in a restored 1800 barn on the family farm is synonymous with a festival of flavour.

Name: Brasserie N4
Description: Friendly restaurant with an "Ardennes" decor and a comforting fireplace hum. Classic style dishes brightened with a regional touch. Surrounded by greenery. Rooms with parquet flooring. Those in the annexe are preferable as they are a little more spacious. Family - run.

Name: JB
Address: rue du Grand Cerf 24, Brussels, 1000, Belgium
Description: This stylish, family-run establishment, which is located in a quiet street just a stone’s throw from Avenue Louise and the courthouse, has acquired a loyal crowd of regulars since it opened in 1979. The onus is on authentic classics that hit the spot every time. Asparagus à la flamande with a velvety hollandaise sauce, juicy lamb served with heapings of gratin dauphinois, and a sweet crêpe normande. Know-how, generosity and eater-friendly prices: the epitome of a Bib Gourmand.

Name: De Maurice à Olivier
Description: Amusingly, you have to walk past Maurice’s newsagents before reaching the Parisian-style bistro of his son, Olivier. Gallic tradition permeates both the service and the food. Dishes range from a delicious white pudding of poultry, served with chunks of lobster, truffles and a frothy sabayon for a masterful finishing touch. The chef may add the occasional original note, but he remains a steadfast champion of classical French fare. A well-stocked wine cellar and a splendid choice of cigars and whiskeys round off this enticing portrait.

Name: La Fermette
Description: Sarah Bohet and Michaël Vancraeynest are at the helm of this authentic farmhouse. They have captured the spirit of the building and serve food that is equally full of character. The natural beauty of the old stone walls is echoed by fine, seasonal produce. Steak and lobster are grilled on the burning log fire.

Name: Selecto
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: This bistro is thriving in the casual vibe of the buzzy, alternative Saint Catherine neighbourhood. Selecto never fails to deliver thanks to its knockout set menu. Bistronomic fare that hits the spot every time, with a dash of Mediterranean flair, such as creamy risotto with shrimps or a sun-drenched tartlet of aubergine, coppa and burratina, throbbing in no-frills, down-to-earth flavours.

Name: Les Coudes sur la Table
Description: Baudouin Galler has mastered the art of sobriety. He not only shines the spotlight on fresh ingredients from local producers, crafting intelligent recipes that focus on powerful flavours, he also enjoys tossing in the odd Mediterranean or Asian touch to jazz up the culinary regional festival. The handwritten wine list offers a fine selection of organic tipples to accompany your meal.

Name: Tero
Description: Sustainability and respect for the product come first at Tero. The vegetables, aromatic herbs and even the pigs and cows come from their farm. The chefs delicately craft clean, light, veg-centric cuisine, whose generous flavours hit the spot every time. All in a pleasing natural setting.

Name: La Cuisine de Yannick
Description: Red and white tablecloths set the warm bistro scene, reinforced by a soundtrack starring the likes of Jacques Brel and Georges Brassens and, above all, the personality of exuberant, fun-loving Joelle in the front of house. It is the perfect spot to (re)discover the importance of home-made cooking and the sheer strength of traditional flavours. The regularly renewed menu shines the spotlight on a line-up of classics ranging from beef tongue in Madeira sauce to a consummately crafted, oozing with taste kidney stew. The reasonably priced wine list is equally awesome.

Name: La Broche
Description: This cosy restaurant has been a firm fixture in town since 1998. The secret of its success resides in Eric Fieuw’s generous cooking. Traditional dishes, jazzed up with the occasional modern touch. Save room for pudding - the chef is a trained pastry cook!

Name: Ciro's
Description: The nostalgic interior, working class atmosphere and traditional Belgian fare will provide the opportunity to turn a meal at Ciro’s into a taste of Antwerp’s past. Steak and chips with six sauces and vol-au-vent deluxe are the stars of the show. Book ahead ?you won’t be disappointed!

Name: La Chapellerie
Address: chaussée de la Seigneurie 13, Petit-Rechain, 4800, Belgium
Description: Sophie’s grandparents were hatmakers (hence the name), but Sophie’s love was cooking. In a tastefully refurbished brick townhouse, she turns out comfortingly familiar dishes, oozing with elegance. Spot-on cooking, a sprinkling of creativity and punchy, powerful sauces are combined in well-balanced dishes.

Name: Nulle Part Ailleurs
Address: rue de la Gare 10, Couvin, 5660, Belgium
Description: Hospitality is the Corman family’s raison d’être. Spend a night in a pretty room, hunt out a few excellent bottles in the shop (or the restaurant) and sample fine cooking, enhanced by modern techniques. The result is remarkable and fully worthy of a Bib Gourmand!

Name: Le Clos des Récollets
Address: rue de la Prévôté 9, Durbuy, 6940, Belgium
Description: The picturesque charm of Durby is fully echoed in this delightful restaurant with a superb terrace. The cuisine, firmly anchored in classical techniques, occasionally delves into a more modern repertory. Each dish is a skilful association of flavours. Stay overnight to finish your meal in style.

Name: Ko'uzi
Description: This sleek minimalist interior draws sushi fans like bees to honey. Whether it is a classic salmon maki wrapped in a soy crepe or a more inventive sushi of smoked eel and red beetroot, Junko Kawada effortlessly combines purity of flavour with cutting-edge Japanese precision. The offer is varied and also features sashimi and salads, without forgetting a knockout range of teas to take home and sushi lessons.

Name: Schnitzel
Description: Good simple food is the ethos of this vintage-inspired bolthole which offers 5-, 6- and 7-course menus. Gert Weyn hits the nail on the head with intuitive personal inventions crafted with just a few ingredients. He has a knack for pairing the gutsy flavours of black pudding with slices of radish, sorrel leaves and herby fromage blanc, for example. Food that is refreshingly hearty, wholesome and oozing with flavour: such is the hallmark of Schnitzel.

Name: Ferme des 4 saisons
Description: A menu rich in exemplary classical dishes and first - class brasserie fare will set your taste buds tingling, an inspired, innovative chef and an authentic, jazzed up interior combining contemporary and rustic details. Franck and Cathy have breathed new life and vitality into their parents?brasserie!

Name: Le Barathym
Description: Barathym is synonymous with good food in a casual, warm vibe, whether on the terrace or in the updated rustic village cafe interior. The tasty seasonal fare is traditional, although sprinkled with modernity, often in the form of Asian or Mediterranean accents. Don’t expect fussy plating, but rather the simple joy of a tender juicy cut of meat served with a crisp salad dressed in a spicy sauce. Good country cooking that our grandmothers would have been proud to serve adapted to today’s tastebuds and ethos. All of which at unbeatable eater-friendly prices!

Name: Les Fines Gueules
Description: This bright, airy restaurant is surrounded by the gently undulating green landscapes of the Herve region. Home to an inventive chef, it offers a tempting à la carte selection, as well as a simpler set menu. The chef puts a great deal of effort into his dishes, playing with techniques and combinations without compromising on flavour and generosity.

Name: La Fermette des Pins
Description: A picturesque farmstead in the heart of the countryside whose terrace makes the most of this idyllic rural setting ?ideal to sample top-notch brasserie fare. You won’t regret booking a table here! The seasoned chef’s veal kidneys served with a velvety béarnaise sauce are out of this world. In short: the quintessence of wholesome country cooking.

Name: Terminus
Description: Don't hesitate to pull into this establishment, just before the French border. You will see the Verheyde family’s farm and the meat comes from their own cattle. The traditional, generous food uplifts the hearts of travellers. Ask the owner Pieter, an excellent sommelier, for his advice about wine.

Name: Biestro H-eat
Description: A hip bistro that never fails to appeal. Trendy lighting, a vintage wood-burning stove and a full view of the chefs consummately rustling up flavoursome fare in the open kitchen. Their boundless inspiration features Flemish classics, Asian nuances and Mediterranean flair in a scrumptious menu. The epitome of a friendly bistro ?from the décor to the plate!

Name: Amu
Description: The elegant, intimate decor of Amu sports a marriage of romantic and sexy. In her open kitchen, Marjanne Moonen rustles up genuine delicacies with just a few ingredients that are free of fancy frills, but always spot on. Her distinctive culinary signature is a patchwork of Mediterranean influences, spices and fermentation techniques. The wine list is sourced from all over the world.

Name: Le Baan Thaï
Description: A whiff of exoticism subtly contrasts with the historic character of the Patershol district in this grand old abode. The welcoming interior sports high ceilings and works of art, without forgetting the walled courtyard - exquisite in fine weather. The dishes are visually appetising and generously presented, revealing the wide range of flavours of traditional Thai cuisine. The ingredients are fresh, steeped in rich perfumes and aromas with just the right balance of spices. A blue-chip value since 1989!

Name: De Garage
Description: You will probably have guessed from the name and the industrial look that this space to be a garage. Now reimagined as a bistro, the blend of untreated materials and vintage design elements creates a unique atmosphere. The menu puts the emphasis squarely on authentic and familiar flavours, eschewing any unnecessary frills. Think braised pork cheek in a robust sauce, sole meunière with pommes frites or even vegan green curry. Sommelier Fitzgerald Rigole's recommendations are always spot on ?and his enthusiasm is infectious!

Name: ANJU
Address: Rue de la Source 73, Saint-Gilles, 1060, Belgium
Description: Sang Hoon Degeimbre reveals his Korean roots in Saint Gilles. In a hip, minimalist interior, he has recruited a kitchen team that crafts an extensive range of dishes to share, ranging from gutsy stocks and hot pots to kimchi. Dig into the decadently addictive Korean-style fried chicken with a sweet, spicy sauce. The antithesis of fussy, but with lashings of traditional generosity.

Name: Pluriel
Address: Rue de la Colline 58, Transinne, 6890, Belgium
Description: A slightly smoky aroma tickles your nostrils as soon as you reach the carpark of this former farmstead, which tastefully sports untreated materials to create a warm vibe. Loélia Gachadoat and Vadim Poncelet, steadfast champions of barbecue cooking, demonstrate their combined talents, mingling rustic flavours with a creative festival of occasionally surprising nuances. The symbiosis between these two chefs signs the characterful cuisine.

Name: Quatre Vins
Description: Put on your rose-tinted spectacles and bask in the warm, cosy interior of Quatre Vins, without forgetting the walled terrace, which is bliss come summertime. The menu features a line-up of international dishes to be shared in a friendly, buzzy vibe. How about steamed pork belly with crunchy hispi (pointed) cabbage in a rich BBQ sauce and a bread roll on the side, or steamed haddock on a bed of leeks and a light, herb-flavoured sauce? In addition to a fine range of biodynamic and natural wines, Maxinne and Olivier bend over backwards to ensure guests feel at home in their fun-loving establishment.

Name: Egg & Flour
Description: As implied by its name, Egg & Flour is an Italian restaurant specializing in fresh, handmade pasta composed only with egg and flour. Even the entrance to the establishment greets us with sacks of flour and pasta rolling machines. The space is located along a winding alley in Haebangchon, yet the Itaewon skyline seen from the terrace and through the glass wall evokes majesty. The establishment’s signature offering is freshly made Italian pasta with a Korean twist ?be it Jeju black pork ragù featuring red chili paste and fish sauce, burrata cheese, or roasted Ecklonia cava.

Name: Haemok
Address: 8 Gunam-ro 24 beon-gil, Haeundae-gu, Busan, 48094, South Korea
Description: Popular among both tourists and local regulars, Haemok offers accessible Japanese fare. Its blue fence and inexplicably exotic edifice create a vibe that makes this spot stand out in the neighborhood. Its wood-based décor and tatami floor also add to the exotic ambiance. Haemok’s menu includes a few selections of Japanese rice bowls, sashimi, tempura, and tataki dishes. But its signature item is unarguably hitsumabushi (Nagoya-style grilled eel). Coated with umami-rich sauce, the eel features bottomless flavor and is a perfect accompaniment to the rice cooked to perfection. And just so you know, Haemok also has outposts in Seoul.

Name: FAGP
Description: In a city where a plate of pasta is as ubiquitous as a bowl of kalguksu, it takes a good dose of creativity and knowledge of the genre to be recognized for one’s craft. Chef Lee Jong-hyuk is armed with both. FAGP is a casual restaurant that offers a simple yet inventive menu with a focus on the relatively humble pasta. There is a genuine sense of conviviality here, which comes as no surprise, as the chef says he revels in engaging with his customers while cooking in the open kitchen.

Name: Soi Mao
Description: Thai cuisine meets natural wine at this new location of Soi Mao. The word mao is Thai for inebriated, a nod to the restaurant's focus on natural wine. The first floor offers a simplified menu, while the second floor offers a more extensive list of dishes, intended to be enjoyed with wine. Bestsellers include the sweet and spicy grilled pork shoulder, crispy Thai spring rolls and tom yum noodles. The supremely aromatic and pungent nature of Thai cuisine and the flavor carnival of natural wines prove to be surprisingly complementary.

Name: Yukjeon Hoekwan
Description: Three generations spanning five decades have kept this restaurant in business since its opening in 1962. At the time, their iconic crispy thin-sliced bulgogi, grilled over open flames, was all that was offered on the menu. The dish became so popular that the name bassak bulgogi was patented. Today, the restaurant stands four stories high, still serving the same dish that has fed generations. Their coagulated beef blood soup with a clear broth is another stunner.

Name: Jin Jin
Address: 60 World Cup buk-ro 1-gil, Mapo-gu, Seoul, 04031, South Korea
Description: For over 40 years, Chef Wang Yuk-sung has been committed to popularizing Chinese cuisine in Korea. Unlike most generic Korean-style Chinese restaurants ubiquitous to Seoul, Chef Wang offers a limited menu of just ten dishes to ensure that the quality of the food he serves is consistently high. Some of the most requested dishes include shrimp toast, stir-fried crab meat with egg white, mapo tofu and stir-fried beef with gai lan.

Name: Hwa Hae Dang
Description: This is the first Seoul branch of the acclaimed Taean County restaurant, located on the west coast of Korea. The name of the restaurant, which translates into “Flower crab house?specializes in soy sauce marinated blue crab, prized for its sweet flesh. Each spring, when local crabs are in season, they are caught and flash frozen to be used throughout the year. The crabs are prepared in Taean and sent to Seoul. The seafood side dishes are also good.

Name: Palmito
Address: 16 Western Road, Brighton and Hove, BN3 1AE, United Kingdom
Description: The plates are small and the flavours are big at this wonderful little neighbourhood restaurant. The style of the food is described as ‘spice driven?and draws on multiple global cuisines across the selection of affordable dishes. The décor is simple and understated, but the cooking is bold and interesting, with an appropriate degree of care taken in the kitchen. Kick your evening off with a colourful cocktail, and make sure to end it with a delicious dessert.

Name: Gunton Arms
Address: Gunton Park, Thorpe Market, NR11 8TZ, United Kingdom
Description: This charming inn overlooks the 1,000 acre Gunton Estate deer park. Enjoy a tasty homemade snack over a game of pool or darts in the bar or make for a gnarled wood table by the fireplace in the flag-floored Elk Room. Dishes are fiercely seasonal; some ?such as the Aberdeen Angus steaks ?are cooked over the fire. Well-equipped bedrooms have a stylish country house feel.

Name: St. JOHN Bread and Wine
Address: 94-96 Commercial Street, Tower Hamlets, London, E1 6LZ, United Kingdom
Description: There is an appealingly stripped-back quality to both the food and the décor at this well-priced St. JOHN spin-off. The highly seasonal menu offers dishes that are perfect for sharing, and the cooking is as British, uncomplicated and hugely satisfying as you would expect ?accompanied by suitably spartan surroundings. The brand’s nose-to-tail ethos is on show too, with options like roasted bone marrow and crispy pig’s cheek. Don’t leave without trying the baked to order madeleines.

Name: The Inn at Welland
Address: Hook Bank, Welland, WR13 6LN, United Kingdom
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Take in delightful views of the Malvern Hills from the charming terrace of this country inn or, cosy up inside, in the understated New England style dining room. Well-presented modern dishes show plenty of flair and deliver punchy flavours, and there’s a wide choice of wines by the glass.

Name: The Anchor
Address: High Street, Ripley, GU23 6AE, United Kingdom
Description: Despite its name, this pub is nowhere near the water. At 400 years old, it retains an appealingly rustic feel but it also has a modern edge and a friendly, laid-back vibe. Cooking is full of flavour, with enticing snacks on offer alongside good value modern dishes of local ingredients.

Name: Imad's Syrian Kitchen
Address: 2.14-2.16 Kingly Court, Carnaby Street, Soho, London, W1B 5PW, United Kingdom
Description: A move to a slightly larger premises on the top floor of Kingly Court has not dimmed the ethos of this sweet restaurant. Affable chef-owner Imad was a restaurateur in Damascus before fleeing and settling in London, and his desire to provide and nourish is evident during your visit. The appealing, great value menu focuses on satisfying Middle Eastern flavours. Expect generous sharing dishes and plenty of lamb ?and don’t miss the falafel.

Name: The Galley
Address: 41 Fore Street, Topsham, EX3 0HU, United Kingdom
Description: Set towards the older part of a delightful town, this cosy, rustic, reinvigorated bistro comes with a cheery atmosphere and prices that won’t frighten the horses. The menu is not overly long but is balanced and appealing, and the cooking is delivered with consummate care and not without some finesse. If it’s game season, don’t miss the venison. If you aren’t a local, this place will make you wish you were one.

Name: Hoppers
Address: 49 Frith Street, Soho, London, W1D 4SG, United Kingdom
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: Street food inspired by Tamil Nadu and Sri Lanka features at this fun little spot from the Sethi family, who also own Trishna and Gymkhana. The 'hoppers' ?bowl-shaped pancakes made from fermented rice and coconut ?are ideal with a creamy kari. The ‘short eats?and the prices are great too.

Name: pahli hill
Address: 70-81 Mortimer Street, Regent’s Park and Marylebone, London, W1W 7SJ, United Kingdom
Description: This extremely colourful, comfortable restaurant in the heart of Fitzrovia is modelled on the communal living ‘building societies?of Bombay, and comes with striking posters, a relaxed ambience and an intimate basement bar. The menu is divided into ‘small?and ‘big?plates and sharing is encouraged. Dishes are confidently executed, easy to eat and full of fresh, regionally inspired flavours.

Name: Root
Address: Unit 9, Cargo 1, Gaol Ferry Steps, Wapping Wharf, City of Bristol, BS1 6WP, United Kingdom
Description: This busy, welcoming little restaurant occupies five first floor shipping containers on the old wharf. Produce from small local suppliers is used in simple yet flavour-packed small plates formed around vegetables. They have a modern, sometimes intriguing style and inventive touches.

Name: tipo
Address: 110 Hanover Street, Edinburgh, EH2 1DR, United Kingdom
Description: Named after the fine Italian '00' flour that’s used for making pasta, this relaxed and comforting restaurant could quickly become your go-to in Edinburgh’s New Town. British, Mediterranean and Italian cuisines all influence the menu, which provides plenty of flavour and value for money. The small plates selection is mightily appealing, but it's the seriously good homemade pastas like bigoli cacio e pepe that most catch the eye.

Name: The Chequers
Address: 50 Rivers Street, Bath, BA1 2QA, United Kingdom
Description: Whether it's Orkney scallops or Wiltshire pheasant, there’s always an appealingly muscular quality to the cooking at this popular pub set in a smart residential street amid elegant Georgian terraces. You can choose between elaborate dishes with international flavours and touches of originality or those of a more traditional bent. The homemade bread is always a must.

Name: Hare & Hounds
Address: Maendy Road, Aberthin, CF71 7LG, United Kingdom
Description: The chef’s passionate desire to make this 300 year old pub the most seasonal in Wales is laudable. Menus change twice daily and produce is from his 3 acre allotment and family farms ?and he also hunts and forages. The cooking is unfussy yet dishes are absolutely bursting with flavour; if you get a chance, don’t miss the buttermilk pudding. A great value 'Saver' menu is available for lunch Thursday to Saturday and early evening on Wednesday and Thursday.

Name: Pulpo Negro
Address: 28 Broad Street, New Alresford, SO24 9AQ, United Kingdom
Description: A characterful, laid-back restaurant in an old townhouse; its name translates as ‘Black Octopus? The stylish interior features exposed brick, rough floorboards and an open kitchen. The chef-owner hails from Barcelona and his tasty, authentic tapas is accompanied by a good choice of Spanish wines.

Name: Six Bells
Address: Main Street, Witham on The Hill, PE10 0JH, United Kingdom
Location: Witham on The Hill, United Kingdom
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: You’ll receive a warm welcome from the charming team at this bright, characterful village pub. It’s decorated in a personal style with framed maps and menus, and its shelves groan under the weight of cookery books. Dishes are skilfully crafted and chock-full of flavour; choose from sophisticated dishes on the main menu, tempting free-range rotisserie chicken or pizzas cooked in the wood-burning oven. Stylishly appointed bedrooms complete the package; Hayloft is the best.

Name: Ibérico World Tapas
Address: The Shire Hall, High Pavement, Nottingham, NG1 1HN, United Kingdom
Description: Hidden in the basement of the old city law courts and jail is this friendly, long-standing restaurant with a vaulted ceiling, colourful Moorish tiles and ornate fretwork. Mediterranean and Asian influenced dishes are listed under ‘snacks, charcuterie & cheese', 'tapas' and ‘desserts? with 4 dishes per person being about the right amount. The ‘express?menu represents great value.

Name: Three Oaks
Address: Austenwood Lane, Gerrards Cross, SL9 8NL, United Kingdom
Description: An appealing, well-run pub in a rural location, comprising several different areas: dine in the brighter room overlooking the terrace and pretty garden. Cooking is tasty, satisfying and seasonal, and they offer particularly good value set lunch and dinner menus. The bright young staff are eager to please.

Name: El Gato Negro
Address: 52 King Street, Manchester, M2 4LY, United Kingdom
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Interesting wine list,Wheelchair access
Description: ‘The Black Cat?is a buzzing tapas restaurant split over three levels: the ground floor is home to the bar and outdoor tables in the pedestrianised street; the first floor boasts great counter seats in front of the open kitchen; and the top floor includes a fabulous roof terrace that’s ideal for private events. The cooking is as enjoyable as the atmosphere, offering great value across the wide selection of recognisable Spanish dishes, including meats from the Josper grill. The chefs certainly know their way round a classical dessert too ?so save room for the crèma catalana.

Name: Skosh
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: This bright, lively restaurant is one of the hottest tickets in town, and it's easy to see why. Located just up the road from Micklegate Bar ?a 12C gateway to the city ?its name comes from the Japanese word meaning ‘small amount? referencing the small plates format the menu adopts.  Dishes are full of flavour, often taking influences from across Asia, like venison tataki or masala spiced cod. Around 6 or 7 dishes is about right between two, with a seat at the counter the best bet if you want to feel part of the action.

Name: Solas
Address: Unit 1, Strand Street, Dingle, V92 FEF2, Ireland
Description: With its attention-grabbing red exterior, Solas manages to catch the eye even in the brightly-painted streets of Dingle. Inside, Irish produce meets Spanish tapas thanks to chef-owner Nicky Foley’s travels in Spain. He manages to keep the range of dishes true to the Spanish originals, whilst incorporating local ingredients and adding a few subtle twists. There’s a pleasing simplicity here, which combines well with the friendly, welcoming service.

Name: Hope & Anchor
Address: Sluice Road, South Ferriby, DN18 6JQ, United Kingdom
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Don’t be put off by its location next to the cement works, as this rustic, nautically themed pub with Humber views is definitely worth the visit. Carefully prepared British dishes display touches of originality and are full of flavour, with top quality ingredients leading the way and fruit and veg from their own smallholding. Meats are aged in a glass-fronted drying cabinet and cooked in the Josper oven; some are designed for sharing and they even offer Wagyu. Bedrooms are modern and some have estuary views.

Name: Dastaan
Address: 447 Kingston Road, Ewell, KT19 0DB, United Kingdom
Description: Dastaan means ‘story?and this simple neighbourhood restaurant is the story of two friends, Sanjay and Nand. Northern India leads the great value menu; portions are generous, spicing is superb and there are many layers of flavour. Sauces are memorable, sides add to the experience and the homemade kulfi is a must.

Name: Bao
Address: 53 Lexington Street, Soho, London, W1F 9AS, United Kingdom
Description: There are some things in life worth queueing for ?and that includes the delicious buns here at this simple Taiwanese operation. It is a sweet and unpretentious place, helped along by service from a friendly young team. The classic bao and the confit pork bao are standouts, along with ‘small eats?like fried chicken with hot sauce. They operate a number of other restaurants across London, including in King's Cross and Shoreditch.

Name: BOX-E
Address: Unit 10, Cargo 1, Wapping Wharf, City of Bristol, BS1 6WP, United Kingdom
Description: Wapping Wharf is home to Cargo, a retail yard made of converted shipping containers, and on the first floor is intimate BOX-E, a compact restaurant clad in chipboard and plywood. Cooking comes from the heart and dishes are rustic, assured and flavour-packed. The panna cotta is a must!

Name: Twelve
Address: Marsh Mill, Fleetwood Road North, Thornton, FY5 4JZ, United Kingdom
Description: Dine surrounded by exposed bricks, reclaimed wood and graffiti art at this passionately run cocktail bar and restaurant set beside one of Europe’s tallest working windmills. The hearty, wholesome cooking has a refined edge and comes at great value for the quality of produce used. Dishes provide a good dose of flavour and the combinations are pleasingly complementary.

Name: The Spärrows
Address: 16 Red Bank, Green Quarter, Manchester, M4 4HF, United Kingdom
Description: Nestled under the railway arches in Manchester’s Green Quarter is this somewhat hidden restaurant where you have to ring a bell to enter. Its name is (almost) the English translation of the word ‘spätzle’?which gives some clue as to the style of food on offer here. The dumplings and assorted pasta dishes are all made in-house and include excellent pierogi. The focus on Eastern Europe carries through to the wine list, which has a leaning towards Polish wines.

Name: Bryn Williams at Porth Eirias
Address: The Promenade, Colwyn Bay, LL29 8HH, United Kingdom
Description: If you’re after a relaxed, friendly environment, this striking beachside brasserie with faux industrial styling, blue leather banquettes and stunning sea views is the place to come. The owner is proud of his Welsh roots and it shows on the menu. Cooking is pleasingly unfussy and local seafood is to the fore.

Name: Bancone
Address: 39 William IV Street, Strand and Covent Garden, London, WC2N 4DD, United Kingdom
Description: It’s all about freshly made pasta and great value at this lively Covent Garden Italian. Start off with antipasti like burrata, prosciutto or grilled artichokes, before moving on to the main event; there’s a range of pastas available, but the best of all might still be the signature ‘silk handkerchiefs?with walnut butter and confit egg yolk. Sit up at the open kitchen to watch the chefs working their magic ?‘bancone?is Italian for ‘counter?after all.

Name: Cornish Arms
Address: 15 West Street, Tavistock, PL19 8AN, United Kingdom
Description: A mix of locals and tourists, drinkers and diners, makes for a great atmosphere at this traditional high street pub. The knowledgeable team are genuinely warm and welcoming, and the appealing dishes mix classic elements with some unusual modern twists. Boldly decorated bedrooms complete the picture.

Name: Gunpowder Spitalfields
Address: 11 White's Row, Tower Hamlets, London, E1 7NF, United Kingdom
Description: A loud, buzzy restaurant with just ten tightly packed tables, serving vibrant small plates from across the Indian regions.
