Description: Meaning ‘come?in the Southern language, ‘Maadae?invites you to enjoy delightful seafood in a welcoming atmosphere. Supporting local Chumphon fishermen and sourcing seasonal organic produce, their menu rotates with fresh ingredients. The evening selection offers diverse options, including superb freshly grilled seafood paired with a spicy sauce.

Name: One Chun
Address: 48/1 Thep Krasatti Road, Talat Yai, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83000, Thailand
Description: Merging her fashion design background with a love of food, owner Khun Prang has created a big hearted dining experience with a distinct vintage feel. The 19th century building sets the scene, as do antiquities from bygone days scattered about, while the food is authentically Phuket, comprising family recipes passed down over 3 generations. Shrimp paste dip served with vegetables delightfully starts the meal.

Name: Chom Chan
Address: 242/2 Yaowarat Road, Talat Yai, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83000, Thailand
Description: Chom Chan has flourished with its own charming character and refreshing ambiance. Situated in a small white house with a leafy façade, the interior is a blend of modern Sino-Portuguese with antique decoration. Some dishes are shared with the other restaurants but do try the fried crab’s spawn with chilli, pepper and garlic; steamed minced pork with salty egg; and deep-fried pork belly with salt.

Name: Sanyod (Sathon-Bang Rak)
Address: 89 Soi Charat Wiang, Si Lom, Bang Rak, Bangkok, 10500, Thailand
Description: For over 50 years, a small alley stall has been serving up Thai-Cantonese noodles to regulars. Its modern dining room, across from the initial take-out spot, offers specialties like secret-sauce chargrilled duck and crispy shrimp balls with mustard greens in sticky sauce. The menu also features tender clay pot-braised beef.

Name: Baan Ta Ko Rai
Address: 112/941 Asian Highway (Bang Pa in-Nakorn Sawan), Khan Ham, Uthai, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, 13210, Thailand
Description: Here at this blue-roofed local favourite they prove there’s more to Ayutthaya than grilled river prawns. Ingredients are carefully selected from produce grown within the community and it uses fish from nearby rivers as the catch of the day. The herb-scented fish cakes are delectable, while stir-fried Chinese kale with deep fried salted fish is equally impressive. Portion sizes are generous, so check before ordering.

Name: Khaotom Chedi
Address: Rochana Road, Phai Ling, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, 13000, Thailand
Description: This well-known street food seller is an ideal spot for locals looking for a late-night bite. Check with the owner for the special ingredients on the day’s menu; the seafood is especially good, as the owner visits the market himself. Stir-fried dishes are a real highlight ?try the shrimps with salt and pepper, or the seasonal clams with roasted chilli.

Name: Majchapasuk
Address: 166 Mu 8, Udon-Nong Khai Road, Mu Mon, Mueang Udon Thani, Udon Thani, 41000, Thailand
Description: A string of wooden pavilions skirts a tranquil pond to form this restaurant’s massive seating capacity. Among them, every seat offers lush scenery and naturally relaxing vibes in which to enjoy the food. Building on over 40 years of experience, the restaurant showcases local fish in traditional Isan recipes. The highlight among them is the spicy fried red tilapia fish salad but whatever you order, start with the excellent deep-fried spring rolls.

Name: Tek Heng Mee Krob Jeen Lee
Address: 326-330 Soi Thoet Thai 18, Talat Phlu, Thon Buri, Bangkok, 10600, Thailand
Description: History is on the menu at this legendary Thai-Chinese restaurant. Starting out as a floating shop on Klong Bangkok Yai before moving onshore in 1907, it’s now run by 4th generation descendants of the Thai-Teochew founders. It fills three shophouses adorned with articles, awards, and photos, including some of King Rama V. He is said to have enjoyed the Mee Krob, or crispy vermicelli ?one of this place’s many classics based on 130-year-old family recipes.

Name: Thai Niyom
Address: Mahatun Plaza, 888/28-29 Phloen Chit Road, Lumphini, Pathum Wan, Bangkok, 10330, Thailand
Description: Hidden in the shadow of skyscrapers is this gem of a restaurant, which got its start serving family recipes, but now offers an array of Thai cuisine from Chiang Mai to Hat Yai. It is a great place to sample delicious Thai cooking from every region on the same table. Quality ingredients are sourced locally and turned into dishes like the recommended Phuket stir-fried pork belly with shrimp paste and the Chiang Mai Combo, a Northern Thai-style appetiser plate.

Name: Gop Phochana
Address: 58/2 Mu 7, Phet Kasem Road, Thai Mueang, Phang-Nga, 82120, Thailand
Description: Now in its second generation, this popular destination attracts locals and tourists seeking comforting favourites with intense seasoning and spices. The stir-fried shrimp with coconut curry is the delicious signature; it’s creamy, the shrimps are plump, and it boasts natural umami.

Name: Thien Duong
Address: Baan Dusit Thani, 116 Saladaeng Road, Si Lom, Bang Rak, Bangkok, 10500, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Thien Duong is a showcase of Vietnamese classical design; the antique artworks, mustard-coloured walls, rose-pink granite tables, shiny black floor tiles and exposed ceiling are an interior design lover’s paradise. The menu of Vietnamese dishes includes plenty of clean and fresh-tasting vegetables, with one eye often on health and wellness. The grilled lamb rack with mint-tamarind sauce is worth ordering, delivering a great balance of flavours.

Name: Penlaos (Pak Chong)
Address: 56 Mu 17, Thanaratch Road, Mu Si, Pak Chong, Nakhon Ratchasima, 30450, Thailand
Description: Penlaos started over a decade ago as a street stall. Today, it’s an altogether different operation offering a quality menu in a building with high ceilings surrounded by lush gardens and views of the mountains. They serve Isan food using homemade condiments ?the spicy catfish salad is a must. The Laosian style spicy mushroom soup is made with Tiliacora juice, seasonal mushrooms and gourd which adds a natural sweetness. The Thai coconut milk custard rounds off your meal nicely.

Name: Tonfon Bistro
Address: Krabi 1002 Rural Road, Bo Saen, Thap Put, Phang-Nga, 82180, Thailand
Description: Since opening its doors in 1995, the chef-owner has consistently cooked flavoursome, well presented southern fare with an emphasis on locally sourced ingredients and authentic recipes. Daily deliveries of fresh seafood and organic produce come from nearby farms. Savour dishes like stir-fried pork with shrimp paste and bitter bean or curry with crab legs and betel leaves. While the menu may be concise, each dish reflects the chef's passion. Indoor and outdoor seating is available.

Name: Phed Phed Bistro
Address: The Circle Ratchapruk, 39 Ratchaphruek Road, Bang Ramat, Taling Chan, Bangkok, 10170, Thailand
Description: Phed Phed has many branches, but this one stands out for its minimalist wire mesh theme décor. The menu offers comforting Isan favourites steeped in flavour. Don’t miss the herbal pork soup with its tender, crispy cartilage and sweet pumpkin, while the green apple som tum and salty fish sauce with dried shrimp perfectly blends sweet with sour. Large groups of locals pack the place at lunch and dinner. As they don't accept bookings, arrive early to avoid a wait.

Name: Toh-Daeng by Baan Ar-Jor
Address: GF, Baan Ar-jor, 102 Thep Kasattri Road, Mai Khao, Thalang, Phuket, 83110, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Garden or park,Wheelchair access
Description: ‘Toh-daeng?translates as ‘red dining table??and you will find one here, running the length of the kitchen wing at this renovated manor house which serves as a window into Phuket’s past. The restaurant is surrounded by farmland, where they grow ingredients including mulberry and coconut. Well-balanced dishes allow the natural flavours of the produce to shine; rambutan red curry with grilled pork neck is a highlight, with the rambutan adding a natural sweetness.

Name: Hong Seng Pochana
Address: 280 Mu 2, Chaeng Watthana Road, Pak Kret, Nonthaburi, 11120, Thailand
Description: On the Chao Praya by the Rama IV Bridge, this renowned Thai-Chinese spot has been known for reasonably priced flavoursome fare since 1957. Its open-air dining room and wooden terrace set the stage for relaxed meals featuring highlights like grilled giant river prawns with spicy sauce and mini deep-fried crab meat wrapped in tofu skin. Open for lunch, the place extends its hours on weekends. Reach it by boat, or if driving, park in the public space under the bridge.

Name: Kua Kampan Khao Yai
Address: 94-94/1 Rural Road NMA.3052, Mu 6, Mu Si, Pak Chong, Nakhon Ratchasima, 30130, Thailand
Description: The kampan (Thai for sailing ship) is an antique boat at the heart of the restaurant that has been transferred from Ayutthaya. The menu, designed by the owner, uses classic Thai recipes packed with intense flavours. The minced pork spare ribs with betel leaf is a signature dish; every meaty mouthful contains crispy cartilage in a spicy curry. Meanwhile, the red curry rice field snail with coconut milk is brought to life by the enlivening aroma of the betel leaf.

Name: Krua Suwimol
Address: 1229 9 Mittraphap Road, Nai Mueang, Mueang Nakhon Ratchasima, Nakhon Ratchasima, 30000, Thailand
Description: This simple, open-air restaurant serves Thai-Chinese fare. The food is distinctive for its simply cooking techniques yet quality dishes with extra-fresh ingredients and intense flavours. They offer a fantastic range, including several seafood and made-to-order options. Deep-fried chicken thigh with fish sauce and stir-fried spicy seafood are recommended.

Name: Indochine
Address: 170 Sappasit Road, Nai Mueang, Mueang Ubon Ratchathani, Ubon Ratchathani, 34000, Thailand
Description: The name Indochine is derived from the connection between two countries - Vietnamese family recipes have been served here for over 50 years. And family is the key to this popular business where everyone pitches in. The restaurant boasts vintage décor, using old wooden furniture and tables made from defunct sewing machines. The Vietnamese rice cake with grille pork is highly recommended, while the signature namnueng comes in a big basket with a mix of fresh local vegetables.

Name: Mook Manee
Address: 1120 Wiset Road, Rawai, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83100, Thailand
Description: Located near Rawai beach, Mook Manee stands out for its array of live seafood for diners to choose from, from squid and tiger prawns to a variety of crabs and 3kg Phuket rainbow lobster. The restaurant holds up to 300, but the best seats have views of the vibrant seafood market trading outside. The menu highlights include Tom Yum soup, Phuket lobster with spicy dip and stir-fried mantis shrimps with garlic and chilli. A wooden terrace on the beach is also available.

Name: Nong Rim Klong
Address: 51 Soi Ekkamai 23, Sukhumvit Road, Khlong Tan Nuea, Vadhana, Bangkok, 10110, Thailand
Description: This former canal-side food stall found new life as a simply decorated shophouse spread across two floors. A semi-open kitchen lets you glimpse the chefs as they work on intensely flavoured, great value dishes based on prime quality ingredients. The sea bass tom yum soup has a wonderful herby flavour and a generous portion of fish, while the rather unique crab omelette offers fresh flavours and a natural sweetness.

Name: Kin Lookdeaw
Address: 35 Mu 9, Tha Chao Sanuk, Tha Ruea, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, 13130, Thailand
Description: The name of the restaurant asks guests to ‘focus on eating?(Kin Lookdeaw) at this quaint house with an open-air pavilion above a serene pond. The chefs, veterans in the kitchen, cook simple Thai dishes and make their own chilli paste from scratch. The regular pounding of pestle in mortar reverberates through nature’s own soundtrack. Try the deep-fried boneless red tilapia with garlic and stir-fried green curry with clown featherback fish balls.

Name: Roe Dang
Address: 55/15 Mu 1, Phet Kasem Road, Lam Kaen, Thai Mueang, Phang-Nga, 82210, Thailand
Description: Roe Dang has basic furnishings with a polished cement floor, wooden tables and plastic chairs. The dishes, too, are modest looking. But locals recognise the great cooking technique and regularly pack the restaurant to enjoy fresh seafood and the nice balance of flavours. Our picks are the signature stir-fried crab meat with spring onion, and soup with sea bass, young coconut shoots and local vegetables. The wall of celebrity photos is testament to its popularity.

Name: Samlor
Address: 1076 Charoen Krung Road, Bang Rak, Bangkok, 10500, Thailand
Description: Samlor means ‘tricycle?in Thai and a traditional one hangs outside this cosy restaurant. Inside the loft-style space, chef Napol creates flavoursome, well-presented elevated Thai cuisine inspired by local street food with specially selected ingredients. They also have an à la carte menu, which includes a cut and catch of the day. Guests need to check with the chef what is available.

Name: Tune In Garden
Address: 139 Mu 3, Pong Yaeng, Mae Rim, Chiang Mai, 50180, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Cash only,Garden or park,Great view,Terrace
Description: This restaurant is owned by the late National Artist of Thailand and his wife. She cooks delicious homestyle fare drawn from a cookbook she wrote based on her mother-in-law’s recipes. First-timers are served a fixed-price menu; returners can order from the cookbook. Roasted pork ribs with cabbage and fermented pork with fermented bean curd relish stand out. Booking is required.

Name: Maan Muang
Address: 165/7 Soi Ramkhamhaeng 112 Ramkhamhaeng Road, Saphan Sung, Bangkok, 10240, Thailand
Description: This lovely wooden Lanna house with rustic charm will magically whisk you off to Chiang Mai. The dining area under the raised house is decorated with traditional Thai wooden furniture and earthenware. The staff too are dressed in Northern Thai fashions and speak in a regional dialect. But it’s the dizzying array of dishes and beautiful blend of northern ingredients that tops it off. The Thai curry soup with pork ribs and jackfruit hits the spot.

Name: Hok Kee Lao
Address: 19 Senarat Road, Bang Nai Si, Takua Pa, Phang-Nga, 82110, Thailand
Description: This heritage restaurant, with over 40 years in the business and now in its third family generation, blends Thai, Chinese, and southern flavours. Their tamarind paste sour soup with sea bass and coconut shoots is a highlight, featuring sweet, firm fish that melds with the spicy sourness. The menu also includes Chinese favourites like steamed chicken paired with morning glory. The chicken stays moist and flavourful, complemented by a seasoned soy sauce, while the morning glory adds crunch and colour to the dish.

Name: Krua Khun Nid
Address: 64 Soi Nonnivet 1, Udon Dussadi Road, Mak Khaeng, Mueang Udon Thani, Udon Thani, 41000, Thailand
Description: This spacious Isan restaurant has been a mainstay of local family dining for over 40 years. Known for fresh ingredients and sharing portions of both seasonal dishes and enduring classics, highlights include deep-fried salted carp and Lab Pa Tong, or fish cakes grilled in banana leaves. For more recommendations, the friendly staff are happy to make suggestions. Drinks are available from the café in front and homemade items like chilli paste are sold in the shop.

Name: Prik-Yuak
Address: 108 Pradiphat Road, Phaya Thai, Bangkok, 10400, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Cash only,Garden or park
Description: Prik-Yuak has flourished for 30 years, starting in the bustling Chatuchak markets and now stationed in a spacious, inviting location. The restaurant maintains its beloved approach to home-style Thai cooking. Signature dishes like the Southern Thai pork belly and egg stew showcase tender meat, boiled eggs, and tofu. The venue charms with light, earth-toned decor, a serene garden, and includes a café and boutique shop to enhance the dining experience.

Name: Mor Mu Dong
Address: 9/4 Mu 3 Soi Pa Lai, Chao Fa Road, Chalong, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83130, Thailand
Description: Mor Mu Dong takes its name from its owner, Mor, and the Mu Dong Canal, where it is located. Nestled in a mangrove forest, it is housed in a set of rustic pavilions where diners can enjoy seafood and take in the views that change with the tide. In the open kitchen, tanks of live seafood affirm the freshness of the food. The signature dish ?Pla Tu Yat Sai, or spicy stuffed fish ?and the stir-fried squid with lime are both highly recommended.

Name: Meena Rice Based Cuisine
Address: 13/5 Mu 2, San Klang, San Kamphaeng, Chiang Mai, 50130, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Don’t be alarmed when you pass through a rice field driving here, as this hidden gem is worth it. As its name suggests, this alfresco restaurant specialises in rice, alongside new spins on Thai classics. Most are garnished with fruits and edible flowers, giving them bursts of colour. Along with the five-colour rice balls, northern-style spicy minced fish salad is a delight. Vegans will enjoy their many options, including the spicy stir-fried eryngii mushrooms.

Name: Krua Chao Baan Samui
Description: Krua Chao Baan means local kitchen, which aptly describes the vibe of this eatery specialised in Southern Thai food. The signature omelette is simple: crispy, not oily, with mixed seafood and well-seasoned minced pork. The stir-fried squid with pineapple, a local recipe only found on the island, is depicted by joyful sweet, sour and peppery notes.

Name: Phunisa
Address: 11/1 Mu 1, Khao Hua Khwai, Phunphin, Surat Thani, 84130, Thailand
Description: Standing atop a picturesque hill, the restaurant commands splendid views of the Tapi River winding through a green landscape of palm tree plantations and mountains. They serve tasty Southern Thai fare, including salted duck egg and local river prawns. A spicy seafood sauce and chargrill aroma add depth and complexity to the natural umami of prawns, while a spicy Southern Thai curry soup with pork cartilage features intense peppery and spicy flavours.

Name: Saiyud and Doctor Sai Kitchen
Address: 32 Chotana Road Soi 12, Pa Tan, Mueang Chiang Mai, Chiang Mai, 50300, Thailand
Description: Since 2004, Doctor Sai has been serving pan-Thai dishes, including royal fare, following recipes from her mother, Saiyud, a former cooking instructor, in a setting reminiscent of dining at home. Start with an elegant appetiser like fried prawns and peanuts in an egg net, flower dumplings, or deep-fried pork wrapped in egg noodles. By dessert ?try the sweet potato in syrup ?you’ll guess this home, with its warm service, belongs to a royal from a bygone era.

Name: Here Hai
Address: 112/1 Soi Sukhumvit 63, Khlong Tan Nuea, Vadhana, Bangkok, 10110, Thailand
Description: Good value, high quality seafood sent directly from Surat Thani is the draw here. Its prices may be considered high for street food, but portions are large and ingredients superb. Go for the fried rice with crabmeat and fried mantis with crispy garlic, both cooked with traditional technique and offer pleasant smoky aroma.

Name: Ruean Panya
Address: 1300/600 Soi Ekkachai 13, Norarat Uthit Road, Maha Chai, Mueang Samut Sakhon, Samut Sakhon, 74000, Thailand
Description: Open since 1995, this family-run restaurant ?which blends food and art ?is a hidden gem. Spread across four houses, it has a relaxed vibe that gives the impression of dining at a friend's, while painting-filled interiors add a gallery feel. Owner Prunhnee does all the cooking herself; her attention to detail and the complexity of flavours make her dishes memorable. Local seafood is a feature, and their signature mud crab coconut dip or ‘Lhon Pu?is a must-have.

Name: Chuan Chim
Address: 37/3 Montri Road, Talat Yai, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83000, Thailand
Description: At one of the oldest food shops in Phuket, now run by the second generation, all the seafood is fresh and everything is prepared à la minute. The results, including the stir-fried noodles and the stir-fried seafood with curry powder, are impressive and worth the wait.

Name: S.B.L.
Address: 710-714 Maha Chai Road, Wang Burapha Phirom, Phra Nakhon, Bangkok, 10200, Thailand
Description: Open since 1954, this Chinese restaurant is currently run by a second-generation family member who is keen to make every aspect of the dining experience pleasurable. The menu features mostly traditional Chinese fare with a few creations that show novel twists. The X.O. scallops are a must-try, as is the expertly-steamed snow fish with soya sauce. Quality ingredients handled with skill and experience is the formula that guarantees a good meal here.

Name: Baan Benjarong Pai (The Crystal SB Ratchapruek)
Address: 2F, The Crystal SB Ratchaphruek, 555/9 Mu 1, Ratchapruek Road, Maha Sawat, Bang Kruai, Nonthaburi, 11130, Thailand
Description: The original Baan Benjarong, in northern town Pai, was set up to champion the region’s cuisine. This Nonthaburi branch opened in 2017. The typically friendly staff all hail from the north and deliver the best of Pai as well as central Thailand dishes. Served in a quintessentially northern sweet and sour soup, the snake head fish is fried to a crispy golden-brown; the caramelised sauce on the baked pork spareribs melds dreamily with salted fish and herbs.

Name: Surf & Turf by Soul Kitchen
Address: 115 Phangnga Road, Talat Yai, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83000, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: The menu changes every month in this intriguing restaurant. Regular options range from home-made pastas to a signature seafood dish, plus specials that are cleverly curated to showcase Chef Tom's latest culinary creations. The chef artfully prepares his dishes, blending quality ingredients to tantalise the taste buds. And thanks to the ever-changing selection of handpicked wines, there's always something different to sip with your meal.

Name: Nai Muang
Address: 33/4 Mu 6, Soi Loma, Khuekkhak, Takua Pa, Phang-Nga, 82190, Thailand
Description: The nostalgic bric-a-brac, old tin mining memorabilia, record players and sewing machines exude a quaint retro charm. It’s all about the seafood here, guaranteed to be fresh, vibrant and big on flavour. Order the crab curry with rice noodles, or stir-fried shrimps with stink beans and shrimp paste. Another popular southern Thai dish is the signature spicy salad, served with crispy prawns, squid and taro, with diced lime and fried chilli for extra pep.

Name: Somchai Go Tae (Bang Len)
Address: 18/13 Mu 1, Bang Phasi, Bang Len, Nakhon Pathom, 73130, Thailand
Description: Go Tae, the owner of this Thai-Chinese restaurant, got his start almost 80 years ago selling stewed duck noodle soup on a boat, before heading to dry land to open this place. Inside the three-storey building (topped with a giant rooftop duck statue), the simple dining room has high ceilings and a roasting and stewing station. The menu features old-school Thai-Chinese fare, including the recommended stewed duck and spicy climbing perch with Chu Chee curry.

Name: Plu
Address: 3 Soi Phra Phinit, Suan Phlu Road, Thung Maha Mek, Sathon, Bangkok, 10120, Thailand
Description: The Water Library’s Plu offers outstanding food, a cosy ambience, and great service in an Art Deco-adorned colonial house. Among the beautifully presented authentic pan-Thailand dishes is the signature braised pork belly and soft-boiled eggs in five-spiced soup; the pork belly is tender and juicy, the deep-fried tofu absorbs the aromatic broth, and the soft-boiled eggs only enhance the flavour and texture. Start with one of the restaurant’s signature cocktails.

Name: Mekin Farm
Address: 114 Mu 7, Ban Khok Klang, Chorakhe, Nong Ruea, Khon Kaen, 40240, Thailand
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Cash only,Garden or park,Great view
Description: Farm and table sit side-by-side at this Isan restaurant on an organic farm 30 minutes from Khon Kaen. Owner Pu-Jongrak grows fruits and veggies and raises ducks and chickens. She then applies simple cooking techniques to bring out their natural flavours in dishes like her duck egg omelette and locally sourced steamed Nile tilapia fish served with a spicy sauce. Meals are taken in an open-air pavilion or under trees. The farm also offers workshops and a farm-stay.

Name: Chai Phochana
Address: 4 Soi Samakkhi 38, Samakkhi Road, Tha Sai, Mueang Nonthaburi, Nonthaburi, 11000, Thailand
Description: Fuss-free food, live seafood in tanks cooked to order and a speedy service have earned Chai Phochana its loyal following. The stir-fried squid comes with a rich, creamy salted egg yolk and spring onions. The spicy sour soup with giant catfish roes and vegetables is also tasty. Open till late, for night owls with a hunger pang, this is the place for you.

Name: Lay Lao (Ari)
Address: 65 Soi Phahon Yothin 7, Phahon Yothin Road, Sam Sen Nai, Phaya Thai, Bangkok, 10400, Thailand
Description: Som Tam comes to the beach at this cosy Ari restaurant, where north-eastern style dishes are topped with the freshest seafood. Opened in 2014 by a family from Hua Hin, the place’s owners delight in offering guests the same food they serve family and friends. The result is fare that balances Isan flavours with seafood from Hua-Hin and Petchaburi, and beef from a notable farm. Fried squid with lay lao sauce is a standout, as is Luang Phra Bang green papaya salad.

Name: Krua Lawng Khao
Address: 18 Mu 2, Soi Sukhaphiban Mae Rim, Ban Duang Di 1, Rim Tai, Mae Rim, Chiang Mai, 50180, Thailand
Description: Food and atmosphere are well-matched at this chill Northern Thai restaurant in Mae Rim. It’s in a two-storey wooden pavilion with regular tables downstairs and cushioned floor seating upstairs; both options offer relaxing rice field views and refreshing breezes. The food here is equally fresh, as well as flavourful and easy on the wallet; the Northern Thai spicy pork salad and the Northern Thai hot and spicy soup with fish and morning glory are recommended.

Name: Gorjan
Address: 161 Kra Road, Talat Yai, Mueang Phuket, Phuket, 83000, Thailand
Description: This simple restaurant, in a family home, serves some local dishes that can’t be found anywhere else. Specials are written on a whiteboard up front. Select from the fish of the day or choose the delicious steamed yellow curry with crab meat and an intense turmeric aroma and flavour.

Name: Baannai
Address: 102/13 Soi Kamphaeng Phet 5, Set Siri Road, Sam Sen Nai, Phaya Thai, Bangkok, 10400, Thailand
Description: Baan Nai, or ‘inner house?in Thai, is so called because the owner’s great grandfather built it on the innermost part of his land. The house, and recipes cooked by its occupants, have passed down through the family to the present day where, as a boutique hotel and homely restaurant, it serves delicious time-tested dishes like Taengmo Pla Haeng (watermelon with dried fish flakes) and Khanom Phra Phai (sweet mung bean dumplings). Booking is required.

Name: Mon Phochana
Address: 46/11-12 Mu 1, Phet Kasem Road, Lam Kaen, Thai Mueang, Phang-Nga, 82210, Thailand
Description: Established for over 35 years, the restaurant has fostered a close connection with local fishermen, ensuring the delivery of a diverse selection of fresh seafood. The open-air main dining area exudes the charm of an old Thai-Chinese eatery. Popular among divers returning from Mu Ko Similan, the intense flavours authentically represent local cuisine, with generously sized dishes. Standouts include the stir-fried crab with lime and the southern curry featuring river snails and wild betel leaves.

Name: Ruanthai Kungpao
Address: 1/2 Mu 4, Soi Thetsaban 10, Ratchakhram, Bang Sai, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, 13290, Thailand
Description: This riverside restaurant is a great place to stop for lunch after paying respects at Wat Choeng Len. Diners gather here for some of the finest fresh produce from the river, including grilled prawns and deep-fried sheatfish. The aromatic green curry with clown featherback fish balls is another highlight. Advance ordering of the huge river prawns ?expertly cooked over charcoal ?is highly recommended, as they are both popular and in limited supply.

Name: Jeh O
Address: 113 Soi Charat Mueang, Rong Mueang, Pathum Wan, Bangkok, 10330, Thailand
Description: Jeh O might be known for her Mama Noodles Tom Yum, but her menu contains numerous other top-notch dishes. Many, including her delicious fried tofu with crispy garlic, boiled rice with duck, and signature crispy pork, are popular Thai favourites. Though the staff only speaks Thai, there’s an English picture menu for non-Thai speakers. Outside the shop, an eager crowd waits up to two hours for tables; to get in faster, arrive just before opening or near closing.

Name: Busarin Cuisine
Address: 133 Rattanakosin Road, Chang Moi, Mueang Chiang Mai, Chiang Mai, 50300, Thailand
Description: Busarin, the new sister restaurant of Magnolia Café, has high ceilings, a collection of chinaware and leather green sofa booths that contrast with the light pink walls. When you dine here, it’s like being welcomed into Chef Noi’s home. They serve northern-Thai based on family recipes with noodles and roti instead of rice. The standout is a streaky pork that’s braised in a hung lay curry for two days and emits a powerful aroma of ginger and spices.

Name: Pae Pochana
Address: 80/1 Rahaeng Market, Rahaeng, Lat Lum Kaeo, Pathum Thani, 12140, Thailand
Description: This hidden eatery in the 100-year-old Rahaeng Market has been serving traditional Thai-Chinese dishes for over 50 years. With a focus on quality ingredients from the market, their homemade dishes like minced featherback fish and pork in tofu sheets are recommended. Arrive early for spicy stir-fried featherback fish and fried sun-dried snakehead fish.

Name: O Pochana
Address: 252/21 Soi Wilai Sena, Prasoet Som Road, Sena, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, 13110, Thailand
Description: This rickety but charming little wooden house that backs onto the River Noi is the perfect local pitstop. Their Thai menu is prepared in an open kitchen with a charcoal stove, mostly comprising local fish and river prawns, caught just behind the restaurant ?as fresh as it can be. The wok produces a wonderful charcoal flavour in the stir-fried salt and pepper river prawns. Meanwhile, the deep-fried sheatfish with sweet fish sauce is succulent, with a crispy texture.

Name: Agave
Address: 153 Phalorangrit Road, Nai Mueang, Mueang Ubon Ratchathani, Ubon Ratchathani, 34000, Thailand
Description: The owner, an agave plant enthusiast, has adorned this cosy space with agave plants throughout. Vietnamese home cooking, enhanced with local Isan spices, fills the air, accompanied by instrumental music in the high-ceilinged room. All ingredients are homemade, offering a choice of pork or fish sausage for the namneung. Don't miss the standout sticky rice waffle served with sun-dried pork, infused with local Isan flavours.

Name: Baan Ton Sai
Address: 189 Pratu Chai, Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya, 13000, Thailand
Description: Named after the banyan tree (ton sai) in the backyard, this local favourite offers tasty Thai-Chinese food at wallet-friendly prices. The chef uses fresh, quality ingredients to create dishes infused with herbs and spices. Tom yum with catfish and crispy pork with salt and chilli are standouts. Choose from two dining areas ?one inside the traditional Thai house and the other under the open-air pavilion ?and arrive early if you haven’t booked as it can get busy.

Name: Kor Chun Huad
Address: Soi Somdet Phrachao Taksin 34 (Kobo), Bukkhalo, Thon Buri, Bangkok, 10600, Thailand
Description: For more than five decades, Koa Chun Huad, with its simple interior, has been attracting throngs of locals. Named after the chef-owner who has worked in many a kitchen in Chinatown, it serves classic Thai-Chinese dishes at appealingly low prices. Each one impresses but the highlights are the boiled pork slices, perfectly complemented by a soybean sauce, and the intense stewed pork with sweet-salty five spice gravy.

Name: Chang-Wang-Imm
Address: 44 Mu 4, Soi Wat Bang Chak, Bang Tanai, Pak Kret, Nonthaburi, 11120, Thailand
Description: Down by the banks of the Chao Phraya, enjoy affordable yet tasty Thai cuisine with relaxing river views from a charming 1950s house. Everything here is vintage, from the old-fashioned décor to the classic cooking techniques and flavours. The traditional Thai curry with pork, shrimp paste and basil is highly recommended. Book table #52 for remarkable private views from the upper deck. Live music adds to the ambience at the weekend.

Name: Arunee Namnueng
Address: 36/8 Panprao Road, Mak Khaeng, Mueang Udon Thani, Udon Thani, 41000, Thailand
Description: Established in 1988, this simple Vietnamese eatery is operated by the founder's descendants. It keeps attracting locals with its bright interior and classic recipes. Noteworthy is the Pizza Vietnam, with a rice cracker foundation and an omelette topping, complemented by home-crafted sweet and sour sauce and fresh veggies to enhance the flavours.

Name: Kao.Piak.Sen
Address: 20/20 Si Suk Road, Mueang Udon Thani, Udon Thani, 41000, Thailand
Description: Formerly a street food stall, the owners have upped the quality of the menu and the dining experience. Kao Piak’s stylish restaurant seamlessly blends timeless and contemporary styles, drawing inspiration from Vietnam’s architectural heritage. Their signature aromatic pork broth is simmered for 8 hours yielding exquisitely tender meat. Don't miss out on the grilled lemongrass-marinated pork kebabs and Vietnamese sausage.

Name: ťazal
Address: Al Qana Marina South, Al Maqta' Street, Abu Dhabi
Description: It may be quite hard to pigeon-hole the style of cooking here as it’s an infusion of European influences and Arabic touches, but the results can be exhilarating. Dishes such as tanja short ribs and zaatar sea bream are as delicious as they are original; the crème brûlée kufana is another example. The modern room has an urban feel and the service is delightful. They do a very good weekend breakfast and coffee is also a passion of theirs.

Name: Al Mrzab
Description: The bright neon sign is the first thing you notice about Al Mrzab; the second thing is the sheer number of diners who flock here, so expect to wait for a table ?but the team cope well with such a busy restaurant. Photos of old Abu Dhabi line the walls, while seating is split between private cabins, majlis and conventional tables. The traditional Emirati and Kuwaiti dishes are packed with flavour, use quality ingredients and offer good value for money. Be sure to finish with the hot, golden, cooked-to-order khanfaroush drizzled with local honey.

Name: Beirut Sur Mer
Address: Lilac 5, Jacques Chirac Street, Saadiyat Cultural District, Soul Beach, Al Saadiyat Island, Abu Dhabi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The name says it all ?this is about enjoying Lebanese food by the sea. Managed by MBT and with an experienced team occupying the open kitchen, you can expect all the classics, from mezze to mashawi; and don’t skip the desserts as they’re good too. Portions are generous and prices are reasonable. The large, colourful and contemporary dining room also boasts a beautiful beachfront terrace. An ideal spot for post-cultural refuelling after visiting the nearby Louvre Abu Dhabi.

Name: Otoro
Address: Al Qana Marina South, Al Maqta' Street, Abu Dhabi
Description: Al Qana Marina witnessed many a restaurant opening in 2022 ?and that included this contemporary Japanese spot, with a great terrace. The experienced chef, under the aegis of consultant-chef Akmal Anuar, has a diligent team supporting him. Signature dishes include yellowtail carpaccio, tuna tartare with yuzu dressing, Wagyu striploin with magnolia leaf and truffle jus and, of course, the titular otoro nigiri. The relaxed space has a funky feel and is dominated by a large open kitchen.

Name: Almayass
Address: Galleria Mall Level 1, Al Maryah Island, Abu Dhabi
Description: Almayass is where Lebanese and Armenian cuisine meet influences from around the Mediterranean. The original was founded in Beirut in 1996 and this large Abu Dhabi branch, where the circular booths are the prized seats, continues the tradition of offering an extensive and appealing menu of richly flavoured and carefully prepared dishes. Try the Kibbeh karaz, a wonderful marriage of lamb and cherries.

Name: Oii
Address: Al Qana Marina South, Al Maqta?Street, Abu Dhabi
Description: Meaning ‘hi?in Portuguese, Oii is located in Al Qana Marina, next to The National Aquarium. There's a Mediterranean influence on the cooking, so expect colourful, flavoursome and rewarding dishes that’ll make you feel generally good about life. Beef cheek Milanese with saffron risotto is sure to hit the spot, as will the lobster piccata and the smoked chicken souvlaki. The warm, sweet service team make the whole experience even more enjoyable.

Name: Tensuke
Description: The lines that form outside Tensuke at lunchtime are a part of the Koenji landscape. Inside, one voice after another calls for the ‘Egg Lunch? Accompanying the speciality of deep-fried egg on rice, tempura items are fried in a set order. Another speciality is the performance of the chef, who tosses the eggshells in the air in poses worthy of a kabuki actor. The idea is to make the waiting time fun, too. Deep-fried eggs fill mouths with yolk and smiles.

Name: Matsunozushi
Description: Shiinamachi is a district indelibly associated with Tokiwaso, the communal home of many now-famous manga artists. Matsunozushi is a classic neighbourhood sushi shop, in true Edo style. White fish is marinated in kombu kelp, silver-skinned fish in vinegar; Tiger prawn is meshed with oboro (fish floss); kanpyo (dried gourd strips) is simmered to a salty sweetness. Old-school craftsmanship, the pride the cooks take in their work, and the authentic atmosphere all add flavours of their own.

Name: Hashimoto
Description: The aroma of kabayaki drifts as far as the north end of the Ishikiri Bridge over the Kanda River. The restaurant opened in 1835 and has been run by the same family ever since. Sixth-generation owner-chef Shinji Hashimoto handles the unagi. The unagi he uses is at least a year old, ensuring, he says, the best texture and flavour; he grills it plain and steams it according to Edo tradition. The recipe for the sauce has been passed down from the time of the founder.

Name: Bistro topology
Description: The signature dishes are hams and sausages, must-have items for any French dinner table. The charcuterie listed on the blackboard provides a snapshot of the chef’s devotion to his craft. The list runs to 20 or more items at any time, including Grandma’s Paté and Jambon Blanc. ‘Museau?(snout) is ham made from pork head wrapped in pork cheek and tongue. Home-cooking items such as andouillette and cassoulet also await. This is carnivore heaven.

Name: Tonkatsu Enraku
Description: The veteran owner-chef has devoted his life to tonkatsu pork cutlets. As he fries pork loin and tenderloin, he concentrates on the changing colour of the coatings and the hiss of oil in the copper pot. Cabbage is chopped by hand as the pork sizzles. Deft, precise movements calculated with the final result in mind fill guests with anticipation. This is craftsmanship learned the old-fashioned way, through patient repetition of the master’s lessons. Bookings are accepted for weekday evenings.

Name: L'AS
Description: The restaurant’s name is French for ‘the ace? as in ‘ace of the culinary world? Reading the trends of the modern era, Daisuke Kaneko strives to offer delicious fare at reasonable prices. The menu offers only a single choice for each course, expressed in a simple, modern style. Crispy foie gras sandwiches are Chef Kaneko’s signature dish. Distinctive touches abound, such as vichyssoise with rillettes of ayu on top, served in summer ?a reason why it’s so busy, and why so many leave satisfied.

Name: Lien
Description: The prix fixe menu dazzles with its range of choices. The chef sources his ingredients from regions with which he is personally connected, mainly from his native Aomori, but also game from Hokkaido. Culinary approaches are varied: terrines, stews and items baked in pie crust are all in the mix. The number of dishes can be increased according to preference. Lien means ‘connection? a reference to the bonds between guests and producers that are deepened through cooking.

Name: Teuchisoba Narutomi
Description: Simple pleasures are best, and shuko in season with soba is one of them. Tempura is almost too beautiful for a soba restaurant—no wonder so many customers order it. As befits a soba restaurant, however, ‘Tennuki? tempura without the noodles, a favourite of true Tokyo-ites, is also on offer. Some wait longingly for the arrival of seasonal dishes like soba with pepper flowers, eggplant soba or burdock soba. The serving vessels represent the tasteful discretion of the owner-chef.

Name: BISTRO GLOUTON
Description: The effect owner-chef Koji Kobuke aims for is a bistro with strong local roots. He runs the restaurant with his wife, and together they foster a welcoming atmosphere. All offerings are à la carte and traditional fare such as pâté de campagne and confit of duck leg are mainstays, while popular Western-influenced dishes, like hamburger steak and creamy crab croquette, are available as well. Small portions are a boon, as you can try a variety of items without overeating.

Name: Teuchisoba Kikutani Sugamo Honten
Description: A ball of cedar sprigs hung from the eaves and water basins by the door steep the shop in the ambience of Sugamojizo-dori. Owner-chef Osamu Kikutani regales customers with the joys of Edo-style soba culture. Duck and leek, cheese marinated in kaeshi seasoning, tennuki and a wide variety of shuko and sake greet the customer. The soba, kneaded in different amounts of filler according to where it comes from, makes a fine companion for a dipping sauce rich with katsuo-bushi aroma.

Name: Tonkatsuya Sato
Description: The owner-chef was born the son of a tonkatsu shop-owner. His preferences in pork are for tender meat and sweet fat. Seeking texture and fragrance, he batters his pork in coarse breadcrumbs. The generous heaps of cabbage are fresh and vibrant, while the plain black crockery frames the tonkatsu majestically. Chicken-katsu is also available. Enjoy with salt, soy sauce or Worcestershire sauce.

Name: Chugokusai Zen Raku Bou
Description: Owner-chef Hanzawa puts great store by the phrase ‘a balanced diet for a healthy body? Insisting on fresh vegetables, he goes easy on fats and oils. Stir-fried shrimp with daylily buds and black-vinegar pork with root veggies are typical examples. The shop’s signature dish is li mian noodles, with a colour scheme that positively radiates good health. Chlorella, a health food, is kneaded into the noodles, which are combined with green onions and pickled mustard-plant stem for a healthy meal.

Name: HARU CHAN Ramen
Address: 1F, Shimbashi Ekimae Ichigokan, 2-20-15 Shimbashi, Minato-ku, Tokyo, 105-0004, Japan
Description: In Shimbashi Ekimae Building, known as an oasis in the business district, you’ll find the earnest figure of Haru-chan, the female chef. Pop art adorns the walls and billboards symbolise the shop. The ramen is served in a dashi of pork bones and dried sardines and flavoured with salt and lard; the flat noodles have a plump, full texture. A bowl of piping-hot ramen fills the stomach and lends strength for a day’s work.

Name: Katchar Batchar
Description: As you might expect from a restaurant whose name means ‘hodgepodge? they mix various elements together with those of Indian tradition. Using Sichuan pepper, Thai fish sauce and adding soy sauce or miso as the secret ingredient is very much the approach of a Japanese chef. The chicken achari curry features two original elements in the form of chicken dashi and green chili pickles. We recommend pairing the Northern Indian butter chicken curry with cheese kulcha.

Name: Tonkatsu Hinata
Description: One advantage of buying whole pig carcasses is the ability to offer everything from sirloin and tenderloin to rare cuts. The evening set menu provides a chance to taste and compare these different cuts: the smooth fleshiness of rump, the richly sweet fat of jowl, and so on. The idea of tasting fried pork with olive oil also piques interest. To end the meal, curry can be added to make pork-cutlet curry. A range of ideas is this shop’s signature.

Name: Soba Osame
Description: The mood of old Edo pervades this detached, gracious home; it’s like a soba shop in an ukiyo-e woodblock print. Kenji Osame is an evangelist for buckwheat from every region. Seeking out the characteristics rooted in local topographies, he draws on them to knead juwari soba with a rich, rustic flavour. Tasting and comparing seiro soba, arabiki soba and kurobiki soba adds to the fun. Soba with ingredients such as junsai in cold broth, large nameko mushrooms and oysters add to the enjoyment. Lunches is prix fixe only; reservations are required.

Name: Negima
Description: Negima has the feel of a small eatery, with the kimono-clad proprietress serving customers. The decor, featuring ship manifests for the Sea of Japan merchant fleet and newspapers from the Taisho period, fosters a retro atmosphere. The name is from negima-nabe, a stew loved by the people of Edo. The signature dish owes its provenance to the proprietress?younger days when she worked for a researcher in Edo cuisine. The conversations about olden-days food culture and history add to the charm.

Name: roku
Description: The name, meaning ‘six? comes from this couple’s birthday month, June. The aim is to serve the Sangubashi area with French cuisine rooted firmly in the region. The chef adds a unique touch with ingredients sourced from producers with whom he has strong relations. Edible wild plants, mushrooms and game are products of his native Nagano. Desserts prepared from seasonal fruits are handled by the proprietress. At the counter, which appropriately seats six, the chef’s explanations create a feeling of intimacy.

Name: Sharikimon Chawambu
Description: The chef applies the skills he learned in a kappo to tonkatsu. His customer-focused attitude is on display as he adjusts the amount of fat, the thickness of the meat and so on, according to what the diner wants. Even the seasonings display this individuality. Homemade sauces are heated to bring out the fragrance of the spices, while soy sauce is made into kaeshi (dipping sauce) and accompanied by mustard. Heated sauce is poured on the accompanying curry, to finish the meal with a curry rice.

Name: Meishan
Description: A Sichuan restaurant with its feet planted firmly in Kagurazaka. Run by two sisters: the elder in the kitchen, the younger serving guests. Home cooking is at the heart of the menu, with standards such as steamed chicken with spicy sauce, Sichuan-style bean curd and dandan noodles. Japanese pepper lends an invigorating aroma; Chinese mala seasoning is numbingly spicy; a variety of sauce seasonings kindle the appetite. The sisters?down-to-earth kindness makes you feel at home ?no wonder locals love this eatery.

Name: TRATTORIA BUCA'MASSIMO
Description: Kiyotaka Onuma opened his trattoria after being seduced by Tuscan cuisine, and his passion for the foods he discovered sampling local restaurants is on full display. Be sure to start with the richly varied appetiser assortment, a product of great time and effort. Meat dishes grilled over charcoal are the highlight. Items are served on plates decorated with the Giglio of Florence, a stylized red iris. Sharing is part of the fun here.

Name: Yakitori Kato
Description: Skewers are assembled with small pieces and char-grilled to lock in their umami. Of special note is how different seasonings are used for each cut. Displaying his originality, the chef offers tsukune (chicken meatballs) flavoured with sansho and gizzards marinated in herb vinegar. He also adds beguiling twists to bring out seasonal flavours: in summer, high-sugar tomatoes are seasoned with garlic; in winter, yam is wrapped in nori and grilled.

Name: LA BETTOLA da Ochiai
Description: ‘La Bettola?is Italian for ‘the dining hall? With its casual atmosphere and fare that is good value for money, this trattoria draws throngs of guests day after day. The menu is crammed with regional cuisines and seasonal dishes. The prix fixe selection allows a choice of items—you’ll find it hard to make up your mind. For the appetiser, we recommend the combination platter, generous in both portions and variety. Sea urchin spaghetti is a perennial favourite.

Name: mille
Description: Chef Chiba applies his experience in gastronomy in this neo bistro. It welcomes guests with a blackboard crammed with à la carte items and a modern, grey-toned interior. Guests can choose their amuse-bouche from several options and arrange their menus freely, combining as many dishes as they like. Paying special attention to his sauces and good, classic French fare, Chiba takes care to make each dish impressive in both flavour and volume.

Name: Sushi Yoshino
Description: This Edomae sushi restaurant offers both individually ordered items and omakase. The second-generation owner-chef, having learned his skills from his predecessor, holds court behind the counter with his son. For first-timers, we recommend the Edomae Nigiri: 10 nigiri with elaborate toppings such as zuke-maguro, gizzard shad seasoned with vinegar and salt, and anago coated in nitsume. Kanpyo and tekkamaki (tuna roll) make a fitting end to your meal. Enjoy sushi in this old-time Tokyo setting.

Name: Hamacho Kaneko
Description: The owner-chef is fond of the culture of enjoying sake and snacks before the soba comes, so serves various snacks and tempura. In addition to shrimp and anago, there are seasonal tempura items such as wild vegetables and young ayu. Lightly fried, they set the stage for the soba. The emphasis with the thin juwari soba noodles is on the kind of texture that makes them go down smoothly. ‘Meoto?is a dish he learnt at the restaurant where he trained. You can enjoy both soba and udon here.

Name: jeeten
Description: Based on yakuzen (medicinal food), the fare at Jeeten is wonderful for physical health. Owner-chef Katsuhiko Yoshida serves Chinese home cooking arranged in his own style. The steamed shrimp rolls use bean starch sheets instead of rice-flour wrappers. Steamed gyoza dumplings are accompanied by vinegar soy sauce into which whole grain mustard has been dissolved for a Western touch. Coconut milk is paired with warabimochi rather than tapioca. The flavour of each has a warmth that soothes the soul.

Name: Katsuyoshi
Description: You’ll find Katsuyoshi in a back-alley of Ningyocho. The interior of the shop, a refurbished traditional home, uses recycled wood to convey a retro feel. In the kitchen, you’ll see two copper pots. When deep-frying pork cutlets, the owner-chef uses hotter oil for some dishes and cooler oil for others. Fried seafood morsels such as scallop and tiger prawn are popular. If you get a seat at the counter, you can watch the chef’s work, which starts with preparing the meat.

Name: Onigiri Asakusa Yadoroku
Description: Ingredients are displayed behind a glass case, as in a sushi shop. Yosuke Miura, the third-generation owner-chef, listens to his customer’s order and immediately begins moulding it by hand. Before taking over the reins here, he was a flautist. In classical music, you play what’s written on the music sheet. Onigiri is the same, says Miura; you don’t try to do something new. Yadoroku is a score handed down from his grandmother, one which he will reproduce faithfully.

Name: Ginza Katsukami
Description: A set menu for tonkatsu is a unique concept. Tenderloin, loin and shoulder are served one slice at a time, so every item can be enjoyed hot to the very end. Unusually, the meat is served with the cut face up. The reason is that skilful frying firing brings the meat juices to the surface, so placing the morsels in your mouth facing the same way works to bring out the flavour more. Only this set menu so clearly highlights the difference in each cut’s flavour.

Name: CHARCUT
Description: The speciality here is charcuterie. Having learned his craft in a delicatessen in Lyons, Chef Takehiko Machisuji applies the knowledge and techniques of his mentors with patience and diligence. His accomplishment shines in appetisers such as salami, sausage and terrine. Dishes such as soupe de poisson, quenelle and choucroute convey the wonder of regional cuisine.

Name: Marugo
Description: Working with his predecessor, the owner-chef has over a quarter of a century of experience. He chooses his pork not on brand but on quality, tenderness and the sweetness of the fat. The tonkatsu of pork loin and tenderloin is pale in hue. Deep-fried slowly at a low temperature, the aroma of the coating draws out the meat umami even more. Inheriting the teachings of his mentor, he carefully controls the heat as he cooks. It’s no wonder diners have been coming regularly since he opened.

Name: IL BALLOND'ORO
Description: The Ballon d’Or, meaning ‘Golden Ball? is awarded each year to the most outstanding football player. Chef Iwata once dreamed of a future as a footballer, so it’s a fitting name for his restaurant. The concept is trattoria, with ‘everyday life in Italy?as the theme and ‘golden risotto? a dish Iwata learned as an apprentice, as the signature offering. The round mound of risotto shaped with his golden right hand glistens with the colour of saffron.

Name: Ponchiken
Description: Ponchiken began when a yoshoku-trained chef hung out his shingle to pursue the world of tonkatsu. Two types of pork, with differing umami, are used for the tonkatsu. Fresh breadcrumbs and vegetable oil are used in accordance with the meat’s characteristics to draw out its natural flavour. Diners can use salt and a variety of sauces to adjust the flavour to taste. Beef cutlets and fried horse mackerel are deep-fried in lard to give them body, creating the unique flavours of this shop.

Name: LANBRoA
Description: The menu lists dishes from every corner of Spain, every one a precious memory of the chef. The preponderance of Basque dishes reflects her attendance of a cooking school in San Sebastián and apprenticeship at a restaurant there. We start with pintxo (pinchos), an apt choice for the Spanish pub atmosphere. Piquillo pepper stuffed with dried and salted cod, squid simmered in its ink and other Basque-country favourites are faithfully reproduced here. Experience the food culture of Spain.

Name: Los Reyes Magos
Description: The exotic mood of the interior and the gracious reception by the proprietress puts the diner in a sunny mood. The signature menu here is the Catalonian cuisine, a bequest from the previous chef . Pickled sardines impart the scent of olive oil and lemons. Hand-cut uncured ham and Catalonian tomato bread are made for each other. The marinera is a seafood paella made with mussels and shrimp. Each item is authentically Catalonian through and through.

Name: Flowers & Spanish Sonrisa
Description: Flowers & Spanish Sonrisa is a collaboration between the chef, Ueda, an advocate of Spanish cuisine, and his wife, who handles the flower arrangements. The Sonrisa-style meatballs are served in Spanish home-cooking style, with cream and cheese. For your choice of paella, we recommend the Arròs a Banda, cooked in a dashi of red sea bream and watari-gani. ‘Sonrisa?is Spanish for ‘smile? and the couple’s concept is ‘making you smile?

Name: Mochibuta Tonkatsu Taiyo
Description: The name ‘Taiyo?means ‘sun,?invoking the vigour of the sun as it rises each day. To bring out the soft texture of the pork, the meat is fried at a low temperature, using vegetable oil for a light finish. The calligraphy on the wall reads ‘The pork looks bigger on your neighbour’s plate’—a tonkatsu version of ‘the grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.?Something to share a smile about while you wait for your order.

Name: Ponta Honke
Description: Ponta’s taste, upheld by fourth-generation owner-chef Yoshihiko Shimada and his family, goes back generations. His famous cutlet is deep-fried in lard carefully taken from the fat of the pork he will fry. Work is done by hand, as it has been from the first generation. Fried anago (conger eel) and Japanese whiting are also popular. Pig’s-tongue stew, aged over three weeks, is even more popular and often sells out. Shimada compromises on nothing, which is why his customers keep coming back.

Name: Asakusa Hirayama
Description: Asakusa Hirayama hangs out its shop curtain near Kappabashi; the calligraphy is done by the chef’s grandmother, a calligraphy teacher, expressing her joy in her grandson becoming an independent restaurateur. The counter seating harks back to his background as a kappo cook and his cheerful demeanour makes guests feel welcome. Soba is preceded by standards like jellied broth of conger eel or stew of duck breast. Tempura items are deep-fried one by one, as good as you’d find in a tempura specialty shop. The 100% buckwheat soba noodles, prepared with homemade flour made with unpolished buckwheat, are richly flavoursome.

Name: grill GRAND
Description: The charm of a Showa-era (1926?989) Western eatery. In true Asakusa style, the whole family pitches in. Brothers race to finish shredding the cabbage, with the winner allowed to prepare food. This time it falls on the elder brother to wait on tables. Hamburger steak, rice-stuffed omelette, beef stew and other ‘Japanese-Western?favourites remind patrons of the good old days. With the teachings of their grandfather and father in their hearts, the family upholds the goodness of Asakusa.

Name: Yakitori SANKA
Description: The spirit in Takamasa Yamanaka’s heart is one of giving back to his home region. To showcase the appeal of his native Kochi, he sources Tosa chicken. The shop’s name is a portmanteau combining characters from his name and that of his hometown, Kahoku. After dusting his skewers with sun-dried salt from eastern Kochi Prefecture, he grills them over Tosa binchotan charcoal, another point of hometown pride. He lists the names of his producers as a way to express his gratitude.

Name: Osobano Kouga
Description: Here, you’ll be spellbound by the various soba dishes, including the uni speciality, hamo and water shield in the summer and oysters in winter. Hiroshi Kouga’s creativity is driven by his inquisitive spirit. While training at an established restaurant, he was taught that combining raw seafood is strictly forbidden with Edo soba, and this guideline became a new turning point for him. The basic offering is toichi seiro and salty-sweet soup.

Name: Kinoshita
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Interesting wine list
Description: Jellied pork, soupe de poisson, beef simmered in red wine ?filled with respect for classic French cuisine, the chef is keen to serve dishes that warm the soul. The style is universal yet prepared with a unique touch, honed by constant improvement. A collection of Bourgogne wines that have aged along with the restaurant await the discerning tippler.

Name: there is ramen
Description: This shop’s message is “Life is well lived that appreciates a nice bowl of ramen? As a young man, the chef learned these words from his grandfather, and they still reverberate in his heart. Like many from the Mogami region of Yamagata Prefecture, he uses light soy sauce. He seeks a natural flavour for his ramen by using dried sardines and the umami of meat to good effect. Ramen here reminds customers of their hometowns. A photo of his grandfather, smiling kindly, watches over the room.

Name: Ramen Break Beats
Description: ‘Break Beats? the name of a musical genre, is the perfect name for this shop, whose chef wears two hats as an active DJ. The clear base soup uses Amakusa Daio chicken, while porcini mushrooms add umami for soy sauce-flavoured ramen, and freshwater mussels does the same for salt-flavoured ramen. Ingredients such as smoked pork fillet and fried enoki mushrooms switch up the flavours. A catchy remix of old ramen favourites.

Name: YAKUMO
Description: ‘Yakumo?is the name of the owner-chef’s hometown. Opening a wonton noodle restaurant kind of made sense, with the first Chinese character in ‘wonton?and the character for ‘kumo?happening to be the same. For the soup, you can choose between ‘Shirodashi?made with white soy sauce or ‘Kurodashi?made with dark soy sauce. If you can’t decide which to order at the ticket machine, just press either one and just ask for a ‘mix? and free yourself from agonising over it!

Name: Tonkatsu Narikura
Description: The pork cutlets, refined through a process of tinkering and improvement, are surprisingly light-coloured, thanks to coating in low-carb breadcrumbs and frying at low heat. The pork juices cling to the delicate batter, not going to waste. In addition to loin, tenderloin and belly, there’s even a mille-feuille cutlet. The chef’s approach is trial-and-error: time-consuming and with mistakes along the way, but the result is success. A unique tonkatsu born of theory, experience and instinct.

Name: Tohakuan Karibe
Description: Using European chairs in an otherwise Japanese atmosphere sets this dining room apart. Chef Masakazu Karibe finely grinds unpolished buckwheat from Nagano and Niigata into noodles, blending the buckwheat from these two regions to make soba without any added wheat flour. The noodles are cut thin to feel good going down the throat. Soba mash squeezed into balls using a cloth is served in the hot water used to boil the soba . Everything is in judicious proportion according to the chef’s finely tuned senses, and faithful to the ways of his mentor.

Name: BRAMASOLE
Description: Kenta Takahashi was charmed by olive oil drenched in the Mediterranean sun. The restaurant’s name means ‘one yearning for the sun? referring to Takahashi himself. One taste of his dishes made with olive oil will convince you of his expertise in the subject. The house speciality is the fennel and sardine pasta. Ever eager to please his guests, Takahashi will even prepare items not on the menu. Taking the freedom of à la carte one step further is one of the joys of Bramasole.

Name: Sushidokoro Shigeru
Description: With his restaurant, the chef depicts a local unassuming sushi shop. The small counter fosters an air of kinship, as does the friendly service. His conviction shows in the meticulous care he pours into each item. Dishes are not only salted, marinated and simmered, they are prepared with knife techniques so practiced as to seem effortless, then formed by hand to finish. An omakase set menu with snacks is on offer, but the focus here is on nigiri sushi, what a sushi shop originally was.

Name: Chukasoba Nishino
Description: ‘Nishino?is not the owner-chef’s name - uniquely, the place is named after a young female pop star with whom he is infatuated. The menu carries only two items, ramen and sansho (Japanese pepper) ramen. Seeking a flavour similar to udon dashi, he creates soup by mixing dried-sardine dashi with white soy-based sauce. His devotion shines in the Narutomaki fish cake, which forms a hiragana no (?. Listening to girl-band tunes while slurping noodles is this shop’s one-of-a-kind experience.

Name: TROMPETTE
Description: Retro posters and antique furniture grace this intimate bistro, where the apron-clad chef works alone. What Kenji Yamada serves up here is honest, traditional French fare. From his experiences walking around trying the food at bistros in Paris and bouchons in Lyon, Yamada serves hearty portions. If you come in the evening, we recommend the pigeon and foie gras baked in pie pastry, a classic dish.

Name: IRUCA TOKYO
Description: The owner-chef discovered an original soup by researching synergistic effects with umami. Blending dashi from chicken, pork, shrimp and shellfish, he created a soup with layer upon layer of umami. His ‘Porcini Soy-sauce Ramen?features a fragrant paste of porcini mushrooms and black truffles. ‘Salted Yuzu Ramen?transforms the soup with ginger and spices for a modern sensibility.

Name: Edosoba Hosokawa
Description: Chef Hosokawa tours producing regions in search of the highest-quality buckwheat. He kneads his soba noodles reverently and you can compare buckwheat from different regions, tasting the unique character the terroir impart to each. The spring ‘Wakatake?with bamboo shoots and wakame is fragrant with the aroma of young pepper leaves. In summer, ‘Hiyakaki?includes the luxury of large oysters. Visiting to taste the soba of each season is one of the pleasures of Edosoba Hosokawa.

Name: ROZZO SICILIA
Description: A Sicilian eatery run by a chef and waiter who struck up a friendship during the former’s apprenticeship. Enveloped in the sunny mood of southern Italy, guests delight in the cuisine of Chef Nakamura and the service of the host, Abe. With fried chickpeas, seafood couscous and cannoli of local confectionaries, the duo serve up authentic flavours of Sicily in a simple, honest way. The ever-present lemon wedges on the table are a nice Sicilian touch.

Name: Hatsuogawa
Description: Founded in 1907, this restaurant is run by the proprietress and her son. Though the building is new, the interior exudes the same charm diners have loved for decades, parlaying an unchanging old-school elegance to a new generation. Unagi is prepared in the old style, time-consuming in its attention to detail but well worth the wait. Side dishes such as steamed egg custard and soft-boiled soybeans help pass the time until the eel is ready.

Name: Le cabaret
Description: The restaurant’s name evokes a French nightclub with a stage. Service is informal and relaxed: as music plays in the background, the staff greet customers in their everyday clothes. Dishes are served in traditional style, with each table sharing a single plate. With the feel of a Parisian bistro, this was also the place that first started serving natural wine. With an atmosphere that says ‘café?and cuisine that says ‘bistro? the fun of the cabaret never changes.

Name: Seki Hanare
Description: The omakase encapsulates the imagination of owner-chef Satoshi Kawakubo. Examples include grilled soymilk sesame tofu and sashimi enjoyed like a salad with lots of condiments. While meat is the main, Kawakubo adds vegetables from Yamanashi Prefecture, imparting a sense of season. Sake, shochu and wine, carefully selected at the brewery or winery, are one of the pleasures of Seki Hanare. Express a preference and Kawakubo will find a tipple that matches the flavour and aroma of your meal.

Name: Pizzeria Bella Napoli
Description: Neapolitan landscapes adorning the walls and Italian paintings decorating the interior conjure up the atmosphere of southern Italy. Tetsuya Ikeda, owner-chef of this Naples-style pizzeria, knows Naples well. Signature dishes are the three types of Margherita pizza. Using mozzarella from Italy, Hokkaido and Okayama lets guests compare the flavours of each region. True to the spirit of craftsmanship he learned in Italy, Ikeda tends to his wood-fired oven with passion.

Name: SOBAHOUSE KONJIKI HOTOTOGISU
Description: The shop curtain reads, ‘If the cuckoo (hototogisu) won’t sing, I will want to make it sing? This maxim, which summed up the character of Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who unified Japan in the 16C, also exemplifies the chef’s labour of culinary love. The clam soup evolved out of endless trial-and-error to find just the right umami components. Each bowl of ramen finely tunes the affinity of the noodles with the more than 60 other ingredients.

Name: Mejiro Shunkotei
Address: 2F, Trad Mejiro, 2-39-1 Mejiro, Toshima-ku, Tokyo, 171-0031, Japan
Description: Chef Koga bills his fare as “novel yet nostalgic yoshoku? This means he incorporates modern techniques into old-school methods to pursue new directions in flavour. Exhibit A is Koga’s use of a decompression cooker. Vegetables are fresh and seafood moist, permeated with umami. Time and effort are spent preparing the demiglace sauce to bring out its body. The skills of an artisan in step with his times come to life in his cuisine.

Name: SUSHI KOURIN
Description: To encourage diners to drop in casually, the chef even accepts orders for single pieces. A blackboard crammed with lists of sushi items and snacks shows his commitment to service. This is the joy of the local sushi shop, where you can choose your items as you sit face-to-face with the chef. While easy to order, each item is still painstakingly prepared. He hangs out his shop curtain at 3 PM, so guests can start drinking while it’s still light out.

Name: Le Monde Gourmand
Description: A chef with passion for his culinary art and a proprietress schooled in the ways of graceful service enfold this French restaurant in a warm atmosphere of bustling activity. Dishes listed on the blackboard are orthodox: pâté en croûte, baked fish in pastry, beef cheek stewed in red wine. The restaurant’s name means ‘the world of the aficionado of food? The world of the good old bistro lures us in.

Name: L'AMITIE
Description: Tucked away in a backstreet of the teeming student quarter of Takadanobaba is the red façade of l'Amitié. As French radio broadcasts play in the background, the proprietress raises the spirits of the diners with her service. Country-style meat terrines, oven-baked escargot and duck confit are just some examples of the substantial, satisfying, à la carte hometown fare. The restaurant recalls the ambience of Paris from chef Miyashita’s training.

Name: Homemade Ramen Muginae
Description: The owner-chef wants the natural flavours of the ingredients to come through in each bowl. The chicken-based soup using free-range chicken in the standard soy sauce flavoured ramen is rich in umami. A combination of dashi from beef, pork and seafood makes for a complex flavour. Numerous toppings are offered for customers to enjoy a variety of different tastes. The roasted wagyu and homemade wontons are popular.

Name: Les Copains de DOMINIQUE BOUCHET
Description: This bistro is the vision of chef Dominique Bouchet, a lifelong disciple of gastronomy, and his philosophy of enhancing simple cuisine with delicious elements. The focus here is on sauces, the foundation of his cuisine. Dugléré sauce, redolent of herbs and tomatoes, poured over fish poêlé, and steak frites paired with rich, sweet port trace Bouchet’s culinary journey.

Name: Tonkatsu Nanaido
Description: To order, you buy a ticket from a dispensing machine, each button listing a different brand of pork. Knowing the owner-chef is a yakitori craftsman, however, means chicken cutlet is also tempting. Note the attention to detail: the thick-cut pork loin is thin only at the ends because it’s full of fat and fibre there; rice cooked in an earthenware pot is transferred to a wooden tub to control its moisture content. Care is also taken with the plates and bowls, with antique Imari porcelain adding a note of elegance.

Name: T'astous
Description: ‘Bistronomy?is the concept here: more modern than a bistro, more gastronomy than cooking. Owner-chef Tsuyoshi Horie named his restaurant after a French dialectical word for ‘as you like it? Patrons can choose prix fixe or à la carte dining. Use of pesticide-free vegetables and natural wine reflects Horie’s emphasis on the natural. Enjoy a dining experience that is neither bistro nor restaurant.

Name: REI
Description: The name REI comes from reimeiki, ‘a new beginning? The décor is monotone, the food pairing is wine, the fare is modern Chinese. The familiar standards of Chinese dining are on the menu, including Sichuan-style bean curd, steamed chicken with spicy sauce and stir-fried shrimp in chilli sauce. The chef deftly matches home-style seasonings with seasonal ingredients. This is neighbourhood Chinese food refined with a distinctive inspiration, such as twice-cooked pork with spring cabbage, and sweet-and-sour pork.

Name: Setagaya Chukasoba Soshigaya Nanachome Shokudo
Description: The name of the restaurant includes the district’s name, to help endear it to the locals. Looking into the kitchen, you’ll see a cauldron and charcoal brazier. The signature ‘Setagaya Chinese Soba?features dried boiled fish and Shodoshima soy sauce. Feel your stomach rumble to the spectacle of the pork being grilled over charcoal. The boiled noodles are poured into the bowl and carefully topped with lacto-fermented bamboo shoots and greens. It’s a simple deliciousness.

Name: Cristiano's
Description: Portuguese cuisine seems distant yet familiar to Japanese people. The word ‘Takoten?is often heard in kitchens and dining halls and refers to the octopus fritters that recreate the local tastes of Portugal and is also the roots of tempura. Local wine brings out the flavour of this local-style cuisine ?flavours that win over the local palate with tastes that seem somehow familiar. The owner-chef’s speciality is bacalhau (dried cod).

Name: SEIJOSEIKA
Description: The owner-chef fell under the spell of ramen, which he had with his grandfather when he was young. He then made up his mind to become a ramen artisan himself. His signature dish is ‘Shio Soba? There’s a wonderful fragrance to the Japanese-style dashi, made from kombu and dried sardines. He cooks pork fillets over low heat to rare doneness and slices them thin. He serves the soup extra hot so that it can be enjoyed like shabu-shabu.

Name: Tachigui Sushi Tonari
Description: A chic stand-up sushi bar in the style of a standing bar. The restaurant shows great inventiveness in the sweet and sour vinegared rice and combinations of toppings. In addition to the typical tuna and gizzard shad, sushi topped with eggplant agebitashi (deep-fried, then soaked in dashi) or red bean paste are available. Reservations, orders and billing are all managed on a digital system. A sushi shop that began as a street stall in Edo ties is reborn in a version fit for today’s Japan.

Name: yoyonam
Description: Locals know the Yoyogi Fifth District (Go-chome) area as ‘Yoyogo? Change the ‘go?to the Vietnamese word for five, ‘nam? and you get Yoyonam, expressing the owner’s desire to earn the love of its community. The fare consists of arrangements of Vietnamese home cooking, such as spring rolls and bánh xèo (crispy, rice-stuffed pancake). The use of Vietnamese tableware and Sông Bé pottery fosters an authentic atmosphere, while the sounds of the passing trains remind you you’re in Yoyogo.

Name: Yoshoku Wine Fritts
Description: ‘Fritts?derives from the French word ‘frites? meaning ‘fried food? and sure enough, Fritts specialises in fried treats such as deep-fried shrimp and deep-fried minced meat cutlets. The ingredients are coated in coarse breadcrumbs, enhancing the fragrance of the batter. In addition to the fried items, Western-influenced dishes such as hamburger steak and gratin are also popular. The owner-chef’s experience with French gastronomy shines in the chicken-liver pâté and lamb stew.

Name: Watabe
Description: Watabe was formerly a trader in river fish and shellfish; the third-generation owners are brothers who turned it into an eel restaurant. New touches are added to traditional dishes, like steaming unagi with tea leaves to produce a tender texture. Opposite from Watabe is Genkakuji Temple, famed for a legend about the god Enma. In tribute, Watabe offers ‘Enmaju? a multi-tiered food box containing both shirayaki, or eel grilled without seasoning, and kabayaki, or eel dipped and broiled in sweet sauce.

Name: Sasaki Seimenjo
Description: Chef Sasaki’s ideal is simply, “everything is delicious? Such a great statement! With ‘seimenjo? or ‘noodle factory? in the name, his use of Japanese wheat is definitely a selling point. Out of love for his home region, he uses salt and soy sauce sourced from Akita Prefecture. Clear soup of chicken and seafood seems somehow nostalgic. The goal is to be a restaurant that yearns for its home region. Produce is purchased from nearby shops, so as Sasaki Seimenjo prospers, so does Nishiogikubo.

Name: Ma Cuisine
Description: The chef’s dedication to strong relationships with producers comes from his ingredients. He works with irregular crops, underused fish and, depending on timing, imported meats. There is an extensive selection of bistro items like ratatouille and bouillabaisse. A full line-up of à la carte offerings and generous portions show the restaurant’s true essence. Pork is prepared as charcuterie, simmered in red wine, or rolled in herbed breadcrumbs and grilled, to bring out the character of each cut.

Name: anikò
Description: The restaurant’s name derives from the word ‘anikò?which, in the dialect of Italy’s Le Marche region, means ‘giving out plenty, a little at a time? Guests who order the Maruke-no-Oka set menu can experience this approach to dining. Diners can have their fill of regional home cooking, including fried olives, fisherman’s soup and pasta in a boar sauce. The relaxing, comfortable atmosphere feels like Chef Iseki has welcomed you into his home.

Name: Yakitori Abe
Description: The chef assembles the sequence of yakitori chicken cuts according to customer preferences. To their delight, he starts beer drinkers off with chicken breast and wine tipplers with chicken heart. Seasoning is simple: salt, sauce or soy sauce, depending on the item—whichever best brings out the flavour. The top recommendation is the chicken wings, which ticks all three boxes. The skin is fragrant, the meat and fat are sweet, and the umami unique to meat on the bone.

Name: Torishige
Description: A pork-skewer eatery established in 1949. Yuji Sakamaki, third owner-chef, prizes the flavours he remembers from his youth. Meat-stuffed bell peppers are a popular skewer item from the days of the first chef. Beef dishes are a relative novelty, having been introduced by Sakamaki’s predecessor. For his part, the set menu Sakamaki added allows diners to enjoy dishes from the good old days. Guided by his pet saying, “lifelong training? he preserves the flavours of Torishige across the generations.

Name: Pot-Bouille
Description: The softly lit counter creates a stylish mood conducive to gatherings of friends. French favourites such as rillettes and ratatouille share the menu with international items like tripe, shrimp spring rolls and tom yam goong ramen, stoking the imagination. The restaurant’s name is French for ‘hodgepodge? an apt metaphor for Pot-Bouille’s medley of gastronomic influences, somehow in perfect harmony. A free-spirited style all its own.

Name: Japanese Ramen Gokan
Description: ‘Japanese ramen?was added to the name from a desire to spread Japanese culinary culture to the world. Naturally, the shop specialises in domestic ingredients. What brings out queues of diners is the salt flavoured ramen. Clear soup of free-range chicken and clams glistens like gold; the noodles, deftly woven into the broth, are silky smooth. The food looks great, the aroma whets the appetite, the flavour captivates: this ramen sets all five senses tingling. But what really drives the popularity is the sixth sense—the chef’s instinct for what pleases his guests.
