In this spacious and informal restaurant with a kitchen that opens out on to the dining room, chef Charis Nikolouzos showcases internationally inspired cooking that combines Greek roots (thanks to his connections with small-scale producers who supply him with his fresh ingredients) and French and Italian culinary detail. On the à la carte, featuring abundant dishes made for sharing, we particularly liked the Cacio e Pepe with “Mikrolimano Shrimp?

Name: Cerdo Negro 1985
Description: This small taverna with a casual ambience, close to the Kerameikos archaeological site, is run in a relaxed fashion by two brothers who have combined their Greek heritage with a passion for Spanish cuisine. In this single-storey property with an attractive covered patio, they complement their varied à la carte of contemporary Mediterranean cooking (most dishes are cooked over a wood fire), with a six-course Taste of Cerdo Negro menu. Make sure you try the homemade bread and the “Welcome to Cerdo Negro?starter.

Name: Fujian Cuisine (Dongsanhuan North Road)
Address: 110-111, Kaidexingmao, 26A Dongsanhuan North Road, Chaoyang, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: The owner and chefs who hail from Xiamen insist on using produce and seafood from their home province to create authentic Fujian dishes, especially country recipes that were the staple diet of the commoners in olden days. Steamed red crab on sticky rice seduces with seafood umami and briny-sweet roe, while the ginger duck is an heirloom recipe passed down for generations, made with Muscovy duck for exceptional depth. Also try the creamy mashed taro dessert.

Name: Yinsan Douzhi (East Xiaoshi Street)
Address: 176 East Xiaoshi Street, Dongcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: Douzhi, the fermented mung bean milk with a slightly sour and somewhat acquired taste, is considered a healthy breakfast drink that strengthens the stomach and neutralises the grease in food. It is served with spicy pickled mustard stems to tone down the acidity. This shop also sells flaky shaobing flatbread and fried dough rings known as jiaoquan. Grab one of each, a bowl of douzhi and add a hard-boiled egg for a typical breakfast in Beijing.

Name: Tianchumiaoxiang Vegetarian (Chaoyang)
Address: 0260, Section D, 2F, Chaowai SOHO, Chaowai Street, Chaoyang, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: This dining room is simple and rustic, with lotus motifs, peach-wood screens and Buddhist sutras on the book shelves. It is said that after converting to veganism and then going on to become a monk, the founder of this chain experienced improvements to his life; and therefore his restaurants keep making tasty vegetarian dishes without eggs, alcohol and aromatics like garlic and onion. Stir-fried winged beans are especially good, and spicy dishes have a kick.

Name: Rong Cuisine (Baiziwan South Er Road)
Address: 77 Baiziwan South Er Road, Chaoyang, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: A budget-friendly spinoff of the decidedly upmarket Xin Rong Ji, this offshoot lets diners enjoy certain premium dishes at a fraction of its flagship’s prices. The open kitchen imparts a bustling, down-to-earth vibe which complements the simple, seafaring-themed room. Unlike other Rong Cuisine siblings, this eatery serves a larger menu with more choices in single servings. In addition to its famous yellow croaker, try sautéed squid with wild rice stems and salted potherb mustard.

Name: No. 69 Fangzhuanchang Zhajiangmian (Fangzhuanchang Hutong)
Address: 1 Fangzhuanchang Hutong, Dongcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: Ordering food at this neighbourhood joint is a no-brainer. There is only one thing on the menu ?zhajiangmian. But diners come in hordes from the moment the place opens till it closes. These lovely, chewy noodles are dressed with the exceptionally deep and aromatic soybean pork sauce and topped with condiments such as shredded cucumber, radish and leafy greens. Feel free to garnish with pickled garlic and cumin chilli sauce for extra kick.

Name: Bao Du Jin Sheng Long (Ande Road)
Address: Lane 1, Liupukang, Ande Road, XIcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: Tripe is enjoyed throughout the world, but not everyone cares about this digestive organ enough to patent a recipe like the owner here. His signature dish ‘tripe 13 ways?is an assortment of four types of beef tripe and nine types of lamb tripe with a secret dip. The charcoal-burning hot pot with eight different cuts of halal lamb and a ginger-fennel broth is also recommended. Make sure you try their cold appetisers such as radish skin salad.

Name: Gong De Lin
Address: 2 Qianmen East Street, Dongcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: This restaurant, a sibling of its landmark Shanghai namesake, offers plenty of surprises. Don’t be alarmed to find ‘pork?or ‘spareribs?on the menu, as the chef is renowned for mimicking the look of meat dishes with mushrooms and veggies. Braised pork belly is in fact winter melon layered with monkey-head mushrooms, then fried and simmered in a brown sauce. Sweet and sour spareribs are lotus root strips wrapped in gluten, fried and dressed in a tangy sauce.

Name: The Red Chamber
Address: 4F, China World Summit Wing, 1 Jianguomenwai Street, Chaoyang, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: Styled a lot hipper than other restaurants of its kind, this aptly named “chamber?is furnished in the requisite colour inside out. The menu is mostly Northern Chinese, with occasional Sichuanese or Cantonese offerings, all very reasonably priced. Dishes are meticulously executed with spot-on flavours. You can see the chefs roasting ducks in the wood-fired oven. Besides consumed on the spot, these bronzed beauties come in a well-designed package to go.

Name: Pang Mei Noodles (Xiang'er Hutong)
Address: Xiang'er Hutong, 69 Dongsi North Street, Dongcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: In Beijing, this is the first outlet of the popular brand specialising in Chongqing-style noodles and snacks. The fiery beef noodle soup is the signature here ?choose between two sizes and four levels of spiciness. Deep-fried pork with mint leaves and pork brain in ma la sauce are also recommended. Round it out with ice jelly and rice balls in brown sugar syrup to soothe the burn. Reservations are not accepted, so expect a long wait.

Name: Liu Quan Ju
Address: 176 Xinjiekou South Street, Xicheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: This three-storey restaurant is a long-standing household name in the city, specialising in Shandong fare and Beijing snacks. Signatures include shredded fried pork in soybean sauce, deep-fried pork balls, and poached fish fillet in distillers grains sauce. Nourishing drinks such as soymilk with red dates and dried longans are also popular among diners. If you’re in a rush, the annexed store carries buns and snacks for takeaway.

Name: Yibin
Address: 28 Xizhong Hutong, Xicheng, Beijing, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: As its name suggests, the kitchen is helmed by chefs hailing from the Sichuanese city of Yibin; most ingredients are shipped from there and cooked in authentically Yibin style. The menu is big and portion sizes are generous. Try Lizhuang boiled pork, and Yibin noodles with bean sprouts dressed in a nutty, spicy sauce. Expect to wait for at least an hour for a table. Reservations are only accepted for private rooms that seat 8 people or more.

Name: Niujie Halal Man Heng Ji
Address: 14 Ping'anli West Street, Xicheng, Beijing, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: This restaurant specialises in instant-boiled mutton, a traditional Beijingese charcoal hot pot dish. Prized for its fine lean meat without the gamey taste, lamb from the Mongolian Sunite Prairie is used in their hot pot, along with beef from western Shandong. Pick the soup base that comes with the rare lamb ‘scorpion?cut (marrow bone) for the tender, juicy meat and rich flavour. Other specialities include Muslim lamb tripe, and five-spice grilled lamb.

Name: Jingyi (Xicheng)
Address: 2 Liulichang East Street, Xicheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: This small, obscure shop in an alley features an understated grey-brick façade and pared-down décor. The calligraphic menu is short but sweet, heavy on river fish and home-style cooking. Try their braised tofu with fish roe, or hot and sour young lotus root with chicken gizzards. Round it out with grass jelly in Osmanthus honey, or the piping-hot egg-drop glutinous rice wine (in winter). Seats are limited, so come early or expect to wait in line.

Name: Bao Yuan
Address: North side of Building 6, Maizidian Street, Chaoyang, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: Popular among foreigners, this shop has been serving dumplings and Sichuanese food for the past 20-some years. The colourful dumpling skin is made with natural fruit and vegetable juices, and there are tens of different fillings to choose from. Order them by the tael (about six per tael) and be careful of the scalding filling. For surf and turf in a bite, try the New Year dumplings. Purple cabbage filled with crispy rice affords interesting textures.

Name: Zen
Address: 302, 3F, 97 Qianmen Street, Dongcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: Founded by acclaimed chef Wei in 2016, Zen is tucked away in a heritage building on the bustling main drag. While not particularly spacious, the room oozes in charm. The rather bulky menu unrolls like a scroll, listing one long-standing Sichuanese classic after another. Braised mandarin fish with dried cabbage boasts velvety flesh and a fine balance of sweet, salty and sour flavours. Also try the house-made kaoliang-based sparkling fruit wine.

Name: Ladychai
Address: Building 21, Ganjiakou Residence, Ganjiakou North Street, Haidian, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: The second-generation owner of this family-run shop still follows the original c. 1920 recipes. The establishment is packed at peak times, so expect to queue, serve yourself and share a table with strangers. Order the signature braised beef by the catty ?about 0.5 catty per person. Specify whether you want it fatty or lean. Plain noodles in beef broth come in two sizes. The flavoursome broth and toothsome noodles are a match made in heaven.

Name: Tong He Ju (Yuetan South Street)
Address: 71A Yuetan South Street, Sanlihe, Xicheng, Beijing, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Foreign credit cards not accepted,Wheelchair access
Description: Founded in 1822, Tong He Ju is one of the oldest Shandong restaurants in Beijing and was heralded the first of the ‘Big Eight?eateries. The signboard itself is a historic relic, featuring handwriting by Emperor Puyi’s younger brother. Specialities such as braised cuttlefish roe in a spicy-sour glaze; cod fillet in distillers grain sauce; and san bu zhan, an egg yolk pudding fried with mung bean flour and sugar, all adhere strictly to old-time recipes.

Name: Qiantang Garden
Address: 59 Shuangyushu North Road, Haidian, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: The owner opened this joint in early 2000s to serve signature dishes from his hometown of Ningbo, especially seafood ?his close connections with fishermen back home mean he gets the freshest catch shipped to him daily. Pick from the fish tank, or try specialities such as oil-blanched river shrimps seasoned with a dash of vinegar and grated ginger. Hairtail cooked in myriad ways is also popular, perfect with house-made waxberry juice.

Name: Lao Chuan Ban
Address: 5 Gongyuan 1st Alley, Dongzongbu Hutong, Dongcheng, Beijing, China Mainland
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Foreign credit cards not accepted
Description: In 1979, the branch office of Sichuan provincial government in Beijing opened this restaurant to cure the homesickness among travelling Sichuan officials with comfort food from home. It opened its doors to the public in 1995 and has been a popular spot among locals ever since. The room was updated recently, but the prices remain approachable. Come here for the all-time classics: mouth-watering chicken, Fuqi beef offal, and Sichuan boiled fish.

Name: Yu Hua Tai (Xicheng)
Address: Building 23, Yuzhongxili Residence, Yumin Road, Xicheng, Beijing, China Mainland
Description: With a signage inscribed by the younger brother of Puyi, the last emperor of Qing Dynasty, circa 1921, this state-owned restaurant is a real treasure. Its first-generation chef played a key part in preparing the first state banquet of the Republic in 1949, thereby earning the restaurant much acclaim. Since 1997, diners have been coming to the current location to enjoy its Huaiyang cooking, especially such dishes as scorched eel with garlic and soy as well as deep-fried eel.

Name: Sushi Hil
Description: Natural light floods the dining room at Sushi Hil, where blonde wood furnishings set a clean, contemporary tone. The best seats are naturally at the counter, where guests can watch the talented and engaging Chef Hil Nguy craft his jewel-like pieces with great care and efficiency. Seasonal ingredients and high quality fish shine, as in a dish of Japanese sweet prawns accompanied by the just-removed head, served simply over crushed ice with a dab of wasabi. Aka Isaki, or red grunt, is served with orange to underscore the power play of salinity and citrusy sweetness, while aji (mackerel) from Kagoshima has an added zing with grated ginger-scallion. Other standouts include otoro, ikura and chopped tuna, and black throat perch.

Name: Fiorino, Italian Street Food
Address: 212 E. Georgia St., Vancouver, V6A 1Z7, Canada
Description: Fiorino, Italian Street Food is a welcoming spot with just a hint of nostalgia (spy the framed photos and art). Giovanni "Gio" Mascagni presides over this serious Italian place where the bread-making skills he learned in Tuscany are on full display. At lunch, focaccia sandwiches and schiacciata, like the one stuffed with guanciale, drizzled with honey and spread with walnut crema, are the hot ticket. At dinner, it's all about pasta. Spaghettoni ai frutti di mare is a classic Italian seaside dish brimming with clams, mussels and prawns in a perfectly spicy arrabbiata sauce. Each strand is heady with flavor; the clams are tender; the mussels are meaty; and the tomato-based sauce is equal parts sweet, spicy and tart.

Name: Karma Indian Bistro
Description: Wood planks, plush banquettes and rustic lighting set a sophisticated tone at Karma Indian Bistro, but its elegant setting isn't the only reason to make a reservation. The food is as pleasing as the surroundings, and the chef's serious vision is outlined on a menu of wonderfully delicious traditional dishes interspersed with bold, innovative plates.Expect richly spiced favorites such as chicken Madras, a fragrant specialty of South India. Coconut rice is the perfect sidekick to sop up all of that delicious, creamy sauce. Savor each bite of the mouthwatering jumbo prawns in a pureed spinach curry, but do leave room for dessert—perhaps the saffron rice pudding or a cooling mango ice cream.

Name: Say Mercy!
Description: Intimate and welcoming, passersby stop in their tracks and do a double take, as it's clear that everyone is having a gloriously good time at Say Mercy! As for the food? It's a mash-up of Italian cooking with a BBQ nudge. Crudo kicks appetites into gear with sweet slices of amberjack in a caper-dill dressing, olive-serrano pepper relish and wafer-thin fingerling potato chips. Don't even think about passing over the BBQ Bolo—it's nonnegotiable. Short for "bolognese," it's a distinctive dish of house-made spaghetti tossed with pancetta, smoked pork butt and Grana Padana. Finally, the unique twist on the cannoli, inspired by banana pudding, is a great way to end the meal.

Name: Farmer's Apprentice
Description: Farmer's Apprentice is a true neighborhood gem. This tiny space with rustic appeal brings people together over innovative dishes like shrimp-crusted striped bass with XO sauce or radish and Sieglinde potato salad with chili-miso-tamarind vinaigrette. Fresh sourdough bread is baked daily?served with chicken asiento, it's a can't-miss. Local produce is feted, as in kale rapini with lush vadouvan butter, accompanied by lemony labneh, smoked pickled raisins and toasted hazelnuts. On weekends, Chef Alden Ong switches gears and serves Basta Barbecue at lunch, inspired by Tausug-Filipino cuisine. The 63 Acres beef cheeks with buttery lettuce leaves, nouc cham and sunchoke kimchi will have you planning a repeat visit before your plate is clean.

Name: Seaport City Seafood
Description: Enter off Cambie Street and climb a set of stairs to reach Seaport City Seafood, an elegant dining room where pristine fish tanks entice and enchant. It's an upscale setting that attracts a moneyed crowd, with tables set with white cloths and gleaming chandeliers overhead. It is best known for dim sum, which leans traditional while also delivering a fresh and elevated perspective. Case in point? The black truffle fried wild rice, an exciting and contemporary take on an old favorite. Bubbling congee is the ultimate comfort dish; steamed pork ribs are crispy-creamy with irresistible umami; and baked barbecue pork pastry is a winner. Stir-fried cumin lamb shank is a can't miss meal, and if you still have room left for dessert, choose the durian mochi or sponge cake with taro paste. Keep an eye if ordering off the menu, since dim sum offers the value at both lunch and dinner.

Name: Vij's
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: When it opened back in 1994, this local staple was at the vanguard of Indian fine dining in North America, and it continues to make a compelling case for the gastronomic riches of the subcontinent. Namesake chef and owner Vikram Vij hasn’t slowed in spreading the good word, still maintaining a daily presence in the dining room, where he stops at tables to check that every guest is happy. He has little cause for worry, in light of the culinary treasure trove on offer: consider a signature dish of wine-marinated “lamb popsicles,?with a fragrant fenugreek sauce or opt for one of the vegetarian dishes, like a curry made with red bell pepper, portobello mushroom and paneer. A list of unique cocktails offers a perfect foil for the well-spiced cuisine.

Name: Phnom Penh
Address: 244 E. Georgia St., Vancouver, V6A 1Z7, Canada
Description: In the heart of Chinatown, find one of the city’s most respected restaurants. Since 1985, this family-run institution has dazzled crowds with both Vietnamese and Cambodian dishes. The menu is massive, offering nearly 100 rice, noodle and soup preparations, but everyone knows to lean on the classics. You could almost make a meal out of #71, thin slivers of nearly-raw beef soaking in a tangy mix of pureed pineapple and fish sauce. It’s a deliciously original effort. Ordering a mound of golden-fried chicken wings coated in an addicting mix of salt, pepper and sugar is also a given. Beef luc lac with fried egg will round out a meal guaranteed to have leftovers. Be prepared to wait for a table; lines form almost as soon as the doors open.

Name: Lunch Lady
Description: Much like a grandmother who has prepared a feast for her family, Chef Nguyen Thi Thanh exudes a warm, loving presence as she looks over her bustling dining room. She is a long way from Saigon, where she ran a successful food stall, and with her she has brought her charismatic cooking to East Vancouver. The menu is endlessly enticing and inspires immediate decision paralysis. One could fill up fast on starters like fried black tiger prawns with fish sauce or beef carpaccio buried under a blanket of fresh herbs, pickled onions and lime vinaigrette. Garlic fried noodles are another big hit, but then will you still have room for the wagyu beef noodle soup? At the meal’s end, admirers are quick to approach and thank her like the local celebrity she is.

Name: Little Bird Dim Sum + Craft Beer
Description: Longtime local restaurateur Jonathan Lee's vision of pairing classic dim sum with local B.C. craft beer was the impetus behind Little Bird, and trendy Kitsilano is the ideal home for this hip lair. Inside, it's contemporary cool—the floors, tables and walls are created in part from recycled chopsticks. It's a classic lineup of dim sum favorites. Sticky rice studded with savory pork and chicken and sweet goji berries is a must-order. Of course, there must be dumplings, and Little Bird's run the gamut from traditional (ha gow) to surprising, with sweet corn, cilantro and shrimp. Supremely fresh, savory and served steaming hot, these dumplings are the definition of comfort food.  As promised, beer is king here.

Name: Magari by Oca
Description: Although there may be a number of Italian-leaning restaurants and pizza spots scattered around Vancouver, this simple pastificio invites diners to pull up a chair and savor authentic, well-prepared pasta dishes.They have bistro charm down pat, with black-and-white tiled flooring, a chalkboard emblazoned with the daily specials and a window onto an open kitchen. Consider the specials, then peek into the pasta rolling station and watch as your meal is made. A salad of romaine and chicory with oil-cured anchovy fillets and roasted red peppers is elegant in its simplicity. Tagliatelle with a wine-rosemary braised rabbit ragu is especially satisfying. There is just one dessert, but you'll be pleasantly full already.

Name: Song (by Kin Kao)
Description: You're in for a real treat at Song (by Kin Kao), where diners come for a distinctive take on Thai dishes that aren't replicated anywhere else (well, except at their other outpost). Kin Kao Song's fare is driven by a creative spirit and the region's bounty. The lemongrass wings are a special surprise. These bite-sized beauties are deep fried and tossed in a fragrant lemongrass coating for a flavorful punch that delights. Pad Thai may seem like an obligatory order, but this savory version vies for best in class. Then, northern Thai laab with tender, rich pork is given a lift with tart fish sauce and lime broth along with crisp vegetables. Finally, mango sticky rice has that wonderful sticky-sweet appeal.

Name: Anh and Chi
Description: The brother-and-sister team have crafted a clean, cool space outfitted with midcentury modern furnishings while nodding to the past—a blue neon sign by the bar is a relic from the former restaurant. For more than thirty years, their parents' restaurant occupied this spot, but Anh and Chi now welcomes a new generation of diners. The menu is a love letter to Vietnam. Gỏi bắp chuối cua lột, a salad of chopped softshell crab piled high atop a banana blossom, is cool and bursting with flavor. Chạo tôm bánh hỏi is prepared in a classic way, with grilled prawn mousse served with an array of fresh herbs, and there is pho, of course. The dessert menu changes daily, but if on offer, the house-made coffee mousse is a standout.

Name: Motonobu Udon
Address: 3501 E. Hastings St., Vancouver, V5K 0E5, Canada
Description: It's worth frequenting this spot, where a simple, light-flooded dining room buzzes with tables full of diners slurping bowls of noodles and savoring sides. As the name hints, it's all about udon here, where the noodles are handmade and cut fresh to order. Traditional varieties are available hot or cold, served with tempura bits and fresh green onions or with mentsyu sauce and tempura egg. Specialty bowls, such as the spicy tanton with braised pork belly, Shanghai bok choy in a spiced chicken and dashi broth, are equally enticing. Peruse the add-ons and you may find yourself topping your bowl with piles of tempura treats, and inari and pressed sushi round out the menu. Don't see something you want? Ask, as the accommodating staff aims to please.

Name: Fable Kitchen
Description: This popular farm-to-table cafe has been drawing crowds to Kitsilano for over a decade. The setting is lively and comfortable, with exposed red brick walls, wood furnishings and two varnished wood counters seating a handful of diners facing the open kitchen. During daytime hours, the team turns out hollandaise-slicked eggs Benedict (and variations), Johnny cakes topped with pulled pork and tomato jam and thickly sliced challah French toast plated with caramelized apples and whipped mascarpone. A side order of rosti, two blocks of uniformly golden-brown finely shredded potato cakes accompanied by chive-flecked sour cream, is always a good idea. Dinnertime eats are equally hearty and satisfying, as in a short rib with polenta and grilled leeks.

Name: Schüpbärg-Beizli
Description: This restaurant is quite out of the way, but it's worth the journey here to this remote location, where a cosy, rustic-style interior awaits diners, as well as a lovely terrace, which is very popular in summer! But let's not forget the cooking of owner Christoph Hunziker: he prepares home-style Swiss dishes with a modern twist, stamped with his own ideas. In addition to this, you can expect charming service ?sometimes the chefs, too, come to the tables.

Name: Hardern Pintli
Description: This picture-perfect inn is warm and welcoming and certainly looks inviting with its red shutters. Chef-patron Falk Fleischhauer achieves a fine balance between traditional fare and classic cuisine, resulting in delicious dishes that are reasonably priced. Both tripe and sole are to be found on the menu. The service is very friendly and anything but stuffy. In summer, the lovely terrace with its trees is very inviting.

Name: SUAHOY
Description: It quickly becomes clear that this friendly, buzzy venue is not your average Thai eatery. Everything is made fresh, the ingredients are good quality, and the flavours are well rounded and pack a punch ?everything you could ask for from this type of cuisine. Cordial staff. In summer, a small terrace is laid out in front of the door. A word to the wise: booking is essential, even at lunchtime!

Name: Brücke
Description: The superb location on the River Aare is a big draw here, and it goes without saying that the terrace is in high demand! As for the food: a modern spin is put on fresh, traditional cuisine. The emphasis is laid squarely on the quality and seasonality of the produce.

Name: Gasthof zur Sonne
Description: This 500-year-old heritage-protected inn is run by Patricia and Cäsar Meyer, who represent the second generation of their family here. He has a penchant for fish caught in Lake Zurich, just a stone's throw away ?you can't get any fresher or more regional than that! The menu includes some truly rare specialities such as fried livers of fish from Lake Zurich. This attachment to regional produce is, not least, indicative of a commitment to sustainability. The cosy, very well-kept dining rooms are on the first floor, along with the gorgeous balcony terrace, which affords an unobstructed view of the lake. The staff are very attentive and cordial ?you're sure to want to come back! Comfortable guestrooms.

Name: Brasserie Le Gogant
Address: Route de France 8, Le Brassus, 1348, Switzerland
Description: Both this restaurant and the designer Hôtel des Horlogers in which it is housed exude a stylish and upscale ambiance. A feast for the eyes awaits: aside from the elegant interior design, guests can relish the panoramic vistas of nature through expansive floor-to-ceiling windows, or opt to observe the captivating culinary artistry in the kitchen, visible through a generously sized glass pane. The seasonal dishes harmoniously blend classical and traditional flavours (with rich stocks and delectable sauces), presented in a contemporary fashion. The aesthetics and impeccable quality of these creations seamlessly complement the overall setting.

Name: Gaijin Izakaya
Description: This place with a name that translates as "foreigner bar" is a really cool spot that follows the style of Japanese izakayas (casual bars that also serve food). A team led by chef-patron Daniel Shu, who trained in Chicago and New York, and his business partner bring you delicious contemporary Asian soul food. There is a reduced menu at lunchtime. Expect creative cooking such as their spicy Korean pork belly: thin, slightly crispy slices of pork belly marinated in a spicy sweet and sour sauce and accompanied by a beautifully soft egg cooked sous vide and placed on sesame rice. The atmosphere is relaxed, with modern music playing in the background.

Name: Golden Dragon
Description: Davos's restaurant scene is not only about regional food ?the Chinese restaurant at the Grischa hotel serves Cantonese and Szechuan-style cuisine. Tip: Some dishes are designed for sharing. If you fancy the Peking duck for two, be sure to pre-order (at least 48hr in advance). You can also combine many of the ingredients yourself according to your preferences. The upscale design features wood, stone, leather and a palette of elegant dark shades for a lovely ambience.

Name: Casa Caminada
Description: This restaurant enjoys a lovely quiet location in the castle grounds. Inside the bright, high-ceilinged space, modern design meets warm wood; outside, there is a delightful terrace. A charming team provides competent service. They serve regional cuisine, in which seasonal ingredients sourced from select local producers go into extremely flavoursome dishes ?the produce steals the show! Andreas Caminada's take on Grisons classics can also be found on the menu. Be sure to try his quark bizochels, for example. Tip: You can buy bread baked in the on-site bakery and other goods in their shop next door.

Name: Café de Riex
Address: Route de la Corniche 24, Riex, 1097, Switzerland
Description: Artisanal seasonal cuisine that showcases small-scale producers and local artisans, featuring hearty meat dishes (pork belly, kidneys, sweetbreads), sauces with real flavour, and delicious home-made ice creams flavoured with herbs from the garden (savory, sage, rosemary). Guests are in for a real treat in this café in the Vaud! The wine list is just as tempting, and features wines produced here in Riex.

Name: Buech
Description: An absolutely delightful place: an idyllic location overlooking the village and Lake Zurich, a stylish dining area exuding traditional charm, a uniquely beautiful vine-kissed terrace affording stunning views! The few seats in the "wine huts" are much coveted. In the kitchen, the emphasis is on select produce from the region.

Name: Bauernschänke
Description: This historical restaurant offers a delightful dining experience, serving cuisine that draws on international influences and is designed for sharing. You can also opt for a surprise menu. The atmosphere is warm and lively and the service is friendly and informal. Don't hesitate to ask for a wine recommendation.

Name: Victoria
Description: In a chic, modern setting, friendly waitstaff serve high-quality, delicious cuisine. The menu proposes a pleasing mix of regional and international dishes. For a more casual alternative, there is the bistro with bar ?here you can order schnitzel or burgers, for example. Minimalist-style guestrooms are available for overnight stays.

Name: La Trattoria
Description: In the charming Hotel Walther, one of Pontresina's most emblematic hotels, this lovely Trattoria has an authentic, lively atmosphere and a stylish rustic feel. The appetising menu embraces all regions of Italy, with delicious pasta as the centrepiece and the focus firmly on flavour and freshness. Friendly Italian service and a good selection of wines.

Name: D'Chuchi
Description: This small restaurant in a side street in the old town has a charming, down-to-earth and almost intimate atmosphere. It also serves really good food, which owner Jan Schmidlin creates by drawing almost exclusively on regional produce. Shining examples of his delicious modern seasonal fare include veal ?saddle, Bäggli, Schupfnudeln (potato dumplings), lettuce, tarragon. There is a four-course set menu and an à la carte selection of dishes. You can also look forward to extremely pleasant, cordial hospitality.

Name: Boléro V Bistro
Description: This chic bistro opposite the railway station is on the same premises as a gallery and a library, and has a bar (where you can sit and enjoy tapas). The cuisine is modern, tasty and based on good-quality ingredients. On weekdays, there is also a three-course lunch set menu. The lovely terrace overlooks the public square. The bar organises live music evenings on a regular basis.

Name: Alpenblick
Description: The Anderhalden family have remodelled this inn set in a rather remote location. Diners now take their seats in the restaurant-cum-parlour ?the lounge area with its fireplace is ideal for an aperitif ?or in the cosy Stübli with its beautiful wooden floor and elegant table settings. The chef-patron cooks up flavourful seasonal dishes; service comes courtesy of the attentive lady of the house, who is always on hand.

Name: Osteria Fagetti
Address: Via San Luzi 1, San Vittore, 6534, Switzerland
Description: Standing on the main street, this small, thoughtfully decorated restaurant with wooden floors and roughly hewn tables offers its guests friendly and attentive service. The cuisine follows the seasons and uses local ingredients. Recommended dishes on the menu include homemade raviolini and veal osso buco with risotto.

Name: Anker
Description: On the first floor, wood panelling and low ceilings provide a cosy setting in which to choose the appealing mix of traditional and international dishes on the menu. The calves?liver with sage, onions and rösti, for example, is delicious. A significant amount of the restaurant’s meat comes from its own butchery.

Name: Netts Schützengarten
Address: Sankt Jakob Strasse 35, Sankt Gallen, 9000, Switzerland
Description: Housed in the Schützengarten Brewery building, this trendy restaurant is popular, not least among the locals! The terrace and beer garden are delightful, but the interior is also inviting ?the front is somewhat rustic, the back more elegant. Along with Swiss classics such as Züricher Geschnetzeltes (sliced veal served in a cream and mushroom sauce) or beef Stroganoff, the menu includes Asian-inspired dishes and vegetarian options.

Name: Candela
Description: This pleasantly lively place is located right in the city centre. With high ceilings, dark wood panelling, exposed brickwork and large windows, the restaurant is really atmospheric. As well as Swiss classics, the menu includes Mediterranean fare. There is also a decent selection of vegetarian and vegan dishes. Tip: Take the time to peruse the digestif list.

Name: Stiva Grischuna
Description: In this traditional Bündnerhaus dating back over 300 years, the wood-panelled rooms abound with charm, and the down-to-earth cooking looks to the region for inspiration. Whether traditional dishes such as capuns and maluns or classics such as "Norbert's Stroganoff" and cordon bleu ?this is simply tasty fare! The prices are also very reasonable. It's best to book. Locals also dine here.

Name: Eintracht
Description: In this restaurant dating back to 1870, the dedicated Meier family have cultivated a sense of tradition while also introducing modern influences. This approach makes itself felt in the bistro and the more elegant restaurant area as well as in the cuisine ?from classics such as veal cordon bleu to a gourmet set menu composed of three to five courses. Excellent wine selection. Simple daily specials are also available in the bistro.

Name: Zum Pflugstein
Description: Considered the largest erratic boulder in the canton of Zurich, the Pﬂugstein is located close to this distinguished vineyard farmhouse and lends its name to its fabulous restaurant. The interior comprises an attractive wood-panelled space and a room with a fireplace, while outside there is a truly idyllic terrace. The service team overseen by the charming Jeannine Meili also deserves a mention. Tip: Try the tender boiled beef!

Name: Le Bologne
Description: Next to the Fine Arts School, this vintage bistro cuts a fine figure with its cement tiles, hanging globe lights and bare bulbs, as well as its bar, banquettes and bistro chairs. The dishes feature high-quality, carefully prepared seasonal ingredients: celeriac "risotto" and foie gras, confit lamb shoulder, cumin, asparagus and labne...

Name: Muntanella
Description: The restaurant in the long-established Arosa Kulm Hotel, not far from the ski slopes, has adopted a dual concept: a simpler lunch menu featuring rösti, pasta, burgers etc, and a more ambitious menu in the evening. High-quality regional ingredients such as Grisons lamb or Val Lumnezia Alpine char take centre stage. The glass-walled walk-in wine cabinet is quite something. The terrace is a delightful spot from which to take in the mountain scenery.

Name: au violon
Description: This place exudes brasserie appeal thanks to its charming, stylish atmosphere and unfussy, honest seasonal menu, which also includes classic dishes. Despite its proximity to the centre, the location is pleasantly quiet ?outside, an attractive terrace with shady trees beckons. There are well-kept guestrooms for overnight stays. Tip: Take the opportunity to visit Basel Historical Museum opposite.

Name: Albrun
Description: The journey up to this enchanting mountain village is something of an adventure, but the food is worth it! The rustic chalet-style interior belies an ambitious menu including roast black nose lamb with artichokes and chickpeas, as well as poached char with curly kale. There are even a couple of simple but well-kept rooms for overnight stays.

Name: Le Bistro by Décotterd
Description: Like its fine dining counterpart, Le Bistro also promises diners a stunning view! In this worthy alternative with a modern interior, the food is simpler, but absolutely the equal in terms of taste and culinary know-how. Be sure to try the pâté en croûte or tarte au chocolat!

Name: Les Curiades
Description: A truly historic restaurant which has been serving food since 1850. The present chef has experience in some of the finest restaurants, and it shows! His cuisine is elegant and refined, including dishes such as chuck beef braised in beer (paying tribute to the chef’s Belgian origins) and a delicious vegetarian menu which is always available. An unqualified success!

Name: Nest- und Bietschhorn
Description: This cosy, rustic restaurant is located in a hotel first opened in 1868, which makes it the oldest hotel in the Lötschental valley (the modern, Alpine-style rooms are particularly attractive). Excellent cuisine including Valais specialities such as duo of veal, braising jus with cooked wine, Hokkaido pumpkin and smoked potato gnocchi on the menu. Fine views from the terrace.

Name: Alla Cantina
Description: Although all the staff at this beautiful historic restaurant on the village square hail from Sicily, they have been working in Switzerland for years. Here, authentic Sicilian cuisine is served in a rustic and welcoming setting that also provides the backdrop for regular music events: the only concessions to Ticino are the polenta-based dishes. Our inspector particularly recommends the sarde in “Beccafico?stuffed sardine roulade with breadcrumbs, sultanas, pine nuts and orange peel). There’s also a pleasantly cool and tranquil outdoor space for summer dining, plus four attractive and inviting guestrooms on the top floor.

Name: Myò Sushi Bar
Description: Situated in the heart of the Esplanade de Montbenon park, this Japanese restaurant offers a summer terrace overlooking the lake, where guests can enjoy authentic Japanese cuisine which includes much more than just sushi. The desserts are equally delicious.

Name: Grotto Valmaggese
Description: Situated in an excellent location slightly above the road, this traditional grotto-style restaurant with a large car park is quiet and cool in summer, with a dining room warmed by a fireplace in winter. In this delightful location, enjoy classic, well-prepared and generous cuisine with personal touches made using top-quality, seasonally inspired ingredients. Make sure you try the venison tartare with marrow gratin and pear jelly, as well as the delicious artisanal ice creams. The highly welcoming and attentive service is clearly in evidence in the dining room.

Name: Barranco
Description: Eat, drink, make merry, meet friends?the Kreis 4 district is to Zurich what the Barranco district is to Lima. Nestled among a host of other restaurants and bars, the Peruvian neighbourhood's namesake serves authentic modern Peruvian cuisine that is bursting with flavour, zing and spices. Equally appealing is the pleasantly unpretentious atmosphere complete with relaxed, nimble service. Great cocktail selection.

Name: La Bottega di Mario
Description: Housed in a historical building (1913), La Bottega is a wonderfully inviting and lively ristorante and salumeria under one roof. Guests are spoilt for choice between the tasty dishes, clearly influenced by Ticino tradition, and the superb selection of salami and ham at the counter ?here, the friendly mastri salumieri serve up the cold cuts. Tip: Try the house wine, Merlot di Ticino, poured from a six-litre bottle!

Name: Le Café Valrose
Address: Place de la Gare 2, Rougemont, 1659, Switzerland
Description: Part of the same establishment as La Table de Valrose, this bistro has a comfortable rustic-style Alpine atmosphere, both outside, on the terrace shaded by chestnut trees, surrounded by mountains, and inside, by the fireplace, in the wood-panelled space. Relax in the lounge bar with a coffee or cocktail in hand. The menu features tasty seasonal fare in the form of simple dishes, while classics such as Valrose fondue (champagne version available), malakoffs and Valrose burgers (meat or veggie) are permanent fixtures on the menu. The dessert trolley is available all afternoon, for teatime.

Name: Auberge Communale Le Mont
Address: Place du Petit Mont 4, Le Mont-sur-Lausanne, 1052, Switzerland
Description: Burgundy ham terrine, gherkin and fresh herb condiment; Jorat veal belly, pistachios and green asparagus: the Burgundian chef and Meilleur Ouvrier de France definitely knows his stuff. This is a fine dining version of modern French cuisine that highlights local and fresh ingredients and showcases small-scale producers. He successfully pulls it off, and keeps it affordable. Fine selection of wines by the glass.

Name: Café de La Plage
Description: With its magnificent theatre dating back to 1879, this restaurant occupies a unique location. The decor successfully combines historical features with trendy modern details. The tasty, top-notch cuisine comprises an interesting array of international dishes and classic fare made using seasonal ingredients. Pleasant terrace. Don't forget to book!

Name: L'Écorce
Description: In this convivial, tastefully furnished restaurant in Carouge’s old town the chef conjures up fresh, aromatic cuisine that combines classic and modern dishes such as mi-cuit tuna with a beetroot and watermelon bouillon and raw and cooked vegetables. Charming service, plus a small summer terrace.

Name: AuGust
Description: This restaurant with its charming brasserie atmosphere is located in what was once the "butcher's quarter" ?and in keeping with its history, the meat theme has been taken up here. Besides design features such as lamps and wall tiles, the open kitchen really draws the eye. They rear their own meat or source it from Swiss producers. Vegetarian alternatives are also available.

Name: Aroleid Restaurant
Description: Located right by the ski slopes just above Furi gondola station, this restaurant is housed in a modern and stylish chalet that exudes rustic charm. As well as stunning views, diners can look forward to a diverse menu of delicious dishes inspired by the chef's international travels. Incidentally, the coffee comes from the hotel's own roastery and the crockery is also made in-house. For those who don't mind the long walk, it's a 1.5hour hike from Zermatt to the restaurant.

Name: Fischerstube
Description: Following a complete conversion this long established restaurant is now newly resplendent. Fish specialities are served in traditional or modern style dining rooms.

Name: DAR
Description: This trendy, understated place is the charming sister restaurant of KLE. Here, the tasty plant-based dishes with Spanish and Moroccan roots, as well as other international influences, are ideal for sharing. There are two dinner services each evening, and drinks are served at the adjoining bar ?before or after your meal. Sat and Sun brunch.

Name: Schönbühl
Description: Reserve a window seat at this restaurant so that you can take in the lake and mountain views as you tuck into tasty regional-seasonal dishes. In summer, a spot on the terrace is highly coveted. At lunchtime, choose from the affordable Tagesmenü (set menu of the day) and a handful of classics ?but you can also order the regular à la carte dishes. Note: closed on Sundays Oct-Mar. There are inviting, well-kept guestrooms, should you need overnight accommodation.

Name: SALZHAUS
Description: At this restaurant you will find an attractive mix of urban cool and historical setting, including some unusual exposed old masonry. The cuisine also combines international, regional and seasonal fare. There is a simple selection at lunchtimes and something more ambitious in the evenings. Try the Thai curry soup or the venison entrecôte with walnut malfatti.

Name: Pensiun Aldier
Description: If you like your food straightforward and pared down to the essentials without compromising on taste, then you'll love the excellent Engadine cuisine here. In the pleasingly unpretentious restaurant of the charming little hotel of the same name, the dishes forgo any frills and instead focus on select, fresh local produce. Good wines at fair prices. Shorter menu at lunchtime.

Name: Die Rose
Description: In the basement of Die Rose, you can enjoy typical Italian cuisine in a really pleasant rustic atmosphere. In summer, make a beeline for the delightful terrace. For groups of four or more, we recommend heading to Tavolata, where various dishes for sharing are served. Tip: the lunch menu in the form of the "Pranzo-Box" ?as with the Japanese bento box, the dishes included in the set menu come in one box.

Name: Rigiblick
Description: This welcoming bistro has a relaxed atmosphere. The kitchen team focuses on regional produce, which is used to create really delicious dishes. In summer, head for the leafy terrace. Tip: It is easy to get here by taking tram line 10 followed by the Funicular Rigiblick.

Name: Osteria della Bottega
Description: This lively restaurant is located on a steep little street in Geneva's old town. Against a chic industrial-style backdrop with an open kitchen, diners are treated to modern, seasonally inspired Italian cuisine and fine wines, plus attentive and friendly service. It's best to book, as Osteria is very popular! Across the street there is a lovely terrace.

Name: Linde
Description: The secret of Linde's success is a formula of classic Swiss cuisine made from good ingredients coupled with reasonable prices. A lively atmosphere reigns in this attractive, well-run place with its various dining spaces, large bar area and glassed-in kitchen. Steak tartare and Zürcher Geschnetzeltes (veal) are among the permanent fixtures on the menu. The wonderful terrace comes into its own in summer, and there are well-kept guestrooms too.

Name: Grotto della Salute
Address: Via Madonna della Salute 2A, Massagno, 6900, Switzerland
Description: A rustic grotto-style restaurant with a warm and welcoming ambience, where staff are happy to advise you on the seasonal dishes on offer. A whole page of the menu is dedicated to classic favourites, all of which are influenced by Mediterranean cuisine ?the veal shank with mashed potato and salted butter is particularly delicious. There’s also a small menu of daily specials which changes according to market availability. The terrace shaded by huge plane trees provides a pleasant setting for summer dining, while an excellent wine list adds to the appeal.

Name: Collonge Café
Description: This modern restaurant boasts a great location next to the historical town hall and has a charming terrace laid out in the garden. The seasonally inspired menu successfully brings together modern Italian and French cuisine, while keeping an open mind when it comes to international influences. Cordial and competent service. Tip: the competitively priced lunch menu.

Name: Bären
Description: Diners come here for straightforward seasonal cuisine that is prepared with fresh produce and, most importantly, utterly delicious. You can dine à la carte or opt for a set menu. The house specialty is Parmesan cheese wheel spaghetti. The lovingly decorated Gourmetstübli is a particularly appealing space. At lunchtime, the more limited choice includes a really sophisticated daily set menu.

Name: Gasthaus Bären
Description: Closed for renovation until spring 2024.Bären serves up flavoursome traditional fare made using local produce ?try the fillet steak goulash with pappardelle or the home-made asparagus ravioli with morels ?in the lovely setting of the 16C Berner Haus, complete with wood-panelled dining rooms and historic charm.

Name: Zum Kaiser Franz im Rössl
Description: Here, you won't want to miss out on the Austrian specialities such as Viennese fried chicken, Tafelspitz (prime boiled beef) or Topfenknödel (curd dumplings)! Available as a large or small portion, the Wiener Schnitzel is a real highlight. Be sure to ask about the fish of the day, freshly caught from the adjacent Lake Zug. As well as the good food, diners can look forward to a cosy, stylish atmosphere and attentive service ?not to mention a warm welcome from the manager.

Name: Café de Peney
Description: Located on an arm of the River Rhône, this lively and popular restaurant calls to mind a vintage picture postcard: charmingly done out, with various antique objects and a wisteria-covered terrace. Fine ingredients go into delicious dishes prepared with finesse. Specialities include, for example, pig's cheeks confit with Gamaret or the runny hot chocolate biscuit.

Name: Alpenblick - Bistro
Description: Bistro makes for a pleasant alternative to Gourmetstübli in the Alpenblick hotel. Diners soak up the cosy atmosphere as they tuck into the excellent food served here. On the menu: delicious regional and seasonal dishes as well as classics such as Kalbfleisch-Geschnetzeltes (slices of Simmental veal in a creamy sauce) and cheese fondue. And be sure to try the rösti! On Tuesday evenings the restaurant hosts a meat fondue buffet.

Name: Gommerstuba
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: The friendly hosts here serve contemporary cuisine, which can be ordered à carte or as a set menu ?there is also a vegetarian set menu. Many regional wines are featured. A restaurant decor blending wood and stone makes for a pleasant atmosphere. The lovely terrace is also inviting!

Name: Asia
Description: At this restaurant, an Oriental-style decor in dark colours provides the setting for Japanese cuisine, including the usual classic favourites. The menu features traditional and fusion sushi, sashimi, delicious Thai curries, dim sum and many other Asian specialities, plus there’s an interesting set menu (at lunchtime) which changes daily.

Name: ZOLLHUUS
Description: This friendly place is perfect for meat lovers. They specialise in steaks, some of which are matured in the restaurant's own dry-ageing cabinet. Vegetarian and vegan alternatives are also available. The first Saturday evening of every month is devoted to Wagyu beef dishes, and it's BBQ night every Thursday (Jun-Aug). There's a fabulous rooftop terrace with views of the Aare and the region. For overnight stays, the adjoining Hotel Kettenbrücke has elegant guestrooms with a minimalist design.

Name: Café du Levant
Address: Rue du Vieux Four 53, Aire-la-Ville, 1288, Switzerland
Description: In a quiet little village in an attractive rural setting, you will find this warm and welcoming restaurant with a down-to-earth vibe. The property backs onto fields and the fresh air is a real tonic. They serve flavoursome seasonal cuisine and regional French fare, which you can accompany with your choice from a good selection of wines from the Geneva region. Lovely terrace.

Name: Josef
Description: This trendy, urban restaurant and bar is located in the middle of a residential area in Kreis 5 (Zürich's fifth district). The atmosphere is lively and bustling, and in light of their interesting concept, it comes as no surprise that the place is well frequented: they serve tasty modern European cuisine with dishes in starter-sized portions (four is a good number to order). Mouthwatering options include the likes of veal shank ragout with mashed potatoes, confit garlic and Trevisano. Alternatively, there is a five-course set menu ?available in omnivore and vegetarian versions. Good wine list and cocktail selection.

Name: Postigliun
Description: Far above the valley lies the Sgier family's restaurant, where Sandro (the son) and Guido (the father) serve up delicious cuisine. You should definitely try "Guido's capuns"! No less appealing are the game dishes with meat from animals they have hunted themselves. Tip: If you'd like to accompany your food with a good wine, we recommend staying overnight in one of their guestrooms.

Name: Gül
Description: This restaurant tucked away in an inner courtyard has a laid-back atmosphere and is pleasantly lively thanks to a vibrant soundtrack of Turkish music. And so the scene is set for the food, a modern take on traditional Turkish dishes ?made in the open kitchen and, in keeping with the way in this part of the world, served in smaller portions or larger dishes for sharing.

Name: Agorà
Address: Via Muro degli Ottevi 10, Brissago, 6614, Switzerland
Description: Located in relaxing Brissago, this historic bistro features a pleasantly retro ambience and well-maintained wood furnishings. The courteous service is accompanied by the delicious flavours of dishes that follow the seasons and include traditional and Mediterranean touches. The ravioli del plin stuffed with braised wild boar are a highlight.

Name: Indian Rasoi
Description: This restaurant not far from Place du Rondeau is based on the interesting concept of serving authentic, hybrid Indian cuisine that is not tied to any single region. The droves of customers suggest this is a winning formula! The atmosphere is modern, the service friendly and attentive. In summer, the terrace is most pleasant.

Name: STÜVA in der Krone - Säumerei am Inn
Description: The different Arvenstuben (Swiss pine lodges), including the over 300-year-old Jahre old Stüvetta, offer an appealing alternative to LA CHAVALLERA. Here, traditional Engadine cosiness is complemented by modern overtones. The menu features delicious dishes that home in on the essentials, including vegetarian options such as beetroot gnocchi or aubergine ravioli that keep diners coming back for more! Most of the ingredients used are locally sourced and seasonal. In fine weather, you can also eat out on the terrace.

Name: Natürlich
Address: Rue de la Coulouvrenière 38, Geneva, 1204, Switzerland
Description: Just a few metres from the River Rhône and the BFM theatre, this popular restaurant appeals with its trendy and relaxed bistro-style atmosphere. It serves seasonal modern cuisine based on quality regional ingredients, in dishes such as roast cuttlefish, purple potatoes and cime di rapa. The food is accompanied by a terrific wine list including organic options. And for an even more convivial experience, plates are designed for sharing! Friendly service, too.

Name: Wiesner Mysterion ?Werkstatt Kost
Description: Those under the spell of the "Wizard of Entlebuch" in Bramboden know they will be getting something special. Like Wiesner ?Zauber, Werkstatt ?Kost is also located in the Weitsicht hotel. The location is simply magnificent; the terrace is idyllic, boasting one of the loveliest views in the whole region. Drawn to the produce yielded by the mountains, Stefan Wiesner pulls off his culinary philosophy of incorporating nature into his dishes ?sustainable and definitely not run of the mill! His four-course set menu makes the most of what the local forest, meadows and gardens have to offer. The wonderfully crusty sourdough bread from the Wegelin wood-fired oven, served beforehand with aromatic, almost black charcoal butter, is the perfect start. Equally unique is the original, cosy interior with a workshop atmosphere. The food counter is also a cookery school.

Name: Alpenblick - Bistro
Description: The bistro may be cheaper than this establishment's upscale restaurant (Stuba), but a meal here is still really tasty and fresh. Whether you come for lunch or dinner, the terrific, no-frills market-inspired cooking won't break the bank. They are keen to use produce from the region, in dishes such as "Hüttler's hamburger" or house speciality "Dad's steak tartare". Another of their classics is the spicy Thai red curry, with just the right amount of heat! In keeping with the Alpenblick style, the atmosphere is nice and relaxed, and the service is charming and attentive. There are also some good wines ?the wine list is the same as at the fine dining restaurant.

Name: Panorama - Bistro
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: This attractive alternative to the Cayenne offers excellent cuisine at a very reasonable price. Although the dishes are simpler in style, they are prepared with equal sophistication using quality regional produce, always with a certain modern twist. Attentive service, plus the same wine list as in the Cayenne. Wonderful views!

Name: Centrale
Description: Particularly renowned and popular with locals, this restaurant has a delightful family ambience. It offers delicious regional cuisine that can be enjoyed outdoors on the lovely terrace in fine weather.

Name: Edo
Description: You can be in the Swiss mountains and still enjoy authentic Japanese cuisine, including dishes such as Japanese fondue, grilled chicken with Teriyaki sauce, and delicious gyozas and sushi (takeaway dishes are also available). Here, legendary specialities from Japan are prepared in front of you with high-quality ingredients and meticulous care. Terrace with views of the surrounding peaks.

Name: Sonne
Description: At the Häfliger family's lovely 100-year-old restaurant, diners can look forward to fresh, flavoursome food and attentive service provided by experienced staff. Classic Swiss cuisine is served in the form of a seasonal or surprise set menu. Alternatively, you can order à la carte. This place even has its own excellent spring water! Pleasant terrace to the rear of the building. Tip: Delicious cheese is sold in the cheesery next door.

Name: Braui
Description: Housed in the cultural centre that shares its name, braui serves good traditional cuisine in a pleasant, brasserie atmosphere. The menu is made up of seasonal dishes and includes classics such as beef tartare or veal cordon bleu. Smaller choice available at lunchtime. Tip: The public car park, Braui-Parkhaus, is handy.

Name: Casa Casutt - Ustria
Description: Linus and Therese Arpagaus offer diners a charming setting in which to tuck into their excellent cuisine made using fresh produce. The menu takes its cue from the region and includes local specialties such as capuns and pizokel. Fans of veal liver, sweetbreads or tripe are also in for a treat. The garden terrace is wonderful, and Sala is another alternative.

Name: Seebistro Belvédère
Description: The location right by the lake is superb! The modern bistro is just in front of the fine dining restaurant ?the same kitchen team works at both. There is a seasonal set menu with Mediterranean influences and made with regional produce, plus a choice of classics.

Name: Gasthaus Schupfen
Description: With a history dating back to 1455, this lovely half-timbered house is really something special. In an inviting atmosphere, food is served in three charming rooms and on the idyllic terrace overlooking the Rhine. The menu features classics, including Kalbsgeschnetzeltes Zürcher Art (veal ragout), and seasonal dishes such as Kundelfinger trout with boiled potatoes and spinach. If you are looking for a good location for a wedding or event, the premises can also be rented out.

Name: Adler
Description: The name of the game here is "Gasthaus at its best" ?this applies to the cosy space, the cordial, attentive service, and chef Daniel Jann's cuisine. Whether you opt for Murmeltierpfeffer (marmot stew), Gitzi-Bratwurst (a goat meat and beef sausage) or asparagus dishes, meticulous craftsmanship and flavour are guaranteed. The focus lies squarely on the region. Eating here is fun! Stylish guestrooms are available for overnight stays.

Name: Kaiserstock
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Credit cards not accepted,Great view,Terrace
Description: This charming establishment perched in a small mountain village is your reward after the narrow, steep drive up! The fact that the restaurant has many regular customers is of course mainly down to its tasty traditional cuisine. The dishes are prepared with flair from good, fresh produce from the region. Popular options include stews and ravioli. A four- to seven-course set menu is also available if you pre-book (two days in advance). Seasonal specialities such as venison and chamois or Metzgete (pork platter) are also worth considering. Tip: Soups, sausages, jams and other delicacies can be purchased to take home. There are pleasant rustic-style guestrooms for overnight stays. N.B. Cash only!

Name: Restaurant du Quai
Description: This inviting restaurant on the shore of Lake Geneva serves tasty seasonal cuisine with no frills. Chef Jérôme Manifacier is a real pro, whose motto is "take your time"; all you have to do is trust him. Superb terrace shaded by the plane trees and with a fabulous view of the lake and the Jura mountains.

Name: Bacchus Bistro & Genussmanufaktur
Description: You will feel right at home at this restaurant, thanks to the tasteful, upscale decor, friendly service and ?last but not least ?good-quality, fresh dishes cooked up by Werner Tobler. There are two set menus: "Du Terroir", comprising three to four courses, and four- to six-course "La Table chez Bacchus". Tip: Genussmanufaktur sells an appealing range of cheeses, spices, cakes, wines etc.

Name: Zum Alten Stephan
Description: This restaurant in the middle of the historical old town is not only steeped in history, it is also a place to enjoy really good food. The menu features "Stephan's Classics" alongside dishes that are somewhat more modern, but by no means contrived. The charming front-of-house team is managed by the proprietress. Delightful terrace in front of the building.

Name: 16 ART-BAR-RESTAURANT
Description: Diners will feel right at home in this charming and inviting restaurant. Set in a former bell foundry, the atmosphere is welcoming and delightfully down to earth. The blend of rustic and modern styles is interesting, and the art on the walls is sure to draw the eye. You can look forward to very friendly and attentive service, as well as pared-down and exceedingly flavourful dishes prepared by owner Nik Buchs. Popular choices here include true classics such as entrecôte or veal cutlet. The extensive wine list also includes organic and biodynamic wines.

Name: Bistro by Regina Montium
Description: Whether you hike up or take the mountain railway (ideal from Vitznau), it's well worth stopping off here. The location is idyllic ?at 1 550m above sea level, the terrace is wonderful ?and the "natural cuisine" is another big attraction! This includes smaller plates and regular dishes such as Rigi beef ragout or burger with Alpine cheese, many of which are made with produce from the immediate vicinity or grown in their own garden. Individual ingredients are explained in a friendly and competent manner. Why not try a gentian root tonic with Rigi juniper gin before dinner? Both the Bistro, for lunch, and fine dining restaurant, Regina Montium, for dinner, are located in Kräuterhotel Edelweiss, where you can stay overnight after your meal.

Name: Blaue Ente
Description: Historical industrial architecture outside and a trendy, lively atmosphere inside ?the old machinery really draws the eye! Diners enjoy the laid-back vibe that comes courtesy of the relaxed yet efficient service team. The kitchen uses regional produce to create uncomplicated, fresh and flavoursome dishes. A good selection of wines. The terrace is very popular.

Name: Chappeli
Description: Up here above the village, the Hausmann/Köhli husband-and-wife team propose a really fun dining experience! A friendly, down-to-earth atmosphere reigns in the restaurant, presided over by your charming hostess. The chef-patron's cuisine is distinctly regional in terms of flavour and aroma. To pair with excellent wine recommendations. Be sure to bag a table on the delightfully verdant garden terrace!

Name: PINOT
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The location in the side wing of the modern Klinik Gut private hospital may be a little unusual, but the food here is excellent?thanks to Roland Schmid, who has made a name for himself in the region over the years. The decor is trendy and minimalist in style, with an open kitchen; the view of the mountains and the surrounding area is fabulous ?tables on the terrace are understandably coveted. Tip: the tasting menu on Thursday evenings.

Name: La Fleur de Sel
Description: Regional cuisine and a bistro style atmosphere in the Fleur de Sel.

Name: Restaurant Schlüssel - Schlüsselstube
Description: Schlüsselstube is a bistro where they also serve outstanding food ?and it represents really great value for money. Classics such as braised veal cheeks are delicious, and the desserts are extremely hard to resist! When it comes to wine, this cosy place also hits all the right notes. The service provided by waitresses in traditional dress could not be more charming!

Name: Wirtshus zum Wyberg
Description: The restaurant on the first floor is a little more elegant and comfortable than the bar. The large menu ranges from a delicious veal schnitzel in morel sauce to the classic saddle of venison grand veneur, not to mention a popular lobster menu which includes home-made ravioli.

Name: Rathauskeller Bistro
Description: The friendly service and relaxed atmosphere here are popular with locals and tourists alike. Diners can choose from the selection of classics such as cordon bleu, Lammhacktätschli (lamb patties) and beef roulades, and there is also a seasonal menu. The tables on the gorgeous terrace in front of the building in the cobbled pedestrian zone are coveted. Tip: Just a stone's throw away, the lakeside is perfect for a stroll.

Name: Blume
Description: At this pleasant restaurant, heart and skill go into rustling up regional cuisine made with top-notch ingredients. Risotto is one of the chef's specialties, but they also serve offal, such as tripe or liver. The spit-roast skewers flambéed at your table and the Chateaubriand have to be ordered in advance and are served to the whole table. The rustic downstairs space is an appealing backdrop for your meal; the upstairs room is a little more elegant. With her friendly, outgoing manner, the owner adds a personal touch to the service. The beautiful quiet location is rural yet still close to Zurich.

Name: Bistrot Dumas
Description: This buzzy bistro located in the Champel neighbourhood is often fully booked. The interior is done out simply and tastefully ?it is the Art Nouveau stained-glass ceiling panels, as well as the columns, that draw the eye. Their classic take on traditional French cuisine is flavoursome and aromatic, plus everything is made in-house. The service is efficient and attentive.

Name: Landgasthof Ochsen
Description: The food is terrific in this inn dating back to 1288 ?the skilful chef clearly pours a lot of love into his cooking. As well as regional dishes and classics, Asian and Mediterranean influences also make their way onto the menu. A meal in their Gaststube is a somewhat simpler affair. There is a lovely terrace overlooking the pond, plus a charming smoking lounge. Pleasant and handy guestrooms.

Name: Bären
Description: The 14th generation of the same family is at the helm of this gorgeous traditional Bernese inn ?it was first documented in 1261. Whether you eat in the pretty, inviting dining area or the lovely garden, you will be treated to friendly service and delicious food with a traditional regional character. One speciality of the house is the Solothurner Wy-Süppli (wine soup). The chef will be happy to explain the origins of their rather special "Bärechöpfli" dessert. Slightly reduced menu at lunchtime. There are also stylish salons.

Name: Auberge de la Croix d'Or - Bistro
Description: Claudia and Olivier Hiernard have combined bistro and restaurant at their charming inn. The delicious bistro fare on the blackboard is now complemented by a market-inspired "Menu du Marché", meaning flavoursome dishes are now served in both parts of the establishment. Just don't forget to leave room for dessert! On Friday and Saturday evenings, only a small selection is available.

Name: Moosegg
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Up here, at an altitude of around 1 000m, there is much to get excited about: the phenomenal view of the Emmental and the Alps ?either from the modern, elegant restaurant with its large window front or the magnificent terrace ?is complemented by good food with a regional and seasonal focus. For a cheaper but equally indulgent alternative, head to Beiz. The terrific wine selection boasts around 800 different options. Chic guestrooms are available in the adjoining boutique hotel.

Name: Chez Philippe
Description: Philippe Chevrier from the Domaine de Châteauvieux is the brains behind this huge restaurant inspired by New York-style steakhouses. Relaxed atmosphere, meats sourced from the renowned Boucherie du Molard, fish caught by small-scale fishermen, dishes cooked over a wood fire, a truly authentic cheesecake and an expansive wine list. A real favourite!

Name: Château de Pleujouse
Description: Perched on a rocky spur, this 10C fortress overlooks the surrounding countryside. A duo of chefs delights diners with organic and regional ingredients; bread, gratins and rice pudding are baked in the bread oven ?a truly artisanal approach, which, by drawing on produce from the terroir, takes us back to the feasts of yesteryear! A very warm welcome.

Name: Bistrot du Lion d'Or
Description: In the restaurant of this hotel dating from 1750, the team offers - in a friendly and relaxed atmosphere - delicious French cuisine with seasonal products, such as artichoke, smoked whitefish from the nearby lakes and buckwheat, or pan-fried sweetbreads, morels and asparagus. The well-curated wine list is also worthy of your attention. In fine weather, the pleasant terrace to the rear of the building is a peaceful little haven for diners.

Name: L'Agape
Description: This lovely old-school bistro ticks all the boxes when it comes to good vibes. It has been tastefully refurbished to showcase features such as its original tiling, wooden banquette seating, mirrors on the walls, a large chandelier fashioned out of old copper pans and a small service counter. As for the food, chef Clément Thellier has designed a short, savvy menu that makes your mouth water with its well-crafted and beautifully presented dishes: sweetbreads en barigoule, bacon crisps, split peas with bacon; beef tenderloin, toasted bread, pan-fried foie gras, mini vegetables and potato emulsion; poached and glazed pineapple, toasted pain d'épices and rum ice cream. A lovely dining experience at a reasonable price ?not to be sniffed at in Geneva!

Name: Ivy 23
Description: A lively restaurant and bar in the historical centre of Carouge. Whitewashed brick walls and 1930s-style decoration, such as lamps and old posters evocative of the prohibition era in the US, make for a distinctive atmosphere, underscored by a soundtrack of jazz/swing sounds. They serve modern and seasonal food with a French twist. Pleasant little terrace in the courtyard to the rear.

Name: Stadthaus
Description: In the restaurant of the grand Hotel Stadthaus, you can either dine in the casual Stadtcafé or the elegant La Pendule; the same flavoursome cuisine is served in both areas. There are classics such as cordon bleu, vegetarian dishes and a bistro set menu ?an ambitious gourmet set menu is also served on Thu-Sat evenings. The range of wines available by the glass and bottles is also impressive.

Name: Auberge Communale
Description: This rather inconspicuous Auberge is located in a small village set slightly above Vevey. Run by the Konrad family, it not only has guestrooms for overnight stays, but also serves really good food! Whether eating in the refined modern space or on the pretty terrace, choose between delicious bistro dishes and the "Gastro" set menu. It is always tasty and prices remain very competitive.

Name: Bären
Description: At this rather grand establishment with two dining spaces, Gaststube and GnussStube, the wide-ranging menu includes simpler dishes and more sophisticated fare, plus vegetarian options. You can dine à la carte or opt for a set menu ?the fine-dining set menu ("MundArt"), has to be ordered in advance. At lunchtime, a reduced à la carte selection and daily specials are available. Ingredients are sourced as locally as possible. There is a decent wine list with a focus on Swiss labels. The waitstaff are friendly, attentive and well trained.

Name: Zum Wilde Maa
Description: In the Matthäus quarter in Kleinbasel, this smart building on a corner plot has housed a restaurant since 1910. The owners, who have already made a name for themselves in the city with their previous restaurant, Bonvivant, serve flavoursome, unpretentious cuisine based on good ingredients. In the evening, you can choose the "Chef's Menu", a set menu comprising three, four or six courses, or order à la carte. At lunchtime there is a shorter menu. The ambience is pleasingly laid back and neighbourly, with a charming vine-kissed terrace in front of the restaurant. Reasonable prices, very friendly service and good wine recommendations.

Name: SALZANO
Description: The restaurant of this family-run chalet hotel presents an interesting concept in a friendly atmosphere. Classic cuisine is on offer at lunchtime and in the evening; in addition there is a lunch deal and a "close-to-nature" gourmet set menu every evening from Tue to Sat. The top-notch ingredients are almost exclusively sourced locally, many of them harvested by the chefs themselves.

Name: Ô Bois Sauvage
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Situated at an elevation of approximately 1 500m above sea level, this restaurant is just 250m away from Hérémence's high-speed lift station. The breathtaking mountain vistas are undoubtedly one of the restaurant's standout features, best enjoyed on the fantastic terrace. Alternatively, you can savour the view from indoors, where the atmosphere is modern and relaxed. Incidentally, the numerous decorative works of art are available for purchase. This restaurant's commitment to sustainability and its strong attachment to the region are evident in the selection of produce, such as fillet of Swiss grass-fed ox or cheese. The short wine list features labels from the region.

Name: Lokal
Description: This pleasantly laid-back and casual establishment occupies a corner plot by the canal-like Suze River at the border between Neustadt-Süd and Neustadt-Nord. Guided by the motto "gemütlich - ehrlich - herzlich" (cosy - honest - cordial), Lokal is a cross between a restaurant and a bar with a relaxed atmosphere; in fine weather, the gorgeous terrace beckons. The cuisine is modern and international, with the focus squarely laid on regional and seasonal ingredients. In addition to the à la carte selection, there is a carte blanche surprise menu comprising four or five courses. Decent wine list, friendly and professional service. You are also welcome to just drop in for a glass of wine, a beer or a cocktail.

Name: Njørd café
Description: Njørd Café is a spin-off of the restaurant Njørden. It serves fresh and seasonal Scandinavian and Swiss cuisine in a modern, Nordic atmosphere. Breakfast and brunch is also available at the weekend. To the rear of the building, there is a charming terrace planted with herbs and flowers. Hotel Hemma has a number of pleasant guestrooms.

Name: Bazaar
Description: At this restaurant in the chic Alpine CERVO Mountain Resort ?which commands a great panoramic view ?you are whisked away to an exotic and predominantly vegetarian world of flavours, ranging from Arabic to Chinese specialities, from Lebanese flatbread (manakish) and pistachio baklava to dim sum and much more. In keeping with its name, this place has a lively and friendly atmosphere, to which original and highly disparate decorative details also contribute.

Name: Le Lab by Adel & Niko
Address: Route de la Crottaz 5, Corseaux, 1802, Switzerland
Description: The house is located directly behind the boundary between Vevey and Corseaux. The ground floor houses a cookery school, while the basement houses the restaurant itself. The ambience is modern, with warm colours (the burgundy-red wall catches the eye), discreet decoration for the wine and a long counter. The charming owner, who runs the restaurant with her husband, adds to the ambience. Interesting dishes come out of the kitchen: uncomplicated, tasty and served in an almost one-size-fits-all format, at a reasonable price. Delicious, for example, "Wild prawns, green curry, Thai vegetables, coconut milk". The small terrace is also very pleasant.

Name: Grey Gardens
Description: Everyone is drawn to restaurateur Jen Agg's hip, boisterous venue, which manages both style and substance with confident charm. An excellent wine list is paired with a small, mercurial menu that punches above its weight class, where ostensibly simple, unassuming dishes turn out to be heavy hitters. Raw items like oysters and crudos are commendably fresh, and the house-made pastas are real showstoppers. Take as an example hearty spaghetti twirled with a mackerel-based twist on XO sauce, lifted with fermented chili puree and crunchy potato crumbs: beguilingly complex, indulgent and umami-packed. The menu might only offer a duo of desserts, but they’re just as inspired as the rest—in other words, not to be missed.

Name: The Ace
Description: Set your alarm. This is cooking worth waking up for. Indeed, brunch usually isn’t a kitchen’s brightest moment, but that is far from true at The Ace, a slim vintage diner that first opened in the 1950s. Husband-and-wife team Rafael Badell and Maggie Stackpole are the latest to hold the keys to this historic haunt, and it’s during the day when the cooking really sings. What’s that smell? It’s probably expert wedges of house-made sourdough sizzling away on the griddle. Start with the duck confit and wild mushroom toast crowned with softly poached eggs.
