For an appetiser, we recommend the shrimp tempura, which uses batter mixed with marunuki.

Name: toi Inshokuten
Description: The ‘toi?in the name of the restaurant is an acronym for ‘trip of imagination? The destination is India, and the mission is to provide traditional Indian dishes. There are meat, fish and vegetable curries. They do things Thali teishoku-style and serve several kinds of curry of your choice on a large plate. You can also add individual items like pakora, an Indian-style tempura.

Name: Menya Ittoku
Description: Every time there’s an order, you hear the sound of the motorized slicer. It cuts Italian pork fillets thin like uncured ham. The signature dish is salt-flavoured ramen. The dashi is made from whole chicken, kombu and katsuo-bushi, and the glutamic acid and inosinic acid produce a synergy of umami. If you order ‘shimemeshi? which is rice with chicken, to go with the remaining soup, it’s like you’re having chicken zosui.

Name: A VOTRE SANTE
Description: Chef Yaoki Tsujimura says that he wants to communicate the sights he saw in France. He recalls memories from training in southern France in the 1990s. Everything from gougère to bread and small confectionery is freshly baked. Dishes made using a generous amount of butter and garnished with sauce have a nostalgic French aroma to them. When you hear the word ‘santé, it means a fun time is about to begin.

Name: Psomi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Brunch,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Owned and run by second-generation Greek-American, Christina Theofilos, this daytime eatery and bakery epitomizes warmth and comfort. Strangers become friends in no time, noshing on breakfast and lunch during the week and brunch on weekends. The menu is laced with Greek items ranging from flavorful and tender octopus ceviche to house-made dolmades that display an added level of care. The farm to your table sandwich is layered with avocado, pickled green tomato, shaved jicama, sprouts and whipped feta. Of course, with a name that translates to bread, there must be baked goods and you'll find it all here. Don't skimp on dessert and order bougatsa, baklava or baklava coffee cake (an impressive marriage of the two).

Name: Jaguar Sun
Description: The group behind Jaguar Sun has had a busy few years, opening, closing, reconcepting and relocating at various points. Steady, though, is the sheer enthusiasm with which the city has embraced each and every development. Indeed, this local favorite cooks as well as it shakes, offering a winning combination of excellent house-made pastas and balanced, creative cocktails. Warm Parker House rolls and Caesar salads stacked to the sky are opening acts to an umami-packed mushroom tagliatelle or spicy strozzapreti with plump mussels, ‘nduja and breadcrumbs. And to drink? A refreshing Sunday Driver balancing tequila, green apple and manzanilla kicks off the night perfectly. As an added bonus, a warm, personal staff makes everyone feel like a regular.

Name: Lucali
Description: Although it's located in sunny South Beach, Lucali exudes a charming rusticity that calls to mind its original Brooklyn locale. The greenery-adorned, umbrella-shaped sidewalk is ultra-tempting; or beat the heat and find a seat inside—outfitted with plank floors and chunky tables. The wood-fired brick oven at the rear is sure to stoke the appetite. The 20-inch pizza is lusciously charred and sports a light crust crowned with fresh pomodoro sauce, a combination of cheeses and fragrant sprigs of basil. Various toppings are offered to embellish the pie, and one may even choose to have just half dressed with say, meatball crumbles and green chili slivers. The bar, which opens in the evening, offers diners the option of a 12-inch pie.

Name: Chug's Diner
Description: What started out as a small café has grown overnight into this full-scale, Coconut Grove essential. All credit is due to Chef Michael Beltran who runs this terrific Cuban diner, fitted with dangling greenery and cozy booths. Truly, if this kitchen were a car, it would break the speed limit, as the team hurries about—opening early, closing late and cooking with panache.One could make a meal out of the oxtail ajiaco alone, a satisfying Colombian stew that cures all ills. But then you wouldn’t have room for the several towering sandwiches, served on fluffy Cuban bread. No meal is complete without at least one of their guava- and cream-cheese pastelitos. Their warm, flaky pastry alone will guarantee a return visit.

Name: Ghee Indian Kitchen
Description: In the thick of a shopping mall, find Niven Patel’s smash-hit restaurant. Warehouse floors, mango wood tables and a wall lined with rows upon rows of spice jars are bound to put diners in the mood for the team's smartly spiced food.The kitchen takes no cues from its suburban locale; in fact, it features a tight menu of flavor-packed dishes made with ingredients sourced from Chef Patel’s own farm. Ghost pepper-cheddar seed naan is a fiery, puff-pastry-like riff, while yellowfin tuna bhel with avocado makes for a zesty first course. Kerala lamb with tomato and coconut is a richly satisfying effort with layered notes, soft basmati rice and meltingly tender meat.

Name: Phuc Yea
Description: There is nothing subtle about Chef Cesar Zapata and Ani Meinhold’s raucous Vietnamese mash-up in the MiMo district. A concrete compound wrapped in glowing red lanterns, the restaurant is practically a club with its sultry lighting, cavernous interior and full-time DJ. Yet, none of it gets in the way of the food, which is boldly seasoned and generously portioned. Stacks of crispy imperial rolls wrapped with mint and tangles of garlic-butter egg noodles aggressively charred on a wok are solid starting points. Everything is meant to be shared, especially the pho, which arrives in a cauldron packed with herbs, rice noodles and a meltingly tender slab of hickory-smoked short rib.All the while, a nearby table might launch into song. You are welcome to join the fun.

Name: Strand
Description: Husband-and-wife duo Alda and Joe Rees are behind this corner spot nestled within an Art Deco building. Its menu, displayed on the front windows, invites passersby inside to a space that may be short on real estate but utterly captivates with mint-green walls and Mason jars that hang above the glossy tiled bar.The seasonal American menu brims with nostalgic Southern inspiration, and presentations are dialed back to let ingredients shine. From local tomatoes to fresh citrus, dishes exude a homey sense. To wit: chilled shrimp is a wonderful contrast against hot fried green tomatoes, while cobia with mustard sauce and Carolina gold rice requires little augmentation. Close out with a citrus olive oil cake along with a sip from the worthy wine list.

Name: The Ravenous Pig
Description: This Winter Park modern gastropub came to be thanks to the vision of noted restaurateurs, James and Julie Petrakis. Housed right beside their eponymous brewery, the space exudes a moody, industrial vibe by way of charcoal hues, rustic wood accents and a gray ceiling marked by exposed ductwork. The open kitchen on the left has frosted glass panels that add a bit of mystery to the culinary proceedings.Chef Clay Miller's menu is a bona fide study of classic pub fare with creative Southern spins—to wit, ranchero sauce-dressed pork burnt ends over cornbread pudding or cured pastrami brisket with pickled cabbage purée and cauliflower giardiniera. The vegetable-forward melon, cucumber and farmer's cheese combo is in fact a rather complex denouement.

Name: Z Asian
Description: Simple on the outside, this casual gem is beloved for its distinctively bold dishes and thoughtful design. As you enter, you'll notice their name emblazoned on a black wall. Other stylish details include hanging lanterns, ceiling fans and artwork throughout. The aura is Southeast Asian, not unlike the focused Vietnamese cooking.Dishes are flavorful, bursting with nuance and balance. Behold the simple yet sublime dia nho like sautéed bok choy with crispy garlic; and bánh xèo, fried crêpe with shrimp, thinly sliced pork and a tangy fish sauce. Ph?tái brings nostalgia to the forefront with that classic beef broth, afloat with rice noodles, eye of round steak and scallions. Donning a host of aromatics (bean sprouts, lime and jalapeño), it is a riot of flavor.

Name: DOYA
Description: This Wynwood operation is particularly beloved, thanks to its lush patio. Inside, the room is vast, open, light-filled and designed with every type of diner in mind. Seats facing the open kitchen offer an intimate experience, while couples may prefer tables armed with powder-blue velvet chairs for a bit of romance.The cuisine bills itself as modern Aegean, and you will discover elements from Greece and Turkey’s coastal regions. Nibble on a refreshing fig salad with greens tossed in a hazelnut-pomegranate dressing before moving on to sea beans with garlic yogurt or some of the most delicate manti in this part of town. Flavors are both correct and comforting, but a scoop of raki ice cream will leave you supremely happy.

Name: Bombay Street Kitchen
Address: 6215 S. Orange Blossom Trl., Orlando, 32809, USA
Description: Amit Kumar's fresh and fine outlet sports a welcoming exterior and cheerful interior, done up with orange booths and bright accents. Diners may settle in for a range of enjoyable, well-prepared South Indian small plates which form the nucleus of this tempting menu.The street special dosa is a departure from the norm, here stuffed with potato, cabbage, paneer and red onion, and served with coconut sambal and curry gravy for dipping.Vegetarians will thrill to the sight of meat-free specials, like kathal masaledar, featuring tender chunks of jackfruit in a zesty tomato-and-onion masala; while tandoor options like hara teekha murg tikka (skewers of white meat chicken marinated in a herbal mixture) is grilled to luscious, crisp perfection.

Name: Otto's High Dive
Description: This tiny but oh-so-sweet space recalls the charm of Old Florida with its whitewashed brick walls and white tile floors. Billed as a neighborhood rum bar, Otto's High Dive is on point at every turn, from the genuine service to the unfussy but well-executed food. The kitchen delivers a concise edit of Floridian/Cuban fare with oodles of tropical elements. Begin with oysters before moving on to an array of cold and hot plates ranging from a shrimp cocktail that's all grown up with its thick "Bloody Mary" sauce to chicken mojo and ropa vieja with sides like rice and beans. Cinnamon bread pudding topped with a delightfully tangy cream cheese whip is a memorable sign-off. Rum is all around, from the Cuba Libre on tap to the daiquiris available by the pitcher.

Name: Norigami
Address: 426 W. Plant St., Winter Garden, 34787, USA
Description: There are just eight seats at this tiny but mighty spot at the Plant Street Market from Chef David Tsan. This is sushi done in a casual "choose your own adventure" style, as guests pick from various cuts of fish and shellfish and then select as either nigiri, sashimi aburi or temaki. It's all fun and may include winning plates like popcorn hamachi, a surprising dish with avocado puree, dots of whipped cream cheese and finished with popped sorghum. Shima aji displays its buttery best as nigiri, and it's all about the sear on the avocado served with a sweet kabayaki sauce. Good products and solid techniques are on display in the hand rolls, where fillings like shredded blue crab make an impression. Can't choose? The well-priced, ten-piece omakase is a nice option.

Name: Papa Llama
Description: Don't be fooled by its modest surrounds, as the interior is modern and cool. Leather chairs are especially inviting, and tables offer a view of the gleaming kitchen.Husband-and-wife duo Kevin and Maria Ruiz prepare modern Peruvian cuisine full of bright ingredients with a bit of polish, and the multicourse tasting menu is an approachable (and affordable) way to sample their sincere cooking. Nigiri kicks off the meal with a smart nod to the Peruvian tradition of Japanese fusion, delivering dialed-in flavors with confidence. Bok choy is elevated with bold, contrasting textures, while chicken thigh roulade with aji amarillo aioli is simply spectacular. For dessert, sweet potato donuts over a blueberry compote seal the deal. The natural wine program is impressive.

Name: Sanguich De Miami
Description: What started out as a little shipping container in 2017 has morphed into this brick-and-mortar hot spot in Little Havana. There is almost always a line of diners vying to squeeze into the narrow space, designed with emerald-green walls, vibrant tile and sleek brass trimmings.Everyone comes for the same thing: a superb Cuban sandwich featuring pork butt that's been marinated for a week in garlic and spices, then pressed between expertly grilled slices of house-made bread. A heavier but equally flavorful alternative is the lechon, starring tender shredded pork slathered in garlic-cilantro aïoli. Thick baton-shaped croquetas also impress if you need a pre-sandwich bite.

Name: El Turco
Description: This charming café, sheltered within a shopping enclave, hosts a loyal following at outdoor tables shaded by age-old oak trees. Inside, Chef Vural Aydoğan and team work out of a glass-walled kiosk, dressed up with blue-and-white tile as well as neatly lined cans and bottles.The menu is an enticing offering of breakfast fare, featuring organic eggs that support Turkish mezzes, manti and savory pastries like borek. Baked in-house, this burnished coil is stuffed with spinach, sprinkled with sesame seeds and garnished with cherry tomatoes. The izmir kofte arrives in a mini ceramic dish filled with beef meatballs baked in tomato sauce alongside batons of roasted potato. A single charred jalapeño adds the perfect bit of heat to each mouthful.

Name: Michael's Genuine
Description: This Design District pioneer from Chef Michael Schwartz is as popular now as it was when it first debuted almost 15 years ago. A well-heeled crowd flocks here, but whether it's a requisite respite from boutique hopping, a spot to catch up with friends or a meal to close a business deal, this dining delight is for everyone. The courtyard is a lovely place to linger, thanks to its lush greenery, fans and heat lamps (when necessary). The interior space features concrete flooring and an inviting bar. A jazz playlist adds to the upbeat and conversation-filled air.The menu focuses on unfussy yet skillful cooking. Staples like pizza, house-made pasta, crudo, pan-roasted chicken and wood oven-roasted fish keep fans returning time and time again.

Name: Gorkhali Kitchen
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: Take the short drive from downtown for a taste of Himalayan cuisine at Gorkhali Kitchen. The mirrored glass exterior means the interior is kept a secret until you're through the door but come inside to experience this place's warm hospitality.The menu is large with a Nepalese focus along with some Indian elements. Of course, there must be momo, those iconic Nepalese dumplings that are seared, pan-fried or even in jhol (soup). Chili momo filled with chicken is tossed in a fiery sauce that's not for the faint of heart. Sweet at the start, the heat builds and then finishes with a very spicy kick—perfect for heat seekers. Chicken is a popular protein that appears often on the menu, but don't shy away from the goat specialties. They're falling-off-the-bone tender and savory.

Name: Zitz Sum
Description: There are countless rules and traditions when it comes to cooking, but don’t tell Pablo Zitzmann, whose inspiration stretches from China to Japan to Italy. Following the wild success of his dumpling pop-up, the Colombian chef found a home on the ground floor of an admittedly stoic office building in Coral Gables. It is the last place you would expect to find ba filled with Niman ranch short rib topped with habanada sofrito and chili crunch, or a thick wedge of charred cabbage capped with melted parmesan cheese and set in a pool of Fresno chili butter.The cooking is original and gutsy; and plates like the shrimp har gow with lime and a tamarind-black garlic chutney exemplify a kind of fearless, borderless ethos that, in the end, makes delicious sense.

Name: Isan Zaap
Description: Orlando's Thai restaurants typically dole out southern curry dishes and the ubiquitous pad Thai, but Isan Zaap strays from the pack with its gaze trained exclusively on northeast Thai cuisine with Laotian overlaps. There is an impressive level of attention to detail and a nice balance of spice and fermented flavors, and though impeccably executed curry makes an appearance, there's also an entire section dedicated to som tums that can be topped with fermented crab or fermented pork sausage. House specialties are a hit, as in the unique whole fish larb, cut into bite-sized pieces, tossed with toasted rice powder and fried to a crisp, and crowned with shaved red onion herbs tossed in a sweet yet spicy sauce. For dessert, dig in to durian sticky rice - if you dare.

Name: Mandolin Aegean Bistro
Description: Founded by husband and wife, Ahmet Erkaya and Anastasia Koutsioukis, this charming bistro welcomes diners with a blue door and whitewashed façade. The space features wood tables, lacquered chairs and an outdoor bar, although the focus is on its courtyard dining area, enhanced with mature trees, orchids and electric fans. This mezze-heavy menu may unveil a creamy slab of baked feta with diced tomato, smoked chili flakes and Turkish peppers. Slices of house-baked bread, stuffed into small brown paper bags, accompany the excellent small plates. Salads, a grilled catch-of-the-day sandwich and larger items, like moussaka, are equally beloved.A wedge of honey pie with a salted shortbread crust is highly recommended, and pairs delightfully with that Turkish coffee.

Name: Hometown Barbecue Miami
Description: From Austin, Texas to Brooklyn, New York, Pitmaster Bill Durney brings his signature barbecue to Magic City. Just like the original location, Durney has built this warehouse-chic space amidst a sea of industry in the Miami Produce Center, where trucks and moving pallets roam the streets. The sheer scale of the space—open kitchen on one side, a long bar on the other, tables in between and a patio just beyond—is something to behold.A hulking beef rib crusted with salt and black pepper, as well as melting, charred slices of brisket are essential orders that have few equals outside of Texas. Satisfying sides, like Frito pie, plancha broccoli and charred summer corn, round out the meal. The food here arrives almost as quickly as it’s ordered, so come hungry.

Name: Rosie's
Description: Husband-and-wife team Chef Akino and Jamila West have been on a journey. What started out as a wildly popular brunch pop-up in Overtown and later evolved into an outdoor-only brick-and-mortar in Little River has now found a permanent indoor setup. The menu remains notably Southern at heart and covers a generous amount of ground. Deviled eggs with chicharrones, biscuits in guanciale gravy and fluffy banana pancakes with vanilla custard are primo brunch favorites. Heartier hits, like fried hot chicken and waffles or a generous fried fish and grits with collard greens, satiate larger appetites. All of it photographs as well as it eats. Tickets to occasional dinner parties sell out quickly and signal more good things to come from this successful duo.

Name: Lung Yai Thai Tapas
Description: You could drive down the street a dozen times and still overlook this intimate little nook that hides in plain sight. Little Havana is certainly an unexpected place to find one of the city’s hottest Thai kitchens, but the long waits are an indication (no reservations) that Chef/owner Veenuthri Trisransri knows what he’s doing. On a menu that mixes typical standbys with Northern specialties, begin with an order of homemade dumplings with a pork or shrimp filling, served steamed or fried. Khao Soi, a coconut-based curry with your choice of protein, bobs with egg noodles and has a rich, creamy profile without too much heat. Tables, plates and even the place itself is small, so order ambitiously and be prepared for a kitchen that sends out dishes faster than you can finish them.

Name: Swine & Sons
Address: 1280 N. Orange Ave., Winter Park, 32789, USA
Description: Alexia Gawlak is behind this sandwich concept nestled within the Winter Park Social House, a collaborative, multi-concept space that buzzes with an industrial farmhouse chic. There are tables indoor and out, but you'll need to order at the counter. The menu is compact but plenty enticing with a line-up of comfort food classics. Tuck into the the likes of a fried chicken sandwich done Thai-style, as well as other sandwiches such as pastrami melts and Cubans, as well as burgers. Finish the meal with a soft chocolate chip cookie that has a hearty amount of flaky salt for good measure.

Name: Bachour
Description: Open since 2019, an arch of roses marks the entrance to this airy and inviting bijou. A perch at the counter in the back offers diners a front-row view of the glass-enclosed bakery (and bakers in action). While the ambience is appealingly industrial and spartan with exposed ductwork, cement floors and natural hues, those shelves of brightly colored tarts and pastries form the focus of the space.A meal here may commence with ham croquettes and garlic aïoli; tailed by a seafood causa salad with aji amarillo-infused potato purée. When hankering for pasta, there's no going wrong with fettucine pomodoro. Be sure to take home a box or two of their wonderful sweets, like the mango-passion fruit macarons or a slice of lemon pie.

Name: Taste of Chengdu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus
Description: A long-standing restaurant in the Orlando area, Taste of Chengdu promises exactly that, as the expansive menu is singularly focused on Sichuan specialties. Chef Xiong “Tiger?Tang shows restraint in his use of spices, instead opting for depth and balance; while classics like mapo tofu are given a nuanced nudge. Heat-seekers will want to dig right in to the Sichuan cold noodles, a ramped up iteration that replaces the traditional thick sauce with a lighter vinegar-based, sesame-laced zing. More mellow dishes include a delicate white fish in a green pepper broth mixed with mushrooms, cucumber and baby bok choy, or a sautéed cabbage tossed in touch of oil with garlic and scallions that has just the right amount of crunch.

Name: Rooster and the Till
Description: It's a low-key spot with a contemporary feel. The bar is central and wraps around an open kitchen, so grab a seat at the counter for the best view. Between the lively tunes and buzzy staff, the aura is anything but stuffy. The plates follow suit—freewheeling, frequently changing and shareable with elements from SE Asia, Latin America and the Levant. Yet, nothing seems out of place, as in sumac-flecked cauliflower with whipped goat's milk feta and falafel-spiced dukkah. Fried cobia collar with nuoc cham boasts a cultish following. Such seductive textures and explosive flavors continue in full force in a dessert of black sesame ice cream with pineapple-cashew jam and Thai tea caramel.The tasting menu, though pricier, is a worthy splurge.

Name: Zak The Baker
Description: This all-day operation is the brainchild of baker Zak Stern. He grew up in Miami, then apprenticed at a number of organic farms in Sweden, France and Israel before returning to his hometown to fulfill his culinary dreams. The crux of his menu is baked, as in breads and pastries, along with sandwiches, soups and salads. The "BLT" features salmon bacon, lettuce and tomato all stuffed into a deliciously flaky croissant. For something sweet, get the flourless dark chocolate cookie bursting with whole toasted almonds.This kosher bakery and café is located in hip Wynwood and welcomes diners with a color-splashed façade.

Name: Domu
Description: Enter Chef/owner Sean "Sonny" Nguyen's trendy ramen haven and you'll find two rooms dressed with concrete floors, a marble bar and wood panels set aglow by a starburst light fixture. The second room cradles the bulk of the crowd. As the name illustrates, this chef makes his culinary "dreams come true" by dint of a classic-meets-creative menu. Beyond the small plates lies the star item—ramen. Creations, like the Ritchie Rich and Curry, are full of bold, memorable flavors and certainly worth a slurp. Tokyo ramen with shoyu chicken broth, fried chicken thigh and duck fat is a sensory feat. Couple it with blistered shishitos for a delicious touch—and bit of crunch.It's all in the family here as sib Tori Tori flaunts a similarly creative izakaya menu.

Name: Tinta y Cafe
Address: 1315 Ponce De Leon Blvd., Coral Gables, 33134, USA
Description: Coral Gables is home to this original operation, happily christened with a name that translates to ink and coffee. Unsurprisingly, there are artfully arranged bookshelves that line its glass façade, while the interior design most certainly resembles that of a coffee shop. Guests may order at the window, grab a table either inside or out under a cluster of palm trees, and settle in for a litany of Cuban delicacies.The furniture is mid-century modern, but the sandwich-focused menu is as classic and comforting as ever. Deep-fried croquetas are not to be missed; and the pavo real with turkey and cream cheese is nothing if not satisfying. Our allegiance, however, is with the patria (their take on the Cubano with pork, ham, mustard and pickles.)

Name: La Natural
Description: You wouldn’t think to make reservations for a pizza place in Little River, but think again. The crowds can be relentless at this popular hangout, which feels rather like an underground party by way of concrete floors and dim lighting.Creative toppings like za’atar and Sichuan peppercorns sing on stunning, picture-perfect pies zealously charred in a wood-burning oven hiding behind the bar. We’re partial to the classic burrata and basil pie, which arrives puffy and pillowy thanks to the signature crust that's cold-fermented for 48 hours. An astute selection of starters (try the papaya with kumquat) and one of the city’s longest lists for natural wines only add to the appeal of this essential pizzeria. A personable staff keeps a close watch on every table.

Name: Bistro de Olliemölle
Description: This charmingly old-fashioned bistro, set in an old watermill, is a remarkable place. The water wheel still turns occasionally but the real treat is the idyllic terrace next to the water! Cooking is, in the main, traditional and generous, but you can also find some more contemporary dishes which demonstrate the chef’s experience.

Name: Blauw
Description: Tradition, a street food influence, authenticity and purity are the words that best sum up this popular restaurant, which showcases the full array of Indonesian cuisine. The rijsttafel (a medley of dishes with rice ?also available in a vegan version) provides an excellent opportunity to discover the chef's talent for seasoning and balancing intense flavours. From the succulence of the lamb, the distinctly nutty flavour of the peanut sauce and the delicate spiciness of the gado gado, you can see that this is a chef who knows how to combine generosity with subtlety. Be sure to try the roast goat meat as well!

Name: Mijn Streek
Description: Cold or hot dishes, whether to share with your dining companions or go solo, to opt for one of the many vegetarian options or plump for fish or meat?In this convivial brasserie on the fifth floor of the Glaspaleis, there are plenty of choices to be made. Brace yourself for an international culinary adventure that takes in ceviche, ravioli, strawberry Romanoff and many other mouth-watering treats. A visit to the Schunck Museum in the same building is a must if you visit the area.

Name: Escobar
Description: This colourful restaurant has a real holiday feel, with its lively Spanish ambience and friendly, enthusiastic staff. The menu features a wide selection of dishes, from well-known tapas to more unusual and less conventional options. An excellent restaurant in which to enjoy a Spanish meal with friends.

Name: Harry's
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: This luxury brasserie is as cosmopolitan as it is vibrant. French flair characterises both the ambience and the cuisine. On the menu, international flavours and vegetarian options show that the chefs are keeping up with the times, but not at the expense of the golden rules of superior brasserie cuisine. The kitchen garden is a manifestation of their sustainable approach (more details on the website). Creative, local, seasonal: Harry's ticks all the boxes!

Name: Zilt & Zoet
Description: The refreshed interior of this countryside villa combines the modern and the vintage, and is a great example of cosy Dutch ambience. The extensive set menu (a choice of three, four or five courses) is impressive. It is created by a chef who creates modern, lavish dishes from largely seasonal produce.

Name: Hofstede de Blaak
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The charm of this authentic English country house (1907), the classic half-timbering and elegant details, the peaceful surroundings ?it is hard not to be moved by this setting. The chef loves working with fine ingredients and accentuates their finesse with contemporary seasonings. He is fond of combining diverse flavours to create elegant nuances. Be sure to try the excellent set menu.

Name: De Voorburcht
Description: Step across the moat, traverse the medieval fortifications and look for the building with a sloping wall. This place certainly makes a magical first impression! Inside, this historical setting has been given a splendid makeover. Here, familiar ingredients are used to produce creative dishes. For instance, the chef combines skate and scallops in a dish reminiscent of a choucroute garnie. This is carefully considered and rich cuisine. At De Voorburcht, new life is breathed into classic fine dining.

Name: Wils Bakery Café
Description: This laid-back establishment has the feel of a traditional bistro but with a Scandinavian twist. As you walk in, you will see the baker kneading dough and the odd customer coming to buy bread. Make no mistake, though: this place has a great menu of well-crafted dishes. This Amsterdam version of a French bistro honours classics such as snails in herb butter, wood pigeon pithivier, foie gras and tarte Tatin. It is rich in flavour, generous and inspired, and the fantastic value for money is an added bonus.

Name: Nova
Description: Located on the edge of the Bergse Bos forest, and featuring a romantic terrace, a pontoon on the River Rotte and a cosy interior ambience, Nova is a delightful restaurant where chef Martin Vaandrager offers guests a menu with a varied choice. His contemporary cuisine is teeming with flavours, combining amusing ideas and impressive expertise in his dishes. A fine example of value for money?and pleasure!

Name: L'Auberge de Neercanne
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Come for lunch beneath the vaults of Château Neercanne's old chapel ?you cannot fail to be impressed by this charming historical setting that has been given a stylish makeover. The terrace affords spectacular views. Chef Remmen serves up his own modern spin on classic dishes, with a focus on quality. Delicious produce is sourced from the region and their own kitchen garden. Cod poached in butter with a delicate white wine sauce, a traditionally prepared rich tarte Tatin: food lovers will be in seventh heaven.

Name: De Uitkijk
Description: With its magnificent natural setting, a lavender-filled terrace with a southern feel, and a restaurant with a country estate atmosphere, De Uitkijk offers a winning combination. Guests can watch the seasons change on the plate, with herbs from the chef's own garden. The elaborate dishes here are full of fresh flavour and boast lots of variety.

Name: Herberg Stadt Stevenswaert
Description: Marcus Schmidt’s inn sits on a picturesque tree-lined square, at the centre of an island flanked by a canal and the River Maas. The menu changes frequently, with seasonal produce ?including vegetables from their garden ?harmoniously coming together in creative dishes; the desserts in particular are delicious. The restaurant also offers a great selection of German wines.

Name: Kasteel Elsloo
Description: Dining in a castle makes for a special experience. The surrounding natural beauty and centuries-old arcades beneath which guests take their seats cannot fail to impress. This fabulous setting inspires the chef to work with respect for the region, the seasons and sustainability. French and Mediterranean flavours dominate the appealingly updated menu, which now features occasionally innovative dishes. Wine lovers will delight in the enticing selection of wines sold by the glass.

Name: De Grote Frederik Bistro
Description: In this cosy local bistro you immediately get the feeling that guests always come first. This is typified by the excellent front-of-house hospitality of host Marjon, who is delighted to offer advice on a superb selection of wines to accompany chef Arnejan’s unique dishes, which are playful and unpretentious, yet which feature wonderful and surprising flavours.

Name: Bouwkunde
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: A dining experience at Bouwkunde is one to be savoured. After being welcomed by the cordial hostess, you can soak up the warm atmosphere of this charming restaurant. Diners will see that wine plays an important role here. The ostensibly classic and simple cuisine proves to be full of surprises and bold flavours. For example, a beurre blanc with a judicious squeeze of lemon enhances a beautifully translucent fillet of skrei. And all at great value for money!

Name: De Beleving
Description: This convivial brasserie boasts all the attractions that you come to expect from a true Bib Gourmand address: a varied choice of enticing yet unfussy dishes that are generous and tasty. The chef does allow himself a few modern touches in his textures, although his cuisine is firmly focused on top-quality traditional ingredients such as haddock and Iberico pork presa. A splendid experience!

Name: Chef aan de Werf
Description: Enjoy a local beer as an aperitif before discovering Charly de Wijs' selection of international dishes, which feature local, subtly flavoured and sustainably sourced ingredients and draw on inspirations from around the globe. His winning combinations include options such as harissa with a fillet of fish, flatbread with carrots, tahini and feta. Just bear in mind that the chef serves up very generous portions! Housed in an old industrial building, this lively restaurant with its vintage decor is bound to have you coming back for more.

Name: Groenewoud
Description: A few authentic decorative features remind us that despite its comfortable and even trendy feel we are in one of the oldest cafés in Nijmegen. The experienced chef at the helm conjures up generous French cuisine with the occasional subtle and surprising touch. Dishes cooked to perfection, a mastery of acidic flavours, intense sauces, plus excellent value for money!

Name: Senang
Description: Chinese dragon heads and lanterns, Japanese sake boxes, photos of owners Jonnie and Thérèse Boer taken during their travels across Asia: this colourful restaurant embodies a melting pot of impressions, and that certainly goes for the food, too. The menu features dishes that are full of flavour and fresh nuances from the Near, Middle and Far East. Chicken yakitori, ceviche, ramen, wonton?This is a truly wonderful culinary adventure. Be sure to try out the generous "Senang Table"!

Name: Moustique
Description: This highly modern restaurant in the centre of Haarlem is open almost every day. Here, you’ll find an extensive menu on which the chef showcases his experience through cuisine with an Asian inspiration and modern presentation, including a choice of vegetarian dishes and plenty of intense and authentic flavours. An impressive new arrival on the city’s food scene!

Name: Bovenmeester
Description: The head teacher might have left a while ago, but it is still evident that this place used to be a school building ?even the children's coat hooks remain. Nowadays, this is a warm and welcoming restaurant with a cosy lounge area. French cuisine unveils all its generosity here. Think unctuous duck liver terrine served with toasted brioche; sea bream on a bread crust and a spicy sauce with saffron?Unbeatable value for money!

Name: Gastrobar Ster
Description: Terry Priem is a man with two faces ?on the one hand, he’s the graphic artist (aka Ster) who, using aerosol paints, decorated the dining room; on the other, he’s a chef who demonstrates his artistic creativity in bold dishes which add subtle innovations to classic favourites. Original cocktails and excellent wines complete the picture.

Name: Boompjes
Cuisine: Country cooking, Cuisine from the Marches
Description: As you enter, you pass the brasserie, where you can enjoy a casual lunch or snack. The space at the rear of the restaurant is like an oasis, with trees, plants and wood setting the tone. The terrace seamlessly merges with chef Jaap Volman's kitchen garden. An ambassador of Dutch cuisine, his cooking style is very much French-inspired, but his creative use of vegetables and fruit adds lightness and freshness . The velvety consommé with its subtle acidity accompanying the succulent pork cheeks was just as delightful as the vibrant medley of garden-fresh vegetables and herbs. What a way to showcase Dutch produce!

Name: Spandershoeve
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Spandershoeve has been showcasing traditional Indonesian cuisine since 1972. Anita Boerenkamp was the first chef in the Netherlands to put a sophisticated spin on the famous rijsttafel. Her confident take on the fiery and intricate blend of spices was remarkable. She taught Timo, her grandson, all he knows ?how to roast goat until it is succulent, how to employ soy sauce to powerful effect, and how to add texture with raw and fried onions. This welcoming neighbourhood restaurant is the perfect introduction to Indonesian generosity and hospitality.

Name: Promessa
Description: “Food is art?is the motto of this relaxed restaurant, a mantra that is evident both in the trendy decor and on the plate. Aesthetics are key here yet without neglecting flavour, with impressive creativity and a variety of influences forming the basis for cuisine that is full of unique character. The varied choice of dishes will rouse immediate interest and ensure that you won’t leave disappointed!

Name: Red Orchids
Description: If you have a hard time making decisions, we suggest you head to this intimate, trendy restaurant where the menu brings together Japanese, Chinese, Thai and Indonesian specialities. The chef always manages to add just the right dose of spices, creating dishes full of rich flavours and crisp textures. Subtle Asian cuisine at reasonable prices.

Name: Bij Mette
Description: Picturesque Linschoten is worth a visit in its own right, but be sure to look out for this beautifully converted grocery shop with its distinctive spiral staircase located a stone's throw from the leaning clock tower. This is old Dutch charm at its best! Chef-patron Carel Alberts welcomes you personally before showing off his expertise in the French classics. Wonderful local produce, intense sauces, respect for tradition: it all makes for an enjoyable culinary experience. Feel free to ask the chef about his French wine list ?he will be happy to tell you more.

Name: Landgoed de Holtweijde
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Valet parking,Wheelchair access
Description: This estate is a beautiful example of classic rural elegance, offering fine views of the surrounding meadows. The chef employs lavish preparation methods and regional produce to create delightful dishes full of strong flavours. A trip here is well worth the effort!

Name: De Watergeus
Address: Simon van Capelweg 10, Noorden, 2431 AG, Netherlands
Description: The walk alongside the canals affords a foretaste of what you can expect in this refurbished restaurant that enjoys a superb waterside location. The chef mixes classical recipes with generosity and modern textures. His culinary palette is diverse and intriguing and the formula is highly recommended. Enquire about overnight stays and boat trips (with a picnic basket) on the Nieuwkoopse Plassen.

Name: De Knip
Description: An idyllic spot on the Vliet canal with a superb view of the glistening water. The original, well-balanced dishes are equally easy on the eye, as well as being delicious and full of flavour.

Name: De Witte Gans
Description: This rustic restaurant is a favourite pit stop for walkers, cyclists and food lovers. The terrace is one of its main draws; another is the superb Bib Gourmand-awarded menu, which features local produce, nods to the East, and vegetarian options. The creative chef works his ingredients hard and prides himself on the presentation of his dishes.

Name: De Beejekurf
Description: Mathijs Jacobs is a truly ambitious chef. If he’s brought a deer by a local huntsman or freshly harvested vegetables by a local farmer, his eyes light up. Whether he decides to cook his ingredients in a salt crust, grill them on the barbecue or use them in an ice-cream, he never lacks in inspiration and the result is always delicious!

Name: Asian Glories
Description: The Peking duck that you see hanging in the kitchen are one of the highlights on the attractive menu at this restaurant, while the pancakes that accompany the dish are prepared in front of you. The culinary traditions of Canton and Szechuan are to the fore here, served in elegant yet unfussy dishes which are full of generous flavours. A real feast!

Name: Hof van Herstal
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Hof van Herstal is an elegant restaurant with a decor that does full justice to its rich history. This establishment has bags of character. Chef Martin Bruggeman takes great pride in his work, proving every day that he is a true master of his trade. He slaughters his own game (venison is a must here!) and is happy to make judicious wine recommendations. His generous sauces are the best evidence of his culinary skill.

Name: Publique
Address: Anna Paulownaplein 4, The Hague, 2518 BK, Netherlands
Description: The corner building where vintage and contemporary design merge with beautiful stained-glass windows is the place to be. This relaxed little place is popular with locals, who come for the market-fresh cuisine. Chef Plat gives vegetables (extensive vegetable menu available) pride of place in fresh dishes which he likes to give a Mediterranean twist. His choices are sometimes rather daring, but always hit the mark, like the amazing shallot and white wine vinaigrette with sweet/salty sea urchin he serves to accompany monkfish.

Name: De Basiliek
Address: Korte Houtstraat 4a, The Hague, 2511 CD, Netherlands
Description: With its trendy, lively atmosphere, colourful decor and pretty terrace at the front, De Basiliek has a decidedly convivial atmosphere. The tempting menu features fresh Mediterranean dishes full of generous flavours, with vegetables playing an important role. The chef draws on his culinary expertise to deliver exciting cuisine brimming with clever combinations. The impressive wine list proposes plenty of options by the glass and in half-bottles. Excellent value for money!

Name: Brasserie BovendeRivieren
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: From this floating brasserie, you can enjoy spectacular views of the marina, the Merwede river and the Biesbosch nature and water reserve. In this delightful setting enjoy imaginative dishes with cosmopolitan influences and typical specialities created by a skilful and enthusiastic chef.

Name: Sukade
Description: Produce from all over the world, including succade (candied citrus peel), was once traded in this monumental warehouse dating back to 1860. Today, it is incorporated into contemporary cuisine served in an impressive setting that takes full advantage of its location on Stoombootkade (grab a table on the waterfront terrace if possible!). The dishes draw on influences from around the globe; succulent poussin breast, for instance, is given a twist with Asian spices. The chef finds creative ways to put vegetables and fruit in the limelight. The lunch and finger food options are slightly simpler, the evening menu more elaborate.

Name: Vineum
FacilitiesAndServices: Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: The wine list is the heart and soul of this warm, aptly named restaurant with an intimate urban garden to the rear. Owner David van Steenderen is a top sommelier who is constantly discovering new wines, while the same quality is mirrored in the cuisine, which features attractively presented dishes full of flavour. Classic cuisine, original ideas and real expertise act as the perfect complement to the fine wines.

Name: Bistro
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: This charming bistro occupies the front room of the farm that is also home to its older Michelin-starred sibling De Gieser Wildeman. The cuisine and name are perfectly matched: traditional, generous and quite simply delicious. One of the highlights on the menu is the crispy duck leg with cabbage. The attractive prices here are as tempting as the cooking!

Name: Le Vieux Jean
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: Chef Robert-Jan Polman produces classic cuisine his way. Authentic flavours, precise preparation and strong stocks and sauces all combine to reveal his experience. The addition of an individual touch further elevates the harmony of flavours. The wine list is impressive and not to be missed.

Name: La Fleurie
Description: Connoisseurs will be in their element in this stylish restaurant, where chef Verbruggen offers a refined menu showcasing contemporary international dishes and ingredients. His cuisine, which features distinctive, rich sauces, is sophisticated and generous, allowing the chef’s passion and experience to shine through.

Name: De Lindeboom New Style
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace
Description: De Lindeboom boasts plenty of style both in terms of the charm of the building (1760), its typical Limburg hospitality, and its varied menu. Chef Jan-Willem demonstrates his preference for Mediterranean freshness and international inspiration on a menu ranging from traditional sole to vegetarian dishes, bringing together all the ingredients needed to delight his guests.

Name: Pouwe
Description: Walter and Vivian Pouwe bring flavours from around the globe to the sleepy town of Hoeven. In their modern lounge-style restaurant, ingredients such as yuzu, tandoori spices and vadouvan are incorporated into creative dishes that pack a punch. For instance, bavette steak really comes into its own in a Mediterranean concoction featuring an interplay with pesto and aubergine caviar. Be sure to sample the enticing cheese trolley ?an unconventional selection of international cheeses that the chef presents with great enthusiasm. A Bib Gourmand restaurant with a cosmopolitan twist!

Name: DiVino
Description: This former school has been transformed into a warm, urban restaurant, including a graffiti portrait of Don Corleone! You can see the chefs working their magic in the open kitchen, where they create French and Mediterranean dishes full of creativity and nuanced flavours. Make sure you ask for advice when making your choice in the beautiful wine library.

Name: Héron
Description: From the farmer, to the gardener, to the fisherman, Héron's suppliers are all local. The season and the Dutch soil will determine what appears on the menu. Sustainability is key at this lively establishment, so dishes might feature previously unheard-of cuts of meat, a variety of preserves and foraged ingredients, and your dessert could contain fish garum. The chef will surprise you with his novel ways of putting local produce centre stage.

Name: Hoog Holten
FacilitiesAndServices: Car park,Garden or park,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: Your experience at Hoog Holten begins with the drive there: the charm of the surrounding Salland countryside is captivating in itself. The terrace of this romantic establishment, housed in an old hunting lodge, happens to be one of the most beautiful in the country! Brasserie Birds keeps things traditional ?go to the restaurant for more varied, contemporary cuisine. The set menu changes daily, but always seeks inspiration abroad for its sometimes truly innovative dishes.

Name: Raedthuys
Description: Just about everything is homemade in this restaurant, which has its own bakery, own patisserie and even its own smokehouse! Choose from the wide selection of generous dishes created by chef Marion, who focuses on genuine traditional flavours with no unnecessary frills. Combine your classic meal with one of the numerous beers on offer here, many of which are on tap.

Name: Scheepskameel
Description: Scheepskameel is a lively, relaxed establishment, providing honest, straightforward food. Everything here starts with top-quality ingredients, prepared without fuss and beautifully seasoned. The wine list is comprised entirely of German wines and accompanies the food perfectly.

Name: Bistro Nijeholt
Description: Whether you are looking for classic, modern or international cuisine, the chef of this trendy bistro switches between different preparation methods to make his menu top notch, and he succeeds with gusto. The atmosphere is informal, allowing diners to enjoy exuberantly delicious dishes.

Name: LEV Foodbar
Description: The relaxed atmosphere at LEV perfectly matches the concept behind this food bar: sharing dishes and enjoying good food together. The dishes (in snack-sized portions) are not overcomplicated; a couple of ingredients suffice to create amazing taste sensations. Steak tartare, pork tenderloin, cauliflower tempura, truffle risotto... At LEV, the table quickly fills with irresistible delicacies, often prepared using produce from the Achterhoek region. The perfect accompaniment to one of the many beers!

Name: Serre
Description: A bright space with a gorgeous canalside terrace, Serre has a Japanese minimalist feel. Reflecting the international atmosphere of the luxury Hotel Okura, this restaurant serves fusion cuisine with a slight penchant for Far Eastern influences. Start with a platter of super-fresh oysters and then pick one of the sharing dishes. Alternatively, there is a set menu with mouth-watering options for each course, such as smoked salmon with a refreshing Thai twist. And those who prefer to avoid meat and fish are sure to find something to their liking.

Name: Uit de Kunst
Description: Hikers and cyclists who test themselves to their limits on the Vijlenberg are rewarded by this modern restaurant situated right at the top. The superb view from the terrace is a feast for the eyes, while the traditional dishes served here are a treat for the taste buds. Simple yet refined and delicious cuisine.

Name: Basaal
Address: Dunne Bierkade 3, The Hague, 2512 BC, Netherlands
Description: A cosy neighbourhood restaurant, Scandinavian and vintage vibes included, nice terrace on the water: what a nice place Basaal is! The full à la carte offer and the attractive wine list complete the picture. The modern market cuisine is based on intense sauces, generous flavours and creative, tantalising ideas. A deliciously unconstrained feast of flavour!

Name: De Aubergerie
Description: People used to come to De Aubergerie for sweets, and in a sense they still do. This is now a pleasant restaurant, and the ‘sweets?these days are modern, flawlessly turned-out dishes. The chef has an eye for quality and produces flavour with originality and skill.

Name: HAVN
Description: Two views, one of the historical harbour and the other of the open kitchen, grab your attention as soon as you enter this restaurant with a buzzing atmosphere. The same playful energy is even more apparent in the creations of chef Robin Blaauw. He is, for instance, as happy to dabble in the rich flavours of South American cuisine as he is to dive into the Asian culinary world. Drawing inspiration from his travels, he works with the finest Dutch produce to conjure up his dishes. Thanks to his eye for detail, this young chef has already made an impressive career for himself.

Name: De Schans by Mike & Wes
Description: When they took over De Schans, Mike and Wes, respectively sommelier and chef, added a trendier, more relaxed vibe, whilst retaining the establishment’s commitment to fine food and wine. The chef crafts dishes in tune with the zeitgeist using cutting-edge culinary techniques to create a subtle blend of textures and unexpected flavours. The set menu is definitely worth sampling!

Name: Bergpaviljoen
Description: Choose your fish from the counter, treat yourself to one of the classics such as steak tartare or just opt for some tasty bar food accompanied by a good glass of wine. In this light-filled pavilion, with its Art Deco design features and spacious terrace by the beehives, you are spoilt for choice. But rest assured that, thanks to the quality of the produce that the chef has to work with, you simply cannot go wrong here.

Name: Fa. Pekelhaaring
Description: Welcome to the urban canteen of a number of Amsterdam’s local residents ?a relaxed eatery without unnecessary sophistication, but one which is both authentic and welcoming. The cuisine is influenced (but not exclusively) by Italy and the chef enjoys adding his own variations and personal touches (such as crunchy textures and local influences) to his cooking. The varied à la carte is impressive indeed!

Name: Lazuur
Description: This charming neighbourhood restaurant proposes a refined fusion of French and Portuguese cuisine. The appealing set menu offers a choice of dishes including, for example, kale, bouchot mussels and molho de coentro. The chef cooks his ingredients to perfection and adds a dash of Mediterranean flair, as demonstrated in his soft-cooked pulpo, creamy riso venere and espuma of paprika. Be sure to check out the impressive port collection, which contains plenty of surprises.

Name: Bij Erik
Description: Wood, metal and leather create an intimate feel, although a table on the terrace is also a good choice: the view of the lock and windmill is magnificent. Erik Tas will have diners' mouths watering with fresh combinations in which stocks and sauces lead to wonderful harmonies.

Name: Marie
Description: Marie possesses that charm typical of the South of France. The brasserie decor exudes luxury, but the terrace overlooking the boats and bridges is where everyone wants a table. This tranquil oasis in the heart of the city is enhanced by the Mediterranean finesse of the cuisine. The lamb fillet and cheeks with a perfectly balanced hollandaise sauce, the salt-baked sea bass, the generous beef tartare: these are down-to-earth dishes that pack a punch, and they are simply irresistible. This is what Bib Gourmand is all about!

Name: Café Caron
Description: This cosy bistro is run by Alain Caron (a well-known TV personality and chef) and his family. The ambience here is typically French, as is the menu which features traditional, generous bistro-style dishes which are a work of art in their own right. Trying out the à la carte here is a real joy.

Name: Le Nord
Description: This authentic farmhouse dating from 1885 combines rural charm and modern design ?the ideal setting in which to experience Grégory Nicole's cuisine. The finesse with which this French chef pays tribute to his homeland is a testament to his expertise. More modern inspirations add a dash of excitement without overcomplicating things. He surprises diners with, for instance, his own take on Poire Williams, or a beautiful cod fillet infused with zesty notes. Be sure to try the tuna pizza, a tribute to master chef Joop Braakhekke. A great Bib Gourmand restaurant that is also a sure bet at lunchtime!

Name: Rijsel
Description: The interior of this lively establishment resembles a classroom, and indeed this building was once a home economics school. Today you can see the 'master' at work preparing his lesson in French gastronomy thanks to the open kitchen. He has a sound knowledge of his ingredients and incorporates a nod to Flemish cuisine into his no-nonsense dishes. Whether you order the intensely flavoured typical Southern French fish soup or côte de bœuf served with a house-made béarnaise sauce and fried potatoes: at Rijsel, every dish is a feast!

Name: Alma Bodega
Description: The more down-to-earth little brother of MICHELIN-starred Alma has its own personality. Chic marble and stylish design give this laid-back restaurant flair. You can drop in any time of day to indulge in a fresh take on familiar flavours. The menu features a variety of dishes that will tempt your taste buds, including gyoza, köfte, pâté en croûte, perfectly done entrecôte with a delicious veal jus, rum baba and more. The skilfully prepared and generously flavoured dishes never fail to impress. Curated by Malou Hagenaars, the wine list always includes some exciting finds. Be sure to make your reservation in good time to avoid disappointment!

Name: Bistro TWO
Description: How about a drink at the Dux hotel’s rooftop bar with its view of the town, lunch on the waterfront terrace or dinner in the chic, lively bistro? TWO is one of Roermond’s must-visit venues, offering a fascinating choice between typical bistro dishes such as duck liver terrine and more modern options such as meat loaf cooked in cocoa. Distinctive, updated cuisine which is quite simply delicious!

Name: Witlof
Description: With the view of the River Waal, the jovial hostess and the chef who you see cooking as you make your way to use the facilities, at the Witlof, you will immediately feel at home. Jurgen Eikholt lovingly prepares classic cuisine with his trademark sophisticated, often oriental touches. Each dish on the menu can be ordered as a large or small portion.

Name: Brasserij Kok Verhoeven
Description: Take the left-hand door to a fashionable, cosmopolitan restaurant offering delicious fish and shellfish. Or, the right-hand door to the more relaxed brasserie with an extensive menu (again largely fish), which will win guests over with its quality and powerful flavours.

Name: Rotonde
Description: They pick up their vegetables in a van which runs on biogas obtained by composting their waste. The aim is to utilise every part of their produce, which is grown with respect for nature and the seasons. Only biodynamic and natural wines are on offer. Sustainability is at the heart of the ethos of Rotonde, which is constantly seeking to improve itself. This vision translates into creative, intriguing taste sensations which are sophisticated and full of surprises. A spot by the open kitchen is a must if you want to watch the chefs tame the flames of their wood-fired barbecue!

Name: La Vie
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Great view,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: The 'living room' of the Hotel Valuas is a cosy luxury brasserie that is open all day long. Generous breakfasts, pastries or afternoon snacks, an enticing à la carte menu and a three-course set menu... there's something for everyone. The chef takes his inspiration from classic French cuisine and selects high-quality (often local) ingredients ?and it's outstanding value for money. A seat on the terrace, overlooking the River Meuse, is a must!

Name: Bistro Aragosta
Description: The Aragosta has the warm, intimate feel of a bistro, where your welcoming host will introduce you to cuisine that is mainly French in feel with the occasional Italian influence, ranging from seafood risotto to duck terrine. Overall, the cooking here is classical, highly subtle and very tasty!

Name: Arles
Description: Arles brings Provence to Amsterdam. The prints on the walls of this bustling little bistro hark back to the hometown of the chef, who also shares his love of jazz music here (get a table in the dining room at the front if you prefer a quieter space). His culinary style is neo-bistro ?a fresh take on the familiar flavours of French cuisine. Think the earthy flavour of beef cheeks cooked in red wine with buttery carrots or a new take on rice pudding. The set menu changes monthly and offers unbeatable value for money!

Name: Bistrot Regent
Description: Why travel all the way to France when you can dine at this timeless bistro, where the best of what the country has to offer is showcased in both the excellent wine list and traditional dishes? Think aromatic fish soup with rouille and croutons, or butter-soft duck leg confit with a zesty caper sauce, followed by crisp tarte Tatin for dessert. You can tell that Robbert and Heleen put their heart and soul into running Bistrot Regent.

Name: Restaurant ñ
Description: The yellow façade of this relaxed restaurant gives it a southern feel, which is further enhanced by the aromas of typical, authentic Spanish and Mediterranean dishes that greet you as you step through the door. The delicious options on the menu include fresh seafood, spicy chilli peppers, and dishes served with fresh, sophisticated sauces, as well as an excellent selection of cheese and charcuterie.

Name: 't Nieuwe Diekhuus
Description: This old thatch-roofed farm on the banks of the Yssel provides a charming setting (including a terrace with a stunning view of the river) in which you’ll feel immediately at ease. To this splendid backdrop, enjoy international delicacies (often with an Asian influence) prepared with top-quality ingredients and well-crafted garnishes that provide the perfect accompaniment. Generous cuisine that is well thought out yet gentle on the pocket!

Name: Bistrôt Chapeau
Description: Experience the charm of its colourful bistro decor, the peace and quiet of the terrace and a soothing ambience in this restaurant straight out of quintessential Burgundy! Here, Nicky Quarz revives often forgotten French classics without any unnecessary frivolity yet teeming with authentic flavours. Through his sauces, intensity etc, enjoy a welcome return to the very roots of French cuisine.

Name: Huson
Description: Huson is a trendy establishment where a lively industriousness always prevails. Here guests' mouths will water at the marvellous pairing of creativity with international ingredients in small dishes which are as subtle as they are exuberant. The chef is a dab hand at beautifully balancing fullness of flavour with freshness, as his signature dishes show.

Name: De Watermolen
Description: The watermill dating back to 1391 is the main attraction of this rustic restaurant, although of course the warmth of the place and lively terrace are also a draw. The chef sometimes opts for more modern techniques, but mainly serves honest, traditional dishes. Vegetarians always have good options here, including the set menu.

Name: Élevé
Description: A superlative view from the top of the WTC Hotel over Leeuwarden is underscored by a hip, casually welcoming ambience. The restaurant is both affordable and yet exclusive. Chef Kalkman’s cooking is modern, subtle and free of unnecessary frills. You can expect premium local produce, jazzed up with the occasional modern twist and generous flavours.

Name: Bistro LOF
Description: The experienced chef at this modern yet rustic restaurant in an old farmhouse in Broekhuizen park takes inspiration from Dutch ingredients, including produce from the restaurant’s own kitchen garden. His dishes are simple yet full of intense modern flavours, which are rich, carefully thought out and painstakingly prepared. Even the simple tomato with prawns dish will surprise you!

Name: Waers
Description: Waers is the incarnation of anti-conformity, which sums up Dennis Vermeulen to a T! In his restaurant showcasing a strong sense of Scandinavian purity, he brings out the very best of market-fresh ingredients and the seasons. There’s no fuss here, just original, well-balanced dishes with a contemporary feel that are well worth discovering and offer excellent value for money.

Name: Gym & Gin
Description: The name Gym & Gin is a reference to the balance we all have to find between pleasure and healthy living. After a workout in the gym upstairs, unwind in this lounge-like establishment with its vintage colour scheme and designer furniture. The cocktail/gin list as well as Kevin Valkhoff's set menu and à la carte options are all as impressive as each other. Inspired by exotic subtleties, he brings flavours to life with original flashes of inspiration, such as adding red pepper to cucumber and mango in order to give salmon some extra pep. If you fancy an afternoon aperitif and a light bite, the good news is that Gym & Gin is always open.

Name: Oriole
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Valet parking
Description: Oriole is a haven of calm in the bustling city centre. The upscale bistro decor is alluring ?the bar is terrific ?though a spot on the verdant terrace is really the place to be. This is quite the hidden gem! The contemporary take on Mediterranean flavours, with a particular emphasis on vegetables, suits the setting perfectly. The "Oriole Express" set menu, with different options for each course, showcases the cuisine and produce of a given country every month. Whether you're tucking into grilled pimientos de Padrón, pâté en croûte or frango estufado with chicken, this Mediterranean-style feast is authentic, exquisite and inspired.

Name: Poortman
Description: Having been around for more than a century, Poortman has evolved from a café-style eatery into a proper restaurant where authentic memories add to the friendly atmosphere. Dutch classics such as veal tongue with pointed cabbage and hazenpeper (hare stew) with red cabbage are prepared with just as much skill as international specialities including ceviche or the celeriac-based dish. The dishes on the menu are certainly hearty but in no way lacking in finesse ?the game jus, for example, is testament to this. At Poortman, flavour reigns supreme!

Name: Gaar
Description: Chef Joachim Müller delights his guests with a worldly and diverse menu which includes dishes such as steak from Limburg beef, scampi in a Thai sauce and Moroccan couscous. A trendy, accessible and lively restaurant with real appeal, plus a menu where traditional dishes go hand in hand with more exotic options. An interesting wine list completes the picture.

Name: Specht
Description: This restaurant in a little side street in the city centre is a wonderfully cosy setting for a pleasant tête-à-tête or meal among friends. Diners can expect delicious traditional Viennese cuisine prepared using local ingredients. The pretty interior combining modern design, wooden floors, dark green wall panelling and partially vaulted ceilings creates a warm atmosphere. There is a U-Bahn station conveniently located close by.

Name: Meierei im Stadtpark
Description: One floor below the Reitbauer’s gourmet restaurant, you’ll find another upmarket eatery. Alongside some 150 wonderfully matured cheeses, it boasts delicious classics like Wiener schnitzel of suckling calf. Or perhaps you’d prefer a whole Arctic char or some venison goulash? Attractive terrace facing the Stadtpark.

Name: Vestibül
Description: With a penchant for seasonal and regional produce, this restaurant serves flavoursome culinary delights such as freshwater fish dishes or classics like Wiener schnitzel. The imposing historical building, which also houses the famous Burgtheater, makes for a unique location with a stylish interior that has a typically Viennese feel with its striking columns and gorgeous stuccowork.

Name: Gasthof Auerhahn
Description: Run with great dedication, this friendly, family-owned restaurant is located at a slight remove from the city centre, close to the train station, but it's well worth making the detour for the excellent food ?their appealing range of dishes includes the delicious Topfenknödel (curd dumplings). Dine in the inviting interior or out on the beautiful verdant terrace. For overnight stays, there are pleasant, well-kept guestrooms.

Name: MAST Weinbistro
Description: Set in a historical town house, this trendy place is a winning combination of modern wine bar and upscale bistro. It is very popular for its great food, is made with seasonal ingredients sourced from local producers ?and at fantastic value for money. Organic and biodynamic wines are recommended to accompany your choice of dishes. There is an appealing outdoor dining area, too.

Name: Carnozet
Description: Tastefully done out in a modern take on Alpine style, this restaurant provides both excellent food and friendly service. The menu features an appealing selection of seasonal dishes, mostly made from locally sourced produce. We highly recommend the grey cattle goulash with Walser Knöpfle (similar to spaetzle).

Name: ONYX
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit cards not accepted,Great view,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Wheelchair access
Description: What was once the bar on the sixth floor of the DO & CO Hotel in the avant-garde Haas Building has been transformed into a trendy restaurant with a lounge feel and large floor-to-ceiling windows that afford a breathtaking view of St Stephen's Cathedral. Interesting Asian and Japanese dishes are served for sharing ?including sushi and sashimi and specialities from the Robata grill.

Name: Koneser Grill
Description: This redeveloped former vodka factory to the east of the city comes with an industrial look and a laid-back vibe. It’s all about steak here, with a focus on Polish beef, aged in-house, and then cooked over a wood-fired grill. Prices represent good value and the steaks to share are a great option.

Name: alewino
Description: Spread across various rooms, this starkly decorated bistro started life as a wine shop. There’s still a range of bottles for sale, along with a wine list that offers plenty of younger and lesser-known producers. The well-priced menu includes more starters than mains, which allows guests to order a few plates to share. Traditional Polish flavours and dishes are approached with a modern sensibility and prepared with plenty of care.

Name: Kieliszki na Próżnej
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Bring your own bottle,Counter dining,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Wheelchair access
Description: A huge, gravity-defying rack of wine glasses is the first thing you notice when you arrive at this friendly wine bar and bistro. Next, it’s the striking black and white wildlife mural filling one wall. The appealing menus represent good value, especially at lunchtime, and include hearty dishes that are bursting with bold and punchy flavours. An extensive wine list offers plenty of great quality choices to fill all those glasses with, but ‘bring your own?is welcome too.

Name: Casa Santo Antônio
Address: Avenida João Carlos da Silva Borges 764, São Paulo, 04726-001, Brazil
Description: A perfect example of how a dream between friends ?now co-owners ?can become a reality. In Granja Julieta, a quiet district in the south of the city, you’ll find this pleasant 1960s style chalet, where guests can choose from an impressive classic Italian menu featuring specialities such as burrata with tomatoes, olives and slivers of Sicilian lemon, or the superb brie tortelli with a truffle-flavoured sauce. Some of the tables on the terrace enjoy views of the glass-fronted kitchen.

Name: Brasserie Victória
Address: Avenida Presidente Juscelino Kubitschek 545, São Paulo, 04543-010, Brazil
Description: It is estimated that around ten million inhabitants of Lebanese descent live in Brazil. Esfihas (a type of Arab pizza) and quibes (meat croquettes) are as popular here as Brazilian staples such as pão de queijo (cheese bread) and coxinhas (chicken croquettes) and are sold at almost every Brazilian street stall. The Brasserie Victória, run by the same family for over 40 years, is nowadays considered the symbol of Lebanese presence in São Paulo, serving authentic, family-style cooking that represents the varied cuisine of their homeland. Make sure you try a little of everything.

Name: TonTon
Description: Located in a quiet residential street, this cosy, bistro-style restaurant is testament to the fact that travelling the world is always an enriching experience. Proof comes in the form of owner-chef Gustavo Rozzino's delicious international dishes, which take their influence from Brazilian, Italian, French and English recipes; this unusual culinary combination representing the various countries in which he trained as a chef.

Name: Manioca
Address: Avenida Brigadeiro Faria Lima 2232, São Paulo, 01451-000, Brazil
Description: It’s spacious, bright and eclectic, yet despite its size, Manioca is somewhat hidden, as its sits inside a huge shopping centre behind the modern Livraria Cultura bookshop and customers to have walk between the bookshelves to reach it. Top-quality products, reasonable prices and a high level of technical skill are the hallmarks of this restaurant, which serves modern cuisine with Brazilian and international influences. Allow plenty of time as it gets very busy.

Name: Charco
Address: Rua Peixoto Gomide 1492, São Paulo, 01409-002, Brazil
Description: Despite its compact size, this restaurant in the Jardins district not far from Parque Trianon, is very welcoming with its small terrace and rustic-contemporary interior. Chef Tuca Mezzomo, a young gaucho from the Río Grande do Sul region, focuses on grill-based cuisine that showcases products and ingredients from different parts of Brazil. Guests are able to discover the large variety of flavours that this country has to offer through his dishes. As an added bonus, Charco even cures its own meats.

Name: Le Bife
Address: Rua Pedroso Alvarenga 1088, São Paulo, 04531-004, Brazil
Description: With French celebrity chef Erick Jacquin as its consultant, Le Bife’s success is down to the simplicity of its menu: four quality meat dishes (filet mignon, entrecôte, steak tartare and hamburger) with salad, three sauces and a choice of sides included in the price. The executive menu, served midweek lunch, is based around the same formula but with just a single meat option (the cut of the day) and a delicious dessert ?hot chocolate gateau with vanilla ice cream.

Name: Miam Miam
Address: Rua General Góis Monteiro 34, Rio de Janeiro, 22290-080, Brazil
Description: A restaurant with retro furniture, colourful decor and exposed brickwork, which harks back to the past; it is, in fact, the former mansion of chef Roberta Ciasca’s grandmother. They serve comfort food and traditional Brazilian classics, which showcase contemporary cooking techniques and a demonstrate a flair for presentation. A simpler, very reasonably priced menu is available at lunchtime, accompanied by a salad buffet.

Name: Cepa
Address: Rua Antônio Camardo 895, São Paulo, 03309-060, Brazil
Description: If you like the idea of a seasonally inspired dining experience, escape São Paulo’s hectic business district and head for this unassuming restaurant—located in a residential district close to the São Luiz hospital. Here, chef Lucas Dante—who runs Cepa with his sommelier wife—focuses on creativity, ensuring that his cooking is always fun and based on products sourced daily from the market. The tasting menu is available in the evening and is a worthy option.

Name: Mocotó
Address: Avenida Nossa Senhora do Loreto 1100, São Paulo, 02219-001, Brazil
Description: Like its founder Zé Almeida, who came here from inland Pernambuco in the 1960s, you’ll need to embark on something of a pilgrimage to get to this famous and secluded eatery specialising in cuisine from the north-east. Originally famous for its mocotó dish, the kitchen, now run by Zé’s son Rodrigo Oliveira, conjures up many other delicacies from the north-eastern hinterland, including unforgettable torresminhos (pork rinds), prepared according to a secret recipe, that are crunchy, succulent and some of the best we’ve ever tasted!

Name: Più Pinheiros
Address: Rua Ferreira de Araújo 314, São Paulo, 05428-000, Brazil
Description: This restaurant, in the western part of São Paulo, comes as a pleasant surprise. It's set within a simple yet charming house, in which chef Marcelo Laskani, co-owner along with maître d?Mauricio Cavalcante, offers Italian-inspired cuisine built around a few solid principles: strong technique, meticulous presentation, and reasonable prices thanks to the judicious use of less luxurious ingredients. It's full almost every day, so advanced booking is highly recommended.

Name: Corrutela
Address: Rua Medeiros de Albuquerque 256, São Paulo, 05436-060, Brazil
Description: A restaurant that showcases the gastronomy of the future, in which sustainability is a central theme and an attractive "leitmotiv". The focus of the chef is on healthy, contemporary cuisine based around seasonal and organic ingredients, including fish and seafood, that help the planet. As an example, Corrutela does not use products wrapped in plastic, it makes its own flour and compost, and creates its own energy from solar panels.

Name: Maria e o Boi
Address: Rua Maria Quitéria 111, Rio de Janeiro, 22410-040, Brazil
Description: This is a pleasant and informal restaurant that specialises in meat and is located in the charming Ipanema district. Here, you can enjoy Brazilian and international cooking with an Italian flair, which is always attractively priced and accompanied by copious sides. It is renowned for its grilled items (no fewer than seven different cuts of meat) and several signatures, including the ten hour-roasted beef rib (costela minga) as well as the surprisingly delicious duck heart with garlic bread and Grana Padano.

Name: Ama.zo - Cozinha Peruana
Description: Ama. zo makes for a memorable dining experience that is both interesting and affordable. Here, in the delightful setting of a landscaped terrace—with large jabuticaba trees and an almost imperceptible cover to protect the dining space from the elements—savour reinterpreted Peruvian cuisine that is crafted from local products. Dishes feature strong flavours and pleasant textures with subtle nods to the Amazon and enticing Latin influences.

Name: Tordesilhas
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Valet parking
Description: This established restaurant has a good reputation and has just celebrated its 25th anniversary.
