It's famous as a trailblazer for tasting menus of Brazilian cuisine, which are served Tuesday to Saturday evenings. There are lots of petiscos for sharing, as well as more creative dishes such as the three Amazonian sorbets served on jambu pearls, and the traditional feijoada, which is only available Saturday lunchtimes. Look out for the impressive collection of artisanal peppers!

Name: Balaio IMS
Description: Occupying the same modern building as the Instituto Moreira Salles, this restaurant is an excellent place in which to discover and enjoy chef Rodrigo Oliveira’s simple, fresh and attractive cuisine in the centre of São Paulo. In this modest setting, enjoy a combination of the successful dishes first created in the Mocotó restaurant, the latter, in particular, bringing a more traditional family-style influence to the dishes served here. Some tables are shared.

Name: The Kith
Description: This restaurant continues to make a big impression in Pinheiros, an office district where more informal eateries tend to be the norm. Its bright interior, which combines contemporary design with industrial touches, acts as a backdrop for the Brazilian cuisine with occasional international twists. Authentic, fresh dishes and refined techniques are the cornerstone here, with a focus on barbecue-grilled meats—a nod to chef Juliana Faingluz’s gaucho roots.

Name: Zena Cucina
Address: Rua Peixoto Gomide 1901, São Paulo, 01409-002, Brazil
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Restaurant offering vegetarian menus,Terrace,Valet parking
Description: Zena, which translates as Genoa in the Ligurian dialect, is a simple, happy and vibrant eatery that pays homage to Liguria; the region which is home to pesto sauce. Faithful to the region’s traditional recipes, Zena Caffè serves dishes that are fresh, healthy and quick; special mention must go to its focaccias (with their light dough and generous fillings), its gnocchi and its home-made desserts such as the splendid latte dolce fritto (a thick milk-based cream which is left to solidify before being breaded and fried, and served with the caramel-flavoured doce de leite). Go with friends and order dishes to share, as well as a jug of sangria or clericot.

Name: Pici Trattoria
Address: Rua Barão da Torre 348, Rio de Janeiro, 22411-000, Brazil
Description: Situated opposite the Praça Nossa Senhora da Paz, this restaurant boasts an Italian-style decor with colourful chairs and tables and windows inscribed with items from the menu. The original menu, overseen by renowned chef Elia Schramm, combines classic Italian recipes and Brazilian ingredients, resulting in a host of generous dishes which are full of flavour. Artists?photos adorn the walls, while jazz music plays gently in the background.

Name: Banzeiro
Description: Banzeiro is a breath of fresh air on Sao Paulo’s culinary scene. Chef Felipe Schaedler made the leap to this Brazilian metropolis from Manaus, where he has two other restaurants, in order to popularise the flavours and cooking of the Amazon. In this vibrantly decorated space, discover dishes—many cooked on the grill—that are contemporary, delicate and highly visual. Make sure to try river fish, such as pirarucú and tambaquià, as well as the highly unusual saúva ant with a mandioquinha foam.

Name: Tanit
Description: The design of this restaurant is a real talking point with its striking entrance, modern high-ceilinged interior, polished concrete floors and wood-panelled walls, along with intelligent use of natural light. Spanish chef Oscar Bosch creates technically skilled, carefully presented Mediterranean dishes which are adapted to Brazilian tastes, alongside local specialities. Its signature tapas, varied rice dishes and popular roast suckling pig are all worthy of particular praise.

Name: Petí Gastronomia
Description: This curious restaurant will come as a surprise, as it’s located in a small glass-fronted courtyard behind a large shop which specialises in fine arts. The young chef, who has already worked in some leading restaurants across Europe, crafts delicately presented, contemporary dishes using seasonal ingredients; all the time using the latest techniques to create fine textures and well-defined flavours. The menu offers several options and is changed every two weeks.

Name: Fitó
Address: Rua Cardeal Arcoverde 2773, São Paulo, 05407-004, Brazil
Description: This restaurant pays homage to the culture and cooking of northeast Brazil ?one of the country’s most popular cuisines. What stands out at this simple restaurant is the authenticity of the food and the enthusiasm of the owners, with the wife running the kitchen and her husband out front. The menu focuses on hearty cooking from the state of Piauí and includes daily specials and north-eastern classics such as Carne de Sol and Arroz Maria Isabel. The petiscos on the counter are well worth trying!

Name: Komah
Address: Rua Cônego Vicente Miguel Marino 378, São Paulo, 01135-020, Brazil
Description: A queue of people waiting outside a restaurant is always a good sign and this is precisely what you see at Komah, a restaurant serving Korean cuisine with a modern flavour. You’ll enjoy a memorable dining experience here, thanks to the chef who delights his guests with a full range of flavours which extends from sweet to spicy. Make sure you try the Samgiopsal (roast pork belly with a gochujang sauce glaze) and the Kimchi Bokumbap (sautéed rice with kimchi and a creamy omelette).

Name: Lilia
Address: Rua do Senado 45, Rio de Janeiro, 20231-005, Brazil
Description: A unique and different restaurant in which young chef Lucio Vieira demonstrates a new interpretation of hospitality. The unassuming façade, adorned with just a small poster, provides access to a steep staircase that leads guests to the upper floors with their decor of extreme simplicity. The highlight here is the updated traditional cuisine, teeming with strong flavours and always based around ingredients from the market to ensure maximum freshness and affordability.

Name: Arturito
Description: Celebrity Argentinian chef Paola Carosella’s aim is to please the palate rather than take it by surprise. Her dishes showcase a passion for fresh vegetables and herbs in which simplicity and honesty are key. Her cooking is delicious, well executed and based around the very best ingredients. For lunch, the excellent executive menu and dish of the day are popular choices, while the dinner menu boasts clear Italian and Argentinian influence along with a contemporary touch.

Name: A Baianeira
Description: Simplicity is the buzzword here as the restaurant developed in a small garage that once upon a time only sold the traditional "pão de queijo". Today, the owner-chef, who has trained the entire team of women working with her, pays homage to her origins by offering family-style dishes that combine the cooking of Bahia and the northeast ?Brazilian dishes that showcase technical skill and attractive presentation. The sweet potato gnocchi with cream cheese is well worth ordering.

Name: Didier
Address: Rua Vinícius de Moraes, 124, A, Ipanema, Rio de Janeiro, 22411010, Brazil
Description: Run by a friendly married couple, Didier combines both Brazilian and French roots, with the female half of the partnership front of house and her classically trained French chef-husband manning the stoves. In this bright setting, reminiscent of a winter conservatory and terrace, enjoy reasonably priced classic dishes that showcase the chef’s international training in France, the USA and Brazil. He achieves great things with a limited budget, working with seasonal products and the freshest possible fish.

Name: Artigiano
Address: Avenida Epitácio Pessoa 204, Rio de Janeiro, 22471-002, Brazil
Description: This restaurant specialises in the cuisine of the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy, serving home-made pasta and pizzas and popular ingredients from the region, such as Parma ham and Parmesan cheese. Everything here is hand-made (as evidenced by its name) and prices are reasonable. Make sure you try the roselline romagnole (pasta stuffed with ham and mozzarella and a Parmesan sauce). There’s a delightful terrace for cool alfresco dining.

Name: Barú Marisquería
Description: This small restaurant with an attractive and relaxed ambience serves fish and seafood with a focus on freshly caught ingredients cooked over the barbecue, a familiar sight on Brazilian beaches but not as popular in the city where grilled meat options are more common. Proud of his Latin-American origins, Colombian chef Dagoberto Torres also includes a choice of superb ceviche dishes on his menu. Simple presentation, yet packed with flavour!

Name: Ecully Gastronomia
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Interesting wine list,Terrace,Valet parking,Wheelchair access
Description: Tables here are set out on the old patio amid a plethora of trees, including an impressive mango tree at its centre. In this rustic yet contemporary space, the young chefs, who met each other in Ecully, France, create recipes influenced by Italian, French and Brazilian cooking. Under the same roof, they also run a wine boutique featuring over 400 reasonably priced labels (they are also importers and distributors). This is a good choice for diners wanting to eat a tasty meal accompanied by wines that won’t break the bank.

Name: A Casa do Porco
Description: Enjoy pork at its best! Chef Jefferson Rueda, a native of São José do Rio Pardo, takes the tastes and flavours of his youth and reinterprets them using contemporary techniques and eye-catching presentation. The welcoming setting is a combination of a bar, restaurant and small market. Don’t miss out on the sushi of pork jowl and the delicious Porco a San Zé, roasted for 8 hours in a special wood-fired churrasqueira. They don't take reservations, so customers are seated in the order they arrive.

Name: Bistrot de Paris
Description: Sitting out on the front terrace of this restaurant, set in a charming little alleyway, you could be forgiven for thinking that you’re in a romantic, secretive part of Paris. It has both the atmosphere and the cuisine of a Parisian bistro; the honest cooking adheres to French techniques but with a nod to Brazilian produce. In 1990, its renowned French chef, Alain Poletto, won the 'best technique' prize at the Académie Nationale de Cuisine as a result of his research into sous-vide cooking.

Name: AE! Café & Cozinha
Description: This is an intimate and surprising restaurant that is also particularly welcoming. Located in a district with a bohemian feel, it is run with lots of enthusiasm and passion by two chefs (Ygor Lopes and Walkyria Fagundes) trained in some of the best kitchens in Spain and Brazil. The highlight is on a contemporary Brazilian menu that is well-edited and focuses on sustainability. Here, dishes showcase a multitude of flavours and textures, and are creatively presented. Given its size, be sure to book ahead.
